Researchers have found that differences in how genes are regulated within a population can cause different phenotypes. These differences can be caused by changes in the DNA sequence of genes and their regulatory regions. Recent studies have shown that changes in the 3′ region of genes, known as 3′ UTRs, can also affect gene regulation and cause differences in phenotypes. However, there is still much that is not understood about how changes in 3′ UTRs affect gene regulation. In this study, researchers used 3′-end RNA-seq to study how changes in 3′ UTRs affect gene regulation and expression. They found that 3′ UTRs contain regulatory elements that control the length of the transcript made from a gene and that these differences can affect gene expression and its variation across different individuals. By studying 3′ UTRs, researchers can better understand the genetic basis of different phenotypes.
LASIV is a type of virus that causes AIDS in monkeys. In the past, some monkeys were infected with a weakened version of LASIV called SIVΔnef, and it was found that they were protected from a stronger version of the virus when they were later challenged. Many studies have found that SIVΔnef-induced protection varies depending on the viral strain used and the genetics of the monkey. Some research suggests that humoral immunity (antibodies) may play a role in protection, but other studies suggest that CD8 T cells (a type of immune cell) may be more important. The researchers in this study wanted to learn more about how SIVΔnef and the immune response interact to protect the monkeys. They used a type of technology called deep sequencing to find out how the virus changed (or evolved) over time in the monkeys. They also looked at how the CD8 T cell response changed over time by fine-mapping the specific epitopes (small pieces of the virus that the CD8 T cells recognize). They found that the virus evolved over time and that the CD8 T cell response also evolved in response to the changing virus. This resulted in a CD8 T cell response with increased specificity, wider breadth (meaning it recognized more different epitopes), rearranged immunodominance (meaning the most important epitopes changed), and enhanced depth (meaning it recognized more specific epitopes within each broad immunodominant epitope). These findings suggest that the immune response and the virus evolve together to protect the monkeys from infection.
The fungus Candida albicans is a common cause of infection worldwide, especially in people with weakened immune systems. These infections often occur in mucosal surfaces, such as the oral mucosa. The epithelium and leukocytes work together to fight off these infections. Neutrophils are the main type of leukocytes and play a critical role in preventing the fungus from invading deeper into the body. A recent study found that a protein called interleukin-17 (IL-17) does not play a role in regulating the neutrophil response to Candida albicans in the oral mucosa. However, the study also found that a different protein called interleukin-1 (IL-1) is critical for the neutrophil response in the oral mucosa. IL-1 is produced by the epithelium and helps regulate the production of neutrophil-chemotactic factors and the release of more neutrophils from the bone marrow to the site of infection.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a parasitic disease that causes physical and economic burden to people worldwide. It affects 1.3 billion people and causes 40 million people to suffer from severe swelling of the limbs and testicles. To eliminate this disease, a Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) was started in 2000. People in 83 countries received mass drug administration (MDA) of anti-LF drugs (albendazole+ivermectin or albendazole+diethylcarbamazine) to eliminate LF. The drugs were donated by their manufacturers GlaxoSmithKline and Merck & Co., Inc. In 8 years, over 1.9 billion MDA treatments were given to 570 million people, preventing 6 million cases of hydrocele and 4 million cases of lymphedema. This resulted in 32 million disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) averted and quality-of-life benefits achieved. However, the financial cost and loss of income for people protected from LF due to the first 8 years of the GPELF has not been analyzed. This study estimates that the economic benefits gained by LF infected and non-infected individuals in MDA-treated areas is US$21.8 billion, and an additional US$2.2 billion in health systems savings. Though this study has not included the value of ancillary benefits on other concurrent infections, it still provides a better understanding of the GPELF's overall impact on one of society's most debilitating and widespread tropical diseases.
Gaucher disease ( GD ) is a genetic disorder that affects the brain and nervous system. GD is caused by mutations in a gene called GBA . These mutations reduce the activity of an enzyme called GCase, which helps break down fat molecules in the brain and body. This leads to the build-up of fat molecules in brain cells called Gaucher cells, which can cause swelling and damage to the brain. GD can be divided into three types, each with different symptoms. The perinatal lethal type is the most severe form and can result in hydrops fetalis and congenital ichthyosis. These symptoms are caused by almost no GCase enzymatic activity. Because current treatments don't work well for the brain symptoms, there is a need to understand more about how GD causes damage to the brain. Parkinson's disease ( PD ) is a disease that causes movement problems. Researchers have found that having mutations in the GBA gene can increase the risk of developing PD. People with type 1 GD also have a higher chance of developing PD later in life. Studies have shown that in PD patients with GBA mutations, there are abnormal proteins called Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites in the brain. These proteins are the hallmark of sporadic PD. It is not clear how GBA mutations cause PD, but research suggests that they can cause the brain to have problems with waste disposal and protein buildup. Medaka ( Oryzias latipes ) are a type of fish that are often used as an animal model for disease research. They are easy to handle, have a short generation time, produce many offspring, and have several different breeds. Medaka have an advantage over other animal models because they have α-syn, a protein that is important for PD. Researchers have made genetic medaka models of PD that have movement problems and selectively lose certain types of brain cells. Considering these findings, medaka have the potential to be a new animal model of PD. In this study, researchers made GBA nonsense mutant medaka and found that they had GD symptoms, including swelling in the brain and body. They also had a lot of α-syn buildup in their brains, which can cause PD. The researchers found that the buildup of α-syn in the brains of the GBA nonsense mutant medaka was mostly caused by the mutation in GBA, and not by the α-syn that is naturally found in medaka. This new information about how GBA mutations cause α-syn buildup in the brain may help researchers understand more about PD and develop new treatments.
Listeria monocytogenes (Lm) is a bacterium that causes food poisoning in humans and animals. Researchers have been studying Lm for decades to understand how the immune system responds to it. When Lm enters a host cell, it escapes from the phagosome into the cytosol of the host cell. This is important because it helps Lm grow and spread between cells. Inside the cytosol, Lm expresses a protein called ActA that helps it spread from cell to cell. ActA-deficient mutants still trigger an immune response, but they don't provide protective immunity. Mutants that can't produce a protein called LLO don't escape from the phagosome, and they trigger an immune response, but they don't provide protective immunity. When Lm is inside the host cell cytosol, it triggers a unique immune response that includes the production of type I IFN. The immune response to Lm helps control early bacterial growth and recruits and arms innate immune effectors such as macrophages and neutrophils. The immune response also helps shape the adaptive immune response, which provides long-lived protection against future Lm infections.
Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a common type of glaucoma that can cause blindness and is caused by the death of nerve cells in the back of the eye. Researchers have found that a genetic mutation in the SIX1/SIX6 locus is associated with POAG and a thinning of the nerve cells in the eye. They found a mutation that may increase the SIX6 protein and further research is needed to understand how this mutation affects the nerve cells in the eye.
Clostridium difficile is a type of bacteria that can cause severe diarrhea and other health problems. The bacteria are commonly spread through contact with contaminated surfaces or objects. One way that the bacteria spread is by producing spores, which are dormant forms of the bacteria that can survive for a long time. When the spores come into contact with certain chemicals, such as bile salts, they germinate and turn into actively growing bacteria. The bacteria can then produce toxins that can damage the intestinal lining and cause diarrhea. One of the most important ways that the bacteria can change their behavior is through a process called phase variation. Phase variation allows the bacteria to switch between different forms that are better suited to different environments. In the case of C. difficile, phase variation can affect how the bacteria move and how they produce toxins. This can help the bacteria to survive and spread in the environment, as well as cause disease in humans.
Spores are dormant cells that are highly resistant to physical and chemical conditions, and are formed by certain types of bacteria. Endosporulation is a process that produces spores. The process has been studied extensively in Bacillus subtilis, a non-pathogenic sporeforming bacteria. In B. subtilis, sporulation is a multi-step process that involves the formation of a forespore and engulfment of the forespore by the mother cell, followed by maturation of the spore. A master regulatory protein, Spo0A, controls entry into sporulation. Four cell type-specific sigma factors control gene expression in the forespore and mother cell, and are activated in a specific sequence during sporulation. The sigma factors control the expression of genes involved in morphogenesis and spore structure formation. Recent studies have revealed differences in the roles and timing of activation of the sigma factors during sporulation in several Clostridial species. In this study, we used cytological and genetic methodologies to define the sequence of sporulation events in Clostridium difficile, a pathogenic sporeforming bacteria. We also used a fluorescent reporter to study gene expression at the single cell level and to correlate the expression and activity of the sporulation-specific sigma factors with the course of morphogenesis. Our study provides a platform for additional studies of the regulatory network and the expression and function of the effector genes, which may be related to host colonization and transmission.
Protein phosphorylation is a common modification in nature that changes a protein's activity by altering its electrostatic properties or spatial structure. The phosphorylation of the same protein at multiple different amino acid residues is also very common. The differences in function between single-site and multisite phosphorylation are not completely understood. Multisite proteins are involved in regulatory processes that can benefit from the presence of bistability, hysteresis, or limit cycles. A reasonable hypothesis is that multisite phosphorylation can give rise to ultrasensitive dose responses. In this paper, we describe a simple mechanistic approach for modeling multisite allosteric proteins named modified fraction (MF) modeling. This approach is capable of describing ultrasensitive dynamics without introducing a large number of additional variables. Under this framework, we keep track of the fraction of modified sites in the protein, and the concentration of active protein over time is estimated from this information. The protein is activated in a way that requires the phosphorylation of several but not all of the sites. The approximation becomes increasingly precise as the number of sites increases. In a sense, this mechanism can be considered a one-variable, quasi-steady state reduction of a model similar to the Monod-Wyman-Changeux allosteric system. The MF framework can also be extended to other types of multisite modification such as ligand binding, multisite transcription factor regulation, multisite methylation or acetylation, and ubiquitination. In this paper, we describe a detailed mechanistic model of a cell size checkpoint, which controls the timing of the switch from polar to isotropic growth of a bud in budding yeast. The variables are illustrated in Figure 1, and we use the modified fraction approach to model the cell size checkpoint. The simulation results of the modified fraction approach are compared with those of a detailed mechanistic model. We analyze the mathematical properties of the proposed checkpoint signaling pathway and hypothesize that this interaction pathway has the capacity to produce a bistable signal responsible for a sudden switch from polar to isotropic growth once the bud has undergone sufficient polar growth. The model presents several desirable qualities for a checkpoint, such as a clear downstream signal when a sufficient polar bud growth has occurred.
In the world of biology, many different proteins, genes, and metabolites work together to form regulatory pathways that are controlled by environmental cues and signaling molecules. These pathways help regulate various cellular activities. However, it can be difficult to determine how biological systems can accurately transmit information over a large range of time. One important factor in determining the accuracy of a signal is the connectivity of the network. In particular, negative and positive feedback motifs are important regulatory mechanisms that can affect the flow of information. Negative feedback loops prevent the signal from becoming too strong, while positive feedback loops amplify the signal. In this study, the authors examined the network connectivity in a bacterial system called quorum sensing. This system uses a combination of negative and positive feedback loops to communicate between bacterial cells. The authors used a combination of experimental work and mathematical modeling to examine the behavior of this system and the interplay of the different regulatory motifs. They identified a new regulatory element that was not previously suggested and used it to build a model of the system. Their model accurately captured the behavior of the intact system and its sub-systems. The authors revealed the importance of a well-regulated network in which a balance between the strengths of different feedback motifs is required for proper functioning.
The authors are describing a study that aimed to understand how being infected with a type of worm called Schistosoma haematobium affects the severity of malaria infections. The study was conducted in an area where malaria and schistosomiasis are common. The authors wanted to know if having both of these infections at the same time made malaria infections worse, and if having soil-transmitted helminths (worms) at the same time affected this relationship. The authors used data from a study of school-aged children in the area to try to answer these questions. They found that being infected with schistosomiasis did not seem to make malaria infections worse, and that having soil-transmitted helminths did not change this relationship.
The balance between inflammation and anti-inflammatory responses is important for the body's effective response to infectious pathogens while minimizing damage to the tissue. Sometimes, however, this balance can be disrupted, leading to an excessive suppression of protective pro-inflammatory responses, making the body more vulnerable to infections. Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is an example of such dysregulation, as seen in the infection with the protozoan parasites Leishmania donovani and L. infantum/chagasi, which cause spleen infections and immunodeficiency in the chronic stage. Leishmania preferentially infects macrophages, but can also be found in other cells such as dendritic cells (DCs), neutrophils, and fibroblasts. Infection with L. donovani causes disruption of the splenic microarchitecture and loss of stromal cells, mediated by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) overexpression, which is also characteristic of VL. Additionally, TNF deficiency mice infected with L. donovani have a lower IL-10 mRNA accumulation in the spleen than their wild-type counterparts, suggesting that TNF is a positive regulator of IL-10 production. Recent studies have shown that the inflammatory response following L. donovani infection is largely mediated by the transcription factor IRF-5, which can be activated by TLR7 and TLR9 via the MyD88 signaling pathway and/or directly by viral infections and Type I interferon. This transcription factor is responsible for activating genes encoding various key inflammatory cytokines.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a serious public health problem in many parts of the world, including Brazil. However, the disease is often neglected and there are few effective and affordable treatments. In Brazil, VL has spread from rural areas to large cities in the northeast, southeast, and center-west regions. During the first decade of the 21st century, more than 40,000 cases of VL and 2,500 deaths were reported in the country, and there was no significant reduction in fatality rates. Treatment options for VL in Brazil are pentavalent antimonial compounds and formulations of amphotericin B, but these have limitations and may not always be effective. Prognostic factors associated with VL can help identify patients at highest risk of an unfavorable outcome and guide treatment decisions. A systematic review of studies published in Brazil has identified potential predictors of death and adverse outcomes of American VL, and proposes improvements for future research.
Leishmaniasis are diseases caused by parasites that can only survive inside living cells. There are many different species of these parasites, and some of them can make people very sick. These diseases can be spread by tiny flying insects called sandflies. There are two types of leishmaniasis: cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) and visceral leishmaniasis (VL). CL is when the parasites only infect the skin and cause sores, while VL is when the parasites infect the organs inside the body and can be fatal. There are many different species of leishmaniasis parasites, and some of them are more dangerous than others. Antimony is a medicine that is used to treat these diseases, but some of the parasites are resistant to antimony. Resistance means that the parasites are not affected by the medicine and can continue to cause disease. In this study, scientists tested the susceptibility of leishmaniasis parasites from different parts of Algeria to antimony. They found that some of the parasites were resistant to antimony, which means that they were not affected by the medicine and could continue to cause disease. This is important information because it can help doctors and other medical professionals choose the best treatment for leishmaniasis patients.
Crohn's disease (CD) is a condition in which the lining of the small or large bowel is inflamed. The lining of the bowel is home to a variety of microorganisms, including bacteria. Studies have found that the bacterial population in CD patients is different from that in healthy people, and that some species of bacteria may be linked to CD. One type of bacteria that is often found in CD patients is called adherent-invasive E. coli (AIEC). Although AIEC is thought to be a benign member of the gut microbiota, recent studies have suggested that it may play a role in CD. To better understand the role of AIEC in CD, researchers have developed two new models to study how CD patients who develop gastroenteritis (inflammation of the stomach and intestines) respond to different types of bacteria. The researchers found that gastroenteritis caused an increase in the number of AIEC bacteria in the colon of the mice, and that this increase was associated with worsening of the disease. The researchers were able to block the increase in AIEC bacteria by sensitizing the bacteria to the host's immune system, which improved the disease. These findings suggest that AIEC bacteria may play a role in worsening CD in patients who develop gastroenteritis, and that treatments that reduce the number of AIEC bacteria or activate the host's immune system against AIEC may be effective in treating CD.
Gametes are the cells that reproduce in plants. These gametes are produced inside small plants called gametophytes. Arabidopsis, a type of plant, produces its gametophytes from a single spore. The gametophyte then divides into eight nuclei and cellularizes, forming four different cell types (Figure 1). Two of these types are the egg and sperm cells. These two cells are fertilized by one sperm cell each, forming the embryo and the endosperm. The other two cell types are accessory cells that surround the gametic cells. Two of these accessory cells attract the pollen tube to the egg cell, while the other two are located at the opposite pole and degenerate before fertilization. The process of determining which cells become gametic and which become accessory is not well understood. In this study, we took advantage of a new marker that allowed us to observe the egg cell more easily. We found that a combination of factors determines which cells become gametic and which become accessory. This process ensures that the gametic cells are formed while preventing the formation of excess gametic cells.
The use of shoes has been linked to a lower risk of developing certain diseases, such as podoconiosis and chronic larva migrans. However, the role of shoes in the prevention of other diseases such as hookworm and Buruli ulcer is inconsistent. There is a lack of research on the impact of behaviors related to footwear and their effect on NTDs. In southern Ethiopia, shoes are being distributed to children with the intention of preventing podoconiosis. This non-communicable form of elephantiasis occurs from long-term exposure to red clay soils. To understand why children might not wear shoes, we used two conceptual models to guide our efforts. First, we relied on the PRECEDE-PROCEED model, which suggests beginning the process by assessing social, behavioral, environmental, educational and ecological issues and needs that may influence whether and when children wear shoes. Second, we considered social cognitive theory of self-regulation, which argues for the importance of targeting individuals' beliefs and attitudes about shoe wearing, how these beliefs influence perceived capabilities to prevent podoconiosis, and whether wearing shoes can be effective in reducing their risk for the condition. Our qualitative study aimed to gain a deeper understanding of the barriers to consistent use of shoes in a rural setting. This information is valuable for investigators designing future studies to assess the association between shoe use and incidence of NTDs, and for those developing shoe-related prevention programs.
In neurons, proteins are sorted to different parts of the cell. These proteins are transported to different areas of the cell through rafts, which are small and dynamic microdomains of lipids and proteins that float freely in the membrane. The proteins that are sorted into these rafts are influenced by the levels of cholesterol and sphingolipids. This has been shown to be essential for the sorting of proteins into the axon, which is a key part of neurons. Viruses that infect neurons, such as herpesviruses, also use these rafts to transport their proteins and capsids. A protein called Us9 from the pseudorabies virus is important for the sorting of these viral proteins and capsids into the axon.
In this study, we investigated the molecular mechanism behind the nongenetic heterogeneity of yeast growth and stress tolerance. The variability of microcolony growth rates differs between natural isolates of budding yeast, indicating that there is a genetic basis of differences in nongenetic heterogeneity. The variability of microcolony growth rates could be due to nongenetic heterogeneity in Msn2 and Msn4 activity or growth rate. Therefore, we aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanism that generates nongenetic heterogeneity in Msn2 and Msn4 activity or growth rate. Our starting point was the regulation of TSL1, which is controlled by the paralogous transcription factors Msn2 and Msn4. The activities of Msn2 and Msn4 are controlled by intracellular cAMP levels via the Ras/cAMP/PKA pathway. However, the pathway by which heat stress activates Msn2 and Msn4 is unknown. As glucose starvation does, heat stress leads to greater nuclear residency of Msn2 and Msn4, but this effect of heat stress is accompanied by Msn2 and Msn4 hyperphosphorylation, which can be blocked by addition of cAMP. This result implies that sensing of heat stress does not go through PKA but instead involves other kinases. Nonetheless, because Msn2 and Msn4 targets are implicated in protecting cells against a variety of environmental stresses, including nutrient starvation and heat shock, it could be that fluctuations in PKA activity induce heterogeneity in Msn2 activity among unstressed cells that in turn creates heterogeneity in susceptibility to acute stress. Therefore, we tested our hypothesis using genetic analysis of the Ras/cAMP/PKA pathway in combination with single-cell assays of cell growth, gene expression, and stress tolerance. Our study not only contributes to our basic understanding of nongenetic heterogeneity but also points to an approach to defeating a bet-hedging strategy: increasing cAMP levels by administering a cAMP analog reduces the slower-growing fraction of the population and renders the population more susceptible to acute stress. This type of one-two punch might provide a useful treatment approach in cases where slow-growing subpopulations of pathogens or tumor cells cause relapse.
Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) has recently spread from Africa and Asia to the Americas, causing an estimated 1.7 million cases of severe, disabling arthralgia. The strain of CHIKV that has arrived in the Americas is from the Asian lineage and does not contain adaptive mutations. However, the mosquito species Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus are prevalent throughout many parts of North and South America. These conditions provide an opportunity for CHIKV to evolve in humans and adapt to its new environment. Using deep-sequencing technologies, we have analyzed the genetic diversity of CHIKV strains directly from human samples collected between week 52 of 2013 and week 5 of 2014. While no significant consensus changes were observed within a short period of time, we have identified a 3’ untranslated genome region (UTR) duplication. This duplication may have been missed by the initial sequencing of the ongoing epidemic in the Americas. It seems unique among the circulating CHIKV strains around the world.
The mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) is a central pathway that controls the way our cells function, including their growth, proliferation, and survival. It is implicated in human diseases such as tumors, obesity, epilepsy, autism, and neurodegeneration. mTOR is regulated by different factors at various organelles in the cell. The mTOR protein forms two complexes called mTORC1 and mTORC2 through interactions with other proteins, and these mTOR interacting proteins play important roles in regulating mTOR activity. One of these proteins is DEPTOR, which is an inhibitor of mTOR signaling found only in vertebrates. It is phosphorylated and ubiquitylated when mTORC1 signaling pathway is activated by serum stimulation, which results in its degradation. We have identified a previously unannotated vertebrate-specific gene called Ubtor as a functional player in regulating cell growth and mTOR signaling. Ubtor is found in hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells, and its levels are reduced when these cells are grown in culture. Ubtor depletion promotes neurite outgrowth in hippocampal neurons and cell growth in HEK293T and U87MG cells. On the other hand, Ubtor overexpression suppresses colony formation in HEK293T and T24 cells. We also found that Ubtor interacts with DEPTOR and mTOR complexes, and regulates DEPTOR’s ubiquitination. Lastly, we have demonstrated that Ubtor regulates cell growth and neoplasia via mTOR signaling using both zebrafish and mouse models.
In this study, researchers created a protein interaction map for Trypanosoma brucei, a parasite that causes the fatal human African trypanosomiasis (HAT). The map is based on four high-resolution fractionation experiments and mass spectrometry analysis. The map contains 866 protein groups, including many hypothetical and unannotated proteins. Clustering of the map led to the identification of 128 complexes. Researchers used the map to identify novel factors involved in the mitochondrial post-transcriptional regulation of T. brucei and validated their findings by several independent experiments. The map provides a useful resource for researchers and could lead to new biological hypotheses and experimental leads.
Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by infection with the bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). This infection can occur in the lungs and in lymph nodes (LNs), which are small organs that help fight infection. Most studies of Mtb infection have focused on the lungs, but recent research has shown that Mtb also commonly infects LNs. This infection can disrupt the normal structure and function of LNs, and may help Mtb to persist in the body and cause disease. New research on Mtb infection in LNs is helping us to better understand how TB progresses and how to treat it.
In this article, the authors describe a collection of 47 microsporidian species they found infecting wild nematodes. Microsporidia are fungus-like parasites that infect a wide range of hosts, including humans. Nematodes are small, soil-dwelling worms that are commonly used as biological models in scientific research. The authors describe the symptoms and effects of microsporidian infection in these nematodes, as well as the methods they used to isolate and identify the microsporidian species. They also provide information on the geographical distribution of each species and their host specificity. Overall, the study highlights the diversity and prevalence of microsporidian infections in wild nematodes, and the potential for these parasites to impact the ecology and evolution of these organisms.
Chemokine receptors are a type of receptor on the surface of cells that help control the movement of immune cells in response to certain signals. These receptors can form dimers, or pairs of receptors, when bound to a ligand, which can affect their function. Some chemokine receptors have been shown to require cholesterol in order to properly function. In this study, we used molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the spontaneous assembly of three chemokine receptors: CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2. We found that the homodimerization of these receptors can be influenced by cholesterol and that they can form heterodimers with each other.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a severe disease that causes fever, loss of weight, organomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and anemia. It can be fatal if left untreated. However, some patients can have subclinical leishmaniasis, which means they have the disease but are not showing any symptoms. This type of leishmaniasis was first discovered by Leishman in 1906 and has since been recognized by other groups of scientists. The proportion of patients with subclinical leishmaniasis to those with the classical symptoms varies depending on the geographic location and population factors such as nutrition and genetics. Diagnosis of leishmaniasis is typically based on a patient's immune response to the parasite, as it is difficult to detect the parasite in tissue examinations or cultures of affected tissues. In our area, we have diagnosed 160 patients who have immune deficiency and underwent extensive laboratory tests without any diagnosis. Our objective in this report is to inform scientists that systemic leishmaniasis can have a variety of different signs and symptoms, not just the classic ones.
The publicly available dbSNP database contains millions of unique human genetic variations. However, few of these are associated with a particular disease. When conducting association studies, researchers often produce hundreds of potential disease-causing variations that need to be "characterized." One way of doing this is by using computational methods that examine non-synonymous changes in human proteins. However, it is difficult to determine whether a change will cause a disease, as the relationship between protein function and disease is complex. To solve this problem, we examined the genome-wide distribution of sequence variants along paralogous proteins. We also compiled a dataset of known disease-causing variations and mapped them to their gene annotations and protein sequences. We found that sequence variants at aligned amino acid pairs occur more frequently than expected by chance, suggesting that similar functional constraints on paralogous protein sequences result in coordinated distributions of both disease and non-disease-causing variants along their lengths. Additionally, if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. Thus, knowledge of a sequence variant's paralogous relationships is useful for identifying novel disease-causing alleles.
In this study, the researchers compared the transcriptomes of parasites causing severe malaria to those causing uncomplicated malaria using RNA sequencing technology. They found that parasites causing severe malaria had a unique transcriptional profile involving genes involved in central carbon metabolism, folate biosynthesis, histone methylation, chaperone function, and surface expression of PfEMP1. Specifically, they found that expression of a conserved subset of PfEMP1s was associated with severe malaria. These PfEMP1s are expressed early in life and recognized more widely by sera from semi-immune children than PfEMP1s expressed by parasites causing uncomplicated disease. The authors believe that their findings have relevance to efforts to design vaccines targeting severe disease.
Scientists are having a hard time finding a vaccine that can stop people from getting HIV. HIV has different ways of avoiding the immune system's attack, and it keeps replicating even when there is a strong immune response. To make a vaccine that works, it might need to stop infection completely or make the immune response better than the one from infection. A promising approach is to use adeno-associated virus (AAV) to deliver antibodies with the ability to neutralize HIV. This method is like classical vaccination, but it doesn't rely on the host's immune system. The antibodies can last for a long time, and they have been shown to be safe and effective in people. There are more than a dozen antibodies that can neutralize over 90% of HIV strains, and they have different specificities. In a previous study, antibodies that were like molecules were delivered to monkeys using AAV, and some monkeys seemed to be protected from being infected with SIV. However, the SIV strain used in that study is easy to neutralize, and some of the monkeys developed antibodies that were attacking the delivered antibodies. It was unclear from that study how much this might have been caused by the fact that the antibodies delivered were not a real form of IgG. In this study, the scientists delivered two full-length IgG antibodies to monkeys using AAV. These antibodies were neutralizing antibodies that didn't work against SIV, but they still might offer some protection against infection.
Protein machines, which can be enzymes, ion pumps or molecular motors, are important for the functioning of biological cells. These machines operate based on slow conformational motions powered by external energy supply. In molecular motors, binding of ATP and its subsequent hydrolysis induce functional mechanochemical motions which are essential for their operation. These motions are conformational relaxation processes and can be large-scale, but they are often considered in the framework of linear response theory and the normal mode approximation. However, there is no general justification for this assumption and relaxation processes in complex dynamical systems can be strongly nonlinear. In this study, we analyze the conformational relaxation processes associated with ligand binding and hydrolysis in two motor proteins, myosin V and kinesin KIF1A. Our investigations, performed in the framework of the elastic network model, reveal that nonlinearity is characteristic for both macromolecules and the normal mode description is not really applicable for any of them. Despite the nonlinearity, well-defined conformational relaxation paths are found in both motor proteins.
In this study, the authors explain the difference between two types of endocytosis: clathrin-mediated endocytosis (CME) and caveolae-mediated endocytosis. CME is the best understood endocytosis pathway and involves the clathrin-coated pits. On the other hand, caveolae are cup-shaped invaginations of the cell surface and are also considered as endocytic vehicles. The authors also talk about the importance of various proteins involved in these pathways and their functions. They also mention the importance of cholesterol and lipids in both of these pathways. The authors further talk about the crosstalk between these two endocytosis pathways. They mention that the over-expression of caveolin can inhibit dynamin-independent internalization of cholera toxin subunit b and fluid-phase markers. The authors also mention that CD44 is a specific marker of CLIC (clathrin-independent carriers) endocytosis pathway and have used it to study crosstalk between CLIC and caveolae. They have found that there is complex crosstalk between these two membrane systems at multiple levels. Overall, the study provides insights into the mechanisms of these two endocytosis pathways and their crosstalk.
The paper is about two types of proteins that help bacteria respond to their environment. These proteins are called "Two-Component Signaling" (TCS) proteins. TCS proteins have two parts: a membrane-bound protein that senses the environment and a protein in the cell that receives the signal. The paper is about the second part of the TCS protein, called the "Receiver" (REC) domain. There are two types of REC domains: "canonical" and "atypical". The paper is mostly about the "atypical" REC domains. These REC domains are different from "canonical" REC domains in that they don't have all the same features, and some of them don't have the part that is normally phosphorylated. The paper describes some of the different types of "atypical" REC domains and their functions. The paper also describes the structure of the REC domain of one protein called "RitR" and how it works, even though it doesn't have the part that is usually phosphorylated.
Oncolytic viruses are a new type of anticancer agent that are low in toxicity and have little impact on the quality of life of patients. Oncolytic herpes simplex viruses (oHSVs) are particularly effective in treating cancer. OncovexGM-CSF, an oHSV, is approved to treat metastatic melanoma. The Clinical trials.gov website lists 22 ongoing or recently completed trials using oHSVs. One of the benefits of oHSVs is their ability to boost the immune response to the tumor and act like a vaccine without the need to identify tumor-specific or patient-specific neoantigens. In combination with checkpoint inhibitors, oHSVs enhance the efficacy of blockade therapy. They can also be engineered to express anti-checkpoint antibodies. To make oHSVs safer, they are often attenuated. Attenuation can be achieved through genetic engineering or natural mutations. Attenuation makes oHSVs preferentially infect cancer cells, but not exclusively. Attenuation also reduces their ability to replicate and to cause harm. To address safety concerns, oHSVs are often engineered to express cytokines or checkpoint inhibitors. The IL-12 cytokine, in particular, has shown promise in clinical trials when administered through oHSVs. An alternative approach to attenuation is to retarget oHSVs to cancer cells. This allows oHSVs to be fully virulent in cancer cells and causes no harm in tumor-free mice. R-115, an IL-12-armed HER2-retargeted oHSV, has been found to inhibit the growth of primary tumors, completely prevent the growth of untreated tumors, elicit a strong immune response, and induce a vaccine-like response in mice.
HIV is a serious disease that continues to be a challenge for global public health. More than 36 million people are currently living with HIV, with over 2 million new infections and 1 million AIDS-related deaths per year. A safe and effective HIV vaccine is an important research priority, but previous vaccine attempts have not been successful. Recombinant viral vectors are one important platform for HIV vaccine development, and several trials have tested candidate HIV vaccines based on human Ad5 vector. However, these trials have failed to show efficacy. Our study aims to understand the role of CD4 T cells in HIV vaccination, and we compare the susceptibility of vector-specific CD4 T cells induced by ALVAC, another important HIV vaccine vector, to Ad5-specific CD4 T cells. We found that ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells are substantially less susceptible to HIV infection compared to Ad5-specific CD4 T cells. We also compared the proliferative response of vector-specific CD8 vs . CD4 T cells, and found that Ad5-specific CD8 T cells proliferate more robustly than Ad5-specific CD4 T cells, while ALVAC-specific CD8 T cells proliferate less robustly than ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells. Overall, our study suggests that understanding the HIV susceptibility of vector-specific CD4 T-cell populations induced by different vaccine vectors may provide new insights into our understanding of host immunity in HIV vaccination.
The study focuses on the way that mammalian females silence one of their two X chromosomes in each somatic cell, a process called X inactivation. This process varies among species and can occur in different ways. In some species, the paternally inherited X chromosome is universally silenced, while in others, each somatic cell can express either the maternally or the paternally inherited X. Recent studies have revealed that some species practice biased X inactivation, meaning that they preferentially silence one of the two X chromosomes. The study explores the evolutionary mechanisms that could account for this variation in X inactivation patterns and suggests that selection for masking the fitness costs of carrying deleterious alleles might favor the evolution of random X inactivation. However, the study emphasizes that the specific properties of sex-differential selection and inheritance that govern X chromosome evolution make it difficult to apply population genetic models to this case. The study therefore developed a mathematical model of X inactivation evolution and used this model to identify the biological conditions that favor different X inactivation strategies. The results suggest that selection on mammalian X inactivation strategies is primarily mediated by the interaction between dominance and sex-differential selection. The study also examines whether sex-differential selection might favor the evolution of biased X inactivation patterns and predicts the magnitude of biases likely to evolve. The results indicate that conditions for evolving biased inactivation patterns are extremely permissive.
ZAP is a protein that was discovered in rats as a way for the body to fight against certain viruses. It has been shown to have antiviral properties against many different types of viruses, including retroviruses, filoviruses, alphaviruses, and hepatitis B virus. However, not all viruses are sensitive to ZAP. For example, herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), vesicular stomatitis virus, and yellow fever virus (YFV) are resistant to ZAP. The protein in humans comes in two major isoforms, ZAP-L and ZAP-S, which differ in the C-terminal region through alternative splicing. The N-terminus of ZAP contains four CCCH-type zinc-finger motifs, which are required for RNA binding and antiviral activity. ZAP works by recruiting the RNA processing exosome complex and poly (A)-specific ribonuclease (PARN) to degrade target RNA from the 3′-end. It can also interrupt translation of incoming viral RNA of Sindbis virus by blocking the interaction between translational initiation factors eIF4A and eIF4G. Furthermore, ZAP-S can associate with RIG-I, a key sensor to recognize viral RNA, to promote the innate immune response and contribute to its antiviral potential. In this study, the authors found that JEV, DENV, and ZIKV were all sensitive to ZAP, and they demonstrated the antiviral mechanism of ZAP against JEV infection.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is a highly contagious virus that affects both humans and animals. It is a priority pathogen according to the National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the United States Department of Agriculture. While there are currently no vaccines or therapeutics for RVFV, a live-attenuated vaccine called MP-12 is being tested in a clinical trial. MP-12 is a mutant version of the wild-type virus that is avirulent in pregnant ewes and apathogenic in adult mice. The virus is transmitted by mosquitoes, and has caused outbreaks on the Arabian Peninsula, and in South Africa in 2010-2011. The disease can be fatal in up to 20% of cases, and causes severe disease in ruminants, particularly in pregnant animals where nearly 100% of infected animals abort their fetuses. The host response to RVFV infection is not well understood, but a recent study found that adult C57BL/6 mice infected with wild-type RVFV had a more significant cytokine response than those infected with the attenuated MP-12 vaccine strain. This response was correlated with histological changes seen in organs of infected animals, and neurologic disease in some cases.
Breast cancer is a common cancer in women and can become resistant to chemotherapy, leading to death. There are different ways to regulate this resistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), which is initially susceptible to chemotherapy but can become resistant. This resistance is caused by changes in genes that affect apoptosis, and the activity of proteins like NF-κB and AKT. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs), which can form new tumors, may also contribute to resistance. Cell-extrinsic factors like growth factors and cytokines in the tumor environment can affect resistance. We found a chemokine called CCL20 that could predict resistance to taxane, a type of chemotherapy. By studying cell lines and mouse models, we found that blocking CCL20 or CCL20-related proteins could reverse resistance and improve the effectiveness of taxane. CCL20 is involved in the positive feedback loop that causes resistance, and it activates p65 NF-κB, which is related to gene transcription. This activation of p65 NF-κB leads to increased efflux of taxane and more CCL20, contributing to resistance. Overall, understanding the mechanisms behind resistance can help doctors find new ways to treat breast cancer.
Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that infects many different animals. It causes toxoplasmosis, an infection that can last for a lifetime and cause serious complications in people with weakened immune systems. When Toxoplasma infects a host, it creates a protective barrier within the host cell called the parasitophorous vacuole (PV). This is where the parasite reproduces and grows. However, the PV also creates a barrier that the parasite needs to overcome in order to fully take over the host and get the nutrients it needs to survive. To do this, Toxoplasma secretes effector proteins that modify the host cell's pathways and allow the parasite to survive within the host. These effector proteins are secreted from organelles in the parasite called rhoptries and dense granules. Recently, two new classes of dense granule effectors have been identified: those that localize to the nanotubular network and/or the PV membrane, and those that travel across the PV and localize to the host cell nucleus. GRA16 and GRA24 are examples of these two classes. Both proteins have been shown to affect important host pathways, but how they reach the host cell nucleus has not yet been understood. In this study, the authors found two new proteins, MYR2 and MYR3, that are involved in the transport of effectors across the PV. They also found that the fusion of an intrinsically disordered protein called GRA16 to a protein called DHFR is sufficient to block its translocation, and this block affects the translocation of other effectors as well. This suggests that effectors are transported across the PV through a translocon-like mechanism.
Papillomaviruses (PVs) are infectious viruses that can cause cancer in humans. They have limited coding ability, so they rely on host cells to help them replicate. The viral genome replicates in stages. It starts out at low copy number in the basal layer of the epithelium, then replicates more in the middle layers, and finally replicates most in the top layers. In this top layer, the viral genome replicates to hundreds of copies and forms particles that can infect new cells.  We have learned a lot about how PVs replicate by studying the E2 protein of bovine papillomavirus (BPV). The E2 protein has three parts: an N-terminal part that helps with replication, a middle part that is not related to other proteins, and a C-terminal part that helps with DNA binding. We also know that E2 binds to a specific part of the viral genome and recruits a protein called E1, which helps with replication. This happens at a specific part of the genome called the origin of replication.
Brucellosis is a common zoonotic infection that affects both humans and livestock. Central Asia is a hotspot for brucellosis, and small-scale urban and peri-urban (UPU) livestock farming is becoming more common in many low-income countries. The genetic characterization of Brucella DNA using qPCR assays can provide rapid and safe detection of the genus Brucella, and further classification of Brucella at the species level can be performed by qPCR targeting the rpoB gene. The current study aimed to investigate the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk with qPCR, perform sequence analysis of Brucella DNA extracted from bovine milk, and investigate how the qPCR result corresponds to previously obtained serology data in the UPU area of Dushanbe, Tajikistan.
The article explains how changes in the structure of the genome can affect how genes are expressed in plants and fungi. These changes are caused by the addition or removal of small molecules called "methyl groups" to the amino acids that make up the proteins that wrap DNA into a structure called chromatin. Methyl groups can be added to a variety of different amino acids, but in plants and fungi, most of them are added to a specific amino acid called lysine. When lysine is methylated, it causes the surrounding DNA to become tightly packed and less accessible to proteins that control gene expression. This process, called "epigenetic regulation," is thought to play a key role in controlling the expression of genes in response to changes in the environment.
Rabies is a fatal disease that can be prevented if treated promptly with post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). PEP consists of several steps, including washing the wound, vaccination, and in some cases, injections of purified rabies immunoglobulin. However, these treatments are not always available in low-income countries, leading to high death rates. The cost and availability of rabies vaccines can vary greatly, with prices ranging from a few dollars to hundreds of dollars per vial. Vaccine shortages are a major problem in many countries, and this can lead to delayed or incomplete treatment. Additionally, the cost of travel and accommodation for PEP can be significant, especially for patients who need to travel far for treatment. New ways of administering PEP, such as through intra-dermal injections, may be more cost-effective and have been approved by the World Health Organization. However, this method of administration is still not widely available. In this article, we provide a framework for comparing the cost-effectiveness of different PEP regimens, including existing approved regimens and new candidates subject to approval. We discuss the implications of these findings for policy and vaccine research.
Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite that causes toxoplasmosis, can infect a wide variety of mammalian cells, where it forms a vacuole called the parasitophorous vacuole. The parasite is auxotrophic for low-density lipoprotein-derived cholesterol and can scavenge it from host cells through endocytosis. Once inside the parasite, cholesterol can be esterified and stored in cytosolic lipid droplets (LD). Recent studies showed that host cells form more LD when infected by Toxoplasma, which may be beneficial for the parasite since it can salvage host LD lipids and use them for various purposes such as membrane synthesis or storage. In this study, the authors explore how Toxoplasma exploits host LD for nutritional purposes. They found that Toxoplasma infection has a profound impact on host cell neutral lipid homeostasis, including changes in LD abundance, distribution, and synthesis. They also provide morphological evidence that Toxoplasma internalizes host LD into the parasitophorous vacuole and salvages their lipid content for incorporation into membranes or storage in its own LD. Overall, the study provides insights into how Toxoplasma manipulates host cell lipid metabolism for its own benefit.
This paper discusses Fasciola hepatica, a type of parasitic flatworm that causes an infection called fasciolosis. This disease affects cattle and is now considered an emerging zoonotic disease by the World Health Organization. The paper highlights that resistance to the only current treatment, triclabendazole, is increasing, making it urgent to develop new ways to treat fasciolosis. One potential way to do this is by targeting a protein called cysteine protease, which is important in the life cycle of the parasite. The paper discusses how cysteine proteases are important at different stages of the parasite's life cycle and how drugs that target these proteins have been developed to treat other diseases. The paper then talks about how chalcones, a type of flavonoid, may be used as an inhibitor of cysteine proteases in Fasciola hepatica. Chalcones are natural compounds that have been found to have medicinal properties and have been approved for use in humans. The paper discusses how chalcones have been tested as inhibitors of cysteine proteases in other diseases and how they may be useful in treating fasciolosis. The paper then discusses how the authors performed a search for small molecules from their own library of synthetic flavonoids that could inhibit cysteine proteases in Fasciola hepatica, specifically FhCL3 and FhCL1. The authors identified several compounds that were effective at inhibiting these proteases and also had fasciolicide activity, meaning they killed the parasites. The paper concludes that the compounds identified by the authors could be used as the basis for developing new drugs to treat fasciolosis.
The retina analyzes images through a complex system of parallel representations that transmit information to the brain. The anatomical structure of these channels is established in the inner plexiform layer, which is made up of five to six distinct strata where dendrites from different types of retinal ganglion cells are found. Bipolar cells, which make connections with defined subsets of retinal ganglion cells, are located in these strata. Each bipolar cell has a unique filtering property that makes it easier to transmit information to different types of retinal ganglion cells. However, it is not clear how so many different filtering properties can be created using a limited number of bipolar cells. The answer may be found in the synaptic connections between the bipolar cells and the retinal ganglion cells, which may be different and have different kinetics due to local interactions with different types of inhibitory amacrine cells. The size of the bipolar cell's terminal may also play a role in how the visual signal is transmitted. By using zebrafish that express proteins that report the fusion of synaptic vesicles or the presynaptic calcium signal driving fusion, we can observe the activity of multiple bipolar cell synapses. We found that bipolar cell terminals of different sizes have different properties. On average, smaller terminals create calcium transients that are larger and faster, resulting in a higher initial gain of responses to an increase in temporal contrast followed by more profound adaptation. Small terminals also transmit high frequencies more effectively. Such differences in the output of small and large terminals are also observed in individual cells, which therefore have an intrinsic ability to filter visual information through channels with different gains, temporal filters, and adaptive properties.
The article introduces a new method for detecting and analyzing individual synapses at scale using fluorescence microscopy (FM) data. This method is designed to work with data acquired using conjugate array tomography (cAT), which combines FM with electron microscopic array tomography (EM-AT). The method produces probability maps that indicate the likelihood that a given voxel represents part of a synapse. The article demonstrates that the algorithm is effective in detecting synapses from FM data alone, and that it can reproduce known architectural features of cortical synapse distributions. The article also discusses the importance of a reliable, high-throughput method for synapse detection, and the limitations of current methods for detecting and analyzing individual synapses at scale.
The article describes the function of a protein called ZnT2 in humans. ZnT2 helps move zinc ions from one place in a cell to another, which is important for the body to work properly. The study looked at how ZnT2 does this and found that it uses a gradient of protons (a type of charged atom) to help move zinc ions across cell membranes. This information is important for understanding how ZnT2 works and how to treat conditions where it doesn't work properly.
This study is about a protein called Exo1, which is involved in DNA repair pathways in humans and yeast. Exo1 removes mononucleotides from the 5′ end of the DNA duplex, but its activity is tightly controlled by post-translational modifications. The study found that Exo1 interacts with 14-3-3 proteins, which are important for controlling the functions of proteins during DNA damage and replication stress. The study also showed that 14-3-3 proteins are required for cell cycle restart and for suppressing genomic instability during DNA damage and replication stress. The study found that 14-3-3 proteins regulate Exo1 phosphorylation and that Exo1-dependent ssDNA gaps accumulate at stalled forks in yeast 14-3-3 deficient cells. This study provides evidence that 14-3-3 proteins have a crucial role in regulating the function of proteins at stalled forks, with Exo1 being a key target.
HIV infection causes the immune system to become overactive, which leads to the depletion of CD4+ T cells and disease progression. This immune activation is caused by different factors, including gut tissue damage and the release of microbial products into the bloodstream. The production of IFN-I is one of these factors that is correlated with immune activation and disease progression. However, it is not clear if the pDCs are the primary source of IFN-I during acute or chronic HIV infection and the role of pDC in HIV replication or disease progression is not well understood. To better understand the role of pDC in HIV infection, a humanized mouse model has been developed that allows for the study of HIV infection in vivo. The pDCs in these models are rapidly activated by HIV infection and their activation level is inversely correlated with the number of CD4+ T cells. To determine the role of pDC in HIV infection, a specific monoclonal antibody has been developed to deplete pDCs in the lymphoid organs of these models. This allows for the study of HIV infection and immunopathogenesis during acute and chronic phases of the disease.
Highly active anti-retroviral treatment (HAART) has saved countless lives, but it comes with high costs, resistant viruses, and short-term and long-term side effects. Understanding how to activate cellular anti-viral defenses may lead to new therapeutic alternatives to overcome these limitations and support prevention and cure strategies. In this study, we show for the first time that sulforaphane (SFN), a natural product known for its health benefits, blocks HIV infection in macrophages. These cells play a critical role in HIV infection and pathogenesis, forming long-lived viral reservoirs and carrying virus into restricted compartments like the brain. Most monocytes, precursors of macrophages, are refractory to HIV infection until they differentiate to replenish the macrophage pool. A small but specific subset of these cells, however, may be readily infectable, even in HAART-treated patients. Infected macrophages have been observed in asymptomatic, untreated patients and in HAART-treated individuals. SFN is generated in cruciferous vegetables after mechanical damage and reaches various tissues after consumption where it maintains biological function. In humans, SFN is absorbed in the gut and peak plasma levels are achieved within 90 minutes. In mice, SFN can reach the prostate after ingestion where biological activity is maintained. SFN is a powerful mobilizer of the transcription factor nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2), a master regulator of the antioxidant response. Nrf2 is held in check by its constitutive degradation through CUL3 ubiquitin ligase complexes using the protein KEAP1 as a substrate adaptor. SFN and other Nrf2-activators modify KEAP1 to prevent engagement of Nrf2. As Nrf2 accumulates, it translocates into the nucleus and initiates transcription from antioxidant response elements (ARE). The consensus Nrf2 binding motif, TGACTCAGCA, was derived from known anti-oxidant response genes and Nrf2 binding was reconfirmed in chromatin immunoprecipitation and transcription analyses. Nrf2 activates several types of genes predominantly encoding proteins that counter oxidizing conditions. Three viruses, Marburg virus, Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus, and Dengue virus, trigger Nrf2 activation. In contrast to Marburg, Dengue, and KSHV, HIV is blocked through Nrf2 and sets the stage for discovering the mechanism underlying this restriction.
Geohelminth infections, also known as parasitic worm infections, are a major health problem worldwide, affecting about 3.8 billion people. These infections can cause anemia, iron deficiency, and impaired nutritional status, as well as negative effects on a baby's growth in pregnant women. The severity of the effects of these infections on pregnant women may vary depending on the region and the level of infection. Hookworm infection causes intestinal bleeding and protein loss, which can worsen iron deficiency and anemia. Ascaris lumbricoides infections are usually asymptomatic, but can cause impaired fat digestion, reduced vitamin absorption, and temporary lactose intolerance. Blood loss can also be a feature of Trichuris trichiura infection, but it is less prominent than in hookworm infection. Malaria is common in areas where these parasitic worms are found, and the interaction between the two diseases is not clear. Pregnancy can increase the prevalence of Ascaris lumbricoides and Trichuris trichiura infections, but it is unclear if there is an interaction between these parasites and malaria during pregnancy. In our study, we looked at the prevalence of geohelminth infections and their effects on pregnant women in rural western Kenya. We found that geohelminth infections were common among pregnant women, and that they were associated with anemia, iron deficiency, and impaired nutritional status. We also looked at how these infections affected pregnancy symptoms and found that pregnant women with hookworm infections were more likely to have anemia, but there was no significant difference in other symptoms between pregnant women with and without geohelminth infections.
Mycolactone is a substance produced by a skin pathogen called Mycobacterium ulcerans, which causes Buruli ulcer disease. The skin ulcers associated with this disease are not painful and do not cause inflammation. Scientists are trying to understand why this is the case, in order to better treat the disease and find new ways to control inflammation. Early research thought that the lack of pain and inflammation was due to nerve damage. However, later research showed that mycolactone can cause local hypoesthesia (a loss of feeling in a specific area) without nerve damage. Mycolactone has been found to activate a type of receptor on nerve cells called type 2 angiotensin II receptors, which can cause the cells to become less sensitive and not send pain signals properly. This mechanism is controversial, as blocking type 2 angiotensin II receptors has been shown to promote analgesia (a reduction in pain) in the past. Recently, scientists have discovered that mycolactone can also cause problems with the proteins that are made by immune cells, which can lead to migration problems, decreased production of cytokines, and decreased responsiveness to cytokines. This can cause inflammation and pain, so blocking mycolactone's effects on immune cells could potentially help with analgesia. In support of this hypothesis, mice were given mycolactone and were found to be protected from skin inflammation and acute inflammatory pain. Mycolactone could potentially be used to treat chronic pain, which is a growing health problem. Nerve damage can cause an inflammatory reaction at the site of the injury, leading to disruption of the blood nerve barrier and infiltration of immune cells into the nerve. Peripheral nerve damage can also cause central sensitization, which is an increase in pain sensitivity in the brain. Mycolactone can cause problems with proteins made by nerve cells and immune cells, which can lead to decreased sensitivity and responsiveness. This could potentially stop the inflammatory reaction and reduce central sensitization, leading to reduced pain.
Human African trypanosomiasis, or sleeping sickness, is a disease caused by a parasite and mainly found in sub-Saharan Africa. The parasite has two sub-species: Trypanosoma brucei gambiense and Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense. Trypanosoma brucei gambiense causes over 95% of all cases of HAT and is prevalent on the coast of West Africa, where the vector, a type of fly called Glossina palpalis gambiensis, is abundant. Symptoms can include intermittent fevers and headaches, and if not treated, the disease can lead to neurological disorders and is widely assumed to be fatal. However, there are cases of asymptomatic carriers who have been described in both old and recent reports, suggesting that humans may be able to develop resistance to the disease. A study was conducted in Guinea to explore the possible role of genetic polymorphisms in IL4, IL6, IL8, IL10, IFNG, APOL1, TNFA, HPR, HLA-G, HLA-A, HP, and MIF genes on susceptibility/resistance to HAT.
Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technology allows us to sequence an entire genome in a cost-effective way. This technology allows us to survey multiple individuals from a population to catalogue genetic variations in the population. By using an unbiased approach, NGS allows us to survey different classes of genetic variants with a single assay. These variants include single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), insertion-deletions (indels), and structural variants (SVs). The 1000 Genomes Project (1 KGP) is a project that surveys more than 2,500 individuals from 20 populations around the world. Recently, a project called the Singapore Sequencing Malay Project (SSMP) sequenced 100 Austronesian Malays at a coverage of at least 30X. This project has shown that deep sequencing can provide a more complete characterization of variants carried by the individuals. South Asia is a diverse continent that comprises more than 20% of the world population. Singapore is home to over 350,000 Indians, who have been designated as Indian, but in reality, they are from different parts of the Indian subcontinent. The Singapore Sequencing Indian Project (SSIP) is a project that aims to perform whole-genome sequencing of 38 healthy Singapore Indians. The project will provide insights into the genetic structure and diversity of Asian Indians in Singapore. The project is now publicly available at http://www.statgen.nus.edu.sg/~SSIP .
Melioidosis is a disease that is caused by a type of bacteria called Burkholderia pseudomallei. This disease is found in tropical and subtropical regions of the world and is considered an emerging disease. Treatment for melioidosis can be complicated because the bacteria that cause this disease are resistant to many antibiotics. This resistance is due to several factors, including the ability of the bacteria to form biofilms and to go into a prolonged latency period in a human host. Genome sequence analysis has shown that the bacteria that cause melioidosis have several genes that can help them resist antibiotics. However, only a few of these genes have been experimentally confirmed. One of these genes, called AmrAB-OprA, can help the bacteria resist aminoglycosides and macrolides. However, our results suggest that this gene does not play a major role in resistance to these antibiotics in some strains of bacteria. Instead, these strains may lack the ability to express this gene, either due to a deletion or because of some other unknown mechanism. Additionally, we found that some strains of bacteria that cause melioidosis have a deletion in their genomes that removes several genes encoding putative virulence factors and other functions implicated in bacterial pathogenesis and physiology.
This study investigates the early stage of differentiation in CD4 T helper cells, using a model system to understand the interplay between intracellular transcription factors and extracellular cytokines. The goal is to avoid biasing cellular fate by studying spontaneous differentiation of naive CD4 T cells in the absence of exogenously added cytokines. The regulatory network governing cell differentiation consists of positive feedback loops and cross-inhibitory interactions between Tbx21 and Gata3. These transcription factors are the master regulators of Th1 and Th2 differentiation, respectively. Tbet and Gata3 activate their own expression and that of their respective target genes, while also silencing the expression of the other transcription factor. To quantify the number of Tbx21 and Gata3 transcripts in activated CD4 T cells, single-molecule fluorescent in situ hybridization ( smFISH ) combined with immunofluorescence is performed on CD4 cells isolated from C57BL/6 mice that were activated by culturing them in wells coated with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 antibodies. This study provides insights into the complex regulatory network governing cell differentiation and the interplay between extracellular cytokines and intracellular transcription factors during the early stage of differentiation in naive CD4 T cells.
This article is about a protein called paqr-2 in C. elegans worms. Paqr-2 is important for metabolic regulation and helps the worms adapt to cold temperatures. To find out how paqr-2 works, the researchers used an unbiased forward genetic approach to screen randomly mutagenized worm populations. They found nine suppressors of the cold adaptation defect in the paqr-2 mutant and established a new regulatory pathway connecting paqr-2, phosphatidylcholine (PC) synthesis, and the regulation of FA desaturation to increase membrane fluidity during cold adaptation.
Herpes viruses cause a variety of diseases, from cold sores and chicken pox to birth defects and cancer. The smallest unit of a herpes virus is called a virion, which is composed of a capsid that contains the viral DNA, a protein layer (the tegument), and an outer lipid envelope. The tegument is a sticky layer that surrounds the virion. It is not a part of the viral DNA or the capsid. The tegument is responsible for releasing the virus from the cell, and it can also interact with the cell to help the virus enter the nucleus of the cell. A new discovery was made recently using cryo-EM and cryo-ET techniques to visualize the structure of the tegument. This study revealed a previously unknown feature in the tegument of HSV-1 virions that is similar to the delivery system of tailed bacteriophages. This feature may help the virus interact with the cell at key points during the viral life cycle, such as when it enters the nucleus or releases its DNA. This discovery provides new information about how viruses interact with cells and may lead to new ways to treat viral infections.
Humans are frequently exposed to a variety of pathogens in their lifetime. Some of these pathogens can even infect us at the same time. When the immune system responds to these co-infections, it may affect the progression of HIV-1 disease and transmission. This is particularly true in people who have already been infected with HIV-1. S. mansoni is an important type of pathogen that is often found in areas with high HIV-1 prevalence. A protein called DC-SIGN, which is expressed by dendritic cells, plays a role in both HIV-1 transmission and S. mansoni transmission. The protein can capture and transfer S. mansoni eggs to immune cells, and it can also bind to HIV-1 particles and assist with their entry into immune cells. CD4+ T cells are infected by HIV-1 when they come into contact with the virus. There are different types of CD4+ T cells, and the virus can infect them in different ways. One way is through a direct infection of the CD4+ T cell itself, called cis-infection. Another way is through the CD4+ T cell coming into contact with a virus-infected dendritic cell, called trans-infection. When CD4+ T cells are infected with HIV-1, they can be lost from the immune system, which can have a negative impact on disease progression. HIV-1 infection can also affect the way CD4+ T cells respond to other pathogens, such as S. mansoni. Studies have shown that S. mansoni can increase the risk of HIV-1 infection in women. Some treatments for S. mansoni have been shown to decrease viral loads in people who are co-infected with S. mansoni and HIV-1. However, other studies have found conflicting results. Therefore, it is important to continue studying the relationship between S. mansoni and HIV-1 to understand how they interact in the body and how these interactions affect disease progression and treatment.
The term "astrocyte" was first used in the 1890s to describe a type of brain cells that were found by a scientist named Lenhossék. These cells are called "macroglia" because they are larger than other types of brain cells. For most of the 20th century, scientists thought that astrocytes were passive and just watched what was happening in the brain. However, more recent research has shown that astrocytes are actually very important and involved in many processes, such as modulating the levels of excitatory and inhibitory chemicals in the brain. They also help with homeostasis, which is the body's ability to keep itself in balance. This is especially true for astrocytes in the brain. Astrocytes are also important for blood flow in the brain. In addition, astrocytes are important in many different brain diseases and injuries. By studying astrocytes, scientists can learn more about how to treat these conditions.
The paper is about how certain parts of DNA, called transposons, are silenced to prevent their movement and to keep our genomes stable. Scientists have found that small RNA molecules called siRNAs are involved in this silencing process. These siRNAs are made from double-stranded RNA by the Dicer enzyme, then incorporated into AGO4 proteins, which help to silence transcription. It is not clear if siRNAs base-pair interact with DNA or nascent RNA transcripts, but it is known that this process is important for transcriptional silencing. There are several other proteins that are also important for this process, including Pol II, Pol IV, RNA Polymerase V (Pol V), RDR2, and DCL3. These proteins are all needed for efficient establishment and maintenance of transcriptional silencing. The paper suggests that the SPT5L protein may work downstream of Pol V and recruit AGO4 to Pol V-transcribed loci. The paper also shows that SPT5L physically interacts with chromatin and is needed for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications at several loci. The paper proposes that the coordinate binding of SPT5L and AGO4 creates a platform for direct or indirect recruitment of chromatin modifying enzymes.
The bacterial genome encodes alternative sigma factors that control the transcription of specific genes in response to changing environmental conditions. One of these alternative sigma factors is RpoS, which is the master regulator of the general stress response in E. coli. Induction of the RpoS regulon occurs in response to a variety of stressors such as low nutrient availability, high osmolarity, reactive oxygen intermediates, and low pH. Up to 10% of the genome is regulated either directly or indirectly by RpoS with the composition of the regulon determined by the specific stressor. RpoS is essential for biofilm formation in Pseudomonas aeruginosa, growth and survival of Legionella pneumophila within phagolysosomes, and infectivity of mice by Salmonella enterica. B. burgdorferi uses just three sigma factors to modulate its transcriptome during its enzootic cycle. Transcription of rpoSBb is directly activated by the alternative sigma factor RpoN with the aid of two enhancer proteins: the response regulator Rrp2 and the DNA-binding protein and Fur orthologue, BosR. RpoS is induced during the nymphal blood meal but is not expressed by spirochetes within replete larvae or unfed nymphs. The expression patterns of RpoS-dependent genes in the tick reflect more than a simple ON/OFF bipartite regulation. Within the mammal, RpoS-dependent genes are required to establish infection.
