At a specific point in development, known as the maternal-to-zygotic transition (MZT), the zygotic genome is activated and development is controlled by the zygotic transcripts. This activation occurs in a coordinated manner with the degradation of the maternally provided RNAs. In Drosophila melanogaster, during mitotic cycle 14, the blastoderm nuclei cellularize and general zygotic transcription is initiated. However, some specific genes required for sex determination, pattern formation, and cellularization are transcribed as early as cycle 8. These genes contain a common set of heptameric DNA motifs that regulate early gene expression. The most important factor in regulating early gene expression is the zinc-finger transcription factor Zelda (ZLD). ZLD is essential for embryonic mitosis and cellularization. In ZLD-depleted embryos, 120 genes were identified whose proper expression during early embryogenesis is dependent on ZLD. ChIP-Seq was used to determine the genomic landscape of ZLD binding as the embryo progresses through the MZT. The results show that ZLD binds to DNA throughout the genome, with a preference for regions that contain a specific sequence.
Circadian clocks are present in almost all living organisms and regulate many of their functions on a 24-hour cycle. In mammals, the circadian clock is made up of a group of interacting genes that produce proteins that work together to regulate gene expression. These proteins form complexes and interact with each other in a specific way to control the timing of gene expression. A lot of the proteins in the body are part of complexes or groups that work together. These complexes or groups are called modules. It is thought that many of the functions of cells are controlled by modules that work together in a time-dependent manner. In this study, the researchers used a technique called yeast-two-hybrid to find out which proteins in the circadian clock are part of modules that work together. They found 109 new interactions between proteins in the circadian clock. They then used another technique called co-immunoprecipitation to confirm some of these interactions. They also looked at how the timing of interactions between these proteins changes over time. They found that the timing of interactions between proteins in the circadian clock is important for the normal functioning of the clock. They also found that many of the modules that make up the circadian clock are organized in a time-dependent way, meaning that they work together at different times of the day. This could be important for controlling many of the functions of cells in the body. The researchers found that 109 new interactions between proteins in the circadian clock are part of modules that work together. They also looked at how the timing of these interactions changes over time. They found that the timing of these interactions is important for the normal functioning of the circadian clock. They also found that many of the modules that make up the circadian clock are organized in a time-dependent way, meaning that they work together at different times of the day. This could be important for controlling many of the functions of cells in the body.
Tandemly repetitive polyproteins (TRPs) are proteins that are made up of repeated units of similar or identical amino acid sequences. Unlike other proteins, the units of TRPs are usually similar in structure and have similar biochemical activities. Filaggrins are a type of TRP that is produced by skin cells and are important for skin structure. Nematode polyprotein allergens (NPAs) are another type of TRP that is produced by nematode worms and can cause allergic reactions in humans. No one knows why more proteins are not synthesized as TRPs. Scientists have now solved the structure of one unit of an NPA from a nematode worm in solution. The unit, called ABA-1A, has a unique seven-helical fold and two discrete hydrophobic cavities that could be used to bind lipids.
The developing Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PICTs) are at increasing risk from both acute and chronic diseases, such as HIV/AIDS and obesity, and are also highly vulnerable to environmental impacts from sea level rise and extreme weather events associated with global warming. Ciguatera is a tropical and subtropical disease that is prevalent in island communities and might be increasing in incidence due to increasing vulnerabilities (such as poverty, global warming, and eutrophication) in these populations. Ciguatera is caused by the consumption of coral reef fish contaminated by ciguatoxin and related toxins from dinoflagellates (microalgae) and cyanobacteria. Ciguatoxin bioaccumulates up the food web either directly from incidental uptake by herbivorous fish or indirectly by carnivorous fish. After the consumption of coral reef fish contaminated with ciguatoxin, people experience potentially severe acute neurologic, gastrointestinal, and cardiac symptoms as well as, in some cases, chronic neurologic symptoms lasting weeks to months. Ciguatera occurs globally, in tropical waters, and is particularly prevalent across the PICTs. Cases of ciguatera have also been reported in temperate regions of the world due to travel and coral reef fish export. Ciguatera poisoning is often under-diagnosed and under-reported, with only 2 to 10% of cases reported to health authorities. Estimates of the incidence of ciguatera in Oceania have ranged from 0.5/10,000/year in Hawaii to 5,850/10,000/year in French Polynesia. Fish is the staple protein source in many PICT communities, with many islands in the region suffering ongoing outbreaks of ciguatera when toxic fish are consumed. Dinoflagellates of the genus Gambierdiscus, which grow epiphytically on macro- and turf-algae on coral reefs, produce the ciguatoxins that cause ciguatera. Coral reef damage or when algal growth is not controlled by herbivorous fish might increase the risk of ciguatera. Despite extensive research, we know little about the ecology and the environmental factors that cause the blooms of the ciguatera causative organisms, nor do we understand the role (if any) of other dinoflagellate genera, including Ostreopsis (palytoxin producers) and Prorocentrum (okadaic acid and dinophysistoxins producers), or marine cyanobacteria. Presently, ciguatoxin can only be detected in fish and Gambierdiscus in specialized labs, and diagnosis in humans is based almost exclusively on symptoms associated with the recent consumption of a potential ciguateric fish. Several factors have been associated with ciguatera cases and the presence of ciguatoxic dinoflagellates, including military activities causing coral reef damage in the Pacific, elevated sea surface temperatures associated with global warming, nutrient enrichment, and warming sea surface temperatures, which have been shown to stimulate Gambierdiscus growth resulting in higher cell densities. Changes in global climate patterns, increased degradation of coastal marine environments through coastal development and land run-off, and increased exploitation of coastal marine resources are predicted to continue to increase the incidence of ciguatera cases in the future. Therefore, we hypothesized that ciguatera incidence is an increasing human health and ecological concern across the PICTs. To test this hypothesis, we report on changes in ciguatera incidence across the Pacific, and the social consequences of changing ciguatera incidence by comparing two 11-year periods of data: 1973–1983 vs 1998–2008.
Chagas disease is a serious public health problem caused by a parasite called Trypanosoma cruzi, which infects millions of people worldwide, and causes approximately 20,000 deaths per year. The main treatment for Chagas disease is benznidazole (BNZ), but it has side effects such as cutaneous, gastrointestinal, and neurological disorders. The effectiveness of BNZ during the chronic phase of Chagas disease is controversial, but several studies have shown that it can improve the immune system and prevent the development of heart disease. In the present study, the authors analyzed the population of a rare type of immune cell called CD4+CD8+ T cells in patients with Chagas disease. These cells are important for the control of the infection and can be affected by the exhaustion process, which occurs when the immune system is constantly exposed to the parasite and cannot function properly. The authors found that the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells was increased in patients with Chagas disease, and that they responded to the parasite's antigens, suggesting that they play an important role in the control of the infection. Furthermore, the authors analyzed the exhaustion process in these cells and found that it was more pronounced in patients with more severe stages of disease. Finally, the authors analyzed whether BNZ treatment could improve the function of these cells, and they found that it reduced the exhaustion process and improved the antigen-specific response. In conclusion, this study provides important information on the role of CD4+CD8+ T cells in the control of Chagas disease and their response to treatment.
The phosphoinositides are important signaling molecules in plants, animals, and bacteria, and are made from phosphatidylinositol through a final step of hydrolysis into IP3 and DAG by phospholipase C (PLC). There are two types of PLC in Arabidopsis: non-specific PLC (NPC) that hydrolyzes abundant phospholipids, and phosphoinositide-specific PLC (PI-PLC) that specifically hydrolyzes phosphoinositides. Nine genes are annotated as Arabidopsis PI-PLC (AtPLC) genes, which are involved in various stress-induced signaling. In this study, the researchers isolated and analyzed mutants of multiple AtPLC isoforms. Lipidomic profiling showed that AtPLC2 is a primary PI-PLC in phosphoinositide metabolism. AtPLC2 protein is highly expressed in trichomes of young rosettes, young floral buds, and vascular tissues of leaves, petals, and roots. Subcellular localization study showed that AtPLC2 is found in the plasma membranes in different cell types. The plc2-1 mutant showed seedling growth defects and enhanced susceptibility to stress affecting ER homeostasis. Thus, AtPLC2 is a major PI-PLC affecting phosphoinositide levels and ER stress tolerance.
The paper proposes a way to measure the cause-effect power of complex systems that are made up of many smaller components. Traditionally, scientists assume that the cause-effect power of a complex system is determined by the cause-effect power of its smallest components. However, the paper argues that this is not always true and that a complex system can sometimes have more cause-effect power than the sum of its parts. The paper presents a mathematical framework for measuring the cause-effect power of a complex system at different spatiotemporal scales, including the smallest scale (i.e. the individual components) and larger scales (i.e. black-boxed groups of components). The paper then applies this framework to a simple model of a neuron and shows that the cause-effect power of the neuron is greater than the cause-effect power of its individual components. This finding suggests that emergent properties of complex systems can sometimes lead to greater cause-effect power than what is possible at the level of their individual components.
Mitochondria are organelles in our cells that produce energy. As part of this process, they make something called reactive oxygen species (ROS). ROS are made when electrons move around in the mitochondria. These electrons can come from different parts of the mitochondria. Researchers have been trying to understand more about the different parts that make ROS and how they change depending on certain conditions. To do this, they use a mathematical model to describe the process of ROS production. They have already built a model that explains how one part of the mitochondria makes ROS, and now they are working on a bigger model that includes all the different parts that make ROS. They hope to understand more about how ROS are made and how they affect the mitochondria.
Intracellular transport is a crucial process that is carried out by motor proteins such as kinesin, dynein, and myosins. These motor proteins move along microtubules to transport various cargoes. In vivo, multiple motor proteins work together to transport a common cargo. However, the behavior of such an ensemble of motor proteins is not well understood. In this study, a new method was developed to study the behavior of an ensemble of motor proteins and the emergent properties that arise from their interaction with each other. The method is based on a mathematical framework called the Master Equation and is implemented using a computer simulation. The study showed that the ensemble of motor proteins exhibits several interesting properties such as an increase in run-length and a decrease in the velocity of the cargo. The study also showed that mutations in the motor proteins can have a significant effect on the behavior of the ensemble. The method developed in this study can be used to study the behavior of motor proteins in various cellular processes and can help us understand the mechanisms underlying these processes.
The ability to learn, adapt to situations, and predict outcomes is crucial to living beings, including humans and rodents. To accomplish this, animals like humans use heuristics, strategies, and ecological biases to infer the structure of their environment and make predictions. Since the environment is often partially observable and has an infinite space of possibilities, these processes can be computationally intractable. Animals like humans rely on different previously acquired or predisposed strategies to solve learning tasks, rather than on a uniform mechanism. In this study, we examined the learning strategies used by two groups of mice, Cav1 . 2NesCre and Cav1 . 2fl/fl. The Cav1 . 2NesCre mice had a genetic modification that caused severe learning deficits, while the Cav1 . 2fl/fl mice had normal gene expression. We found that Cav1 . 2NesCre mice used different behavioral strategies than Cav1 . 2fl/fl mice, but they did not have a general learning deficit.
Scientists are trying to use bacteria called Wolbachia to fight mosquito-borne viruses such as dengue and Zika. Wolbachia are already present in some mosquitoes and they can stop viruses from spreading in the insects. Wolbachia can be transferred from one type of mosquito to another and this is currently being tried in an effort to reduce the spread of dengue and Zika viruses. However, the transmission of Wolbachia can be affected by environmental factors, such as temperature. Researchers found that if mosquitoes develop at high temperatures, the bacteria's ability to spread through the population and cause cytoplasmic incompatibility is reduced. This means that the bacteria may not be effective in reducing the spread of viruses if the mosquitoes are exposed to high temperatures. The researchers suggest that different Wolbachia strains may be suitable for different environmental conditions, but further research is needed to determine the best approach.
Adenoviruses were discovered in the 1950s and they infect many different animals, including humans. Initially, they were classified into four subgroups based on their ability to agglutinate rat and rhesus erythrocytes. However, as more information became available, other attributes, such as the ability to induce tumors in rodents and the molecular masses of capsid proteins, were used to expand the subgroups to six (A to F). Some reservations have been expressed about the justification of assigning a separate subgroup to HAdV-4, the only defined human adenovirus member of subgroup E. Infections with HAdV-C are a common cause of pediatric upper respiratory tract infections, while HAdV-B causes epidemics in adults. Both HAdV-B and HAdV-E have been found to cause infections in the setting of military boot camps. The prevalence of neutralizing antibodies to HAdV-C has been found to be high in Europe, USA, and Africa, while the prevalence of antibodies to HAdV-B is comparatively lower in a European cohort. HAdV-F is frequently implicated as a cause of infectious diarrheas worldwide, but other adenovirus serotypes were also frequently co-isolated under these conditions. Less is known about the natural history of naturally occurring adenovirus infections in humans, but recombinant forms of human adenoviruses have been aggressively pursued as vectors for human gene therapy and genetic vaccines. Natural history studies of large cohorts of families in Seattle and Long Island showed that clinical sequelae of adenovirus infections and recovery of virus in immune competent humans are self-limited, although prolonged shedding was observed in a subset of individuals. An early clue to the biology of adenovirus infections in great apes was provided by Hillis in 1963 in a study which attempted to isolate the cause of transmissible hepatitis in chimpanzees. He recovered from stool of 25/87 chimpanzees an uncharacterized cytopathic virus that grew in vitro but was not related to hepatitis. He concluded that “there are a number of enterically excreted viruses in the chimpanzee, some or all of which may be part of the animal's ‘normal flora’ ”.
Scientists have studied the structure and behavior of a small unit of DNA called a nucleosome. They found that the DNA is wrapped around a core of eight histone proteins, forming a tight coil. However, this coil needs to be loosened for DNA to be accessed and manipulated. The scientists used a combination of experimental and computational methods to study the loosening of the coil and found that it occurs in a specific way. The outermost part of the DNA coil is loosened and then re-tightened, with this process happening about 5 times faster than the inner part of the coil. The outermost part of the coil is also easier to loosen than the inner part. The scientists used molecular dynamics simulations to gain insight into the behavior of the histone proteins and DNA. They found that the proteins interact with the DNA in a periodic way, with each interaction occurring about 5 base pairs apart. The scientists also found that the histone tails (the flexible parts of the protein) have different effects on the stability of the outer and inner parts of the coil. The outer part of the coil is more stable due to the contribution of the histone tails, while the inner part is more stable due to the contribution of histones themselves. Overall, the scientists gained valuable insights into the behavior and structure of nucleosomal DNA and how it can be manipulated.
Lysosomes are acidic organelles that play an important role in cellular processes like recycling damaged cellular material and digesting harmful substances that enter the cell. These organelles are essential for the functioning of neurons, and their dysfunction can lead to neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and Huntington's disease, as well as normal aging. The protein ApoD is consistently over-expressed in the brain in aging and neurodegenerative diseases. ApoD is involved in protecting neurons from oxidative stress and promoting their survival. In this study, the researchers found that ApoD is endocytosed into lysosomes under stress conditions, and it helps maintain the acidic pH of these organelles and their integrity. This helps prevent damage to neurons and supports their survival. The study also provides evidence that ApoD is involved in two important processes that depend on lysosomes, myelin phagocytosis and autophagy.
Visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar, is a deadly disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani and mainly occurs in the Indian subcontinent and Africa. In Africa, VL is endemic in the eastern part of the continent, including the Horn of Africa and adjacent countries such as Sudan, South Sudan, Kenya, Somalia, Uganda, Eritrea, and Ethiopia. In Ethiopia, the main endemic areas are located in the lowlands of the southwestern Ethiopia (e.g., Omo river plains and Segen/Woito valleys) and Metema-Humera plains in the northwest. Three sand fly species, Phlebotomus orientalis, P. celiae, and P. martini have been implicated as vectors, but P. (Larroussius) orientalis seems to be the only vector in most of Ethiopia. Despite several attempts to colonize and maintain P. orientalis, it remains difficult to do so in laboratory colonies. In this study, we focused on P. orientalis from two geographically distant Ethiopian localities, Addis Zemen and Melka Werer. We compared these two populations using Random Amplification of Polymorphic DNA (RAPD) and sequencing analysis, as well as cross-mating studies. Our study allowed us to optimize the conditions for laboratory maintenance of both colonies and to conduct experimental infections with Leishmania donovani to compare the susceptibility of both colonies.
Schistosomiasis is a disease caused by parasites that infect the blood vessels in the body. It is a serious health problem in many countries, especially in Africa and Asia. Advanced schistosomiasis is a more severe form of the disease that can lead to liver and spleen damage, bleeding in the stomach, and other serious complications. In China, advanced schistosomiasis is more common in rural areas where people are exposed to the parasites in the water. The disease can lead to loss of productivity and quality of life, and it can also be fatal. There is still a need for better treatments and prevention measures to reduce the burden of this disease.
Trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness, is a parasitic vector-borne disease that is prevalent in sub-Saharan Africa. The disease is transmitted by the bite of tsetse flies, which are insects native to Africa. There are two types of trypanosomiasis: HAT, or human African trypanosomiasis, which affects humans and is caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma brucei (T. b.), and AAT, or African animal trypanosomiasis, which affects animals such as cattle and is also caused by T. b. The tsetse fly belongs to the genus Glossina and there are three groups of tsetse flies: G. morsitans, G. palpalis and G. fusca. Tsetse flies are k-strategists, which means they thrive in specific environments defined by factors such as climate, vegetation, and fauna. The World Health Organization and public-private partnerships began programs in 2000 to enhance HAT surveillance in sub-Saharan Africa, and by 2004, the number of new cases had dropped to 17,500, with a cumulative incidence of 50,000 to 70,000 cases. However, much of rural sub-Saharan Africa lacks HAT-diagnostic capacity and passive surveillance programs, which means that the true population prevalence outside of active case-finding areas is not known. In 2007, Médecins sans Frontières found that the population prevalence rate in a rural area of the Democratic Republic of the Congo was 3.4%, with 60% of cases in the first stage of disease, suggesting intense transmission. Other countries, such as Kenya, have tsetse habitats for T. b. rhodesiense and also border countries that are in need of enhanced HAT surveillance programs. AAT also affects rural sub-Saharan Africa, and the effects of AAT most heavily impact sub-Saharan Africa's poor as 85% of these individuals live in rural areas, with over 80% relying on agriculture for their livelihoods. In Kenya, there are 7 tsetse belts, or zones, where tsetse vectors for T. b. rhodesiense and other trypanosoma agents that cause AAT are present. In 1999, the proportion of the population living in poverty within these 7 tsetse belt zones is provided. In this study, the authors will use individual level reports of disability collected during the Kenya National Census in 1999 and incorporated into the Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (IPUMS) census microdata for social and economic research to estimate the likelihood of disability in individuals, nested within households, nested within tsetse fly habitats of varying levels of poverty. They will estimate the effect of living in tsetse-endemic environments on the likelihood of disability, controlling for individual and household level differences and area-level poverty. They will also estimate the modifying effect of living in poverty and tsetse fly habitats on the likelihood of disability, controlling for individual and household level differences. It is hypothesized that (a) the prevalence of disability will be higher in tsetse belts than outside tsetse belts, regardless of poverty levels; (b) the prevalence of disability will be higher among residents than migrants because of increased duration of direct-tsetse and indirect-tsetse/poverty exposure; and (c) the prevalence of disability for residents and migrants will vary by gender and housing characteristics.
Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) has effectively controlled the viral loads in HIV-infected patients, but it has not eliminated the virus. HIV persists in the body as a result of a special type of cell called latently infected cells, which carry a copy of the virus in their DNA. The virus inside these cells is not active and is resistant to the effects of HAART. To eliminate HIV from the body, scientists are trying to find ways to activate the virus in these cells so that it can be killed by the immune system. Prostratin, IL-7, and valproic acid are some of the treatments that have been tried, but they have not been very successful. Hexamethylene bisacetamide (HMBA) is another treatment that has been tested in a lab. It activates HIV transcription, which makes the virus active and sensitive to HAART. However, scientists are still trying to understand how HMBA works and how it activates HIV transcription.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by a parasite called Leishmania that affects humans and animals. It can result in a variety of symptoms, including mucosal leishmaniasis, which can cause severe inflammation, and disseminated cutaneous leishmaniasis, which can cause skin lesions to spread to other parts of the body. Researchers have found that a parasite virus called Leishmania RNA virus (LRV) is present in some strains of Leishmania and can worsen disease symptoms. Scientists have developed methods for detecting and quantifying LRV in parasites, which could help predict the risk of leishmaniasis dissemination.
This study aimed to understand the role of actin pedestals in the pathogenesis of EHEC and EPEC. These pathogens have different mechanisms for reorganizing actin, but they can both form pedestals that help them to colonize the intestine and resist phagocytosis. The study showed that EPEC and EHEC pedestals have similar functions, but EHEC pedestals are better at enabling bacteria to move and colonize cells. This is due to faster EspFU-driven motility and a new mechanism of cell-to-cell transfer. Overall, this study provides important insights into the role of pedestals in the pathogenesis of EHEC and EPEC.
Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are tiny particles released by cells that contain proteins, DNA, and RNA. These particles play an important role in cell-to-cell communication, but they can also be used to diagnose diseases and study the development of cancer. However, there is no standard method for isolating EVs from cells or body fluids. In this study, researchers compared two different methods for isolating EVs: differential centrifugation (DC) and size exclusion chromatography (SEC). Both methods have their pros and cons, but the SEC method was found to produce more pure and homogeneous EVs, which could be useful for research on EVs in cancer and other diseases.
This paper presents a reverse-engineering approach to study the role of post-transcriptional regulation in pattern formation during early embryonic development of Drosophila melanogaster. The authors use mathematical models, structural and practical parameter identifiability analysis, and experimental data to study the dynamics of three trunk gap genes: Krüppel (Kr), knirps (kni), and giant (gt). They find that post-transcriptional regulation is not required for the correct timing and positioning of gap protein domain boundaries. However, their models suggest that post-transcriptional regulation is needed for accurate control of gap protein levels, implying some temporal regulation of translational efficiency and/or protein stability. The authors' approach provides a rigorous and quantitative way to test the hypothesis that post-transcriptional regulation is not needed for pattern formation.
Rotavirus is a common cause of gastroenteritis in children and can even lead to death in babies in countries where medical care is limited. It mainly affects babies under 6 years old, but adults do not get sick from it. In mice, babies are also more likely to get sick from rotavirus than adults. This is because the virus causes a lot of damage to the lining of the small intestine in baby mice. As mice get older, their resistance to rotavirus infection increases and they become less likely to get sick. This resistance is not due to an immune response, but rather to changes in the lining of the small intestine. In humans, babies are also more likely to get sick from rotavirus than adults, and there are similar changes in the lining of the small intestine. Scientists have found that the reason why baby mice are more likely to get sick from rotavirus is that their intestinal cells express more of a type of protein called TLR3. This protein helps to recognize viral particles and trigger an immune response. The scientists also found that this TLR3 protein is expressed less in adults. They also found that the TLR3 protein is expressed less in babies than in adults in humans. This protein is important for protecting against rotavirus, and the increased expression of TLR3 in the intestinal cells of baby mice and humans may be a factor contributing to their susceptibility to rotavirus infection.
The genetic architecture of Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) includes both common and rare variants. While analysis of rare variants has identified certain genes as playing a role in liability for ASD, it has not produced many findings. A new ambitious study, called the ARRA autism sequencing consortium (AASC), aims to identify novel ASD genes by sequencing nearly 2000 case and control subjects. Because of the potential downstream implications regarding treatment, this study is very important. However, most published candidate gene studies have not reported a p-value small enough to attain exome-wide significance. For rare variants, association tests need to examine the cumulative effects of observed rare variants in the target set. Several statistical methods are now available to test for association with rare variants. However, meta-analysis is the most effective way to test for association using these data, as it combines p-values from different data sets using a weighted Z-score method. This report shows that mega-analysis is the more powerful procedure for gene-based tests such as SKAT. After quality control and controlling for ancestry, the AASC data reveals no clear-cut associations.
Mycetoma is a disease caused by a fungus called Madurella mycetomatis. This disease affects the lower limbs and causes multiple nodules and sinuses to develop, which discharge pus. The fungal grain found in these nodules contains a hard brown matrix that protects the fungus from the body's immune system. It is not known what is inside the grain, but it is thought to contain chitin. Chitinases are part of the immune system and are produced by cells when the body is exposed to chitin. Chitinases break down chitin, which is found in the fungal cell wall. In this study, the researchers are investigating whether having a certain polymorphism (a change in the DNA sequence) in two genes called chitotriosidase and acidic mammalian chitinase (AMCase) is associated with mycetoma. They think that people with these polymorphisms may have decreased chitinase activity, which could increase their susceptibility to infections, including mycetoma. The researchers are testing their hypothesis by comparing the frequency of these polymorphisms in mycetoma patients and healthy controls.
Herpesviruses have a special way of surviving in their hosts by using a strategy called latency and reactivation. Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is the best known herpesvirus and is used as an example of viral latency. During a productive infection, HSV-1 rapidly spreads to the sensory neurons, where it initiates a lytic phase of infection that involves the expression of roughly 80 viral functions in a specific order. However, this phase of infection is eventually stopped by the development of an adaptive immune response. The resulting state of viral DNA persistence in the absence of infectious virus is considered latency. In mouse models of HSV-1, latency is particularly profound and reactivation is difficult to induce. It was previously thought that viral transcription during latency was restricted to a family of RNA transcripts called LATs, but recent studies have shown that lytic gene transcription also occurs during latency. The retention of activated, virus-specific CD8+ T cells within the sensory ganglia of latently infected individuals provides evidence for the translation of lytic proteins. However, direct evidence for the translation of lytic proteins during latency has been difficult to find. To test whether certain promoters drive protein production during HSV latency, we constructed a set of HSV-1 viruses that express Cre under promoters that drive well-characterized CD8+ T cell targets or proteins with an immune evasion function. We found that unlike promoters tested previously, those driving gB and ICP6 can produce protein during HSV latency.
This study compares the spread and accumulation of misfolded prion protein in the brain of mice infected with three different strains of mouse-adapted scrapie. The study uses a technique called microinjection to inject the prion protein into the striatum of the mice. The researchers then follow the spread of the prion protein through the brain using a technique called dual staining, where the prion protein is stained along with a marker for a specific type of brain cell. The researchers found that the strains of prion protein had different patterns of association with astroglia and neurons. To understand the relationship between the spread of the prion protein and the brain's response to the infection, the researchers also analyzed the expression of genes associated with neuroinflammation in the thalamus of the mice. The researchers found that despite the different patterns of association of the prion protein with different types of brain cells, the three strains had similar patterns of gene expression associated with neuroinflammation. The researchers also compared the patterns of gene expression associated with neuroinflammation to the patterns seen in mice infected with two viruses that caused similar levels of gliosis. The researchers found that the patterns of gene expression associated with neuroinflammation were different in the two groups.
The genetic information found in all cells of a multicellular organism is different among different tissues and cell types due to variation in gene expression. Recent studies have revealed that the physical organization of chromosomes inside the cell nucleus plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression. Chromosomes are organized hierarchically during interphase, the longest phase of the cell cycle where genes are expressed and DNA is replicated. This organization involves chromosomes occupying their own territory, with genes sharing the same transcriptional state colocalizing in the center, while inactive regions are at the periphery. Chromosomes are partitioned into consecutive 3D interaction compartments, called topologically-associated domains (TADs), which share the same epigenomic state and have enriched contact probabilities with other loci within the domain. The behavior of long polymer chains, such as chromosomes, during an extended time period is crucial for understanding chromosome folding. However, very few approaches account adequately for the topological constraints generated by polymer entanglement. We developed a generic coarse-graining strategy that allows to drastically reduce the computation time while maintaining the polymer in the same topological regime. This strategy involves a step-by-step process of data analysis and coarse-graining that systematically reduces the number of variables while preserving the essential features of the model. We applied this strategy to investigate the role of epigenomic-driven interactions in the folding and dynamics of the drosophila genome.
This study investigates the factors that influence the specificity of eQTLs, or SNPs associated with gene expression, in different cell types. The authors analyzed data from 11 studies involving seven different cell types to identify cis-linked SNPs associated with each gene expression trait in each study. They also analyzed the overlap between eQTL SNPs and cell type-specific regulatory DNA elements to identify potential functional determinants of cell type specificity. Additionally, the authors built predictive models that can be used to predict the cell type specificity of eQTLs in the absence of additional gene expression data and to predict the function of GWAS SNPs with phenotypes relevant to cell types lacking eQTL data. The study aimed to improve the utility of eQTLs for complex trait interpretation and facilitate more substantial mechanistic analyses of individual SNPs by enabling the integration of disease genetics and regulatory SNPs with the thousands of genomic data sets that have been produced.
Scientists have been working on a vaccine to protect against the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) for over 30 years, but a vaccine that is effective against HIV infection has not yet been created. One of the challenges is figuring out the best way to design the vaccine and how to produce it in a way that will work well for large-scale manufacturing. A recent study found that a type of monoclonal antibody that protects against HIV infection requires certain types of glycans on the virus particles to bind to them. This is a problem for vaccines that use the protein gp120 from the virus, because gp120 does not have these glycans. To solve this problem, scientists have been working on a way to create a new type of cell that will produce gp120 with the right type of glycans. They have done this by using a new type of gene editing technique called CRISPR/Cas9 to create a new type of Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell that cannot produce the glycans that gp120 needs to bind to these monoclonal antibodies. This new type of CHO cell should be useful for creating a vaccine that will protect against HIV infection and other diseases where certain types of glycans are important for the vaccine to be effective.
Scientists have found that parasites called nematodes cause diseases in the tropics, like lymphatic filariasis. The diseases cause long-term disability and distress to people. These diseases are transmitted by mosquitoes. There is currently no cure for them and the drugs used to treat them have side effects. Researchers have found a new target for a drug that would cure this disease. They have found that a protein called T6PP is necessary for the survival of the nematodes. They have found that a drug that inhibits this protein could be a potential cure for the disease. To find out more about the protein, the researchers have studied its structure using a technique called X-ray crystallography. They have found that the protein has a cap domain that helps it to work. They have also found that the drug inhibiting the protein can only reach the active site of the protein when the cap domain moves out of the way. This study could lead to the development of a drug to cure the disease.
A new tool called REANIMATE is introduced that combines high-resolution imaging data from large, intact, optically-cleared tissue samples with mathematical modelling and in vivo imaging to make predictions regarding fluid and mass transport in tumors. This tool can be used to test new hypotheses and designs in a more efficient and effective manner than traditional experimental methods. In this study, the authors present a computational model that efficiently simulates both intra- and extravascular fluid transport across large, discrete microvascular networks. The model is based on the optimisation scheme of Fry et al. and is parametrised and validated against in vivo ASL-MRI data. The authors also provide a comprehensive description of the model's application to whole tumor vascular networks and apply the model to two different tumor types. Sensitivity analysis is performed on the model parameters associated with transvascular fluid delivery, such as vascular hydraulic conductance and interstitial hydraulic conductivity, to explore the impact on tumor IFP and IFV profiles. Finally, the authors use the computational framework to explore the biomechanics underlying vascular normalization, a method that aims to restore tumor vascular structure and function to physiological levels. The authors believe that this study will contribute to a better understanding of the fluid dynamics in tumors and provide insights into new ways to improve the delivery of anti-cancer drugs.
The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that spreads efficiently between cells. There are two ways HIV spreads: through cell-free viruses and by cell-cell contact. HIV infection can also occur through cell-cell contact, which is more efficient and faster than cell-free infection. The virus can also be transmitted through nanotubes and filopodia. It is unclear whether cell-free or cell-cell infection is more important for the spread of HIV in humans. This gap in knowledge poses a problem for the development of vaccines and entry inhibitors, as it is unclear whether both modes of infection need to be targeted. Neutralizing antibodies are antibodies that recognize and block the entry of the virus into cells. However, it is not clear how well neutralizing antibodies can stop cell-cell transmission of HIV. Previous studies have shown conflicting results, but these differences may be due to variations in experimental setups and cell types used. Our study aimed to clarify the capacity of neutralizing antibodies to block cell-cell transmission of HIV. We used a variety of in vitro assays to study the transmission of HIV between cells, including single virus tracking, keeping cultures in motion, and careful time course analysis. Our study provides a necessary first step towards determining the in vivo relevance of the different modes of HIV transmission and the requirements for their inhibition by vaccine-induced antibody responses and entry inhibitors.
The study by Castelo-Branco and colleagues examined how attention affects the responses of neurons in the visual cortex. They found that attention can produce both contrast-gain and response-gain effects, as well as biased competition between neurons. Additionally, they found that attention can alter the size and shape of receptive fields, both in topological and fine feature space. The authors proposed a simple mechanistic model that explains how a top-down modulatory signal from higher areas of the visual hierarchy can produce all these effects. The model suggests that feedback connections between areas, interacting with short-range divisive mutual inhibition within each area, are sufficient to account for the observed effects of attention. The authors also made a novel prediction: attentional effects on response curves should turn from response gain to contrast gain as the focus of attention shifts away from the center of the studied cell's receptive field.
The Drosophila lymph gland is an organ that produces blood cells. It has three zones, one for multipotent prohemocytes (progenitor cells), one for differentiating hemocytes (cells that phagocytes or crystalize), and one for a signaling center. The signaling center controls the balance between prohemocytes and differentiating hemocytes. It also helps prohemocytes keep their ability to turn into lamellocytes, which are cells that encapsulate foreign bodies too large to be phagocytosed. This signaling center is controlled by a type of receptor protein called Dome, which signals when a cytokine called Upd is present. Another type of receptor called Latran acts as an antagonist of Dome, turning off the JAK/STAT signaling pathway in prohemocytes following parasitization. This allows lamellocytes to differentiate and encapsulate the parasite.
The study aims to investigate the impact of recombination on genome-wide interaction networks in begomoviruses. The authors use a genome-wide association approach and controlled evolution experiments to analyze the patterns of recombination in begomoviruses. They use permutation tests to determine how recombination can disrupt intra-genome interactions, identify host adaptive nucleotide polymorphisms, and indirectly visualize long-range intra-genome interaction networks. The study provides valuable insights into the mechanisms of recombination and its impact on genome-wide interaction networks in begomoviruses, which may have important implications for understanding the emergence of new pathogens.
Nucleosomes are small structures that wrap DNA around histone proteins, and they are important for controlling how our genes are expressed. In DNA, nucleosomes are not randomly placed, but they tend to form on certain parts of the DNA that are easier to wrap around the histones. Changes in the DNA sequence can affect where nucleosomes form, and this can change how genes are expressed. Previous studies have shown that nucleosome positioning can affect how mutations occur and how they are repaired. A recent experiment in yeast showed that mutations were less common in parts of the DNA that were wrapped around nucleosomes, suggesting that nucleosomes may protect DNA from damage. However, these studies only looked at the effects of nucleosomes on mutations in one species of yeast, and it is not clear if this is true for all yeasts or for other species like humans and worms. To address this, we compared how mutations occurred around nucleosomes in humans to mutations in a group of halophilic archaea called Haloferax. Like their orthologs in eukaryotes, Haloferax nucleosomes wrap around DNA in order to control how genes are expressed, but they also differ in many ways from eukaryotic nucleosomes, such as being smaller and not having long tails like eukaryotic histones. Despite these differences, we found that the way mutations occurred around nucleosomes in Haloferax was very similar to the way mutations occurred in humans, suggesting that the effect of nucleosomes on mutations is the same in these two very different organisms. We also found that these trends did not hold true for the Haloferax sister lineage, suggesting that nucleosomes may move around in response to mutations. This means that we need to be careful when trying to understand how mutations affect the relationship between genes and their expression. It also means that we need to consider the role of nucleosomes in understanding the effects of mutations on epigenetic changes.
Researchers have found that the function of proteins is related to their conformational dynamics, which means how they move and change their shape. They used computational tools to identify specific regions of proteins that are important for their dynamics and, therefore, for their function. These regions are called normal mode subspaces. Researchers studied the effects of mutations on these subspaces to understand how changes in the sequence of a protein can affect its dynamics and function. They found that some regions of proteins are more important for their dynamics and, therefore, for their function than others. These regions are associated with low-frequency normal mode subspaces, which are the most collective and functionally relevant modes. The researchers were able to identify the specific positions in these regions that are important for ligand binding and the dynamics of the protein. These positions are called key positions and can be used to design new proteins with desired functions.
Mtb is a bacteria that causes tuberculosis in humans. It has the ability to adapt to different environments in the body, and it uses fatty acids and lipids as a source of energy. However, Mtb also has the ability to use other sources of energy such as glucose and glycolytic compounds. A protein called FBA is important for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, which are the main processes for breaking down and producing glucose. Mtb needs FBA to grow and survive. A study was done to understand the importance of FBA in acute and chronic infections of mice. The study found that FBA was essential for growth in certain conditions, but it could be replaced by other sources of energy in other conditions. The study also found that FBA was important for growth during acute and persistent infections in mice.
This article describes a group of organisms called trypanosomatids, which cause various diseases such as Leishmaniasis and Chagas disease. These organisms lack efficient enzymes that can get rid of harmful chemicals called peroxides, so they rely on enzymes called peroxiredoxins (PRXs) to do this job. PRXs have a special cysteine that can react with peroxides to neutralize them. In trypanosomatids, these cysteines are also involved in protecting the organisms from being killed by the host's immune system. The article shows that one particular type of PRX called mTXNPx is especially important for the parasite's survival inside the host. It also shows that mTXNPx has another important role as a "chaperone", which means it helps to keep other proteins in their proper shape. Overall, this article highlights the importance of mTXNPx in the survival and pathogenicity of trypanosomatids.
Histoplasmosis is a fungal disease that is common in Latin America and in Mexico. It can be a serious illness if not diagnosed and treated quickly. The current method of diagnosing this illness is to grow fungus in a lab, but this takes a long time and requires special safety equipment. Because of these issues, some people think that histoplasmosis is not reported as often as it really is, and it is thought of as a neglected disease. In the United States, there is a quick and easy test that can diagnose the illness. However, the accuracy of this test has not been compared to the gold standard of growing fungus in a lab. Because of these reasons, we decided to study the accuracy of the quick test for diagnosing histoplasmosis in Mexico.
The article is describing a study that used a new method called metagenomic analysis to explore the viral communities in the stool of children with diarrhea. Metagenomic analysis uses mass sequencing to identify the viruses in a sample. In this study, the researchers collected stool samples from 12 children with diarrhea and analyzed them using a simplified method called "micro-mass sequencing." They found evidence of known and novel viruses, as well as viral co-infections. The researchers think that this new method will help them to better understand the causes of diarrhea and to develop new treatments.
The Dominican Republic had a big dengue fever outbreak in 2015 and 2016. Then, in late 2016, the first cases of Zika virus disease were detected. By the end of 2016, 5,235 people had been infected with Zika, 22 babies had been born with microcephaly, and 600 people had developed Guillain-Barre syndrome, a type of paralysis. A retrospective disease surveillance dataset was used to study the spread of Zika and dengue in the Dominican Republic, as well as the associated cases of Guillain-Barre syndrome. Additionally, the study compared the age and sex-adjusted distributions of both Zika and dengue outbreaks and calculated the reproductive number of each outbreak. This information may help to better understand the outbreaks and develop more effective control strategies.
The paper describes the roles of poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation, a process in which ADP-ribose units are transferred from NAD+ molecules onto target proteins, in plants under stress. PARPs are enzymes that mediate poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation and have been implicated in DNA repair and programmed cell death. PARGs are enzymes that reverse poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation by cleaving covalently attached poly(ADP-ribose). The paper found that Arabidopsis has two PARPs, PARP1 and PARP2, that have different functions in plants under stress. PARP2 is preferentially induced by dehydration and cadmium, whereas PARP1 is robustly induced by ionizing radiation. The paper also found that Arabidopsis has two PARGs, PARG1 and PARG2, that also have different functions in plants under stress. PARG1 was found to play a role in pathogen defense, whereas PARG2 was found to play a role in circadian oscillation. The paper presents evidence that PARG1 rather than PARG2 is the primary enzyme that counteracts poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation in Arabidopsis. The paper also found that PARP1 and PARP2 interact with both PARG1 and PARG2, and that PARP2 rather than PARP1 plays the major role in plant DNA damage and immune responses.
The article describes a study that looks at how glutamatergic synapses are formed in a type of neuron called mechanosensory neurons. The authors found that a protein called RPM-1 helps to regulate this process. They also identified several other proteins that work with RPM-1 to help form these synapses. The authors explain that these proteins are part of a signaling pathway that involves a specific type of MAPK called JNK. They also explain how the RPM-1 protein affects this signaling pathway by inhibiting an upstream kinase. The authors suggest that this signaling pathway may be involved in short-term learning, as they found that the RPM-1 protein affects the ability of these neurons to learn. Overall, the article provides important information about how synapses are formed in the nervous system and how this process may be affected by certain proteins.
Animals, including nematodes like worms, have genetic information to produce either males or females and must choose which sex to become. In the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, this choice is made by a signal transduction pathway that controls the activity of a master transcription factor TRA-1. The pathway decides which genes will be expressed to become a male or a hermaphrodite. TRA-1 is controlled by a protein called TRR-1 that works with TRA-1 to promote the expression of genes needed for hermaphrodites, like the gene fog-3. TRR-1 also interacts with other proteins that regulate TRA-1 by controlling the levels of a cleaved TRA-1 repressor. These two functions have been conserved throughout the genus Caenorhabditis, but their importance has changed dramatically during recent evolution. This explains the differences between the functions of some genes in Caenorhabditis elegans and Caenorhabditis briggsae.
The article presents a new way of measuring the complexity of systems with many interconnected elements. The complexity of these systems can be understood as the balance between differentiation (where parts of the system are different from each other) and integration (where the system as a whole behaves coherently). The article introduces a new measure of integrated information that captures this balance. This measure is called "integrated information" and can be used to understand how systems generate information. The article provides a new way of calculating integrated information that can be applied to real-world data, and it shows that this measure is equivalent to another measure called "auto-regressive integrated information". These measures provide a new way of understanding the relationship between information generation and complex systems.
Scientists are trying to understand why a disease called Rhodesian human African trypanosomiasis (HAT), caused by the Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense parasite, is spreading in Uganda. Previously, it was thought that two forms of HAT only occurred in different parts of the country, but now there are concerns that the two forms are spreading closer to each other. Scientists think that the spread of Rhodesian HAT is due to the movement of untreated, infected livestock from other areas. To understand this spread better, scientists are using a new way to analyze data that takes into account the spatial relationship between the disease cases and environmental and climatic variables. They found that environmental and climatic variables did play a role in the spread of Rhodesian HAT, but that more work needs to be done to fully understand why the disease is spreading.
Ecologists have long tried to understand how many species can coexist in an ecosystem without causing instability. A new study shows that the number of species required to maintain stability varies depending on the type of interactions between them. The study also shows that weak interactions are more likely to lead to stable ecosystems. Furthermore, the study suggests that the structure of ecological systems, such as their food web, plays a minor role in determining stability. The study used computer simulations to analyze the stability of different types of ecosystems and found that weak interactions increase stability in mutualistic and competitive ecosystems. However, weak interactions decrease stability in predator-prey ecosystems. The study suggests that the optimal level of interaction strength for maintaining stability varies depending on the type of ecosystem.
Q Fever, caused by the bacteria Coxiella burnetii, affects both humans and animals. Humans can be infected through the respiratory route or by consuming contaminated dairy products. Cattle can be infected through inhaling contaminated air or coming into contact with infected ticks. Q Fever causes a variety of health issues in humans, including acute Q Fever, chronic Q Fever, and post-infection fatigue syndrome. In addition to its health effects, Q Fever can also have economic impacts on livestock farmers due to decreased productivity and increased veterinary costs. In Africa, Q Fever is prevalent in both humans and animals, with seroprevalence rates ranging from 7% to 33% in humans and from 4% to 55% in cattle. However, there are large variations in seroprevalence within small distances. Risk factors for human exposure to Q Fever include male gender, illiteracy, younger age group, and camel breeding. Risk factors for cattle include older age, female gender, presence of buffalo near grazing areas, and ethnicity of livestock owner.
Schistosomiasis is a serious health problem around the world, affecting about 200 million people and putting 700 million more at risk. Researchers have identified the genes involved in this parasite's development and reproduction, which may help develop new treatments. A technique called transgenesis can be used to introduce new genes into parasites, and researchers are looking for ways to use this technique to target the reproductive cells in schistosomes. A protein called Vasa is commonly used as a marker for germ cells (reproductive cells) in many organisms, and researchers have found Vasa-like genes in schistosomes. They used a technique called in situ hybridization to determine where these genes are expressed in the parasite. They found that the genes are expressed in the ovary and developing eggs. This suggests that using a Vasa-like gene as a marker to identify transgenic eggs could help researchers monitor the integration of new genes into the germ cells of schistosomes.
Heart valves are critical for pumping blood in the right direction during the heartbeat. Valve disease can lead to problems like calcification or stenosis and eventually result in heart failure. VGLL4 is a protein that helps control the growth and development of heart valves. In this study, the authors identified the role of VGLL4 in heart valve development and maintenance. They discovered that VGLL4 is expressed in the valve region and that only endothelial deletion of VGLL4 led to valve malformation. The authors also found that VGLL4 works by antagonizing YAP activity.
The study looks at the idea of "soft sweeps" in genetics. This is a model of how beneficial mutations can become fixed in a population over time. The authors argue that the evidence for soft sweeps in the genomes of organisms such as humans and Drosophila melanogaster is limited and unclear, as these organisms do not show signs of frequent occurrence of multiple high-frequency haplotypes. They propose that this idea of soft sweeps is not a good explanation for the patterns of genetic variation seen in these organisms.
Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are known to be the primary carriers of dengue fever, causing 50-100 million infections among humans per year. These mosquitoes are attracted to human blood to lay eggs and can feed on multiple hosts. They go through a natural period of host-seeking inhibition for three days after a blood meal, during which they develop eggs and switch their attraction from humans to egg-laying sites. This natural period of inhibition can be regulated by two mechanisms: (1) abdominal distension that is communicated through the nerve cord and (2) a humoral substance called Head Peptide-I discovered in the mosquito's hemolymph. Researchers have recently identified a candidate receptor for Head Peptide-I, NPYLR1, but removing this receptor's activity did not affect feeding or host-seeking behavior in mutant mosquitoes. Therefore, researchers suspect that other signaling mechanisms must exist to regulate host-seeking behavior after removing the activity of NPYLR1.
Schistosomiasis is a disease caused by flat worms and is spread by freshwater snails. It is a major public health problem in Nigeria, with over 240 million people needing treatment globally. The highest prevalence of infection is among children aged 5 to 10 years, and males are more likely to be infected than females. The majority of cases are caused by a species of flat worm called Schistosoma haematobium, which can cause bladder cancer. To control schistosomiasis, Nigeria has identified 150 high-risk areas, and GIS/RS is being used to develop a predictive model for the disease. This will help to identify areas where transmission is likely to occur, and to develop strategies for prevention and control.
In this study, the authors investigated the effects of pneumococcal meningitis on the neocortex of the brain and the role of the major pneumococcal toxin, PLY, in causing these effects. They used a mutant form of PLY that is unable to form pores, called the delta6 mutant, to study the effects of pore formation by PLY. They found that PLY is critical for the clinical course of experimental pneumococcal meningitis. They also found that PLY persists in the cerebrospinal fluid, which correlates with a poorer prognosis in human patients. Additionally, the authors studied the neocortex, a highly specialized brain structure, and found that it is affected by pneumococcal meningitis. They found that the major component of the neocortex is pyramidal neurons, whose somata are predominantly in layers III, V, and VI, and send projections throughout the cortex and receive projections from other neurons from other brain areas. They also found that astrocytes wrap around the synaptic cleft and parts of the pre- and/or post-synapse, allowing them to rapidly remove released neurotransmitters. The authors conclude that the findings suggest that PLY-dependent changes in neocortical synapses could be responsible for the cognitive impairment seen in patients with pneumococcal meningitis.
Papillomaviruses (HPV) are a family of small, non-enveloped viruses that infect the skin and mucous membranes of humans and animals. There are over 100 different genotypes of HPV, some of which cause cancer. These viruses have a complex life cycle that is tightly linked to the differentiation of the host epithelial cells. HPV infects only dividing basal cells of the epithelium and establishes itself as a nuclear plasmid. As the host cells differentiate, the virus is maintained at a low copy number in the basal cells, and then it amplifies and encapsidates itself in terminally differentiated cells to produce progeny virions. The authors recently developed a method to produce infectious HPV virions in high yields, which allows them to study the early steps of the HPV infection process. They used this method to screen over 5,000 compounds to identify cell cycle inhibitors that block HPV infection. The authors found that progression through early stages of mitosis is critical for successful HPV infection. These findings provide new insights into how HPV infects cells and identify new potential targets for preventing and treating HPV infection.
Researchers have identified 24 potential microRNA (miRNA) candidates in a fungus called Penicillium marneffei that causes respiratory, skin, and systemic mycosis. miRNAs are small non-coding molecules that regulate gene expression in animals and plants. The researchers found that these miRNAs were more abundantly expressed in the mycelial phase of the fungus than in the yeast phase. They also identified two genes, dcl-1 and dcl-2, that are important for miRNA biogenesis, and a third gene, qde-2, that encodes an Argonaute-like protein. Using Northern blot analysis, the researchers confirmed the differential expression of two miRNAs, PM-milR-M1 and PM-milR-M2, in the mycelial phase, which was dependent on the dcl-2 gene but not the dcl-1 or qde-2 genes. These findings provide evidence for the existence of miRNAs in thermal dimorphic fungi and differential expression of miRNAs during different growth phases, which may provide new insights into the mechanism governing thermal dimorphism.
Zika fever is a new disease that can make people very sick. It is caused by a virus, called Zika virus, that is spread by a type of mosquito called Aedes. This virus can cause microcephaly, a condition where the baby's head is smaller than it should be, and other problems during pregnancy. The virus has spread to many parts of the world, including the Pacific and Central America. In the Pacific, there are several different types of mosquitoes that could spread the virus. We want to know if these mosquitoes are able to get infected with the virus and spread it to other people. To do this, we collected mosquitoes from different places in the Pacific and tested them in the lab to see if they can get infected and spread the virus. We also compared the results for two different types of mosquitoes that are found in the Pacific, called Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis.
Scientists have been studying a specific type of non-coding RNA called Xist for a long time. It is known to play a crucial role in turning off one of the two X chromosomes in females. However, little is known about its structure or how it works to achieve this function. The Xist RNA has a repeating region called the "A-repeat" that is important for its ability to turn off genes. Scientists have been able to probe this region in vitro (outside of the cell) and create a model of its structure. However, there is no way to do this probing in the cell itself, which is where it is most active. A new approach called Targeted Structure-Seq has been developed that combines in-cell DMS probing with a sequencing platform to probe the full-length Xist RNA in mouse cells. This has provided the first in-cell model of the Xist repeat A conformation and identified new structured elements in Xist, including a new evolutionary conserved structural element near the C repeats that is important for Xist function.
This study proposes a new statistical framework that can be used to evaluate the performance of genetic risk prediction models. These models use genomic profiles of susceptibility variants to predict the risk of developing certain diseases. The framework is based on the liability threshold model, which assumes that people who develop a disease have a liability that is above a certain threshold. The framework shows that it is possible to estimate the performance of these models and create visual graphs that show how well they work. The authors hope that this framework will help evaluate the usefulness of genetic risk prediction models in the clinic.
Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) is a disease that affects 70 million people in sub-Saharan African countries and can be fatal if left untreated. It is caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambiense (g-HAT). This disease has two stages: an early stage where the parasites are present in the blood and lymphatic system, and a late stage where the parasites invade the central nervous system. To diagnose g-HAT, a screening test called CATT/T.b.gambiense is commonly used. However, the implementation of CATT for mass screening has been challenging due to operational issues. Recently, two rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) have been developed that can detect antibodies in the blood: RDT1 and RDT2. In this study, the diagnostic accuracy of RDT2 was evaluated in a multi-centric, prospective study in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), where it was compared to RDT1 and CATT. The results showed that RDT2 had non-inferior diagnostic accuracy compared to RDT1, and it was also more accurate than CATT.
Chagas disease is a major global health threat in Latin America and causes over 10,000 deaths annually. To control the disease, indoor residual spraying (IRS) has been used in many countries to eliminate triatomine vectors from homes. In Guatemala, this strategy has been successful in most endemic regions, but some areas have persistent infestation with T. dimidiata, a major vector species. In Comapa, a municipality in Southeast Guatemala, some communities have infestation rates of 15% despite multiple IRS interventions. We analyzed entomological indices and serological data from three cross-sectional studies spanning 15 years in Comapa. Our primary objective was to evaluate the effects of the Chagas control program on vector infestation and changes in human seroprevalence in school-aged children. We also evaluated seroprevalence in women of child-bearing age as a proxy for congenital transmission. We discussed the implications of these findings for sustainable integrated vector control, including insecticide-based methods within a program with limited resources. We also discussed strategies for preventing congenital disease transmission.
The enteric bacterium Citrobacter rodentium is a natural pathogen of mice and causes intestinal hyperplasia in suckling mice. This study aims to understand how this bacterium adapts to its host and to identify the factors that influence its virulence. To do this, the researchers compared the genomes of two different strains of C. rodentium: ICC168 and EX-33. They found that the genomes of these strains were different, with some genes being present in one strain but absent in the other. This indicates that these genes may have been acquired by HGT or lost through mutations. The researchers also found that the genomes of these strains had undergone genomic rearrangements, which could affect the ability of the bacterium to infect its host and cause disease. These findings are important because they help us understand how pathogens evolve and adapt to their hosts over time.
Scientists have found that stochastic events happen during transcription and translation, which leads to variations in RNA and protein expression levels. Protein and RNA expression levels have been shown to contain information about the molecules that produce them, but it is not clear how much information is contained. Researchers have developed a model of stochastic gene expression to understand how these variations occur. They use this model to predict how the protein count distribution will look like, which can then be tested experimentally. However, it is difficult to determine the exact parameters that make up this model. To solve this problem, researchers have developed a fitting algorithm that can compare the predicted protein count distribution with the experimental data and find the parameters that best fit. They have also developed an analytical solution to the first four moments of the protein count distribution. They have tested the algorithm and found that it returns ensembles of CDRC sets that are consistent with the protein count distribution. These ensembles are informative and can provide information about the molecular machinery that underlies gene expression.
Monkeypox virus (MPXV) is a type of virus that can infect many animals, including humans. When it infects humans, it causes a disease very similar to smallpox, with symptoms including a rash, fever, and lymphadenopathy. The virus is endemic to Central and West Africa, but it is increasing in numbers of human infections. There is currently no antiviral treatment or vaccine specifically for MPXV in humans, although vaccines against smallpox have shown some protection against MPXV. Scientists are exploring new and efficacious vaccines to protect against human MPX, including using genetic engineering techniques to create new viral vaccine vectors that are safe and effective. One such vector is BoHV-4, a gammaherpesvirus that causes a persistent infection in the monocyte/macrophage cell lineage of the natural host, the bovine, and has been isolated from other ruminant species such as goats and sheep. BoHV-4 has been shown to infect many different animal species, and scientists have successfully used it to express immune-dominant antigens from different pathogens to create recombinant BoHV-4s that can be used as vaccine vectors. One study used 129 STAT1 (-/-) mice to evaluate the capability of BoHV-4-based vectors expressing MPXV antigens to elicit a protective immune response against a lethal MPXV challenge. The study compared the capability of the BoHV-4-based vectors to the smallpox vaccine MVA. This work has established a starting point for BoHV-4-based vector applications toward MPX and other important human diseases.
This paper is about the process of mRNA decay in eukaryotes. In this process, the mRNA cap is first removed by the decapping enzyme Dcp2, which is then helped by several other proteins. These proteins are called decapping enhancers, and they are involved in the removal of the mRNA cap. However, some species of eukaryotes, including trypanosomes, have a unique decapping enzyme called ALPH1 instead of the usual decapping enzyme. The paper describes the properties of ALPH1 and its role in mRNA decay in trypanosomes.
The pancreas has two parts: one produces digestive enzymes for the digestive system and the other produces hormones for the body. One of these hormones is insulin, which controls blood sugar levels. Type 1 diabetes is a disease that results from the loss of insulin-producing cells. Current treatments for type 1 diabetes help people control their blood sugar levels, but it is difficult and there is a high risk of complications. Scientists are trying to understand how these cells are made and what genetic programs are involved. This knowledge may help in the development of new treatments for type 1 diabetes. During the development of the pancreas, several genes play important roles. The gene Pdx1 is involved in the early stages of development. The gene Ngn3 is involved in the development of endocrine cells, which make hormones. Other genes, such as Arx and Pax4, also have roles in the development of endocrine cells. The misuse of these genes in adult cells can change their properties and make them into cells that make different hormones. Scientists have generated a new mouse model that allows them to turn off the gene Arx in adult cells that produce glucagon, a hormone that regulates blood sugar levels. They found that when they turned off Arx, these cells turned into cells that looked like they made insulin, a hormone that controls blood sugar levels. They also found that when glucagon-producing cells were turned off, new cells were made that looked like insulin-producing cells. These new cells were able to produce insulin and make the mice healthier. They also found that when they turned off Pax4 in these mice, the cells continued to change and make even more insulin. These findings suggest that Arx is the main gene involved in changing glucagon-producing cells into cells that look like they make insulin. They also found that when they turned off Arx in adult cells, this caused the cells to turn into new cells that looked like insulin-producing cells. This suggests that these cells are able to change and regenerate. These findings may help scientists understand how to treat diabetes and how to make people live longer.
In order to prevent re-replication of DNA, eukaryotic cells use a complex control system to ensure that replication machinery is only assembled once per cell cycle. In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, replication is tightly controlled by cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), which target four different proteins that are involved in assembling the replication machinery at the origin of replication. When these proteins are no longer regulated, many origins can re-initiate, but with different efficiencies. A local control mechanism called a "re-initiation promoter" (RIP) has now been discovered that specifically promotes re-initiation at some origins without affecting their initiation activity. These RIPs are located in 60-base-pair segments and work independently of the chromosomal context and silencing effects. By analyzing the re-association of replication machinery with origins, it was found that RIPs work by antagonizing an inhibitory mechanism that operates after Mcm2-7 has been loaded at the origin. This discovery provides a new understanding of how diversity can be introduced in the regulation of eukaryotic replication origins.
Entamoeba histolytica causes a potentially deadly parasitic infection called invasive amebiasis (IA). The infection is most common in developing countries in Asia, Africa and Central and South America, but it also occurs in travelers and immigrants from these areas to developed countries. Recently, Japan, Taiwan, and South Korea reported a rise in cases of IA among men who have sex with men (MSM) due to oral-anal sexual contact. HIV-1 infection, which is increasing among MSM in these countries, has also caused growing concern about IA among HIV-1-infected MSM. The recommended treatment for IA is metronidazole or tinidazole, followed by a luminal agent to eliminate intestinal colonization. A previous study found no difference in the response to treatment between HIV-1-positive and -negative IA patients. However, it is not clear how effective luminal treatment is in preventing recurrence. In this study, the authors analyzed 170 HIV-1-infected Japanese patients with IA and genomic typing of E. histolytica in 14 of these patients, to delineate the clinical features of IA in HIV-1-infected individuals and the efficacy of treatment.
Sleeping sickness, or human African trypanosomiasis (HAT), is a deadly disease caused by certain subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei and transmitted by tsetse flies.
