The presence of DENV in tissue specimens from autopsies can be determined by viral RNA detection or viral protein detection by immunohistochemistry. Here, we aimed to assess the usefulness of NS1 capture tests as a diagnostic technique to demonstrate DENV antigens in human tissue specimens. We used tissue homogenates from dengue fatal cases that occurred in Brazil in 2002.
Multiple myeloma (MM) is a cancer of plasma cells that happens due to changes in the genes that code for immunoglobulins. It is the second most common blood cancer in the US and affects about 10% of all hematologic cancer patients. MM is preceded by a condition called monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), where there is an increase in the number of antibody-making cells in the blood. MGUS is more common in people over 50 years old, and about 1% of people with MGUS develop MM every year. There are differences in how MM affects people of different races and ethnicities. For example, African Americans (AA) are three times more likely to develop MM and have a higher rate of death compared to Caucasians (CA). However, there have been improvements in treatments for MM, which have led to an increase in overall survival. But these improvements have not been seen in AA patients. Researchers are studying the genetic changes in MM to understand how these differences occur and to develop better treatments. The CoMMpass study is a research project where researchers are studying the natural history of MM in 1,000 newly diagnosed patients. The researchers are using DNA sequencing to look for genetic changes in the tumor cells. They are also using ancestry testing to determine the genetic background of each patient. This allows the researchers to compare the genetic changes in tumors from patients of different races and ethnicities. The study has found some differences in the genetic changes in tumors from AA patients compared to CA patients. However, more research is needed to understand the reasons for these differences and how they affect patient outcomes.
The paper introduces a new method to study the evolution of cancer. The authors explain that cancer cells have many mutations, some of which are harmful and some of which are not. The mutations that are not harmful are called "passengers" and do not respond to targeted therapy, but they can still cause problems for the cancer. The authors also explain that previous research has shown that many cancers have a small number of "driver" mutations that are responsible for causing cancer, and many more "passenger" mutations that do not cause cancer. The authors then describe a mathematical model that can be used to study the evolution of cancer cells with passenger mutations. This model is based on a famous mathematical model that was developed in the 1940s to study the evolution of bacteria. The authors explain that their model is different from the old model in that it includes more cell types and that it takes into account the fact that cancer cells grow and die stochastically, meaning that their growth and death can be unpredictable. The authors then explain that they used their model to study the evolution of cancer cells with passenger mutations in colorectal cancer. They found that the growth of cancer cells with passenger mutations can be used to learn more about the process of cancer evolution. The paper is important because it suggests a new way to study the evolution of cancer cells and it shows that passenger mutations can be used to learn more about the process of cancer evolution.
Huntington's disease (HD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is associated with a polyglutamine (polyQ) expansion in the huntingtin protein. The first exon (XN1) of the huntingtin protein, which contains the polyQ region, has been implicated as the pathogenic polypeptide. It is hypothesized that after it is cleaved from huntingtin, the XN1 polypeptides misfold and form lethal cellular aggregates or inclusions in neuronal cells. Although previous experimental and computational studies have focused on specific regions of XN1, we propose to study the structure and dynamics of monomeric XN1 in order to help illuminate the aggregation mechanism and determine the role of these aggregates. Due to the structural complexity of XN1, we perform all-atom discrete molecular dynamics (DMD) simulations to systematically study the structural dynamics of XN1 and its variants. We construct 12 polypeptides categorized into three sets, including XN1 in its entirety, XN1 without the polyP flanking regions, and polyQ homopolymers, with different numbers of glutamine repeats. We find that the polyQ region has a lower probability of adopting β-sheet conformations in the context of XN1, and that the residues in the polyQ region can be induced to fold into a β-strand by increasing the number of glutamine repeats. We suggest that the polyQ and flanking regions in XN1 are strongly coupled in XN1 folding and misfolding.
CRISPRs are parts of bacteria's DNA that protect them from viruses. CRISPRs consist of repeats that are found in most bacteria, and spacers that are taken from viruses. CRISPRs come with special genes that help them fight against viruses. CRISPRs have been found in many different types of bacteria, and they are constantly changing to match the viruses they are fighting against. Previous studies have shown that CRISPRs are found in many different places in the human body and that they are constantly changing. A recent study found many different types of CRISPRs in saliva from people's mouths. By analyzing more than 700 samples from different places in the human body, we have found even more CRISPRs and studied how they are changing over time. This is important for understanding how bacteria protect themselves from viruses in different parts of the human body.
The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans ( C. elegans ) is a well-established model organism for studying development and behavior. In their soil habitat, worms are exposed to daily temperature fluctuations corresponding to solar irradiance during the day-night cycles. Several studies have previously reported the presence of circadian rhythms in C. elegans, but these rhythms were variable and non-robust. It was unclear whether C. elegans exhibits true bona fide circadian rhythms. In this study, the authors used expression profiling to identify light- and temperature-regulated transcriptional rhythms in C. elegans. They found that light and temperature globally drive the expression of many genes, indicating that C. elegans exhibits systemic responses to these stimuli. Light- and temperature-entrained transcripts appear to be largely nonoverlapping. The authors also found that conserved clock gene homologs do not exhibit circadian rhythmicity at the mRNA level, and that the TAX-2 cyclic nucleotide-gated channel subunit, previously implicated in thermosensory signal transduction and phototransduction, is required to transduce both light and temperature information to the clock. These results demonstrate that C. elegans has a circadian clock that is entrained by light and temperature, and indicate that this model organism can be used to further explore the evolution and function of the critical timekeeping mechanism.
Rad3 is a DNA helicase that is a subunit of the TFIIH complex. This complex is involved in transcription initiation and nucleotide excision repair (NER). NER is the process by which damaged DNA is repaired. Rad3 is responsible for unwinding the DNA containing a UV-induced lesion, producing single-stranded DNA that is then repaired. However, mutations in the rad3 gene can cause a hyper-Rec phenotype, which is a sensitivity to DNA-damaging agents such as UV radiation. The mutations can affect the ability of TFIIH to move along the DNA and repair damage, resulting in increased recombination and gene conversion. The mutations can also cause an increase in other types of genomic rearrangements such as deletions and duplications. The association between recombination and regions with elevated frequencies of the damage associated histone modification gamma-H2AX suggests that recombination can occur in response to DNA damage. The high level of deletions and duplications at the sub-telomeric region on the left arm of chromosome XV in rad3 hyper-Rec strains suggests that this region may be particularly sensitive to DNA damage. The similarity between the patterns of recombination observed in the rad3 versus wild-type strains suggests that a subset of spontaneous mitotic recombination events may be initiated by incomplete NER reactions.
A recent study explored how the bacterium Helicobacter pylori adapts to the changing microenvironment of the human stomach during infection. The bacterium's adaptation is achieved through a process called phase variation, which involves the sudden changes in the expression of specific proteins. These changes occur due to the presence of repeated sequences of DNA (simple sequence repeats) in the bacterium's genome. The study identified a particular repeated sequence of DNA, known as the T-tract, that affects the production of a protein called SabA, which is involved in the binding of the bacterium to the gastric mucosa. The study found that the length of this T-tract varied between different strains of the bacterium and that this variation affected the production of SabA. The authors also discovered that the T-tract affected the binding of the RNA polymerase to the DNA of the SabA gene, which in turn affected the production of SabA. The study suggested that this process may be used to regulate the production of other proteins in the bacterium. The study highlights the importance of understanding how bacteria adapt to their environment during infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for treating bacterial infections.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are a group of more than 100 viruses that cause cervical and other genital cancers. These viruses infect the cells of the genital tract and must evade the immune system to cause long-term infections. Some of the HPVs are high-risk viruses that increase the risk of cancer. These viruses use their own proteins to help them produce more copies of themselves and to avoid the immune system. Some of these proteins are called E6 and E7. E6 and E7 are important for the HPVs to cause cancer. The HPVs also use the immune system to make more copies of themselves. The immune system helps the HPVs produce more copies of themselves so that they can cause cancer. This process is not yet understood and more research is needed to learn how it works.
Salmonella enterica serovars Typhi ( S . Typhi ) and Paratyphi A ( S . Paratyphi A ) are human-specific pathogens that cause a serious disease known as enteric fever. This disease affects over 21 million people each year and results in 200,000 deaths. Enteric fever usually begins with the ingestion of contaminated water or food, and the pathogens invade the gut and then travel to different parts of the body including the liver, spleen, gallbladder, and intestinal lymph nodes. Most people recover from the acute stage of illness and clear the infection. However, a small percentage of S . Typhi ( and S . Paratyphi A ) infected individuals develop a chronic, but apparently asymptomatic, infection in the biliary tract that can persist for decades. Since S . Typhi and S . Paratyphi A are human-restricted pathogens, chronic carriers may act as reservoirs of infection within a community. Currently, there is no reliable diagnostic assay to identify asymptomatic S . Typhi and S . Paratyphi A carriers. Therefore, correctly identifying and treating chronic carriers is critical for the long-term control of enteric fever. A study used an immunoscreening technique called in vivo-induced antigen technology ( IVIAT ) to identify potential biomarkers unique to S . Typhi chronic carriers. The study hypothesized that S . Typhi surviving in the biliary tract of humans may express a proteomic profile distinct from that expressed in bacteria grown using standard in vitro conditions or during acute infection. This study may help advance our understanding of Salmonella pathogenesis of the chronic carrier state and identify potential biomarkers that can help identify asymptomatic chronic carriers.
The study of the genomes of eukaryotes has revealed that they produce an enormous number of non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) that can potentially have important biological functions. These RNAs are diverse in size, subcellular localization, and mechanisms of action. Some ncRNAs are part of epigenetic regulatory networks that have striking evolutionary conservation. RNAs can recruit chromatin modifying complexes to specific loci, leading to differentiation. The study of Position Effect Variegation (PEV) in the model system D. melanogaster shows that non-functional white alleles can increase eye pigmentation by trans-reactivating a variegating wm4h line, and this phenomenon is heritable. This new epigenetic phenomenon involves the presence of diffusible homologous RNA molecules and is affected by mutations in genes involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing. The study provides strong evidence that trans-reactivation is a new epigenetic phenomenon that positively controls gene expression in the context of heterochromatin through homologous RNA molecules.
Blood-sucking insects and ticks produce proteins that prevent blood from clotting, inflammation, and the immune response. These proteins have been identified in the salivary glands of these animals, and they are called Kunitz, Kazal, Serpin, Cathepsin, and Trypsin Inhibitor-Like (TIL) inhibitors. These proteins also affect the functions of immune cells, endothelial cells, and platelets. Some of these proteins have also been found in the midgut of these animals, and they have been shown to prevent blood clotting. For example, the proteins ornithodorin, hemalin, brasiliensin, dipetalogastin, rhodniin, and rhiphilin-2 from insects and ticks have been shown to prevent blood clotting. Additionally, some of these proteins, such as Boophilin from ticks, have been shown to affect the functions of multiple enzymes, including thrombin, plasmin, elastase, kallikrein, and Factor VIIa. It has also been shown that the silencing of the Boophilin gene in ticks results in a decrease in the weight of eggs laid. However, more information is needed on the kinetics of these proteins' interactions with different enzymes, how they affect platelet function, and whether they prevent blood clotting in vivo.
This paper introduces a new computer model called SEGMEnT that simulates the growth and structure of the gut tissue. This model can be used to explore different ways that gut tissue can become damaged or diseased. Specifically, SEGMEnT models the way that the gut tissue is arranged into crypts and villi, and how these structures are maintained and changed by the processes of cell division, movement, and differentiation. The model also includes information about the signaling pathways that control these processes, and how these pathways can be affected by inflammation. The model can be used to understand the relationships between different parts of the gut, and how they interact with each other to maintain a healthy gut. It can also be used to test different hypotheses about how the gut can become damaged or diseased, and how these diseases might be treated.
Mosquito-borne diseases like dengue, chikungunya, and Zika viruses pose a significant health threat in tropical and subtropical regions. These viruses are spread by mosquitoes and can cause serious illnesses. Brazil has reported a significant number of cases of these viruses in recent years. To combat these mosquito-borne diseases, it is essential to control mosquito populations. However, due to insecticide resistance and logistical constraints, traditional methods of controlling mosquito populations are limited. As an alternative, a new approach is being tested in which endosymbiotic bacteria called Wolbachia are used to block the transmission of these viruses. Wolbachia are present in 60% of all arthropods, but not in mosquitoes. However, a few strains have been successfully transinfected into mosquitoes. These strains can be used to replace mosquito populations with reduced potential for virus transmission. The World Mosquito Program, in collaboration with the Brazilian Ministry of Health, has released Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes in a community in Rio de Janeiro. However, the bacteria were unable to spread into the mosquito population. After an investigation, the factors that may have hindered the Wolbachia invasion were identified. Further releases of Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes are currently underway in the same community.
Scientists have discovered that viruses can use their own proteins to inhibit the host's defense systems. One example is the vaccinia B1 Ser/Thr kinase, which impairs a specific aspect of the host's antiviral response. B1 is highly conserved among poxviruses that infect mammals, with only a few exceptions. However, it's important to understand how this protein is regulated and what evolutionary mechanisms may have driven its conservation in all kingdoms of life. To do this, scientists have investigated the vaccinia B1-related kinases (VRKs) that share at least one common substrate with B1. By studying a B1-deficient virus, scientists have found that a loss of function mutation in the B12 locus provides a striking fitness enhancement. They have also discovered that B12 primarily localizes to the nucleus and that expression of wild-type B12 leads to a marked reduction in fitness of viruses with a defect in B1. Together, these findings present novel evidence that a paralogous kinase-pseudokinase pair can exhibit an epistatic relationship in a virus. This relationship may be important for enhancing B1 conservation during poxvirus evolution and for orchestrating nuclear events during infection.
A new study used computer simulations to investigate how the environment affects the folding, aggregation, and partitioning of two synthetic peptides, LK and EALA. Both peptides are modeled after natural peptides that cause neurodegenerative diseases and are able to form aggregates. The study looked at how the peptides behave when placed in bulk water, as well as when placed at hydrophobic/hydrophilic interfaces, such as the air/water interface or the presence of another peptide molecule. The study found that the peptides exhibit a highly dynamic conformational behavior with a significant amount of intrinsic disorder. However, the presence of interfaces or oligomerization had a significant impact on the folding equilibrium, potentially triggering the formation of toxic species.
In 2012, researchers found that HHV-6A and HHV-6B were different viruses that have different DNA sequences and characteristics. Most adults have HHV-6B in their bodies. HHV-6B usually causes a mild illness in children called "sixth disease" and can sometimes cause seizures or encephalitis (a brain infection). HHV-6A's disease association and epidemiology are not well known, but it can cause lymphoproliferative disorders. When the viruses enter the body for the first time, they establish latency (a period of inactivity) so they can persist in the body for life. Researchers found that both viruses integrate (attach to) human chromosomes, but they do not make circular copies of the virus. They also found that the viruses can integrate into germ cells, causing inherited chromosomally integrated HHV-6 (iciHHV-6), which is present in about 1% of people. A recent study found that 41% of iciHHV-6A and 59% of iciHHV-6B cases occur in the human population. When the viruses reactivate from their latent state, they can cause diseases, such as encephalitis and infections following transplantation. However, the mechanism of how these viruses integrate into human chromosomes is still unknown. In this study, researchers created recombinant viruses that lacked the TMR (telomeric repeats) or only had the perfect TMR (pTMR) or imperfect TMR (impTMR). They found that the TMR are essential for efficient virus integration and that the pTMR are the key component for integration, while the impTMR only play a minor role. This study provides the first molecular evidence of the HHV-6A integration mechanism and the viral sequence elements that facilitate its integration.
Poxviruses are a family of viruses that can cause serious illness in humans, and vaccinia virus is one type of poxvirus. The process of creating vaccinia virus is multi-step and involves the formation of different types of particles. Scientists have been studying vaccinia virus for a long time using electron microscopy, and they have learned about the process of creating the different types of particles. However, they still do not know how the particles are formed, especially the crescents and immature particles. Recent studies suggest that the membrane surrounding these particles comes from open-ended lipid sheets, and not from flattened double membranes as was previously thought. The D13 protein is a protein that is important for creating these particles, but it is not clear how it works. Scientists have now determined the structure of the D13 protein, and they have learned about its ability to remodel membranes.
The root system is essential for plants to grow and survive, as it provides them with water, nutrients, and other resources. The way that roots grow and branch is influenced by the soil's nutrient distribution. Plants can only respond to changes in nutrient availability within their genetic limits, which means that developing plants with better root systems can be beneficial for crops. We know a lot about how root growth and branching are controlled from studies on the Arabidopsis plant model system, and this information has helped us understand how these processes work in other plants like rice and maize. Many genes involved in root growth and branching produce proteins that have regulatory functions. These proteins often work in pathways that involve plant hormones, such as auxin and ethylene. For example, a mutation in a gene that encodes a protein involved in auxin biosynthesis can result in a plant with no roots. In this study, we describe a mutation in a Brachypodium gene called BdTAR2L that affects how roots grow and branch. The Bdtar2l mutant has a normal shoot, but its roots grow slowly and in strange patterns. This mutation seems to be affecting the way that auxin is distributed within the plant, which could be why the roots are growing so differently.
Biological traits can change in response to changing environments or genetic mutations, and these changes occur on different time scales. Regulatory mechanisms control how an organism adapts to changing conditions, while genetic mutations alter phenotypes over long time scales. Genes with regulatory variance that need to be buffered against environmental or stochastic changes are harder to change through genetic mutations. Moreover, regulatory variance can direct evolutionary dynamics by identifying the directions that are most likely to change. Recent studies in yeast have linked the evolutionary divergence of gene expression to the structure of promoter nucleosomes and highlighted the role of gene expression in generating phenotypic diversity. In yeast, genes with low regulatory variance (DPN genes) have a pronounced proximal NFR and tend to have a TATA box in their promoters, while genes with high regulatory variance (OPN genes) are more responsive to environmental changes and have a higher cell-to-cell variability (noise). The increased divergence of OPN genes may be due to their highly responsive promoters, which are more sensitive to random mutations and non-linear interactions between promoter nucleosomes and transcription factors. Alternatively, DPN and OPN genes may be subject to different selection pressures, where changes in the expression of DPN genes are more deleterious and therefore removed more efficiently by purifying selection, whereas mutations in OPN genes may contribute more to evolutionary adaptation. In this study, the authors artificially selected for high expression of GFP-fused yeast proteins and examined the genomic response to this selection. The expression of dozens of GFP-fused proteins was successfully increased regardless of their promoter class. However, promoter class influenced the genetic changes leading to increased expression: selection for high expression of DPN genes resulted in duplication of large genomic regions, whereas large-scale duplications were less prevalent in OPN genes, which primarily changed their expression through trans mutations. When selection was removed, DPN strains reverted back to wild-type expression levels, whereas OPN strains did not, indicating that promoter organization impacts early evolutionary dynamics and biases the path of long-term evolution.
Human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) causes a blood cancer called adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma. It does this by infecting certain types of white blood cells and causing them to grow and divide uncontrollably. The virus has a protein called Tax that helps it spread and grow inside the body. Tax also makes it easier for the virus to copy itself. Tax works by stimulating a molecule inside the cells called NF-κB. NF-κB is like a switch that tells the body to make more of certain proteins. Tax helps turn NF-κB on, which leads to the body making more of the proteins it needs to fight off the virus. However, Tax also causes other problems, such as rapid aging and cell death. The virus has another protein called HBZ that can help turn NF-κB off, which helps the virus grow and expand without causing rapid aging or cell death.
The ability to adjust to uncertain, changing, and open-ended environments is a characteristic of human intelligence. This involves using and updating multiple strategies to achieve a goal. In natural situations, such as selling lottery tickets, we often adjust, switch, and create new strategies. The frontal lobe is responsible for driving action based on task sets, which are active representations of behavioral strategies stored in long-term memory. Reinforcement learning (RL) models suggest that the frontal executive function adjusts these task sets to maximize action utility, and uncertainty monitoring (UM) models indicate that the frontal executive function monitors the task set's reliability for resetting it when it becomes unreliable. However, these models do not explain how the frontal executive function manages an expanding repertoire of behavioral strategies and decides to create new ones rather than simply adjusting and switching between previously learned ones. The PROBE model proposes a computational formulation of how the frontal executive function manages an expanding repertoire of behavioral strategies and controls the selection, learning, retrieval, and creation of behavioral strategies that drive action. The PROBE model is tested in a behavioral experiment inspired by the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test, and it is compared to alternative models. The results show that unlike these alternative models, the PROBE model best fits human data and has a monitoring capacity of three or four task sets.
This study proposes a computational approach to simulate and predict the long-term effects of pharmacological interventions on biological systems. The approach, called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations in Parameter Trajectories (ADAPT), uses a mathematical model of metabolic pathways in the liver to predict changes in metabolite concentrations and fluxes over time. The model parameters, such as reaction rate constants, are allowed to vary in time and are optimized to match the experimental data obtained during different stages of the treatment. The approach allows for the identification of the pathway adaptations that occur as a result of the pharmacological treatment without the need for developing detailed kinetic models of the modulating mechanisms. The study applies this approach to a model of mouse hepatic lipid and plasma lipoprotein metabolism to identify the adaptations that occur upon pharmacological treatment with the liver X receptor agonist T0901317. The results show a decrease in the expression of scavenger receptor class B1, a receptor that facilitates the uptake of cholesterol from high-density-lipoproteins (HDL) by the liver. This prediction was experimentally confirmed by immunoblot analysis of SR-B1 protein expression in hepatic membranes. The study provides an integrative understanding of the dynamic response induced by the pharmacological treatment that was not directly apparent from the experimental data. The approach may be useful for investigating metabolic pathways in relation to progressive diseases such as Type 2 Diabetes and cardiovascular disease.
This paper focuses on how the cerebellum processes information from multiple sources to coordinate movements. The paper discusses the spinocerebellar and spino-reticulo-cerebellar systems, which are major sources of mossy fiber (MF) inputs for the cerebellum. The paper also discusses how these systems receive sensory feedback and motor command components, and how this information is combined before it reaches the cerebellum. The paper also explores how the cerebellum integrates this information to generate useful functions and how non-linear interactions between input dimensions are handled in the spinal circuitry and the cerebellum. The paper concludes by discussing the limitations of these systems in handling non-linear interactions.
The study is focused on the spread of vector-borne diseases, such as malaria, dengue, and chikungunya, which are a major economic burden in tropical and sub-tropical regions, particularly in Asia. India, for example, is predicted to have the maximum global burden of dengue, and nearly half of the global population is at risk for vivax malaria. There are no vaccines available for these infections, and the only effective measure for disease control is vector control. Transmission blocking approaches show promise in laboratory conditions, emphasizing the importance of understanding vector-pathogen dynamics for effective control strategies. Mosquitoes play a significant role in disease transmission in humans, and their response to pathogens is driven by fundamental biological processes such as blood feeding for egg development and defense against microbial invaders. The study used deep sequencing to identify mosquito host miRNAs that may be impacted during chikungunya infection. Aedes albopictus cells were infected with chikungunya virus, and the study identified several Aedes known and novel miRNAs that were profiled during the CHIKV infection. The study also highlights the repertoire of common and distinct host miRNAs regulated during Plasmodium and CHIKV infections in their respective hosts. Additionally, the study predicts the targets of some of these miRNAs, shedding light on their potential role during pathogen infection in mosquitoes.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a zoonotic disease caused by the larval form of the tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus. The parasite's life cycle involves livestock and dogs as the primary intermediate and definitive hosts, respectively. Humans can also become infected by ingesting infective parasite eggs. The parasite typically develops into a cyst, which can put pressure on surrounding tissues and cause anaphylactic shock if it ruptures. Cystic echinococcosis is highly endemic in Iran, where many species of intermediate host are commonly infected with E. granulosus. The disease can cause significant monetary losses for affected individuals, their families, and the community as a whole. Recently, the World Health Organization has included CE in its list of Neglected Tropical Diseases to be addressed in its strategic plan for control of NTDs. Although CE is assumed to be a significant public health and economic problem in Iran, the extent of its socioeconomic impact is not fully understood. The purpose of this study is to estimate the monetary burden of CE in Iran using existing country-level data on human and animal CE.
The Merkel cell polyomavirus (MPyV) is a small virus that infects human skin cells. During the early phase of infection, the virus produces three proteins from one region of its DNA. These proteins cause the infected cell to start growing. Later, the virus produces more proteins that help it replicate its DNA and make new viruses. A study used deep sequencing to look at how the genes of the virus and the host cell changed during infection. They found that many host cell genes were turned up or down, and that some of the changes were related to how the virus replicates itself. They also found that the virus changed the way it made some of its proteins, and that the changes were related to how the virus replicates itself. The virus also changed the way it makes some of its proteins, and this also affects how it replicates itself.
In this paper, the authors present a mathematical model that can be used to determine the fuel requirements and associated performance limitations of any endurance runner over a range of distances. They use a combination of the aerobic capacity, the energetic cost of running, and the size of the carbohydrate and fat energy reservoirs to make these predictions. The model allows for personalized answers to the questions of how much carbohydrate a runner needs for a given distance and how a runner can avoid exhausting his or her carbohydrate reserves before completing the race. The authors also use the model to reveal the functional dependencies of the distance required to run glycogen stores to depletion and the fastest pace at which a given distance can be run without exhausting glycogen stores. Finally, they show how individual physiologic variation and the population distribution of aerobic capacities limit marathon finishing times and how these limitations can be used to establish marathon qualifying standards.
Toxoplasma is a parasite that affects a wide range of animals. It can cause serious illness or even death in humans, particularly in immunocompromised individuals and in congenital infections. Some strains of Toxoplasma are more virulent (cause more severe disease) than others, and different strains can affect disease in different ways. Researchers have been studying how different strains of Toxoplasma affect human cells. They have found that the parasite modifies human cells in different ways depending on the strain. This research provides insight into why different strains of Toxoplasma can cause different symptoms and severity of disease in humans.
The paper is about how viruses change and evolve over time. This happens because when they replicate, sometimes they can swap parts of their DNA or RNA with other viruses. This process is called "recombination." There are two ways that recombination can happen. The first is that a virus's DNA polymerase (an enzyme that helps copy DNA) can switch templates while making a copy of the virus's DNA. The second is that two different viruses' DNAs can be joined together by a cellular enzyme. In this paper, the authors describe a new way to study how recombination happens in viruses. They use a special system that allows them to study only the recombinant viruses, without the parent viruses getting in the way. This allows them to better understand how recombination happens and how these new viruses behave.
Obesity is a major health risk factor that causes diseases such as type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and liver disease. Fat is stored in the body in adipose tissue (AT), which can be divided into three types: white, brown, and beige AT. White AT stores energy as fat and can be broken down by lipolysis. Brown AT generates heat to maintain body temperature, especially during cold temperatures. Beige AT is a type of brown AT that can be made from white AT when it is exposed to cold temperatures or other stimuli. This process is called beiging and can help counteract obesity and its related diseases. To beiging, white AT is stimulated by chemicals like norepinephrine (NE) that activate β-adrenergic receptors (β-ARs). This stimulation leads to an increase in cAMP, which causes protein kinase A (PKA) to become active. PKA then promotes the expression of genes involved in thermogenesis, such as UCP1, PGC1α, and DIO2. However, the process of NE clearance is also important because if too much NE is present in the area around the β-AR, it can cause damage. The researchers found that a type of transporter called OCT3 is involved in the clearance of NE from adipose tissue. Mice with knockouts of this gene did not clear NE as well as normal mice, which caused a higher expression of thermogenesis, mitochondria biogenesis, and glycolysis genes in their white fat. The researchers also found that people with a certain genetic variation in the OCT3 gene had a higher BMR, which is a measure of the amount of energy used by the body at rest. This suggests that OCT3 plays an important role in regulating energy expenditure pathways.
HP1 proteins are important regulators of chromatin structure and gene expression in mammalian cells. There are three HP1 isoforms (HP1α, HP1β, and HP1γ) in mammals, all of which are found in dense heterochromatin as well as in the rest of the nucleus. HP1 proteins are thought to regulate enzymatic activities involved in gene expression, but are not "chromatin condensers" per se. HP1 proteins contain two domains, the chromo-domain (CD) and the chromoshadow-domain (CSD), separated by a hinge region. The CSD is necessary for dimerization and recruitment of HP1 proteins to DNA damage sites. The CD recognizes and binds histone H3 tails methylated on lysine 9 (K9), which is frequently associated with transcriptional repression. HP1 proteins bind weakly to reconstituted methylated nucleosomal arrays, but more efficiently to native chromatin. HP1 proteins interact with several molecular partners, including the hSWI/SNF complex. HP1 proteins and hSWI/SNF have opposite effects on chromatin structure and gene expression.
The article explains how RNA molecules have a specific structure that is crucial for their function. Different types of RNA molecules, such as tRNA, rRNA, and miRNA, have unique structures that allow them to do specific tasks. The article discusses the different ways in which RNA molecules can be modified to change their structure or function, and how these modifications can be used to treat diseases. The article also explains how the different types of RNA molecules are made and how they are related to each other. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of RNA molecules in biology and medicine.
This study aims to understand how plants recognize and defend themselves against necrotrophic fungal pathogens such as Botrytis cinerea. The authors find that the plant recognizes fungal cell wall components and fungal enzymes that are essential for their growth and reproduction. The authors also identify four transcription factors that are important for resistance to B. cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina. These transcription factors are named WAK1, BIK1, MAPK, and WRKY33. The authors then identify a set of genes that are commonly up-regulated in these four transcription factor mutants, and they name these genes PROVIR factors. The authors find that many of these PROVIR factors also function in disease susceptibility to fungal necrotrophic pathogens. Lastly, the authors use in vivo localization studies to show that many of the PROVIR factors are located in the pericellular space of plants.
The uterine endometrium (the layer of tissue lining the uterus) is receptive to an implanting embryo only during a specific time in the menstrual cycle. This time is called the "window of receptivity" and is critical for the embryo to attach to the uterine wall. During this time, the embryo and endometrium interact to prepare for the implantation of the embryo. These interactions require a complex set of genes and proteins to work together. Scientists have identified a protein called FOXO1 that plays a role in these interactions. They found that FOXO1 is present in the endometrium during the window of receptivity in humans and mice. When FOXO1 was removed from the endometrium in mice, the implantation of the embryo failed. The scientists also identified several genes that were affected by the removal of FOXO1 and that may play a role in the implantation process. They found that one of these genes, PGR, was also affected by the removal of FOXO1 and that PGR may be a marker for the window of receptivity in both humans and mice.
Dengue is a dangerous disease caused by a virus and spread by mosquitoes. Bangladesh has seen cases of dengue since 2000, but there is not enough information about how many cases are actually happening. We used a special kind of math to look at the relationship between the number of dengue cases, the weather, and the population of Bangladesh. We used this information to make maps of where dengue is most common in Bangladesh. These maps will help doctors and health workers know where to focus their efforts to stop the spread of dengue.
When introduced into a new environment, rats have a preferred place that they visit most often and stay in for the longest time. This preferred place is established early in the session and influences the overall behavior of the rats. Scientists have tried to find similar behavior in mice, but they haven't been successful. However, when scientists injected mice with saline and placed them in an open field arena, the mice established a preferred place that they visited occasionally. Scientists called this behavior "knot-scribbling" because the mice traced a twisting and turning path in the preferred place. This behavior was also found in intact mice, but it wasn't as pronounced as in saline-injected mice. To find this behavior, scientists measured the curvature of the path and looked for areas with the highest curvature. They then used algorithms to define the boundaries of the knot and measure some of its features. Finally, scientists asked whether the knot had the same features as the preferred place in rats and considered its function.
In this study, the authors describe the discovery of a new drug target for treating fungal infections. The drug target is a protein called Sec14p, which is involved in the secretion of molecules that help the fungus survive and grow. The authors found a compound, called NGx04, that inhibits the activity of Sec14p and showed that this compound can effectively treat fungal infections. The authors used a combination of genetic and biochemical techniques to study the mode of action of NGx04 and found that it works by blocking the activity of Sec14p. They also showed that NGx04 is effective against both laboratory strains of fungi and clinical isolates, which are strains that have been isolated from patients with fungal infections. The authors also discovered that NGx04 can even treat strains of fungi that are resistant to other drugs. Overall, this study provides evidence that NGx04 can be used as a new drug to treat fungal infections.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease that affects over 200 million people worldwide and can cause serious complications such as liver and intestinal fibrosis. The main treatment is a single drug, praziquantel, but there is a need for new drugs to be developed. Some antimalarial drugs have also shown promise against schistosomiasis, and we tested one such drug, mefloquine, against two different species of schistosomes (S. mansoni and S. japonicum). We found that mefloquine was effective against both juvenile and adult worms, but had a stronger effect on juvenile worms. Additionally, we examined the stage-specific susceptibility of S. mansoni to mefloquine and found that the ( + ) and ( − ) erythro enantiomers had different effects on different stages of the parasite. Overall, our results suggest that mefloquine could be a promising new drug for treating schistosomiasis.
Podoconiosis is a non-infectious disease that affects people who are in long-term contact with irritant red clay soil of volcanic origin. This disease has been reported in over 30 countries worldwide and it is estimated that there are 4 million cases. The most affected countries are Ethiopia, Cameroon, Uganda, Burundi, and Rwanda. However, the precise distribution and the geographical limits of the disease are unknown. In Cameroon, one of the major differential diagnoses of podoconiosis is lymphatic filariasis. To determine the prevalence and distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon, a nationwide mapping survey was conducted in 2016 targeting three intensive case management diseases (ICM-NTDs). The results of the study will help in developing an efficient and cost-effective podoconiosis control and elimination program.
In the past, it has been observed that the pool of stem cells diminishes during aging. This happens for satellite stem cells, male and female germline stem cells, and C. elegans germline stem cells. The communication between stem cells and their surrounding niche is important for maintaining stem cell identity, and during aging, the communication between these cells is compromised. There is a lack of information about whether stem cells influence their own attachment to the niche during aging. Additionally, it is unclear how the stem cells and the surrounding niche cells communicate with each other during aging. Drosophila is an excellent model to study this communication, as it has a short lifespan, genetic approaches are available, and the ovary contains well-characterized germline stem cells (GSCs) and their niche. The niche of Drosophila ovaries is made up of terminal filament, cap cells, and anterior escort cells. GSCs attach directly to cap cells through E-cadherin-mediated cell-cell adhesion, and the GSC fusome, an organelle, is juxtaposed to the interface between cap cell and GSC. When GSCs divide, they give rise to cystoblasts, which undergo four rounds of incomplete division to form a 16-cell cyst. The 16-cell cyst is surrounded by follicle cells and eventually develops into a mature egg. The Notch signaling pathway is highly conserved and plays critical roles in the regulation of stem cells in different systems. In Drosophila, Notch controls the maintenance of niche cap cells, but it is not clear if it plays a role in GSCs. Drosophila has one Notch receptor (encoded by Notch), which is a single-pass transmembrane protein. The extracellular domain of Notch is composed of several epidermal growth factor (EGF)-like repeats, which must be highly glycosylated for proper function of the protein. Fringe (encoded by fng) is a glycosyltransferase that adds N-acetylglucosamine onto this domain, thereby modulating the binding of Notch to its ligands. The insulin/insulin-like growth factor (IGF) signaling pathway is also evolutionarily conserved, and it controls various stem cell types in response to nutritional input and aging. Previously, it was observed that insulin signaling controls Fringe-mediated Notch activation in the GSC niche, which is required to maintain niche integrity, thereby supporting the retention of GSCs in the niche. In addition, insulin signaling directly controls GSC proliferation. In this article, the authors demonstrate that insulin and Notch signaling have independent roles in regulating GSCs, in contrast to the earlier observation that insulin signaling regulates Notch activation in niche cells to support their maintenance. While insulin/IGF signaling is required for GSC proliferation and maintenance, Notch signaling underlies the diminished ability of GSCs to occupy the niche during aging. In young ovaries, Notch signaling in GSCs is low, allowing them to persist in the niche; as ovaries age, Notch signaling in GSCs is elevated, resulting in the loss of GSCs from the niche. In contrast to GSCs, Notch signaling in niche cells (which is required for niche integrity) is decreased with age, thus contributing to age-induced GSC loss. The authors demonstrate that both intrinsic and extrinsic Notch signaling control the niche residency of GSCs during aging.
Human herpesviruses are a large family of viruses that infect cells, cause disease, and can be life-threatening in people with weakened immune systems. Many proteins encoded by these viruses have kinase activity, meaning they can phosphorylate other proteins to control cellular functions such as gene expression, DNA replication, and cell cycle progression. However, not all herpesvirus kinases are the same. We found that some herpesvirus kinases, called CHPKs, can phosphorylate the tumor suppressor protein Rb, disrupt the nuclear lamina, and function as cellular Cdks. However, other CHPKs do not have these functions, even though they are similar in sequence and structure. These findings show that herpesvirus kinases can have different functions and substrates, even if they are closely related.
Melioidosis is a disease caused by a bacterium called Burkholderia pseudomallei. It is found in the environment and people get it by coming into contact with it. The bacteria can enter the body through the skin, inhalation, or ingestion. Most cases of the disease have been reported from Southeast Asia and northern Australia, but it is also found in many other parts of the world. Scientists want to create a map of where the bacteria is found to help people in those areas take steps to prevent the disease. However, the methods used to find the bacteria are not standardized and vary greatly, making it difficult to create an accurate map. Scientists have come together to create guidelines on how to find the bacteria in the environment in a standardized way. These guidelines will be made freely available to the scientific community and will help to ensure that the map of where the bacteria is found is accurate.
Membrane fusion is a crucial step for the entry of many viruses into cells, including those with envelopes. This process is facilitated by a viral fusion protein that is activated in response to specific molecular cues. The Flaviviruses are a group of insect-borne viruses that have positive-strand RNA genomes and a fusion protein called E. The E protein is responsible for forming the outer layer of the virion. When the pH drops below 6.2, the E protein undergoes a large-scale conformational change, allowing fusion to occur. CryoEM reconstructions have shown that in the prefusion dimer, the stem segment folds into a helical loop and the fusion loop is located at the tip of domain II. In the postfusion conformation, the fusion loops and the transmembrane anchors cluster at one end of the rearranged protein. By blocking the zipping-up step in the refolding process, soluble forms of domain III or the stem can inhibit viral fusion. Stem peptides have also been shown to inhibit viral infectivity by binding the virion at neutral pH before cell attachment and internalizing along with the virus into endosomes. Hydrophobic interactions between the C-terminal segment of the peptide and the viral membrane contribute to virion binding and hence to inhibiting infection. Sequence-specific contacts may also have a role in initial binding.
This article presents a new way to study the spread of cholera using a technique called whole genome sequencing (WGS). Cholera is a serious disease that causes diarrhea, and it affects millions of people worldwide. WGS helps researchers understand how the disease spreads and evolves over time. They can use this information to improve how they prevent and treat cholera. The article describes how WGS can be used on dried stool samples collected on filter paper, even if there is no cold chain transport or laboratory capacity nearby. This is important because cholera often strikes in remote areas where it can be difficult to collect and transport stool samples. By using this new technique, researchers can study cholera in more places and get a better understanding of how it spreads. This information can help them develop better ways to treat and prevent cholera.
A recent study has shown that Dynein, a minus-end-directed microtubule motor, plays an important role in apico-basal polarity in Drosophila follicle cells. The researchers found that Dynein is required for the proper localization of a protein called StarDust (Sdt) in the apical plasma membrane. Sdt is a key component of the Crumbs complex, which helps maintain epithelial polarity. Further experiments revealed that an alternatively spliced coding exon in Sdt mRNA acts as an apical localization signal. The presence of this exon is required during early stages of epithelial development, but is not necessary in mature epithelia. These findings suggest that the strategy for apical targeting of the Crumbs complex changes during epithelial maturation.
Leishmania is a type of parasite that causes several diseases in poor countries. It can survive in both the sand fly vector and in the mammalian host. In humans, different clinical forms of the disease can occur. Visceral leishmaniasis is a severe form that can be fatal if not treated. Genetic population studies of different human strains of Leishmania have revealed that genetic exchange may occur during the mating process. This is supported by experimental studies using genetically modified Leishmania strains, which have allowed the visualization and recovery of the progeny after experimental crosses. Additionally, naturally occurring hybrid genotypes have been identified in field isolates involving different species of the Leishmania (Viannia) subgenus. These findings suggest that Leishmania is able to perform genetic exchange between the same genotype during the mating process.
Leishmania donovani complex is the main cause of visceral leishmaniasis (VL), a disease that is invariably fatal if not treated properly. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that there are around 2-400,000 cases of VL and 20,000 deaths every year, with most cases occurring in Brazil, the Indian subcontinent, and East Africa. In East Africa, VL is caused by L. donovani, while in other regions, where VL is caused by L. infantum, this disease is a zoonosis with dogs and wild canids acting as reservoir hosts. In Ethiopia, VL is distributed throughout the lowlands, with the most important foci found in northwestern and southwestern parts of the country. Recent studies using multiple molecular markers have shown that East African strains of the L. donovani complex are now classified in one group as L. donovani s. s. Several of these studies identify genetically distinct populations among the L. donovani complex associated with different geographic regions. A recent study using 14 unlinked microsatellite markers of 90 East African strains, including 63 new isolates from Ethiopia, showed that L. donovani can be divided into two genetically distinct populations, Sudan plus NW and Kenya plus SW. The repeat region of the L. donovani and L. infantum HASPB protein is recognized by human and canine VL sera and has been used with varying success for serodiagnosis. A specific PCR targeting the L. donovani complex HASPB repeat region (k26-PCR) was shown to distinguish between L. donovani and L. infantum strains, grouping them according to the size of the amplicon. In this study, the authors characterized 63 recent L. donovani strains from Ethiopia using k26-PCR and high resolution melt (HRM) analysis. Several strains from Kenya, Sudan, and India were also included for comparison. Analysis by these techniques split the Ethiopian strains into groups that are correlated with the geographic origin of the parasite strain. DNA sequencing of the amplicons showed that the number and organization of the peptide motifs comprising the L. donovani HASPB repeat domain vary with the geographic origin of the strain. The potential effect of k26 polymorphism on the use of HASPB for serodiagnosis and vaccination is discussed.
HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, causes AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) and changes very quickly because of the error-prone nature of reverse transcriptase and its tendency to switch between RNA templates. These mutational events, combined with high levels of viral turnover and diversifying selection from the immune response, create extreme diversity within infected individuals and in the pandemic as a whole. HIV-1, the virus that causes AIDS, has different subtypes, which form distinct clusters in phylogenetic trees. When a person is infected with two viruses from different subtypes, recombination can occur, generating inter-subtype recombinant forms, which are called circulating recombinant forms (CRFs). These recombinant forms have the potential to be of epidemiological significance and to have novel properties that led directly to their prevalence. However, it is widely assumed that recombination has limited biological significance, and most recombination breakpoints are selectively neutral. We tested this hypothesis using a probabilistic model for the copy-choice recombination process, which takes into account the local sequence identity between the co-packaged RNA genomes and produces an expected null distribution of breakpoints across two parental sequences. We generated this distribution using 162 laboratory-generated inter-subtype recombinants where no selection was applied to the recombinant products. We then compared this distribution with the observed recombinant breakpoints from the global HIV-1/AIDS pandemic. Our results strongly indicate that the most important recombination breakpoints are approximately on either side of the envelope gene, or at least gp120, which is involved in immune evasion.
The paper discusses the use of computational models to analyze data in various fields of neuroscience, such as decision neuroscience, psychiatry, and neuroimaging. Computational models are used to analyze behavioral and brain imaging data, and often rely on free parameters that vary across individuals and need to be estimated from data. However, capturing individual variation is a key challenge in parameter estimation and model comparison. Hierarchical models are used to characterize parameters in a population and each individual subject’s parameters given the population distribution. The paper presents a new method called Hierarchical Bayesian Inference (HBI) that addresses this challenge. HBI is a fully Bayesian approach that solves the problems of model fitting and model comparison within the same framework using variational techniques. The paper also introduces a new statistical test, the HBI t-test, which enables inference about parameters of a model at the population level. The paper demonstrates the advantages of the proposed method using synthetic choice datasets as well as empirical datasets.
The mammalian brainstem plays a crucial role in controlling vital functions. It contains a complex system of reflex arcs and relays information to higher brain centers through interconnected neuronal circuits. The rhombomeres (r) are subdivisions of the hindbrain along the antero-posterior (A-P) axis, which are segregated into modules of progenitor cells. Individual rhombomeres give rise to distinct portions of sensory and motor columns depending on their position along the dorso-ventral (D-V) axis. These progenitor cells eventually develop into nuclei of multi-segmental origin and topographic patterns of connectivity. For example, the facial somatosensory map is generated by afferent innervation from mandibular or whisker pad (maxillary) facial dermatomes targeting the r2- or r3-derived components of the principal trigeminal sensory nucleus. The cochlear complex, which is the primary relay station for central auditory processing, originates from different rhombomeres. The central auditory pathway includes the sensory organ for sound, the cochlea, which contains two types of receptors, the inner and outer hair cells. From the periphery, sound information travels through the VIIIth cranial nerve to the brainstem cochlear nuclear complex. A significant portion of the cochlear complex derives from a dorsal rim of neuroepithelium referred to as the auditory lip. The MOC reflex and the MEM reflex are two parallel sound-evoked feedback mechanisms acting on the auditory periphery to modulate incoming acoustic stimuli. The Hox genes are a large family of homeobox-containing genes that display rhombomere-restricted expression patterns and provide early patterning information to progenitors and their neuronal derivatives. In this study, the authors carried out a detailed fate map of r4 derivatives by generating a novel, highly restricted, r4-specific Cre-recombinase driver. They found that cells originating from r4 significantly contribute to the VLL, an important relay station in the sound perception pathway. In Hoxb1 and Hoxb2 mutants, the VLL, PVCN, and MOC motor neurons are selectively affected, though with different severities. Early conditional Hoxa2 inactivation in rhombic-lip derivatives selectively perturbs the AVCN axonal pathfinding to the MNTB, resulting in decreased contralateral and increased ipsilateral targeting of MNTB due to the down-regulation of Rig1, the main axon guidance receptor for midline crossing. Altogether, this study provides genetic and functional evidence for a Hox gene network in the establishment and maintenance of proper auditory rhombomere-specific circuitry during hindbrain development.
Scientists have studied how CO2 is fixed by prokaryotes on land, in the oceans, and in the air. They have also studied which bacteria break down complex polysaccharides, such as those found in algae and higher plants, and release CO2 back into the atmosphere. However, they have not yet studied which bacteria break down these complex polysaccharides in the oceans. Recently, a bacterium called Saccharophagus degradans strain 2-40T (Sde 2-40) was found to be able to break down these complex polysaccharides in the oceans. This bacterium was isolated from decaying salt marsh cord grass in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. It is a pleomorphic, Gram-negative, aerobic, motile gamma-Proteobacterium that has 4008 genes in a single replicon consisting of 5.06 million bases. The bacterium has an extraordinary variety of depolymerases and an unusual number of open reading frames coding for complex polysaccharide depolymerases. These carbohydrases and related proteins comprise 10% of the genome and have unique modularity, architecture, and a remarkable proportion of membrane targeting domains. Although such an arrangement is limited to a few taxa, bacteria within these taxa appear to be widely distributed in marine and estuarine waters. Sde 2-40 has the potential to have a significant role in the marine carbon cycle, functioning as a "super-degrader" and mediating the breakdown of complex polysaccharides from plants, algae, and invertebrates.
JEV is a type of encephalitis virus that is transmitted from mosquitoes to humans and animals. The virus is carried by several mosquito species, including Culex (Cx.) mosquitoes. The virus has been found in more than 24 countries in the South Asia and Western Pacific regions. There are five different genotypes of JEV, but the most dominant strain is genotype III (GIII). Recently, a new genotype, genotype I (GI), has emerged and has replaced GIII. The GI virus has a higher replication rate in mosquitoes, which may explain why it has been spreading faster than GIII. The virus has been found in 17 species of Cx. mosquitoes, including Cx. pipiens, which is commonly found in China. The study found that both GI and GIII JEV are transmitted to humans by Cx. pipiens mosquitoes.
Dengue is a dangerous disease that is spread by mosquitoes and has become a serious problem around the world. There are four different types of dengue viruses that can cause severe symptoms, and it is estimated that over 3.6 billion people are at risk of getting it. Since the first outbreak in Malaysia in 1902, dengue has been a notifiable infection in the country since 1973. In recent years, the number of cases has increased rapidly, with over 108,698 cases reported in 2014. While the case fatality ratio has remained low, it is concerning that the disease is becoming more severe and is affecting a wider range of ages. Currently, there is no cure for dengue, and only supportive treatments are available. This review aims to understand more about the epidemiology, clinical characteristics, and causes of death in fatal dengue cases in Malaysia during 2013 and 2014.
The study aims to understand why certain traits are used by animals to assess the quality of a potential mate. The study focuses on Drosophila melanogaster, the fruit fly, where the attractiveness of females is believed to be related to their reproductive potential. However, it is not entirely clear how attractive traits are linked to fecundity. The study proposes that the insulin signaling pathway, a central nutrient-sensing pathway in many animals, affects both the composition of the female pheromone profile and the male attractiveness. Insulin signaling can influence the expression of genes that encode enzymes that synthesize cuticular hydrocarbons in the fruit fly. The study proposes that flies and beetles may have evolved to read insulin pathway activity in different forms as an honest and accurate metric of reproductive potential. The study aims to investigate the tissue-specific effects of insulin signaling on reproductive potential and attractiveness in Drosophila melanogaster.
The Ebola virus disease (EVD) outbreak that started in Guinea in December 2013 quickly spread to Liberia and Sierra Leone, becoming the largest EVD epidemic ever observed. This study used district-level data to investigate local outbreaks and risk factors for EVD transmission during the 2013–2015 epidemic. By quantifying the transmissibility of EVD, this study aimed to provide insights that could improve epidemic management in the future. The study found that the basic reproduction number (R0), which describes the average number of secondary infections generated by a primary case during the initial phase of an outbreak, ranged between 1.5 and 2.5. The study used a statistical approach to estimate R0 from the generation time and the intrinsic growth rate (r), which is defined as the per capita change in case numbers per time unit and can be calculated directly from observed incident case counts. The study used a mixed effects model to take into account the hierarchical nature of subnational data and explored the relationship between R0 and socio-demographic variables as potential drivers of EVD transmission at a population-level.
Scientists have long been interested in understanding why protein evolutionary rates vary so much. Some factors that have been proposed as determinants of protein evolutionary rates include protein dispensability, number of mRNA molecules per cell, number of protein molecules per cell, codon adaptation index, number of protein-protein interactions, sequence length, role in the interaction network, and structural properties such as solvent accessibility and folding robustness. Researchers have used principal component regression analysis to disentangle these factors and found that a single component, which included codon adaptation index, protein abundance, and gene expression level, accounted for nearly half of the observed variability in protein evolution. However, expression-related factors have been measured with less noise than other possible factors. In related work, scientists observed covariation between sequence evolution, codon usage, and mRNA level among a broad range of species. They suggested there may be selection for robustness against mistranslation, since mistranslation-induced misfolding would be more deleterious for highly expressed proteins. In addition, they found that proteins with a higher fraction of exposed residues evolve faster. However, Bloom and others found the opposite pattern. Bloom et al explained this incongruence using protein designability, defined roughly as the number of sequences that can fold into a structure. They found that highly designable proteins have a higher fraction of buried residues and that highly designable proteins have stable cores, allowing the exposed residues to freely mutate without compromising stability. Researchers have also found that proteins with a higher contact density tend to evolve more rapidly in fly, yeast, E. coli, and human. Additionally, highly designable proteins have been shown to evolve more functional innovations. In this study, scientists explored the interplay between two very different factors: a protein's age and its structural properties. They found that differences in evolutionary rates previously observed among age groups could not be explained due to differences in the structural properties among age groups. Similarly, differences in rates correlated with structural differences cannot be entirely explained by the age of the PDB structure. Their results therefore reinforce the idea that there is not a single determinant of evolutionary rate, and that both intrinsic present-day properties as well as evolutionary age independently contribute to differential rates of protein evolution.
Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) helps control which genes are turned on and off during early development. PRC2 contains several important proteins, including Suz12, Eed, and Ezh2. Ezh2 adds a chemical group called methyl to lysine 27 on histone H3, which helps keep genes turned off. PRC2 also works with another protein complex called PRC1, which helps keep genes turned off. In embryonic stem cells (ESCs), there is a special kind of gene regulation called bivalency, where genes are marked with both methyl and chemical groups that help keep genes turned on. CpG islands are special DNA sequences that are often found near genes and can help keep genes turned off. Pcl3 is a protein that helps PRC2 function, and removing Pcl3 from ESCs can disrupt gene regulation and lead to problems with development and differentiation. Therefore, Pcl3 is an important protein for keeping gene regulation in check in ESCs.
The article discusses how animals adjust their chemosensory behavior based on their feeding state. For example, when they are hungry, they optimize their food search strategy. To do this, animals can dynamically change the expression levels of their chemoreceptors, which are specialized receptors found in chemosensory neurons. The article explains that chemoreceptor gene expression is regulated by transcription factors, which are proteins that bind to specific regions of DNA to control gene expression. The article describes how researchers have identified specific transcription factors that regulate chemoreceptor genes in C. elegans, a type of nematode worm. They found that the bHLH family of transcription factors has important roles in regulating chemoreceptor gene expression. These proteins can form homodimers or heterodimers through interactions with other bHLH family members. The researchers found that the feeding state of the worms affects the expression levels of these proteins. They also found that some of the bHLH factors have an important role in regulating the expression of srh-234, a chemoreceptor gene specifically expressed in ADL sensory neurons. The researchers found that the expression of srh-234 is highly dependent on the feeding state of the worms. They also found that the E/Daughterless protein, HLH-2, works together with bHLH transcription factors to regulate srh-234 expression. This suggests that HLH-2 is a feeding state-dependent transcriptional regulator for chemoreceptor genes.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium ulcerans that can cause severe damage to skin and soft tissue. BU is a neglected tropical disease that occurs in many parts of Africa, Asia, and the Pacific. In Australia, BU is primarily found in tropical areas of Queensland and Victoria. The bacteria that cause BU are closely related to the bacteria that cause a non-harmful skin infection called marine ulcer. However, M. ulcerans has a virulence plasmid that allows it to produce a lipid toxin called mycolactone. Mycolactone causes cells to die and stops the body's immune system from fighting the bacteria. It is not clear how the bacteria that cause BU are spread, but it is thought that the bacteria may be transmitted by biting insects. To determine if there is a link between the spread of M. ulcerans and the incidence of BU, the authors tested mosquitoes from different areas for the presence of the bacteria. They found that M. ulcerans DNA was present in mosquitoes from areas where BU cases were common. This provides evidence that mosquitoes may play a role in the spread of BU.
Myelin is an essential component of the nervous system of higher vertebrates. It acts as a natural insulator of axons, allowing for the maintenance of axonal integrity and the fast conduction of action potentials. In the central nervous system, myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes, while in the peripheral nervous system, this function is achieved by Schwann cells. Myelination is completed within a relatively short period of time during mammalian development, requiring a high rate of production and transport of different kinds of molecules, mostly proteins and lipids. In adult life, myelin is constantly remodeled, and the maintenance of functional myelin sheaths requires a careful balance of de novo synthesis and turnover. Any event generating an imbalance in the myelination or remyelination process has the greatest chance of inducing dys- or demyelination of either the central or peripheral nervous system. Scientists have studied the myelination process in great detail using observations from human patients affected by defects of myelination or myelin turnover, as well as animal models, such as mutant mice and rats, including those that have been induced by transgenesis or genetic engineering in ES cell lines. Unfortunately, only a small number of the many genes that are directly or indirectly involved in the myelination process have been identified, and only a few of these genes have been functionally annotated. For this reason, any new mutation occurring spontaneously or after mutagenesis is of potential interest for unraveling the molecular mechanisms involved in myelin assembly. In an earlier paper, we reported the discovery and pathology of a rat mutation designated "demyelination" (symbol dmy), which is characterized by severe and progressive myelin breakdown in the central nervous system. This demyelination syndrome appeared to be unique, with no homologue so far reported in any other mammalian species, including humans. In this report, we demonstrate that the causative gene (Mrs2) encodes a protein that is an essential component of the major electrophoretic Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria. This gene has orthologues in other organisms, including lower eukaryotes and plants. The protein shares many of the properties of bacterial CorA and yeast Alr1 proteins, but its specific involvement in the myelination process was not known or even suspected.
In recent years, scientists have used technology called microarrays to analyze and measure genes in a patient's body. This can help doctors make more accurate diagnoses, predict how well a patient will do, and decide on the best treatment. However, the technology itself can be difficult to use, and the rules for using it to make a diagnosis are not always clear or easy to follow. To help doctors better understand these rules, scientists have created something called a "signature." This is a set of rules that tell doctors how to use the technology to make a diagnosis. However, scientists need to make sure that the rules are easy to understand and follow, and that the technology itself is easy to use. This means that scientists need to make sure that the rules are well-documented, or explained in a way that is easy to understand. In this paper, scientists have looked at how well-documented signatures are in eight studies where microarray technology was used to diagnose patients. They found that many of the rules were not clearly explained, which could lead to doctors making different diagnoses than the ones the original study had made. To fix this problem, the scientists have made some recommendations for how to better document rules for using microarray technology. This should help doctors make more accurate diagnoses using this technology.
Amyloid formation is a feature of many diseases, such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s, and occurs when proteins misfold and clump together in a specific way called cross-β. These clumps can be very stable and resistant to chemicals or proteases. One type of amyloid that has been studied recently is called curli, which are produced by E. coli. Researchers have now determined the structure of curli using X-ray crystallography, and they found that curli are made of tightly packed β-strands. They also found that the fibrils of curli are different from those of other types of amyloids, in that they are not made of β-strands stacked on top of each other, but instead have α-helices. These findings show that different types of amyloids have different structures, which could be important for understanding their functions and potential uses in medicine.
Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a serious illness caused by a virus spread by mosquitoes. It can lead to death in 30% of cases and cause long-term health problems in 30-50% of survivors. The disease is most common in children under the age of 15 and can be prevented through vaccination. The Philippines is believed to be endemic for JE, but the disease has not been well studied in the country. To better understand JE in the Philippines, we did a review of all the information available and collected data from JE surveillance and laboratory systems. This information will help the government decide whether to include JE vaccine in its routine immunization program.
In recent years, scientists have discovered that the vast majority of genes in living organisms are not essential for their survival and can be removed without causing significant harm. This phenomenon, known as genetic robustness, refers to a biological system's ability to continue functioning despite mutations. Environmental robustness is another type of robustness that allows organisms to withstand changes in their external environment, such as temperature, salinity, or nutrient availability. Genetic and environmental robustness are intertwined, as environmental robustness can enhance genetic robustness by providing alternative ways for an organism to survive and grow. In this study, the authors used computer modeling to examine the relationship between genetic robustness and environmental robustness. They found that environmental robustness can enhance genetic robustness in metabolic networks by providing alternative pathways for an organism to use when one pathway is no longer available due to a mutation. The authors also found that genetic robustness can be influenced by natural selection and that it can evolve as a byproduct of other, more adaptive traits.
