By studying cilia in Caenorhabditis elegans, a type of roundworm, scientists have been able to learn more about how cilia work and what causes ciliopathies. In this article, researchers used RNA-Seq analysis to identify specific proteins that are found in the cilium and how they relate to other parts of the cilium. They found that a protein called RAB-28 is involved in the regulation of cilia and cell movement. By studying the function of this protein, researchers were able to gain new insights into how cilia work and how ciliopathies develop.
The hippocampus helps us remember things by encoding where we have been, or our position in space. Neurons, or nerve cells, in the hippocampus called place cells fire when an animal is in a particular location in space. This place field location can change depending on the environment, so a place cell can have multiple different place fields. In this study, the authors show that even without knowing where the animal is, we can still infer the general shape and size of the space, or environment, by just looking at which groups of place cells fire at the same time. They do this by analyzing the activity of place cells and using tools from mathematics to infer the topology and geometry of the environment. This work provides insight into how the brain might represent the environment without needing to know the exact location of each place cell.
Viral fulminant hepatitis (FH) is a severe liver disease that causes massive damage to hepatocytes (liver cells) and is associated with hepatic encephalopathy (a brain disorder caused by liver disease). MHV-3 (a type of coronavirus) is a common cause of FH in mice. It is known that FH is caused by an imbalance between pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory factors in the body. However, the exact cause of FH is not yet known. Recent studies have shown that an overactive protein called NLRP3 can cause FH by triggering the production of the protein IL-1β. This can lead to inflammation and liver damage. It is not clear what triggers the activation of NLRP3, but it is believed to be related to the production of certain molecules called danger-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) and pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs). These molecules are produced when the body detects viruses or other foreign substances. It is thought that NLRP3 may be activated by molecules such as virus RNA, nigericin, ATP, silica crystals, mitochondrial DNA, and aluminum hydroxide. However, it is not clear what triggers NLRP3 activation in viral FH.
Hookworms, which are parasites that infect the human digestive system, cause serious health problems worldwide. They are estimated to affect over 500 million people, causing anemia and iron deficiency, especially in children. These parasites attach to the mucous lining of the bowel and feed on the blood of the host, leading to blood loss and iron deficiency. To determine the number of hookworms in the intestines, a test called Kato-Katz microscopy is used, but it is time-consuming and often not done. Two hookworm species, Necator americanus and Ancylostoma duodenale, have different geographical distributions. N. americanus is prevalent in tropical environments, while A. duodenale prefers colder, drier conditions. However, both species cause similar symptoms, but A. duodenale is estimated to cause more blood loss per worm than N. americanus. To differentiate between these species, a multiplex real-time PCR test is used, which is more sensitive and specific than the Kato-Katz microscopy test. The objective of this study was to use the multiplex real-time PCR test to determine the prevalence of hookworms and the number of worms in children in Malawi. The study also aimed to determine the association between the two species and severe anemia and bone marrow iron deficiency in children.
In this study, the authors explore the role of a protein called COM-1 in DSB repair during meiosis in C. elegans. DSBs are breaks in DNA that can occur due to various reasons and must be repaired correctly to prevent genome instability. Two main pathways for DSB repair have been identified: HR and NHEJ. HR is considered more conservative and error-free, but it requires an undamaged template, which may not always be available. NHEJ, on the other hand, is more efficient but error-prone. The authors found that COM-1 is required to prevent chromosome aggregation and CO failure during meiosis. Specifically, COM-1 acts to block toxic Ku activity at meiotic DSBs. In addition, COM-1 plays a role in interhomolog HR, working in parallel with the nuclease EXO-1 to generate RAD-51-coated recombination intermediates at early/mid pachytene stage. Overall, the authors identify a dual role for COM-1 during meiosis, making it a crucial player in maintaining genome stability during gametogenesis.
Melioidosis is a disease caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, a bacterium found in water and wet soil. It is a significant health threat in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia, where it causes up to 40% of fatalities. The disease is also endemic in Central and South America, southern regions of China, and India. There are several methods used to diagnose melioidosis, including bacterial culture, antigen detection, and serological testing. However, current methods for diagnosing melioidosis are too slow or not sensitive enough to identify patients with severe sepsis, who have a high mortality rate. Therefore, there is a need for a more sensitive and specific diagnostic test for melioidosis.
Mitosis is a critical process in which a cell divides into two identical daughter cells. To start this process, a protein called cyclin B1 binds to another protein called cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (Cdk1) and turns it on, or activates it. This complex of cyclin B1 and Cdk1 is able to perform a number of tasks necessary for cell division, including separating the chromosomes in the cell's nucleus. The activation of cyclin B1 and Cdk1 is regulated by other proteins, such as Wee1, Myt1, and the Cdc25 phosphatases. These proteins make sure that cyclin B1 and Cdk1 are not activated too early, but rather are turned on at the right time during the cell cycle. However, it is not clear exactly how this regulation occurs or how the activation of cyclin B1 and Cdk1 is coordinated with other processes during cell division. In this study, the authors used a number of different methods to study the activation of cyclin B1 and Cdk1 in human cells. They found that cyclin B1 and Cdk1 are activated in late G2, the stage before mitosis, and that this activation gradually increases until the cell enters mitosis. They also found that, once activated, cyclin B1 and Cdk1 are able to continue their activity even when the cyclin B1 and Cdk1 levels are reduced. This suggests that the activation of cyclin B1 and Cdk1 is governed by a process called bistability, in which the proteins are either inactive or active, but not somewhere in between. The authors propose that the activation of cyclin B1 and Cdk1 helps to coordinate early and late mitotic events, such as the separation of the chromosomes in the nucleus.
The article discusses the development of a neutralizing antibody (Nab)-based vaccine for human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1), which is a major global health challenge. The article highlights four main epitope targets on the HIV-1 Envelope that have been identified through the isolation of monoclonal antibodies from HIV-infected individuals. The article also discusses the results of a study that tested the Nab specificities of 21 superinfected women infected with HIV-1 subtypes A, C, and D. The study found that none of the women had a dominant Nab response to the four main epitope targets, suggesting that exposure to diverse HIV-1 antigens following superinfection may drive a broad and potent Nab response that may be mediated by polyclonal antibodies targeting multiple different epitopes.
Congenital Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection causes permanent brain damage in newborns and children. To understand how HCMV affects the brain, scientists have used neural progenitor cells (NPCs) as a model to study the underlying mechanisms. Hes1 is an important protein that helps NPCs grow and develop properly. HCMV infection causes Hes1 levels to decrease, which could lead to abnormal growth and development of the brain. Scientists found that IE1, a protein produced by the virus, can bind to Hes1 and cause it to be broken down. This could be a new way that HCMV causes brain damage in newborns and children.
Scientists are interested in how the genetic basis of differences in animal development can affect the way they look. They think that changes in the way genes are expressed, rather than the genes themselves, are a major source of this diversity. They believe that certain parts of the DNA that control the way genes are expressed may have important roles in the evolution of animal morphology. These parts of the DNA are called enhancers. Enhancers are known to change quickly during evolution. Scientists have found that the way transcription factors (proteins that control gene expression) bind to these enhancers is often different in related species, but they are not sure how this affects the expression of genes. To study this, scientists looked at the way four transcription factors work in four different species of Drosophila embryos. These species are closely related but have diverged over a period of 5 to 40 million years. By comparing the expression of genes and the binding of transcription factors in these four species, scientists were able to understand more about how differences in DNA sequences can affect the way that genes are expressed.
The aim of the global programme to eliminate lymphatic filariasis is to eliminate the disease as a public health problem by 2020. This is done by interrupting transmission through annual single dose mass drug administration of albendazole (fixed dose 400 mg) either with diethylcarbamazine citrate or ivermectin for at least 5–6 years. The programme has been gradually scaled up to reach all 250 endemic districts spread over 20 states and union territories covering nearly 421 million people at risk in 2007. In India, the programme has been implemented in 13 of the 250 endemic districts since 1996–97. By 2010 the programme had delivered billions of treatments to nearly 897 million people in the world.
Vector control is currently the only way to prevent and control the transmission of dengue, a mosquito-borne disease. Various methods for controlling Aedes aegypti, the main mosquito species responsible for dengue transmission, are used. These methods include applying pesticides, using biological agents, or changing the environment to get rid of mosquito breeding sites. These methods can be used alone or in combination. However, it is not clear how effective these methods are in reducing dengue transmission. Previous reviews have shown that some single interventions, such as peridomestic space spraying and the use of Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis, are not very effective in reducing dengue transmission. One commonly used method for dengue vector control is temephos, an organophosphorus compound that kills mosquito larvae. It has been used since 1965 and is safe to use in drinking water. It is effective and easy to use, and its effects last longer than traditional methods. Temephos is available in different forms, such as emulsifiable concentrates, dilute solutions, dusts, and granules, including slow-release formulations. It can be applied by hand or by injection using drip system devices or power sprayers. It can also be applied to household water storage containers by using a calibrated plastic spoon to deliver a consistent dosage of 1ppm. While temephos is effective in killing mosquito larvae, it is not always effective in the field. This systematic literature review aims to assess the effectiveness of temephos in reducing dengue transmission when delivered as a single intervention or in combination with other interventions.
In budding yeast, the proper movement of chromosomes during cell division requires that the two copies of each chromosome are held together by a special protein complex called cohesin. This complex forms links between sister chromatids during DNA replication and is then broken down during cell division. The formation of these links is carried out by a complex series of steps that are tightly connected to DNA replication. In particular, a special group of proteins called the Ctf19 complex is thought to be involved in this process. These proteins have been implicated in cohesion formation, but their specific roles have not been fully defined. In this study, the authors use a genetic analysis to investigate the roles of two proteins from the Ctf19 complex, Iml3 and Chl4, in cohesion formation at the pericentromere, which is a specific region of the chromosome where cohesion is particularly important. They find that Iml3 and Chl4 are required for the formation of cohesion links at the pericentromere during both mitosis and meiosis. The authors also investigate the role of another protein called Csm3, which has previously been implicated in cohesion formation, and find that it is not involved in the formation of cohesion links at the pericentromere. Together, these findings provide new insights into the complex process of cohesion formation and its role in the proper movement of chromosomes during cell division.
A recent study examined changes in the serum metabolome and lipidome of people with dengue fever (DF). The study found that DF caused significant changes in both the metabolome and lipidome. The authors found that the body responds quickly to inflammation during DF and that this is followed by pro-resolution counterbalances to restore homeostasis. Additionally, the study identified potential associations between sphingomyelins and CD8+ lymphocyte activation during the early febrile period and between plasmalogen phosphatidylethanolamines and lysophosphatidylethanolamines with platelet numbers during the later phases of defervescence and convalescence. The authors propose that the widespread changes in the metabolome and lipidome play an important role in the self-limiting outcome of DF.
Neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) are a group of diseases that affect some of the world's poorest populations. Research and development efforts to find new treatments and better ways to diagnose NTDs have been increasing in recent years, but there is still a lot of work to do. In order to use limited resources more efficiently, a global observatory has been proposed to identify research needs and match funding with public health priorities. New tools are available to help analyze research activity and collaboration between researchers, but these tools have not been used much to study research on NTDs. In this study, the authors used network analysis to map research on NTDs and identify the most important researchers and collaborations. This information can help policymakers make better decisions about how to use limited resources to find new treatments and better ways to diagnose NTDs.
Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) are a group of 17 parasitic, bacterial, and viral infections affecting over 1 billion people worldwide. Four of these diseases can be controlled by administering medicine to entire eligible populations or large segments of these populations, and three of these diseases are endemic in Haiti. The three soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections caused by Ascaris, Trichuris, and hookworm affect the intestines and can cause poor cognitive development and learning capacities in children. Lymphatic filariasis (LF) causes a variety of physical and mental health complications and is one of the most debilitating parasitic diseases. Haiti has one of the largest populations of LF at risk in the Americas. The ENVISION project, led by RTI International, is a U.S. government-funded initiative that aims to control and potentially eliminate NTDs in 19 countries, including Haiti.
This paper aims to study the regulation of the cell cycle in Sinorhizobium meliloti, a type of bacteria that can form a symbiotic relationship with legume plants. The authors want to understand how the regulatory protein CtrA controls the cell cycle in S. meliloti and how it interacts with other proteins and factors in this process. To do this, they will study the effects of CtrA depletion in S. meliloti free-living cells and analyze its direct and indirect transcriptional regulons. The goal is to develop a model of CtrA cell cycle regulation in S. meliloti that can help to understand how plant factors can modify the bacterial cell cycle during symbiosis.
Francisella tularensis is a highly infectious bacterium that can cause the disease tularemia in a large number of mammalian species. Four different subspecies of F . tularensis that differ in virulence and geographic distribution exist. These are designated subsp . tularensis ( type A ) , holarctica ( type B ) , novicida and mediasiatica . F . tularensis subsp . tularensis is the most virulent subspecies causing a severe disease in humans , whereas F . tularensis subsp . holarctica causes a similar disease but of less severity. In this study, the authors identified a gene called FTL_0766 that encodes a putative gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) that plays a critical role in the virulence of F . tularensis . They used a bacteriostatic antibiotic to select intracellular growth-deficient mutants directly from a pool of mutants. One of the mutants isolated by this procedure had an insertion into gene FTL_0766 , encoding a putative GGT. The authors focused on the role of this gene in the virulence of F . tularensis . They demonstrated that FTL_0766 of F . tularensis encodes a genuine GGT involved in the metabolism of γ-glutamyl-containing peptides . GGT allows the utilization of γ-glutamyl peptides as a source of cysteine during intracellular multiplication of the pathogen , and is thus critical for virulence.
In a 1995 paper, James Moulder proposed that microbial parasites customize the morphology, composition and function of the parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) where they are sheltered. In some cases, it is possible to generate chimeric vacuoles when cells are infected with different pathogens. In the current study, macrophages were coinfected with two species of Leishmania parasites, which are normally found in PVs with different biogenesis, morphology, and parasite occupancy. Macrophages are immune cells that can engulf and destroy infectious agents. Leishmania are a group of parasites that can cause various skin and mucous membrane infections in humans and animals. Leishmania parasites go through different forms during their life cycle. Extracellular promastigotes form in the sandfly vector and differentiate into infective amastigotes that can be taken up by macrophages. Inside the macrophage, amastigotes multiply and can be taken up by other macrophages. Leishmania PVs are organelles that are bounded by a membrane derived from the host cell and undergo changes in composition as they fuse with late endosomes/lysosomes. Most studies on Leishmania PVs have been performed with L. amazonensis, which forms large, communal PVs that contain many amastigotes. However, most Leishmania species form small, membrane-bound PVs that contain a single parasite and undergo fission as they multiply. The pH within these small PVs is around 5.5, and an increase in pH to 5.8 exacerbates intracellular infection. In the current study, macrophages infected with L. amazonensis were challenged with L. major amastigotes or promastigotes and observed by multidimensional live imaging. While L. major amastigotes were excluded, L. major promastigotes were delivered into L. amazonensis PVs, where they survived and multiplied but did not differentiate into amastigote forms.
Eliciting broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) is a major goal in HIV-1 vaccine development. However, HIV-1 infections are caused by a diverse and evolving virus, making it difficult to elicit effective antibodies. To overcome this challenge, scientists are trying to develop a vaccine platform that consistently elicits potent autologous antibodies that can neutralize tier 2 viruses. Researchers have found that a trimeric form of the HIV-1 envelope (Env) gp120/gp41 heterodimer is the optimal form of Env to induce neutralizing antibodies. Scientists have also found that DNA priming followed by protein boosting can improve the neutralizing antibody response. These findings suggest that the development of a vaccine platform based on authentic Env trimers may be the key to inducing potent autologous neutralizing antibodies.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a skin disease caused by bacteria called M. ulcerans. It often affects the subcutaneous tissue and can cause ulcers if not treated. BU can affect people of all ages, but it is more common in children and the elderly. BU lesions can appear as nodules, plaques, edema, and ulcers. Treatment for BU involves taking oral rifampicin and intramuscular streptomycin for eight weeks. However, recovery can be slow and may require skin transplantation. During treatment, some patients may experience paradoxical reactions, which can make the disease appear worse before it gets better. The healing process of BU lesions is complex and can be affected by various factors, including immune responses and secondary infections. We analyzed markers of cell activation, myofibroblast formation, and matrix deposition in tissue biopsies from BU lesions before, during, and after treatment.
Mitochondria are small organelles that generate energy and distribute it along nerve cells, or axons. To study how this process happens, scientists often use cultured cells or slices of tissue. However, there are limitations to studying mitochondrial transport in these conditions. For example, the cells are growing and developing, so the results reflect both their steady state energy needs and their growth. In addition, the slices of tissue do not have blood vessels or other regulatory mechanisms that are important for the body to function properly. To overcome these limitations, scientists have used zebrafish embryos and live nerve cells in mice to study mitochondrial transport in vivo. However, it is not known if the nerve cells in these animals behave the same way as nerve cells in humans. To study this, scientists used confocal time lapse imaging to track mitochondrial movements, distribution, and morphology along nerve cells in mice. They also used electrical and chemical stimulation to study how mitochondrial transport changes when nerve cells are active.
The study explores the mechanisms behind the development of vertebral fusions in spondylocarpotarsal synostosis (SCT) syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive bone fusions in the spine, hands, and feet. FLNB is a protein involved in bone growth that is required for proper endochondral ossification, a process in which cartilage is replaced by bone. In the absence of FLNB, TGFβ and BMP signaling is increased, leading to ectopic differentiation of the AF (annulus fibrosus) in the intervertebral discs (IVDs) towards a chondrogenic lineage. This results in abnormal endochondral ossification and vertebral fusions. The findings of the study provide a developmental model for degenerative disc disease, a common problem in older adults.
Transcription is a crucial process in which DNA is copied into mRNA. Pol II is the enzyme that carries out transcription and it needs help from several factors, including GTFs, to start and continue transcription. However, sometimes Pol II gets stuck on the promoter and cannot continue transcribing. This is known as pausing. Pausing is important because it allows for extra regulation of gene expression. In some cases, paused Pol II is released from the promoter by the action of P-TEFb. This allows for productive transcription to continue.
Human parvovirus B19, also known as fifth disease or slapped cheek syndrome, is a small, non-enveloped, single stranded DNA virus that can cause hematological disorders. B19V infects human erythroid progenitors in the bone marrow and fetal liver, which results in the death of infected cells. The virus has a linear single stranded DNA genome of 5,596 nucleotides and encodes four proteins: non-structural protein (NS1), and two capsid proteins (VP1 and VP2), and an 11-kDa protein that uses a different open reading frame. NS1 contains nuclear localization signals, DNA-binding/nickase, and ATPase domains. NS1 is essential for replication of viral DNA, binds the P6 promoter of the virus, and regulates viral gene expression. NS1 also transactivates several host genes, arrests cell cycle at “G2-phase,” induces apoptosis of infected erythroid progenitors, and induces late S-phase arrest. In this study, the authors performed a genome-wide RNA-seq analysis of B19V-permissive cells to identify genes that are regulated by the NS1 TAD2 domain and function in NS1-induced G2-phase arrest. The results show that the TAD2 domain is predominantly responsible for the transactivation of cellular genes in NS1-expressing cells. The authors also found that activated ATR phosphorylates CDC25C at serine 216, which in turn inactivates the cyclin B1/CDK1 complex and induces G2-phase arrest.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne virus that causes a range of illnesses, from mild to life-threatening. Dengue virus (DENV) has 4 serotypes (DENV1-4) that infect humans, causing dengue fever (DF) and dengue hemorrhagic fever/dengue shock syndrome (DHF/DSS). The DENV positive-strand 10.7 kb RNA genome encodes a polyprotein that is cleaved into 3 structural proteins and 7 non-structural proteins (NSPs). DENV NSP1 is synthesized as a monomer in infected cells and released into the extracellular milieu as a hexamer. The hexamer circulates in the blood during acute illness, and its levels correlate with dengue disease severity. Under normal physiological conditions, the microvascular endothelium maintains a low permeability to fluids and molecules. DENV NS1 plays a role in viral replication and immune evasion. Our previous study showed that DENV NS1 can directly induce endothelial hyperpermeability in vitro and vascular leak in vivo in the absence of DENV infection. In this study, we sought to evaluate the relative contributions of cytokine-driven inflammatory mechanisms and NS1-induced endothelial glycocalyx degradation to NS1 pathogenesis of the endothelium. We found that DENV NS1 triggers hyperpermeability independently of the pro-inflammatory cytokines TNF-α and IL-6. We also demonstrated that DENV NS1 induces localized vascular leak in the dermis of wild-type mice and that this effect is specific to DENV NS1 and independent of TLR4 and TNF-α signaling. Finally, we showed that DENV NS1-induced endothelial dysfunction is dependent on endothelial sialidases, cathepsin L, and heparanase both in vitro and in vivo. Our results indicate that DENV NS1 acts directly on the endothelium to induce vascular leak in vivo that is dependent on components of the glycocalyx.
In this study, the researchers present new findings about how the budding yeast septin ring is regulated during cell division. The septin ring plays a key role in separating the chromosomes during cell division, and the researchers have discovered that the regulation of this ring depends on a network of kinases and phosphatases that work together to ensure that the ring remains stable and in the correct position during cell division. They have identified two ubiquitin ligases, Dma1 and Dma2, that are involved in regulating the position of the septin ring and are required for proper cell division. They have also identified a kinase, Elm1, that works in conjunction with the ubiquitin ligases to regulate the position of the septin ring and ensure proper cell division. Overall, the study sheds new light on the complex regulatory mechanisms that control cell division in budding yeast.
The article is about how certain traits in humans, such as body size, skin pigmentation, and metabolism, are influenced by the climate and geography of the place where people live. This happens because some traits are better adapted to certain climates and geographies. These traits are called ecoclines. The article explains how scientists can identify the genetic basis of these ecoclines by studying the variation in allele frequencies, or the frequency of different versions of a gene, in different populations. The article provides evidence that several genes in humans are associated with climate and geography, and that this variation is likely due to natural selection.
The short QT syndrome (SQTS) is a rare genetic disorder that causes the heart to beat abnormally fast. This can lead to arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats) and sudden death. In SQTS, the heart beats too quickly because of a problem with a type of potassium channel in the heart called hERG. The hERG channel plays an important role in regulating how fast the heart beats. Researchers have found that a mutation in the hERG gene causes SQTS. This mutation causes the hERG channel to open too quickly, which makes the heart beat too quickly. The hERG channel is responsible for a type of current in the heart called IKr, which helps to regulate how fast the heart beats. Scientists have studied the hERG channel in labs to understand more about how it works in people with SQTS. They used computer models to simulate the effects of the hERG mutation on the heart. They found that the hERG mutation causes the heart to beat too quickly and increases the risk of arrhythmias and sudden death. The results of this study provide more information about how the hERG mutation causes SQTS and how it affects the heart.
Collective behavior is a phenomenon where a group of individuals work together to achieve a common goal. There are various models to understand collective behavior, which can be classified based on their accuracy and complexity. Low-complexity models have a small number of parameters and are easy to understand, but they may miss important biological components. These models are not typically tested for their detailed quantitative predictions. New techniques allow for tracking each animal in large collectives with high precision, and can provide enough data to build accurate models of collective behavior. However, it can be difficult to increase accuracy without increasing complexity. Deep neural networks are a technique that can provide high accuracy and insight into the problem, but they can be difficult to analyze. In this paper, we propose to use deep attention networks, which express social interaction as a combination of two deep-network modules of few inputs and outputs each, and thus allow us to simultaneously achieve insight and predictive accuracy. We can illustrate the reduction of variables in a modular model by comparing it against a non-modular model. By using deep attention networks, we can reduce from 150 variables to modules of 4-6 variables, which allows for insight into the rules by analysis of these modules, while still achieving high prediction accuracy. We found deep attention networks to be well suited for this recovery, as tested for a variety of interaction rules and different number of interacting neighbors.
The paper introduces a new method to estimate the fitness cost of drug-resistant human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) by analyzing cross-sectional sequence data. This method uses a phylodynamic approach that models a birth-death-sampling process, where a "birth" event corresponds to infecting a new host and a "death" event corresponds to removing a host from the infectious pool, such as successful treatment. The approach considers each major resistance mutation separately, and allows for the quantification of fitness costs on a population level, as well as the rates at which resistance mutations evolve and are reversed.
In a genetic search for deletion mutants with altered sensitivity to H2O2, a gene was found which is required for tRNA modification. The gene is called sin3/elp3 and encodes a component of the Elongator complex. This complex is involved in the regulation of chromatin accessibility and the transcription of stress-related genes. However, the results of the study showed that the sin3/elp3 mutant does not display enough alterations in transcriptional events to explain the substantial sensitivity to peroxides. Instead, the wobble U of tRNAs for Lys, Gln, and Glu is not modified in cells lacking Sin3/Elongator. This defect in tRNA modification seems to be sufficient to cause the oxidative stress phenotype, since cells devoid of the second modification pathway, such as Ctu1 or Ctu2, are also sensitive to stress. Furthermore, overexpression of one of these tRNA species, tRNALysUUU, is sufficient to complement all the stress defects of cells lacking Sin3/Elongator. Importantly, the results of the study also show that the mRNAs for the Atf1 and Pcr1 transcription factors, which are critical for CESR gene expression and are enriched in the AAA codon for Lys, are not greatly affected in the knock-out strain (Δsin3/elp3). However, Atf1 and Pcr1 protein levels are severely decreased in Δsin3/elp3 and Δctu2 cells. Furthermore, a mutated atf1 transcript with AAA-to-AAG lysine codons is efficiently translated in all strain backgrounds.
HIV-1 is a virus that causes AIDS. It has a protein called Nef that is involved in the virus's ability to infect cells and make copies of itself. Nef can down-regulate certain molecules on the surface of cells that HIV-1 targets, such as CD4 and MHC-I. It can also affect the behavior of T cells and macrophages. Nef is found in virions, but it is not clear how it affects the infectivity of these virions. Other virion modifications are likely responsible. Nef has been shown to interact with proteins involved in intracellular vesicle formation, which may affect the way that the virus is incorporated into virions. HIV-1 Env, the protein that helps the virus enter cells, has certain features that Nef may interact with. Neutralizing antibodies can target these features, and Nef may affect their ability to neutralize the virus. In this study, the researchers used neutralizing antibodies to investigate how Nef affects the way that HIV-1 Env interacts with them.
Cholangiocarcinoma, also known as bile duct cancer, is a common type of cancer in Southeast Asia that is caused by the food-borne parasite Opisthorchis viverrini. The parasite's life cycle involves two intermediate hosts and multiple stages of development. The parasite is ingested through the consumption of raw or undercooked fish, which are the second intermediate hosts. Infected humans are the definitive hosts, and they release the parasite's eggs through their feces. The eggs hatch in the water, and the parasite infects the first intermediate host, snails, and develops into an adult worm. The worm produces eggs that are excreted in the bile and released in the water, where they infect fish and continue the life cycle. The parasite can cause cancer of the bile ducts, which is often fatal. A better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of the parasite is needed to develop new methods for diagnosing, treating, and preventing the cancer. Recent advances in high-throughput sequencing technology and bioinformatics have provided a better understanding of the systems biology of the parasite. The first reference transcriptome of the snail intermediate host, Bithynia siamensis goniomphalos, has been generated and characterized. This sequence dataset provides a valid resource for molecular studies of these organisms and can be used to identify key molecules and biological pathways associated with the processes of invasion and survival of the parasite in the snail intermediate host.
Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease that primarily affects the skin and peripheral nervous system and can later reach other organs and systems. It is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae or M. lepromatosis and is more common in certain countries such as India, Brazil, and Indonesia. Leprosy can fit within a broad clinical spectrum with two antagonistic poles, from paucibacillary tuberculoid to multibacillary lepromatous disease. Genetic variants of the host and environmental factors influence the quality of the immune response and the development of the disease. In addition, polymorphisms of genes associated with Parkinson and Alzheimer diseases modulate susceptibility to leprosy in independent populations. The complement system includes 47 proteins and protein fragments that activate, coordinate, and regulate a proinflammatory, proteolytic cascade of the immune response. Several polymorphisms of genes of the complement system are associated with leprosy. In this study, we aim to investigate the association of polymorphisms of complement receptor 1 (CR1) with leprosy in Brazilian patients. We will also examine CR1 mRNA expression levels and serum sCR1 levels in these patients.
Metabolomics is a scientific field that analyzes the different substances (metabolites) present in an organism's biological fluids and tissues. This field helps us understand how an organism's intrinsic properties (such as genetic factors) and its exposure to lifestyle, diet, and environment affect metabolism. Metabolomic studies can involve hundreds of metabolites, which are analyzed from complex biological samples at a high rate. These metabolomic studies often involve the integration of genetic, epigenetic, transcriptomic, and proteomic data for a systems biology approach.
The aim of the paper is to discuss the use of metabolic flux analysis for understanding the behavior of metabolic networks within cells. This analysis is performed by using mathematical models that simulate the movement of metabolites and the reactions that occur within the network. However, the results of these simulations are highly dependent on the way the reaction stoichiometry is represented in the model. This can lead to incoherent predictions when different representations of the same network are used. The paper proposes a new methodology called Minimization of Metabolites Balance (MiMBl) that takes into account the reaction stoichiometry in the simulation by mapping the flux space to the metabolite turnover space. The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of this new methodology by predicting genetic interactions in the metabolic network of S. cerevisiae.
Scientists studied how the landscape affects the spread of plague in Madagascar. Plague is a disease caused by bacteria and is mainly transmitted by fleas that live on rodents. Madagascar has been dealing with plague for a long time, and many people in certain areas of the country have been infected with the bacteria. Scientists found that the areas with higher rates of plague infection in humans were also areas where the fleas carrying the disease were more genetically diverse. They think that this may be due to the different topography (landscape) of these areas. The scientists also studied the rodent populations that carry the bacteria and found that the rodent populations in areas with higher plague infection rates were more genetically diverse. They think that this may be due to the barriers (such as rivers) in the landscape that prevent the rodents from moving around. Overall, the scientists found that the landscape of the areas where plague occurs affects how the disease spreads in both the rodent and human populations.
Schistosomiasis is a disease that affects over 200 million people. Researchers have been trying to develop a vaccine to prevent the disease, but no vaccine has been successful yet. To find a potential vaccine, researchers are studying the proteins in schistosomes, the parasites that cause schistosomiasis. They found several proteins that are similar to a protein family called Ly6. These proteins have not been studied much before, but researchers think they might be important in the immune response to schistosomiasis. They studied the immune response to two of these proteins in a group of people with schistosomiasis in Uganda. They found that people with schistosomiasis had antibodies against these proteins in their blood. This suggests that these proteins might be on the surface of the parasite and could be a target for a vaccine. The study is important because it helps researchers understand the immune response to schistosomiasis and find new ways to prevent or treat the disease.
In living organisms, tissues are made of many different types of cells that have specialized functions and unique shapes. The shapes of these cells can be influenced by mechanical forces that are generated by specific molecules on the surface of cells. In this study, the researchers examined how mechanical forces control the shapes and organization of cells in the Drosophila retina, which is a thin layer of tissue that covers the back of the fly's eye. The researchers used a mechanical model to describe how the shapes of cells in the retina are influenced by the distribution and dynamic properties of the molecules that generate mechanical forces. They then used this model to test different hypotheses about how the distribution of these molecules is controlled. The researchers demonstrated that the model can successfully describe the shapes of cells in the retina, and that the model incorporates important dynamical features of morphogenesis.
The protein MT1-MMP is important for cancer cell invasion, but it is inactivated by an endogenous inhibitor that prevents persistent degradation of ECM. A recent study aimed to measure the turnover rate of MT1-MMP at a single invadopodium and analyze its role in ECM degradation. The study used FRAP experiments to analyze the turnover rate of MT1-MMP. Based on the results of these experiments, the study constructed a computational model to analyze the role of the rapid MT1-MMP turnover in ECM degradation. Simulations showed that the rapid turnover of MT1-MMP is critical for ECM degradation and that a decrease in the turnover rate of MT1-MMP would reduce ECM degradation. The study also showed that the rapid turnover of MT1-MMP works synergistically with the vesicular content of MT1-MMP in ECM degradation. Overall, the study provides a new in silico tool to design and evaluate intervention strategies in cancer cell invasion.
HIV-1 is a virus that causes AIDS. It is becoming more resistant to drugs used to treat it. It is not clear where this resistance comes from or how it spreads in the body. In this study, researchers used genetic analysis to track how HIV-1 spreads in four different parts of the body (blood, gut, lymph node, and vagina) of four monkeys infected with a virus that contains HIV-1 reverse transcriptase (RT-SHIV). The monkeys were treated with a drug that helps HIV-1 develop resistance. The researchers sampled HIV-1 from four different parts of the body before, during, and after the resistance developed. They also analyzed the genetic information from HIV-1 viral DNA and RNA taken from the same four parts of the body. By comparing the genetic information from different parts of the body, the researchers learned more about how HIV-1 spreads and how it develops resistance to drugs. This information could help doctors better understand and treat HIV-1 infection.
This paper describes the role of diffusible molecules in the formation of three-dimensional structures such as sacs, tubes, sheets, buds and branches. These molecules can create large-scale spatial patterns called Turing patterns, which can drive branching morphogenesis in the lung and digit morphogenesis in vertebrate limbs. However, the necessary conditions for Turing patterning are relatively restrictive. This paper describes a different mechanism by which diffusible signals can drive morphogenesis, not one based on creating patterns that act upstream of tissue growth or cell movement, but on regulating cell lineage progression, so that patterns arise directly out of tissue growth and cell displacement. This mechanism can create large-scale spatial structure, and generate sharply-demarcated tissue forms both spontaneously and in response to graded and/or transient extrinsic cues. Underlying this mechanism is a negative feedback loop that has primarily been studied for its role in size homeostasis of continually self-renewing tissues. However, this paper shows that negative feedback control of self-renewal can also achieve nearly perfectly robust final states for tissues that do not turn over. This paper describes the co-expression of renewal-inhibiting and renewal-promoting factors in the developing olfactory epithelium, muscle and other tissues. These opposing feedback loops can give rise to interesting dynamic or spatially-dynamic behaviors, which manifest as sharply localized differences in net growth. The paper mathematically defines the conditions required for underlying phenomena such as bistability, ultrasensitivity, and spatial self-organization to arise in such systems, and shows how they can be used to drive the formation of induced or spontaneous bulges, buds and fingers (the basic building blocks of many types of morphogenesis). The paper also shows that even though such phenomena arise out of the opposing interactions of diffusible factors, the patterns that arise are not Turing patterns. Rather, pattern formation is driven by the coupling between tissue growth and the inherent ultrasensitivity of the underlying system, and not by intrinsic differences in the spatial ranges of action of diffusible positive and negative signals.
Myopia, or nearsightedness, is a common eye condition that affects millions of people worldwide. In the United States, about 40% of adults have myopia that is severe enough to affect their vision. Myopia develops as a result of increased axial length of the eye, which causes images to be focused in front of the retina. Myopia can develop in childhood or early adolescence and tends to worsen during adolescence. It can also develop later in life as a complication of other eye conditions. While genetics plays a significant role in the development of myopia, there are many environmental factors that have also been linked to it. A genetic test called a genome-wide association study (GWAS) can identify genes that are associated with myopia. In a recent GWAS, researchers analyzed data from over 45,000 people and found 22 genes that are associated with the age of onset of myopia. Ten of these genes have not been previously identified. The researchers also analyzed data from a smaller cohort of 8,323 people and found that ten of the newly identified genes and one of the previously identified genes replicate in this cohort. This suggests that these genes may play a role in the development of myopia.
The paper focuses on the development of a computational model of the lamprey closed-loop neuromechanical system, a model organism for studying locomotion. The model includes a Hill-type muscle model, calcium dynamics, a passive structural model coupled to a viscous, incompressible Newtonian fluid using an immersed boundary formulation, and a coupled-oscillator representation of the CPG. The CPG receives feedback from proprioceptors located on the spinal cord that sense body movement. The paper examines the effects of two classes of feedback based on body curvature: directional feedback and magnitude feedback. The directional feedback provides both the magnitude and direction of curvature, while the magnitude feedback provides only the magnitude of curvature. The paper shows that the directional feedback alters the duration of muscle activation without altering the overall frequency, while the magnitude feedback is either generally excitatory or inhibitory, speeding up or slowing down the overall oscillation. The paper then integrates the CPG with the fluid dynamics model and examines the effects on swimming kinematics and energetics.
HIV infections are caused by the group M lineage of HIV-1, which jumped from chimpanzees to humans about 100 years ago. As it spread to other parts of the world, the virus became quite diverse, and distinct groups of viruses started to expand rapidly. The global diversity of HIV still shows the signs of strong "founder effects" that happened during this first expansion. In most places, HIV is dominated by only a few groups or types of the virus, and these are typically found in different groups of people, such as different ethnic or risk groups. These groups often have parallel, isolated epidemics that do not usually spread across national borders. The way that HIV spreads and changes over time in these places is not completely constant, but it happens quite slowly. Scientists have developed a model of how HIV spreads through networks of sexual contacts, which helps them understand how different strains of HIV compete with each other and how they spread over time. This model was based on information about generalized heterosexual epidemics in Africa.
During development, living organisms have specific features that help them function properly. One such feature is the arrangement of stripes in muscle cells. As muscle cells mature, their stripes get rearranged from a scattered pattern to tightly bundled groups that span the length of the cell instead of the width. Scientists have studied how these bundles form from their molecular parts, but we still don't know how they organize into their specialized pattern. This is important because changes in muscle structure can occur not only during development but also during diseases. Muscle cells contract in a force-dependent way, suggesting that their contraction may play a role in organizing their stripes. Scientists have observed this in non-muscle cells, where the cytoskeleton within a defined area becomes organized with increasing force. So, we hypothesized that the shape of the extracellular environment can guide the organization of the intracellular architecture and potentiate stripe formation. Because it's hard to see new stripes form in living muscle cells, scientists study this process by making muscle cells assume shapes they don't normally have in vivo using engineered substrates in a lab. To help guide these experiments, scientists developed a computer model that shows how the intracellular architecture changes depending on the shape of the extracellular environment. By comparing the computer model with their experimental results, scientists were able to figure out the roles of different parts of the stripe formation process and how they are guided spatially by the shape of the extracellular environment. After understanding these roles, scientists expanded their model to test how these architectures affect the muscle cells' function. They engineered muscle cells to have different shapes and measured their contraction strength compared to the computer model's results. Together, these results suggest that the self-assembly and organization of the stripes is facilitated by a symmetry-breaking event that is potentiated by either a geometric cue in the extracellular environment or a random event in the intracellular environment.
Dengue fever is a serious and widespread disease that affects millions of people around the world. There is currently no effective vaccine or cure, making it important to develop alternative methods of control. One promising approach is the use of Wolbachia, an endosymbiotic bacterium that is naturally present in many insect species. Wolbachia can be used to reduce dengue transmission by infecting the mosquitoes that carry the dengue virus. Wolbachia can prevent or severely reduce infection by dengue in the mosquito host, as well as preventing females from producing viable offspring without Wolbachia. This makes it easier for Wolbachia to spread through the mosquito population. The use of Wolbachia as a biocontrol tool has been successful in reducing dengue transmission in field trials in Australia, Vietnam, and Indonesia. However, the effectiveness of Wolbachia may vary depending on the physical, environmental, and socioeconomic conditions at different locations. Therefore, it is important to identify these conditions and determine if they could potentially limit the spread of Wolbachia. This work aimed to determine whether the likelihood of a successful Wolbachia invasion could be influenced by differences between release sites in preparation for the release of Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes in Brazil. The results of this study show that successful invasion is likely for all sites; however, the means by which this occurs may vary between sites. The results of this work can help to develop optimized release strategies for each field site, which will greatly benefit the upcoming biocontrol trials.
Histone methylation is an important way that cells change the way they use their DNA. It affects how genes are turned on or off, which can impact everything from our health to our behavior. There are enzymes that can add or remove methyl groups, and scientists are trying to learn more about them. One of the enzymes they are focusing on is called JMJ703. JMJ703 is an enzyme that can remove methyl groups from histones. Scientists have found that it is important for the growth and development of plants, and they have studied its structure and function. They have found that it is similar to other enzymes in that it can remove methyl groups, but it also has unique features that make it different from other enzymes. They also found that certain parts of the enzyme are important for its function, and that some of these parts are shared with other types of enzymes that have similar functions. This can help scientists understand how these enzymes work, and how they can be used to help with medical problems like cancer.
HIV-1 infection is a complex process that involves many host factors. Cyclophilin A (CypA), karyopherin substrate CPSF6, nuclear import/pore proteins TNPO3, NUP153, NUP358, and LEDGF have all been shown to play a role in HIV-1 infection. These factors are recruited by the viral core, and play a key role in reverse transcription, capsid uncoating, nuclear entry, and integration. Different factors may act at different stages of HIV-1 infection and are likely to work together in a coordinated way. The viral capsid plays a crucial role in the recruitment of these factors and how they influence each other. The importance of each factor is dependent on a specific residue in the viral capsid protein CA, which is important for binding to the host factors and for reverse transcription. The crystal structures of the complexes formed between CA and the different host factors reveal that these factors bind to different sites on CA. CPSF6 and TNPO3 have a common binding motif, but their interactions with CA are distinct. The crystal structures provide a molecular basis for the association of these factors with the viral core and for the resulting effects on HIV-1 infection.
The mosquito Aedes aegypti can spread dangerous diseases like dengue, yellow fever, and chikungunya. This mosquito species originated in Africa and was spread globally through trade and travel. In the 1960s, Ae. aegypti was virtually eliminated from 21 countries in the Americas through a continental eradication effort. However, the mosquito has re-established itself in many regions and causes diseases in humans. Scientists have been trying to control the mosquitoes with methods like releasing transgenic males and infecting the mosquitoes with bacteria. However, these methods are not yet effective, and scientists need to understand more about the mosquitoes' genome to create better control techniques. The mosquito Ae. aegypti has a large genome that is difficult to assemble. To understand the genome better, scientists have used genetic and physical mapping techniques to identify the location of scaffolds on the chromosomes. In addition, they have found a major resistance locus to the filarial nematode Brugia malayi on the first chromosome, which could potentially be used as a genetic tool to compare vector populations and understand vector competence in different mosquito populations.
This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of different types of traps for catching mosquitoes. Four traps were used to catch mosquitoes: the ovitrap, MosquiTRAP, Adultrap, and BioGent-Sentinel. The study took place in five cities in Brazil that were monitored simultaneously. The results showed that all traps caught mosquitoes, but the Adultrap trap was more effective. The study also found that trap indices were consistent over time, but larval indices were not always consistent. Overall, the results suggest that using traps for mosquito surveillance is a viable alternative to using larval surveys.
The human protein APOBEC3G (A3G) is a protein that prevents HIV-1 from replicating in human cells. A3G has two CDA domains, and both of them are needed to stop HIV-1 from replicating. The crystal structure of APOBEC3G and a related protein called APOBEC2 has been studied, and it has been found that these proteins can form tetramers. A tetramer is a group of four proteins that form a complex together. It has been shown that A3G also forms tetramers, but it is not as well understood as the tetramer formation of APOBEC3G. In this study, the authors show that hydrophobic residues that are important for the tetramer formation of A3G are also important for its ability to stop HIV-1 from replicating. They also show that a positively charged pocket at the predicted dimer interface of A3G is important for its ability to stop HIV-1 from replicating.
The authors sequenced the bab locus, which controls pigmentation in the adult cuticle of Drosophila, from 96 flies to understand the genetic variation responsible for this trait. Bab is made up of two anciently duplicated paralogs that are involved in patterning the adult abdomen, legs, and ovaries. Previous studies have shown that bab alleles are responsible for 60% of the genetic variation in female abdominal pigmentation within a natural population of Drosophila. The authors found that the bab locus extends for less than 1 kb, providing an opportunity to dissect the causative nucleotide variation that contributes to the cumulative effect of QTL alleles. They also found evidence of directional selection in two regions within the bab locus, including a cis-regulatory element that controls sex-specific abdominal pigmentation. The authors were able to identify specific DNA polymorphisms responsible for variation in gene expression and, ultimately, in pigmentation.
The bacteria known as Streptococcus pneumoniae (or pneumococcus) lives in the human nose and throat and is a common cause of pneumonia, meningitis, and other infections. The pneumococcus is well adapted to living in the nose and throat because it can change its outer coating (capsule) easily, which helps it to avoid being recognized and eliminated by the body's immune system. Pneumococcus is able to change its capsule because it has a special system that allows it to take up and exchange genetic material with other bacteria. This system, called "competence," is controlled by a quorum sensing system that responds to a chemical signal called CSP. When the quorum sensing system is activated, the pneumococcus becomes competent and can take up new genetic material, which may help it to survive in the competitive environment of the nose and throat. The pneumococcus also produces bacteriocins, which are chemicals that kill other bacteria. The production of bacteriocins is controlled by a system called "blp" and is also regulated by the quorum sensing system that responds to CSP. When the quorum sensing system is activated, the pneumococcus becomes competent and may also produce bacteriocins, which can kill other bacteria and help the pneumococcus to take up new genetic material. This genetic material could come from other bacteria that the pneumococcus kills with its bacteriocins. Overall, the ability of the pneumococcus to change its capsule and produce bacteriocins helps it to survive and compete in the complex environment of the nose and throat.
Translation of eukaryotic mRNAs typically occurs via a cap-dependent mechanism ( Figure 1A ) where the 7-methyl guanosine cap at the 5′ end of the mRNA is recognized by the eukaryotic initiation factor 4F (eIF4F) cap binding complex. The eIF4F complex consists of three proteins: eIF4A, eIF4G, and eIF4E. The complex then recruits the ribosome to the mRNA for translation initiation. The 40S ribosomal subunit binds to the 5′ noncoding region (5′ NCR) of the RNA and translation initiation occurs a few hundred nucleotides downstream from the cap. However, some viruses, like picornaviruses, have evolved a cap-independent translation initiation mechanism ( Figure 1B ) where the 40S ribosomal subunit binds to an RNA sequence, structure, or ribonucleoprotein complex in the 5′ NCR of the RNA. This mechanism involves internal entry of ribosomes for translation initiation. The binding of ribosomes to the RNA occurs without a 5′ cap and involves specific sequences and structures within the 5′ NCR. The poliovirus and encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) viral genomic RNAs were the first RNAs found to contain sequences in their 5′ NCRs, termed internal ribosome entry sites (IRESes), which mediate the internal binding of ribosomes for translation initiation. During almost all picornavirus infections, cap-dependent translation is shut-down via cleavage of translation factors by viral proteinases. The viruses utilize IRES-mediated translation initiation to direct the synthesis of viral proteins. Certain IRES trans-activating factors (ITAFs), such as poly (rC) binding protein 2 (PCBP2), have been extensively studied for their role in picornavirus translation. PCBP2 is a 38 kDa cellular RNA binding protein that has been associated with RNA stability and translational regulation of cellular mRNAs. This protein is also known to bind the 5′ NCR of several picornavirus RNAs. For poliovirus, the binding of PCBP2 to stem-loop IV in the IRES is required for translation, and depletion of PCBP2 from cell-free extracts results in a dramatic decrease in viral translation. Poliovirus also requires the interaction of PCBP2 with cellular splicing factor SRp20, and these two proteins have been shown to function synergistically in poliovirus translation. SRp20 is a 20 kDa RNA binding protein that shuttles between the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells, and contains one RNA-recognition motif (RRM) and one serine/arginine-rich (RS) domain. SRp20 functions in constitutive splicing as well as alternative splice site selection in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. In this study, we observed a dramatic re-localization of SRp20 from the nucleus to the cytoplasm of poliovirus-infected cells, where we also observed partial co-localization with PCBP2 during infection. We also demonstrated that both PCBP2 and SRp20 partially co-sediment in translation initiation complex-containing fractions. Finally, we designed a deleted version of SRp20 lacking one of its functional domains (denoted SRp20ΔRRM), and determined that its localization in mock- and poliovirus-infected cells (and co-localization with PCBP2) resembled that of the wild type SRp20 protein. Significantly, expression of SRp20 lacking the RRM domain resulted in an approximate two-log decrease in virus yield for poliovirus when compared to expression of wild type SRp20. Taken together, these results support the model that SRp20 interacts with PCBP2 on poliovirus RNA, and this interaction functions either directly or indirectly to recruit the translation machinery to the viral RNA for IRES-mediated translation initiation.
The neural crest (NC) is a group of cells that form during the development of a fetus. These cells can turn into many different types of cells, such as the pigment cells of skin, the nerve cells of the nervous system, and the cells that make up the heart. There are many diseases that can happen when the NC cells don't develop properly, which is called a neurocristopathy. One gene that is important for NC cells to develop properly is Sox10. Mice that have a mutation in Sox10 can show symptoms like those seen in neurocristopathies. These mice are also useful for studying the development of NC cells because they have a gene that reports where the Sox10 protein is expressed in the mouse. We used this gene to study how Sox10 works during NC cell development. We found four mutations that changed the way Sox10 was expressed in the mouse. One of these mutations was caused by a mistake in the Erbb3 gene. This mistake caused the protein made by this gene to be a little different, and this change affected the way that the NC cells developed. We showed that this little change was enough to stop the NC cells from developing properly, which led to embryonic lethality.
Schistosomiasis is a common disease that affects over 200 million people worldwide. A study has been done in a fishing community in Uganda to better understand the factors that contribute to reinfection with the parasite. The study found that age and sex are important factors that contribute to the risk of reinfection. It also found that the Alur people in this community may be more susceptible to infection. The study also explored the role of immune responses to schistosomes in protecting against reinfection. By taking a multidisciplinary approach, the study was able to better capture and adjust for variations in exposure, leading to more robust conclusions.
Clonorchiasis is a disease caused by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish infected with Clonorchis sinensis, a type of parasitic flatworm. Although patients with clonorchiasis often do not show any symptoms, it can lead to serious complications such as cholangiocarcinoma. Therefore, it is important to diagnose and treat clonorchiasis as early as possible. There are several methods for diagnosing clonorchiasis, including fecal examination, serology, and ultrasonography of the liver. The Kato-Katz (KK) method is a way of counting the number of eggs in feces that can estimate the intensity of infection. In this study, we recovered adult Clonorchis sinensis worms from 42 egg-positive and 10 egg-negative individuals in a hyperendemic area, and compared the number of worms with the number of eggs counted using the KK method. We found a correlation between the number of worms and the number of eggs counted in the feces of infected individuals. This suggests that counting the number of worms could be a direct method of diagnosing clonorchiasis, especially in cases with high egg counts.
The authors present a study where they used genetic screens to identify new targets for antifungal drugs against Candida glabrata, a species that causes fungal infections and is resistant to azole drugs. The authors used a genetic approach to identify synthetic lethal and synthetic sick interactions with mutations in the PDR1 gene, which is involved in azole resistance. They then used this data to identify small molecule inhibitors that could be used to treat azole resistant C. glabrata infections.
Poliovirus, a type of enterovirus, infects cells by invading the cytoplasm and replicating its genetic material. The events between virus entry and the start of exponential amplification of the genetic material are called the eclipse phase. The eclipse phase includes important steps like the translation of viral proteins, the establishment of the site of replication, and the assembly of the virus. The study by Ehrenfeld et al. used electron tomography to observe the structures induced by poliovirus during the eclipse phase. The authors found that the most dramatic changes to the cell membrane occurred after the replication of the viral genetic material had started. They also found that the virus-induced organelle, previously thought to be located in the perinuclear region of the cell, is actually made up of a network of vesicles. The authors concluded that the vesicles are the virus-assembly organelle, a site where new viral particles are made and assembled. However, the authors also found that the network of vesicles was not present in the earliest stages of the eclipse phase. Instead, the earliest events included remodeling of cell membranes and the formation of tubular membranes. The authors suggest that tubular membranes are the genome-replication organelle, a site where the viral genetic material is copied. The authors also found that a mutant strain of poliovirus, which cannot be cleaved at a specific site, has a longer eclipse phase and exhibits defects in the assembly of infectious virus particles. They suggest that vesicular clusters, which are thought to be a later stage organelle, may contribute to steps after genome replication that are required for the production of infectious virus. Overall, the study provides important insights into the structure and function of the organelles that are induced during the eclipse phase of poliovirus infection. It also highlights the importance of the P3 proteins in the formation and function of these organelles.
Chagas disease is a disease that can be caused by a parasite called Trypanosoma cruzi . The parasite's life cycle involves two replicative forms, an epimastigote in the insect vector and an amastigote in the infected mammal . The disease can have an acute phase or a chronic phase, with the acute phase starting shortly after infection and the chronic phase developing over many years. The acute phase may not be noticed because it is symptom-free or exhibits only mild symptoms that are not unique to Chagas disease. The chronic phase can cause symptoms that affect the heart, nervous and digestive systems . Chagas disease can be treated with nifurtimox and benznidazole, but these drugs are not effective in chronically infected patients and have severe side effects. The development of new, safer and more effective drugs to treat Chagas disease is important. A protein called cruzain has been identified as a potential target for drug development, and has excellent pre-clinical validation evidence . Several classes of peptide and non-peptide inhibitors have been identified as effective at inhibiting cruzain. In this study, a screening of a database of commercially-available compounds for virtual screening was performed, followed by enzymatic assays, X-ray crystallography and SAR studies. Of the compounds screened, five were found to be trypanocidal, meaning they were able to kill the infective form of the parasite. A new fragment of the 2-acetamidothiophene-3-carboxamide class was also identified, which can advance the search for new non-covalent cruzain inhibitors.
The yellow fever (YF) virus causes a disease that results in over 200,000 cases and 30,000 deaths per year, with 90% of cases occurring in Africa. Currently, the only effective way to prevent YF infection is through vaccination. However, despite improvements in the manufacturing process and quality control, severe side effects resulting from vaccination continue to be reported. In view of this, the development of alternative vaccination strategies, such as DNA-based vaccines, has been considered. In this study, researchers investigated T-cell and humoral immune responses to the envelope of YF virus in mice immunized with DNA formulations expressing the full-length YF envelope protein, either as a wild-type or fused to LAMP. The results showed that the YF 17DD vaccine produced higher neutralizing antibody titers than the DNA vaccines. However, both DNA vaccine constructs encoding the entire E protein were also able to protect the mice against lethal challenge.
V. cholerae, the bacteria responsible for cholera, naturally lives in the marine environment and forms biofilms on the shells of microscopic crustaceans called zooplankton. These zooplankton have chitin shells, which are made up of N-acetylglucosamine. Chitin is the second most abundant biopolymer on the planet, and Vibrio species play an important role in recycling it in the aquatic environment. Chitin is also important for cholera transmission to humans because cholera outbreaks are seasonal and closely associated with blooms of chitinous zooplankton. Chitin oligosaccharides can also make V. cholerae more likely to take up and use chitin as a source of food and energy. Chitin degradation, uptake, and utilization are regulated by a protein called ChiS. ChiS is normally turned off by a protein called CBP, which binds to chitin oligosaccharides. However, ChiS can be turned on by deleting CBP or by exposing it to chitin oligosaccharides. In this study, the authors screened for proteins that are required for ChiS to turn on the chb operon, which encodes the genes that help V. cholerae take up and use chitin. They found a new transcriptional activator that helps turn on the chb operon.
This paper presents a novel nonlinear programming (NLP) framework for solving large-scale parameter estimation problems arising in biological models. The framework is based on a direct transcription approach that converts the dynamic model into a large set of algebraic equations by applying time-discretization techniques. The resulting NLPs are of high dimension (hundreds of thousands to millions of variables and constraints) but are also sparse and structured. The sparsity and structure of the NLPs allow for efficient handling of many parameters and experimental data sets, and the availability of derivative information enables efficient solution using advanced optimization methods. The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed framework by solving challenging parameter estimation problems arising in microbial community models and shows that the framework can be easily extended to handle advanced estimation formulations. The paper also introduces a novel problem formulation for parameter estimation using risk measures.
The West Nile virus (WNV) is a disease-causing virus that naturally occurs in parts of the Americas, Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. It is transmitted by mosquitoes and infects birds, humans, and other animals. Humans infected with WNV develop a febrile illness that is self-resolving, but a subset of cases may develop meningitis or encephalitis. WNV has become a major public health concern in North America. From 1999 to 2012, over 37,000 cases of WNV infections were reported in the US, of which 16,114 were neuroinvasive and 1,549 were fatal. Since its introduction in 1999, the US has experienced annual epidemics of WNV disease, with a peak in 2002-2003. Since then, the number of cases has remained relatively constant until a sudden increase in 2012. Large outbreaks of neuroinvasive disease in humans and horses involving multiple lineages of WNV have also been reported in European countries. Researchers have used various mouse models, including inbred and outbred mice, to study the host response to WNV infection and identify aspects of innate and adaptive immune responses that offer protection against WNV infection. Microarray analysis has been used to detect changes in gene expression after viral infection in order to better understand the immune mechanisms governing viral pathogenesis. The nCounter molecular detection and quantitation system was used to examine how infection with highly neuroinvasive WNV strain 382–99 (often termed “NY99”) altered the kinetics of the inflammatory response over the course of infection in a common outbred mouse model of neuroinvasive WNV disease. Genes common to multiple tissues that are differentially expressed when WNV RNA is detected and genes that are differentially expressed in a tissue-specific manner following active WNV infection across multiple tissues over the entire course of infection are reported.
Rabies is a deadly virus that affects the central nervous system. It is caused by a bite from an infected animal, usually a rabid dog. Rabies is a major health problem in many low and middle income countries, and Mozambique is one of the countries with the highest burden. The Mozambican government has a plan to control rabies, but it is not well implemented. In Maputo City, Mozambique, a rabies outbreak was discovered in July 2014. To investigate the outbreak and determine the risk factors for developing rabies, researchers collected information on human rabies cases and animal bites in the city and neighboring Matola City. They found that most of the rabies cases were in children and that the incubation period of rabies in children was shorter than in adults. They also found that people who did not receive post-exposure prophylaxis after being bitten by a dog were more likely to develop rabies. The researchers hope that their findings will help the Mozambican government develop better strategies to control rabies and prevent future outbreaks.
Fevers are the most common cause of seizures in young children, known as Febrile Seizures (FS). These seizures affect 2-5% of European and North American children. Studies suggest a genetic cause for FS, as they run in families and siblings of those with FS have a 2-9% chance of developing seizures later in life. Some of these later-onset seizures can be severe and resistant to anticonvulsant therapy. These seizures include generalized convulsive, as well as simple and complex partial seizures. FS can also be a sign of a more serious condition called Dravet syndrome, which is an early-onset epilepsy disorder characterized by prolonged and non-discriminatory lateralized seizures. Dravet syndrome is caused by a mutation in the SCN1A gene that encodes the alpha subunit of the sodium channel. However, some patients with Dravet syndrome do not have a mutation in the SCN1A gene, suggesting a complex genetic etiology. Linkage analysis identified a 10 centimorgan region on chromosome 2q24 containing five sodium channel α subunit genes, including SCN1A, that are highly expressed in the brain. These genes have been linked to epilepsy and seizure susceptibility.
This paper introduces a new framework, called GPT-framework, for modeling how tissues grow and develop into specific shapes. To create this framework, the authors start by explaining how growth and shape are related to one another. They point out that final shape is not directly determined by locally specified properties, but rather depends on the mechanical constraints of the surrounding tissue. They then describe two ways in which genes can influence how tissue grows. In one way, they say, genes control the rate at which a particular region of tissue grows. In another way, they say, genes control the direction in which a particular region of tissue grows. They also explain how stresses in the tissue can act as cues for orienting growth. The authors then introduce a new concept, called "polarity," which describes the direction in which a particular region of tissue grows. They say that this concept is similar to the concept of stress, but rather than stresses acting as cues for orienting growth, polarity acts as a cue for orienting growth. The authors then describe how polarity can be generated by the concentration of signaling molecules. They say that this concept is useful for understanding how tissue develops into specific shapes. They then introduce a new software program, called GFtbox, that can be used to create models of tissue growth and development.
