Although Ascaris, Trichuris, and hookworm infections are likely to self-resolve within 1 to 6 years after arrival, Strongyloides infections are likely to persist for many years after arrival. Previously published work suggested that presumptive treatment of immigrants from high-burden countries with albendazole and ivermectin is cost-effective. However, these earlier studies had limited data on the burden of disease in these populations and were out-of-date because of the changing cost of interventions and testing. Newly available data allow for more accurate estimates of the burden and consequences of these infections in refugee populations. We also have detailed cost estimates for overseas programs from ongoing or pilot programs. These new data can be used to quantify the economic impact of CDC’s presumptive treatment recommendations for Asian refugees, both the proposed but largely unimplemented use of ivermectin and the already-implemented albendazole. We selected the Asian refugee population for this study to focus on albendazole and ivermectin. The African refugee population was excluded from the analysis because they also receive praziquantel for schistosomiasis and coartem for malaria. However, an analysis of presumptive treatment of African refugees with albendazole and ivermectin is included in the appendix. Our analytic objective was to quantify and compare the benefits and costs of overseas presumptive treatment with domestic screening and treatment programs and no intervention for intestinal parasitoses. The conditions included in the analysis were infections with Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichiura, hookworm, and Strongyloides stercoralis. Per CDC guidelines, domestic screening (stool samples + serology for Strongyloides) is unnecessary for refugees that receive presumptive treatment overseas unless they present with clinical symptoms or persistent eosinophilia.
A new species of microsporidia was found infecting non-intestinal tissues of a wild-caught Caenorhabditis elegans animal. The new species has a broader tissue tropism compared to other Nematocida species identified to date and infects a wide array of tissues and cell types, including the intestine, epidermis, muscle, neurons, and specialized phagocytic cells called coelomocytes. However, the majority of intestinal infection fails to replicate. The new species' genome contains an enormously expanded species-specific gene family encoding for RING-domain containing proteins of unknown function, which may explain its distinct infection life cycle.
Cockayne syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that causes developmental and neurological problems, sun sensitivity, and premature aging. It is caused by mutations in a gene called CSB (Cockayne syndrome complementation group B), which is important for DNA repair and transcription regulation. CSB is a type of protein called SNF2/SWI2 ATP-dependent chromatin remodeler. It can reposition nucleosomes, which are the basic units of DNA packaging, and this activity is greatly enhanced by certain types of proteins called NAP1-like histone chaperones. CSB and these chaperones work together to establish a chromatin environment that is conducive for DNA repair and/or transcription resumption after repair.
Scientists have been studying how our genetic information differs from one person to another for quite a while now. However, they have recently discovered that our epigenetic information, such as DNA methylation levels, also vary among individuals. This study used data from five different human cell types to identify regions of common epigenetic variation. These regions, called variably methylated regions, contain hundreds of loci that show highly variable DNA methylation levels. The study found that these regions co-localize with other functional genomic features and are enriched for CpGs that influence gene expression. The study also provides evidence that environmental factors play a role in shaping the epigenome. By looking at how methylation levels at these regions change in response to the environment, the study sheds new light on the relationship between our genetic information, the environment, and our health.
Dengue is a viral infection that affects millions of people worldwide. It is caused by a group of four different viruses and is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes. The disease can range from a mild fever to a potentially deadly condition called Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever and Dengue Shock Syndrome. There is no cure for the disease, but there are diagnostic tools available to help doctors identify it early, such as a dengue NS1 detection test. This test can be done quickly and requires minimal technical expertise, making it a useful tool in areas where medical resources are limited. The test has been evaluated in two separate study sites in Southeast Asia and has shown promising results in helping doctors identify dengue cases.
RNA molecules play a variety of roles in cellular processes, such as translation. RNA structure is crucial for its function in the cell. RNA structure can be predicted from the sequence using computational methods. However, these methods cannot predict the entire folding pathway or the structure of transient structures. The program RNAkinetics can simulate the folding of an emerging RNA sequence, taking into account co-transcriptional folding. The program Kinefold can model the kinetic folding pathway for a given sequence. Kinefold can also model dynamic transcription speeds. The programs Kinwalker and Transat are used for studying RNA folding pathways in vivo.
This study focuses on the function of specific genes in a plant immune signaling network. It is known that non-additive interactions between genes can affect their function. This study aims to quantify these interactions to understand the overall network function of plant immune signaling. It is important to understand these interactions because mutations in specific genes may have unexpected effects on the immune response. The study uses a plant pathogen, the bacterium Pseudomonas syringae, and the plant hormones jasmonic acid (JA), salicylic acid (SA), and ethylene (ET). The study uses a combination of genetic and biochemical techniques to understand how these hormones interact in the immune response. The study concludes that network interactions are important in the immune response, and that the buffering of gene function is crucial for the overall network function. It also highlights the limitations of using mutant analysis to understand complex biological networks like the immune response.
Scientists have studied how the fruit fly's visual system develops and how it is patterned during embryogenesis. They found that the visual system develops from a small area called the optic placode, which forms in the head of the embryo. The placode is made up of cells that can become either photoreceptor (PR) neurons or non-PR neurons. The cells that become PR neurons are divided into two types: primary and secondary. The scientists found that a protein called Atonal (Ato) helps promote the formation of primary PR neurons, while the protein Tailless (Tll) helps maintain non-PR cells. The scientists also found that Hedgehog (Hh) and Notch signaling are important during early patterning of the optic lobe. The Hh protein is needed for the development of many different types of cells, while Notch prevents cells from becoming neurons. The scientists also found that Ato is initially expressed in all PR neuron precursors in the placode, but its expression gets progressively restricted to primary PR neuron precursors. They also found that primary PR neuron precursors recruit secondary precursors using a protein called Spitz, which is produced by primary precursors. After that, other proteins like Senseless, Spalt, Seven-up, and Orthodenticle help determine which type of PR neurons will form. The scientists also found that tll and ato expression mark different domains of the optic placode: tll is expressed in cells that will form the optic lobe, while ato is expressed in cells that will form the larval eye precursors. They found that tll regulates ato expression, and that Notch represses ato expression by promoting tll expression. They also found that Hh signaling regulates cell number in the optic placode and controls PR subtype specification in an ato- and sens-dependent manner. Finally, they found that Notch has two distinct roles in larval eye development: it initially represses ato expression by promoting tll expression, and later it represses sens expression to control the binary cell fate decision of primary versus secondary PR precursors. In summary, the scientists found a network of genetic interactions that pattern neuroepithelial cells of the optic placode and ensure timely specification of neuronal subtypes during development.
The innate immune system is the body's first line of defense against infection from microbes. Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are small molecules that are part of the innate immune system and help protect the human body from bacterial overgrowth. They shape the microbiota, which is the collection of microorganisms that live inside the body, and help keep them in balance. One type of AMP is called defensins, which are small cationic peptides with disulfide-bonds. There are two types of defensins: alpha-defensins and beta-defensins. These defensins are important for fighting off bacteria and viruses. One beta-defensin in particular, hBD1, is important for innate immunity because it is constitutively expressed in all human epithelia. In this study, we used electron microscopy to observe how hBD1, which is reduced in the human intestine, affects the structure of bacteria. We found that hBD1red forms a net-like structure around bacteria, which helps to inhibit their growth. We also found that hBD1ox, which has three closed disulfide bonds, does not have this net-like structure and does not have the same effect on bacteria. This study shows that hBD1 provides distinct and complementary killing-based and killing-independent antimicrobial mechanisms, supporting its diverse and important role in shaping the microbiota.
Lowe syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that causes cataracts, mental retardation, and kidney problems. It's caused by a mutation in a gene called OCRL1, which is involved in endocytosis, the process by which cells absorb nutrients and other substances from their environment. The zebrafish model has been generated to better understand the disease mechanisms of Lowe syndrome. The model has shown that endocytosis in the kidney is impaired, which may cause kidney problems. The model also shows that OCRL1 is required for efficient endocytosis in vivo, and supports the hypothesis that endocytic defects give rise to the renal manifestations of Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease.
Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a mosquito-borne illness that affects both humans and animals. It occurs in cycles of 5 to 15 years in Eastern Africa and the Horn of Africa. It is caused by the Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV), a member of the genus Phlebovirus in the family Bunyaviridae. In humans, RVF can cause mild illness or severe illness. The disease is an occupational hazard for people in close contact with infected animals, such as livestock keepers, abattoir workers, laboratory workers, veterinarians, and others. In recent years, evidence of RVF transmission during the inter-epidemic periods has been reported in some parts of Africa. To investigate potential inter-epidemic period transmission of RVF in an area experiencing seasonal floods annually, we conducted a study in Morogoro region of Tanzania, where the Kilombero River valley is located. Our goal was to establish baseline information on the exposure status to RVF in livestock and assess the relationship between RVF seropositivity, animal characteristics, and environmental factors.
The contractile vacuole complex (CVC) is a structure in some protists that stores water and helps regulate the amount of water in the cell. T. cruzi, which causes Chagas disease, has a CVC. T. cruzi cells can shrink or expand based on the amount of water they need. In addition, the CVC can help move proteins from inside the cell to the surface. Some of these proteins, like TcTS, TcTSSA II, and mucins, are important for T. cruzi to survive and cause disease. The CVC can help move these proteins to the surface of the cell. It's not clear exactly how this happens, but it may involve a special part of the CVC that is like a lipid raft. TcRab11, a protein that is important for moving things inside cells, is also found in the CVC. Changing the amount of TcRab11 in the cell can change the shape of the CVC, the way water is regulated in the cell, and how TcTS is moved to the surface. This suggests that the CVC may use an unconventional way of moving proteins from inside the cell to the surface. This new way of moving proteins may be different from what happens in other cells.
Rabies is a serious illness that can cause death, and it is caused by a virus. It is still a big problem in many countries, especially in Asia and Africa. The WHO is working to eliminate the disease, but it is still listed as a "neglected tropical disease" because prevention is not always good in certain places where medical care is not good. There are different ways to prevent rabies, but the most common is called post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). This includes vaccinations and other treatments. In some places, a special kind of vaccine called "human rabies immunoglobulin" is also used. However, it is not always easy for people in these places to get the full treatment because they may not have easy access to medical care. This can be a problem because you need to take the full treatment to be effective. To solve this problem, researchers have found a way to take the treatment in just one week instead of four weeks. This new method uses four vaccinations instead of two, and they are given on different days (D0, D3, and D7). This new method has shown good results in clinical trials. Researchers wanted to show that the new method was just as good as the current method, which is the updated 2-site/TRC regimen with or without concomitant administration of human rabies immunoglobulin. They used a purified chick embryo cell culture vaccine and found that the new method was just as effective as the current method.
The human brain is a complex system capable of supporting a wide range of adaptive goal-relevant behaviors. The salience network (SN) is a crucial part of this system and plays a role in cognition and emotion by detecting and attentional capturing of goal-relevant stimuli. The SN is composed of two nodes: the anterior insula (AI) and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC). The SN is ubiquitously involved in various cognitive tasks, and atypical functional engagement of the SN is a common feature of several neuropsychiatric disorders. The goal of this study is to investigate the dynamic spatiotemporal properties of the SN using high temporal-resolution fMRI data and novel graph-theoretical techniques. We focus on the spatial and topological properties of SN interactions within a whole-brain system that includes key nodes of the SN as well as a large set of brain regions that have been implicated in a wide range of cognition paradigms. We found that the SN has a rich repertoire of distinctive features that are behaviorally significant. We demonstrate the test-retest reliability and robustness of all our findings across two datasets.
The virus life cycle is a series of steps that are tightly controlled, starting from binding to a host cell, to assembly, and finally to the release of viral progeny. Most enveloped virions exit the cell by budding or membrane fission. Nonenveloped viral release usually requires cell lysis after viral replication. However, a cytolytic pathway that avoids apoptosis would be advantageous to ensure optimal viral release. SV40 is a virus that serves as a good paradigm to study the nonenveloped viral life cycle, including viral release. VP4 is a protein found in the viral particle of SV40. It has a hydrophobic domain that plays a role in membrane disruption to trigger viral release. VP4 efficiently binds red blood cell and liposome membranes and forms small pores in mammalian membranes. Deleting or substituting the hydrophobic domain of VP4 abolishes its membrane disruptive activity. These results suggest that VP4 plays a central role in the direct disruption of cellular membranes to trigger SV40 viral release.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne disease that affects millions of people each year. It can lead to severe symptoms like plasma leakage, hemorrhage, and shock. The dengue virus has four different types and the disease can be caused by infection from any of them. The virus has a single-stranded RNA genome that is translated into a polyprotein. The polyprotein is then broken down into several proteins, including a protein called NS1. The NS1 protein can be found in mammalian cells and is secreted into the circulation as a soluble multimer. It is highly immunogenic and can elicit both protective and potentially pathogenic immune responses. The pcTPANS1 DNA vaccine encodes the NS1 protein and has been shown to be protective against dengue in mice. This protection is in part due to the activation of CD4+ T cells and the production of anti-NS1 antibodies. Our data provides important insights into the immunity elicited by DENV NS1 antigen and its role in protection against dengue, as well as a potential for vaccine development.
This study focuses on a family of proteins called RNPP that help bacteria communicate with each other and regulate important biological processes. These proteins are made up of a tetratricopeptide-repeat (TPR) domain and a histidine kinase domain. The TPR domain is responsible for binding to specific peptides, while the histidine kinase domain is responsible for activating target genes. The researchers solved the structure of one of these proteins, Rgg2, and found that it has a unique mechanism of activation. They also suggest that this mechanism is shared by other proteins in this family. This study provides important insights into how bacteria communicate and regulate important biological processes.
Scientists have discovered a new type of ion channels called pentameric ligand-gated ion channels (pLGICs). These channels are important for controlling the flow of ions in and out of cells, and they are found in many different types of cells throughout the body. The scientists studied two types of pLGICs from bacteria, one called ELIC and the other called GLIC. They found that ELIC and GLIC have similar structures but different functions. While GLIC opens when the pH of the surrounding fluid becomes more acidic, ELIC does not open in response to changes in pH. The scientists also found that ELIC has a non-conducting conformation of the pore, which is different from the conducting conformation of GLIC. They used X-ray crystallography to study the structure of ELIC in more detail and found that it has a pocket in its ligand-binding domain that is similar in size and shape to the pocket in the acetycholine binding protein (AChBP). This finding led them to investigate whether ELIC could be activated by a ligand similar to the ones that activate the AChBP. They found that ELIC could be opened by a class of primary amines, which they called ELIC-activating ligands (EALs). EALs bind to the pocket in the ligand-binding domain of ELIC and open the channel by a strongly cooperative process. Although the channels are stable after opening, they eventually desensitize, meaning that they become less responsive to subsequent stimulation. The scientists also found that the open channel of ELIC conducts ions in a way that is similar to the way that other pLGICs conduct ions, and they have determined the selectivity of the channel. Their findings may help to understand how pLGICs work and may have important implications for human health.
The article you are referring to discusses the connection between atopic dermatitis (AD) and asthma. Asthma is a chronic lung disease that causes airway obstruction and inflammation, while AD is a skin condition characterized by redness, itching, and inflammation. It has been observed that AD patients have an increased risk of developing asthma later in life. In this article, the authors explore the mechanisms behind this connection by comparing the genetic and immune responses of AD patients and asthma patients. They propose that a combination of genetic and immune factors may contribute to the development of asthma in AD patients. The article also discusses the role of filaggrin, a protein that is lost in many AD patients and may be involved in the development of asthma. Overall, the article highlights the need for further research into the mechanisms underlying the connection between AD and asthma, and the potential for genetic and immune interventions to prevent or treat asthma in AD patients.
The goal of the study was to obtain a complete inventory of bacterial cellular components and their interconnections. The study used a multi-omic approach, which combined genomic, transcriptomic and proteomic experimental data with bioinformatics tools to annotate bacterial genomic features that cannot accurately be detected using in silico approaches alone. The study used Thermotoga maritima as a model organism, which is a deep-branching, hyperthermophilic bacterium with a compact genome. The study discovered several unique features of the T. maritima genome, including short intergenic regions, a single rRNA operon, and an ability to ferment numerous mono- and polysaccharides. The study also explored the impact of temperature on genome features essential to gene expression such as promoters and ribosome binding sites. The study provides valuable information about the T. maritima genome and a framework for future comparative analysis of annotated features across microbial species.
Visual inputs are first represented in early visual stages such as the retina and primary visual cortex, where the input features such as color, orientation, luminance contrast, and spatial scale of image patches are encoded by the activities of retinal and V1 neurons with various input sensitivities. The neural representation of inputs is then used by the brain to infer the possible objects in the 3-D scene causing the 2-D input images. The brain employs cortical area V2 where neurons tuned to surface border ownership signal which of the possible object surfaces is likely responsible for each luminance edge. However, perception is rarely ambiguous and typically reveals only the most likely object at any time given an input. Perception is defined as the result of revealing a cause to visual awareness, while inference is the process of assigning a probability to each cause. As both perception and inference are assessed operationally by the same observer reports, the two words are often used interchangeably in this paper. It is difficult to state the veridicality of the perception objectively. Visual inference from any part of the input is often influenced by the contextual input. The speed and accuracy to recognize an object significantly depend on whether it is in an indoor or outdoor scene, and the color appearance of an image patch depend on the surrounding patches. Contextual influences are also present in the input encoding. For instance, the sensitivity of a V1 neuron to an input bar can be increased by contextual bars aligned with it, and this colinear facilitation has been manifested in human sensitivity to detect a small bar or gabor (or grating) patch. This study uses stimuli that are easy to manipulate and describe. They are composed of several bars, like those used in probing contextual influences on input sensitivity. In each trial of a yes–no task, after only one stimulus presentation interval, observers have to answer “yes” or “no” regarding whether they perceive a target bar, i.e., whether the target rather than noise is the inferred cause of the luminance profile at the would-be target location in the input image. The bias (to respond “yes”) in inferring the target object is assessed in the yes–no task. One particular bias is filling-in, which we define as a behavioral indication of a target object (by responding “yes”) when there is no input contrast at the corresponding image location. In the framework of a Bayesian model, our data suggest that contextual facilitation or suppression of input sensitivities plays no role in the inference probed by our task, and hence the neural substrate responsible for this inference is more likely beyond V1.
In this study, the researchers investigated how defectors can create small population sizes, which can help rescue cooperation. The study used a model based on the production of a common good by microbial populations and combined stochastic and deterministic components. The results showed that defectors can cause population collapse, extinction, and resource limitation, which can all contribute to the rescue of cooperation by creating small population sizes and large variation in cooperator frequency. This study provides insight into how cooperation can survive even in the presence of defectors.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a type of bacteria that can cause infections in humans. These infections can be acute or chronic, and can affect people with weakened immune systems, burns, or mechanical ventilation. Chronic infections with P . aeruginosa can impair the quality of life and life expectancy of people with cystic fibrosis, which is a genetic disease that affects the lungs. In healthy people, billions of cells die each day, and these cells need to be removed quickly in order to prevent inflammation. This process of removing dead cells is called efferocytosis, which means "to bury" in Latin. Epithelial cells, which are cells that line tissues and organs in the body, are able to remove dead cells by a process called apoptotic cell extrusion. This process involves the dying cell signaling to its neighbors to form a contractile ring around it, which squeezes the cell out of the tissue. Once the cell is removed, the gaps that were created during the process are sealed. In this study, researchers found that P . aeruginosa can attach to and enter epithelial cells in a process called efferocytosis, which involves the bacteria attaching to apoptotic cells that are being removed from the tissue. Once inside the epithelial cell, the bacteria are found inside an efferocytic phagosome, which is a specialized compartment where dead cells are broken down. The bacteria are then eliminated from the cell after 24 hours.
The hedgehog (hh) signaling pathway plays a crucial role in patterning and development of multicellular eukaryotes. However, to reach target cells, the hh ligand must be able to signal over long distances. Recent studies have uncovered a unique mechanism for this long distance signaling. The hh ligand is initially targeted to the secretory pathway, undergoes a series of processing steps, and is then released from the apical surface of polarized epithelial cells. The unmodified Hh-N ligand diffuses much farther along the apical surface than the modified Hh-Np ligand. The movement of Hh-N is independent of factors like tout-velu (ttv) and dispatched (disp) that are critical for the spreading of the modified Hh-Np ligand. Long distance signaling is mediated by an unusual multistep pathway in which Hh-Np is transmitted from the basolateral membranes of the sending cells. The modified Hh-Np is not properly released from the basolateral membranes and instead accumulates in punctate aggregates along the basolateral membranes in hmgcr− mutant embryos. Geranylgeranyl-pyrophosphate is used to modify the G protein γ subunit 1 (Gγ1) which helps mediate the intracellular trafficking of membrane vesicles and cargo.
Scientists are trying to understand why some people can control HIV without taking medication. These people are called long-term nonprogressors (LTNP). Researchers have found that LTNP have strong CD8+ T-cell responses to HIV. These cells kill HIV-infected cells and can stop the virus from spreading. Scientists have also found that some MHC (like Mamu B*08 and B*17) are associated with immunologic control. The scientists in this study looked at HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell responses in people who got the Merck Ad5/HIV trivalent vaccine. They found that the vaccine did not induce strong cytotoxic capacity in most people. However, people with protective MHC had higher cytotoxic capacity. The scientists concluded that the vaccine induced relatively modest cytotoxic capacity in vaccinees, and that protective MHC may have an effect on the cytotoxic capacity induced by vaccination that is mediated during T-cell priming.
In the past, scientists have found that from a young age, human infants are better at jointly intentional actions, which involve collaborative activity, than apes. This ability, which pervades human life, is crucial for modern human cognition. However, it is not clear how this trait evolved. In this study, we model the evolution of the ability to undertake jointly intentional actions. We found that shared intentions can either slow or speed the adoption of new technologies, depending on whether the benefits are high or low. If the benefits are high, shared intentions evolve and become dominant in the population. This emergence of shared intentions is consistent with evidence that composite tool manufacture and grammatical language evolved at about the same time. Our study sheds light on the evolutionary advantages and disadvantages of collaboration, and how these affect the spread of new technologies.
Spermatogenesis is a complex developmental process that produces spermatozoa and supports fertility in adult males. This process can be divided into three main stages: mitosis, meiosis, and spermiogenesis. During mitosis, spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs) and differentiating spermatogonia generate a large pool of cells that will undergo further differentiation. Meiosis produces round spermatids with recombined genomes, which then undergo spermiogenesis to transform into spermatozoa. Many of these stages occur without much transcription, meaning gene expression is regulated post-transcriptionally. One way this happens is through the use of microRNAs (miRNAs), which are small non-coding RNAs that can regulate gene expression by degrading target mRNAs or inhibiting translation. While miRNAs have been studied in many other processes, none to date have been found to regulate mammalian spermatogenesis.
The probiotic E. coli strain Nissle 1917 ( EcN ) is a strain isolated during World War I that has antibacterial activity and can fight against gastrointestinal bacterial infections. It has been used to treat inflammatory bowel diseases and has been found to be effective in treating ulcerative colitis in children and adults. This strain produces a Trojan horse toxin called siderophore-Mcc that can enter and kill bacteria, and it also produces a genotoxic compound called colibactin. A recent study aimed to decouple the antibacterial activity from the genotoxic activity of this strain, and they found that the pks/clb island is more intimately connected to EcN probiotic activity than they expected.
The paper is about a fungus, Cryptococcus neoformans, which is a pathogen that causes serious respiratory disease and can lead to death, especially in immune-compromised patients. The fungus has a thick capsule that is made of a complex mixture of polysaccharides and proteins. The two most important polysaccharides are glucuronoxylomannan (GXM) and glucuronoxylomannanogalactan (GXMGal). GXM is a linear mannose polymer with glucuronic acid and xylose side chains, while GXMGal has a galactose backbone modified with galactofuranose and galactomannan side chains bearing glucuronic acid and xylose residues. Beyond the capsule, the fungus has many other types of glycoconjugates and glycosphingolipids, which play important roles in its survival and pathogenesis. The fungus also has a lot of glycan-synthesizing machinery that requires a lot of energy and is important for its viability and pathogenicity. The paper focuses on understanding how the fungus makes its glycans and how its glycan-synthesizing machinery works. The paper describes the functions of two proteins, Uxt1 and Uxt2, which are responsible for transporting UDP-xylose and UDP-galactofuranose in the cell. Without these proteins, the fungus cannot make these glycans and its growth is severely impaired. The paper also describes the role of these proteins in the virulence of the fungus in a mouse model of disease.
NTDs are diseases that affect more than half of the world's population. They are caused by parasites and are often found in low-income areas. One way to control NTDs is by giving people medicines. However, we need more information about where these diseases are located so we can give the medicines to the right people. We are creating a database that will help us figure out where NTDs are located. The database will include information from different studies and reports. It will be available to anyone who wants to use it. We are also working on a database that will include information about other types of NTDs. This database will be updated regularly with new information from studies and reports.
Tuberculosis and parasitic worms affect about one third of the world's population. In some areas, these diseases overlap and many people have both infections at the same time. People with parasitic worms have a type of immune response that is different from the immune response to most other types of germs. Over time, the immune response to parasitic worms helps keep the worms alive, but it also affects the immune response to other things. In some cases, this can be good, like a reduced risk of allergies or autoimmune disease. However, it can also be bad, like a poor response to vaccines. Mycobacteria, the bacteria that cause tuberculosis, require a different type of immune response to be controlled. The immune response to parasitic worms can interfere with this response, making it harder for the body to fight off tuberculosis. In this study, researchers looked at how chronic infections with parasitic worms affect the body's ability to fight off tuberculosis in cotton rats. The results showed that the presence of parasitic worms had a negative impact on the ability of the body to fight off tuberculosis. This suggests that people who have parasitic worms may be at a higher risk of developing tuberculosis or having a worse outcome if they already have tuberculosis.
Scientists have found a new family of ion channels that might be involved in chemosensory behavior in insects. These channels are called DEG/ENaC channels and are found in both the peripheral and central nervous systems in insects and animals. The channels are activated by diverse stimuli such as protons (acid-sensing ion channels) and the peptide FMRFamide. However, the function and ligands of most DEG/ENaC channels are unknown. The fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster has 31 DEG/ENaC channels, called Pickpocket (ppk) channels, which is a greater number than for any other currently sequenced animal genome. Scientists have found that some DEG/ENaC channels function as receptors for extra-cellular signals and are expressed in chemosensory organs in Drosophila and other species. To test the hypothesis that DEG/ENaC channels might contribute to chemosensory-driven behaviors in insects, scientists have used a genetic approach and expression analyses to discover specific DEG/ENaC channels and their possible contributions to behaviors. They have identified ppk23, a DEG/ENaC channel, as a gene that is enriched in gustatory sensory neurons that are part of the sex circuit in flies. They have shown that ppk23 and the cells expressing it play a role in normal male-female courtship behavior but not feeding.
This study explores how the levels of nucleus-encoded tRNAs imported into mitochondria are related to mitochondrial codon usage. Using the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii as a model, the researchers modified mitochondrial genes to contain more seldom-used codons, and observed no changes in the import status of nucleus-encoded tRNAs. However, this modification led to decreased levels of respiratory complexes, which could be explained by decreased mitochondrial translation. The study suggests that the regulation of mitochondrial tRNA import is fixed during evolution to meet the requirements of mitochondrial translation.
Type 2 diabetes is a big health problem worldwide, affecting millions of adults. It is caused by a combination of genetic and lifestyle factors. Blood glucose levels are regulated by multiple organs, and if they become too high, it can cause complications such as heart disease, kidney disease, and nerve damage. Lifestyle changes can help prevent or delay type 2 diabetes, and personalized nutrition recommendations can be useful. However, current methods for diagnosing diabetes and prediabetes do not measure how glucose levels change over time. A new method has been developed to measure how glucose levels change after meals, and this method can identify individuals who have high levels of glucose after meals. This information can be used to create personalized diet plans to help people with high glucose levels after meals.
The study shows that the protein EDR1 controls a signaling pathway called MAPK cascade, which helps plants defend themselves against pathogens. EDR1 is a negative regulator of the MAPK cascade, meaning that it slows down the signaling pathway. EDR1 and another protein called KEG work together to do this. The study also shows that when EDR1 is not working properly, plants have more defense against pathogens and cell death.
Infectious diseases are a major global health burden that cause millions of deaths each year, especially in poor and low-income countries. The emergence and spread of infectious diseases are influenced by spatial and temporal factors. Machine learning algorithms can help predict disease cases to develop protective measures. However, traditional machine learning algorithms, such as random forests and boosted regression trees, may fail to capture complex dependencies in disease modeling scenarios. Gaussian processes are a type of machine learning algorithm that can capture nonlinear dependencies and make reliable predictions. We present a computational framework that uses Gaussian processes to perform spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. We extract spatial and temporal features from the disease properties and combine them to obtain a similarity matrix. We use the similarity matrix and reported case counts to train a Gaussian process regression model, which can make predictions for future cases under three scenarios: temporal prediction, spatial prediction, and spatiotemporal prediction. Temporal prediction can help predict disease prevalence for each location in the future, while spatial prediction can help predict disease spread within the same time frame in other locations. Spatiotemporal prediction is especially important to prepare against emerging infectious diseases since there will be no historical data for the locations that experience the disease for the first time.
The paper by Drake et al. (2014) explores the potential impact of periodic events on the transmission of Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) in Egypt. The virus is primarily transmitted through bites from mosquitoes and causes significant morbidity and mortality in livestock. RVFV outbreaks have occurred in Egypt since the 1970s, coinciding with the peak mosquito season or the timing of the Eid al-Adha festival, which involves the mass movement of livestock. The authors model the transmission dynamics of RVFV using a system of ordinary differential equations with periodic drivers, representing the seasonal changes in mosquito abundance and the peak movement of livestock during the festival. The model is validated using historical data on RVFV outbreaks in Egypt. The results indicate that periodic events can have a significant impact on the transmission and spatial dispersal of RVFV, highlighting the importance of understanding the underlying mechanisms behind outbreaks to develop effective control strategies.
Anthrax is a disease that can affect humans and animals. It is a bacterial infection that occurs mainly in herbivores, with humans often getting it through contact with infected animals or contaminated materials. Anthrax is a threat in areas with a weakened public health system, and it can lead to economic losses from livestock mortality and lost worker productivity. In this study, researchers looked at the historical occurrence of anthrax in Azerbaijan. They found that the disease has been reported in the country for over 200 years, with the first description of an anthrax-like illness recorded in 1697. In 1996, Azerbaijan experienced a series of livestock anthrax outbreaks that resulted in more than 70 human cases. The researchers used spatial-temporal statistics to analyze the distribution of human anthrax in Azerbaijan. They found that the disease occurred more frequently in certain regions and during certain times of the year. This information can help researchers and public health officials identify areas to prioritize control and develop more effective disease management strategies.
Scientists have used computer simulations to study how a specific type of fat called polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) affects the activity of potassium channels. These channels play important roles in the nervous system and their malfunction can lead to diseases such as epilepsy. The simulations showed that PUFAs can interact with the channels in both an open and a closed state. In the open state, PUFAs formed a variety of interactions with the channel, including hydrophobic interactions with two helices and electrostatic interactions with three regions of the channel. In the closed state, fewer interactions were formed compared to the open state. These findings provide new information about how PUFAs affect potassium channels and could help scientists develop new treatments for diseases caused by malfunctioning channels.
Cryptosporidium is a parasite that causes diarrhea in children in developing countries. It is hard to treat because it can live in water and it takes a long time to develop immunity. The parasite cannot make its own purines, so it relies on taking them from other sources. A study has found that a protein in the parasite called CpIMPDH is a promising target for new treatments. The study also found a way to test the effectiveness of these treatments using a genetic engineered parasite called T. gondii. They also found a way to test the effectiveness of these treatments directly on Cryptosporidium. The study found five compounds that could be effective treatments for Cryptosporidium.
Researchers studied tooth development in infancy to discover the genes responsible for it. They looked at children in two different studies: one in Finland and the other in England. The researchers measured how long it took for teeth to erupt and how many teeth had erupted by the age of one. These measurements are important because they can predict later tooth development. The researchers found that there are genetic factors that influence tooth development during infancy. This research can help us understand why some people have dental problems and how to prevent them.
Down syndrome (DS) and M21 are genetic disorders that affect human chromosome 21 (Hsa21). Full M21 is rare and usually not compatible with life, with only a few cases reported. M21 is a partial deletion or mosaic of Hsa21. The phenotypes of M21 vary depending on the specific deleted region of Hsa21 and can include intellectual disability, facial dysmorphology, and physical abnormalities. DS is the most common viable cause of chromosomal aneuploidy in humans and the most frequent genetic cause of intellectual disability. DS is characterized by facial dysmorphology and hypotonia. However, the causes of delayed motor performance affecting both gross and fine motor skills and weak muscle strength are not known. Hypotonia is a state of low muscular tonicity that can be caused by abnormal muscle function, abnormal neurological input, or metabolic diseases. Impaired exercise endurance is observed in DS individuals and could arise from endocrinal or metabolic perturbations. Mouse models offer a chance to develop mouse models of aneuploidies and investigate the relationship between phenotype and genotype. Several mouse models have been generated over the years that display many features of DS, but locomotor activity has not previously been fully investigated in these models. Ts65Dn mice are trisomic for 102 orthologous of Hsa21 genes located between Mprl39 and Zfp295 on Mmu16, but it is not clear if they have locomotor deficits. A new mouse model, Ts3Yah, has been generated that is trisomic for the Hspa13-App Hsa21 syntenic region on Mmu16, and this model displays impaired locomotion and increased grip strength and muscle mass. The opposite phenotype was observed in Ms3Yah, a monosomic model for the same region. The transcription profile analysis of skeletal muscles revealed coordinate changes in muscle metabolic activity and mitochondrial biogenesis, and this finding was confirmed by alterations in the oxidative capacity and mitochondrial content of the skeletal muscles. This study unravels new insight into the metabolic changes that result in defects of skeletal muscle strength and performance associated with Hsa21 aneuploidy and suggests new candidate genes involved in DS and M21.
The paper focuses on the classical signaling cascade that leads to the opening of GIRK channels, which are important regulators of heartbeat, neuronal excitability, and plasticity. The authors present a model that explains the relationship between the basal activity of GIRK and the extent of activation by inhibitory neurotransmitters or Gβγ, which is regulated by the availability of Gαi/o. The authors demonstrate that the same relationship between basal and evoked activity exists in hippocampal neurons as it does in Xenopus oocytes and HEK cells. The authors also use the model to estimate the functional stoichiometry of Gα and Gβγ available for GIRK, which indicates that 3-4 Gβγ molecules are available for GIRK activation, while only 2 Gα molecules are available. The authors suggest that the unequal and variable stoichiometry of GIRK and Gα and Gβγ explains the inverse relationship between basal and evoked activity. The paper proposes a novel explanation of the molecular mechanisms of GIRK and suggests that Gα is not an obligatory partner in the GIRK-G protein signaling complex, but that GαGDP plays a crucial role in regulating basal activity and the magnitude of agonist response.
This paper introduces PrediTALE, a new approach for predicting target genes of TALEs. TALEs are proteins that infect plants and control their growth and disease development. They contain a DNA-binding domain with repeats that bind to specific sequences in the plant's DNA. The specificity of each repeat is determined by its sequence, with amino acids at positions 12 and 13 being the most important. PrediTALE uses quantitative data from recent studies to predict TALE target genes more accurately. It accounts for dependencies between adjacent repeats, between the first repeat and the start of the target sequence, and for the fact that mismatches are more tolerated at the end of the target sequence. PrediTALE also works for TALEs that have repeats of different lengths, called aberrant repeats. The paper provides examples of how PrediTALE can be used to predict TALE target genes in both forward and reverse orientation.
The task of determining if a change to a person's mitochondrial DNA causes a disease is a difficult job. It can be done in the lab or in a computer, but it can be difficult and sometimes even impossible because of a lack of resources. Many different software programs have been created to help with this task by using information about the DNA sequence, its structure, and its function. These software programs can give a prediction about the harmfulness of a change to the DNA. However, studies have shown that the predictions made by these programs are not always the same. There is no single program that is the best at predicting which changes to the DNA cause a disease. Therefore, researchers are working on a new program called APOGEE, which is designed to help with this task. The program uses data from other programs and databases to make its predictions and it uses decision tree learning, which means that it gives investigable rules for predicting if a change to the DNA causes a disease.
Dengue is a very common mosquito-borne virus that causes illness in approximately 390 million people worldwide each year. Some people with dengue develop severe symptoms, such as bleeding and organ failure, but it's not clear exactly how this happens. Platelets (blood components that help blood clot) are affected in both mild and severe cases of dengue. There is a protein called NS1 that is released into the blood during dengue infection, and it may be involved in platelet activation and death, which can lead to thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and hemorrhage (bleeding). A recent study has shown that a receptor called TLR4 may be involved in the process, and this study aims to investigate the possible role of NS1 in causing platelet activation and hemorrhage through TLR4.
AVP and ANP are hormones produced in the brain that help regulate blood pressure and water balance. AVP is produced by cells in the hypothalamus and stored in the pituitary gland, while ANP is produced by cells in the heart. Both hormones act on receptors in different parts of the body to affect blood pressure, water balance, and other physiological processes. There are several factors that can influence the production and release of these hormones, including stretch receptors in the heart and blood vessels, and hormones such as renin and aldosterone. The actions of AVP and ANP are mediated through different receptors and signaling pathways, but both hormones ultimately help to maintain homeostasis in the body.
Blood clots can form when the wall of a blood vessel gets damaged or inflamed. This can cause a blockage in the blood vessel, which can be life threatening. There are two types of blood clots: intravascular clots (thrombi) that form inside the blood vessel, and emboli that break off from the thrombi and get stuck in the lungs or brain. These blood clots are a major problem in the United States, causing 900,000 cases per year and 300,000 deaths. Injuries to the blood vessel wall cause small thrombi to form, but the growth of these thrombi slows down after a few minutes. This is because the surface of the thrombus changes as it grows. At first, the surface is covered in platelets. But as the thrombus stabilizes, it is covered by a fibrin network with clusters of platelets and cells in it. We have studied how these thrombi grow and how they are affected by the fibrin network. We have also looked at how thrombin, a protein that activates platelets, moves through the fibrin network. Our research shows that the fibrin network does not create a diffusion barrier that would limit the movement of thrombin. However, it does create a permeability barrier that prevents platelets from reaching the center of the thrombus where the thrombin concentration is high enough to activate them. This means that the fibrin network may be able to limit the growth of small thrombi by preventing them from growing big enough to cause problems.
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases that affect the gastrointestinal tract. There are two main types of IBD: Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC). UC is characterized by inflammation of the colon and rectum, while CD can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract. Both diseases can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss. IBD is a complex disease that is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. Treatment options for IBD include medication, surgery, and lifestyle changes.
Candida albicans is a type of fungus that can cause disease in humans. It often lives inside humans without causing any problems, but when a person's immune system is compromised, Candida albicans can cause disease. Researchers have found that Candida albicans colonizes humans early in life, and it is thought to colonize the mouth of most infants within one month. It also colonizes the intestinal tract of many adults. The researchers were interested in understanding more about how Candida albicans behaves in the human body. They used gene expression studies to look at how the fungus behaves in the mouth during infection and when it is growing in the intestinal tract. They found that a gene called EFH1 is important for determining how many Candida albicans cells are in the intestinal tract, even though it does not affect how the fungus behaves under laboratory conditions or in the disseminated infection model. They also found that two other genes called RBT1 and RBT4 are required for virulence in the disseminated infection model, but they are not required for normal intestinal colonization. This suggests that genes that influence commensal colonization can be distinct from genes that are required for virulence.
Immunization with irradiated malaria sporozoites can protect against subsequent challenge with live parasites. This protection is thought to be mediated by CD8+ T cells in both mice and humans. Studies have proposed that antigen persistence after sporozoite immunization may help generate protective immune responses, but there is no evidence that this material, assumed to be of parasite origin, is immunogenic or presented to effector cells of the immune system. Recent studies have reported antigen persistence after acute viral infections, but it is not yet clear how antigen persistence affects CD8+ T cell responses. To study this, we used TCR transgenic T cells specific for the circumsporozoite protein, a leading vaccine candidate antigen. Our results show that CS antigen persists for more than 8 weeks after immunization, and that prolonged antigen presentation drives the maximal expansion of effector cells, can stimulate the proliferation of established memory cells, and recruit naïve cells, including recent thymic emigrants to the immune response. Therefore, prolonged antigen presentation may be required for the full development of CD8+ T cell mediated protective immunity.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by parasites that are transmitted by sandflies and can cause skin ulcers. These ulcers can become infected by bacteria and can lead to mutilation and scarring. Current treatments for leishmaniasis are effective but have side effects and require hospitalization. Nanoparticles have been shown to be effective at delivering leishmanicidal drugs to infected cells, and they can also be used to deliver antibiotics to infected skin ulcers. In this study, the authors fabricated nanoparticles that were adsorbed with an antibiotic called polymyxin B. They found that these nanoparticles were effective at killing both the parasites and the bacteria in infected skin ulcers. This suggests that these nanoparticles could be used as a new treatment for leishmaniasis.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a serious disease caused by a parasite that affects the liver and spleen. It can be fatal if left untreated. VL is most commonly found in six countries: Bangladesh, Brazil, Ethiopia, India, Nepal, and Sudan. In Brazil, where VL is caused by Leishmania infantum, it has spread due to urbanization. Between 1990 and 2009, 57,973 cases of VL were reported in Brazil, representing 90% of all cases in the American continent. The Brazilian government has implemented a program to control VL, but it remains a difficult challenge. A recent study looked at the early clinical manifestations of VL and created a clinical score to help identify patients at a higher risk of death.
In plants, RLKs are an important component of extracellular sensing that helps plants respond to changing environmental and developmental conditions. These RLKs are divided into two types, RD and non-RD kinases, which have different ways of activating downstream signaling. BAK1 is a RLK that forms ligand-dependent heteromers with several ligand-binding RLKs. These heteromers regulate multiple signaling pathways leading to growth, cell death control, and innate immunity. In this study, the researchers discovered that the kinase activity of BAK1 is required for complex formation with some RLKs, and that BAK1 has a unique way of regulating signaling downstream of non-RD kinases compared to RD kinases.
Anticancer research aims to understand how cancer cells grow and divide and how treatments affect this process. Researchers have found that cancer cells can be divided into different phases during cell division, and that they can have different amounts of time in each phase. They have also found that cell division is not always a simple process and can be influenced by a variety of factors. Researchers have used mathematical models to simulate the growth of cancer cells, but these models have limitations in their ability to account for the complexity of cell division. Researchers have now developed a new model that combines data from two different types of experiments to better understand how cancer cells grow and respond to treatment. This model is more accurate and allows researchers to better understand how different factors affect cancer cell growth.
Coenzyme Q (CoQ) is a chemical that helps with energy production in cells. In humans, there are two genes that make up an enzyme that helps make CoQ. These genes are called PDSS1 and PDSS2. A mutation in the PDSS2 gene causes a rare genetic disorder called kidney disease (kd). Kd causes damage to the kidneys that can lead to kidney failure. PDSS2 mutations have also been found in humans with other health problems. In this study, researchers looked at different types of PDSS2 mutations in mice and found that only mice with PDSS2 mutations in their podocytes (a type of cell in the kidney) developed kidney disease. The researchers also found that the mice with PDSS2 mutations had no other health problems, such as liver disease or muscle weakness.
In this paper, the authors investigate the genetic basis of phenotypic robustness, which is the ability of a phenotypic trait to remain constant despite environmental or genetic perturbations. They show that the determinative development of invertebrates, where the developmental process and cell fate are fixed, is highly robust to cell death. They identify multiple nonrandom features of the cell lineages that explain the ontogenic robustness, and show that this characteristic can arise as an adaptation to certain disturbances in ontogenesis.
Phenomics is the study of the complex set of characteristics that make up a living organism. It involves the use of high-dimensional data to better understand how traits are related and interact to create the whole-organism phenotype. Currently, a lack of transferrable technologies for high-dimensional acquisition of phenome-level data is a major bottleneck in the advancement of phenomics and is recognized as a key challenge in biology. High-dimensional phenotyping allows for the identification and measurement of traits that cannot be detected using manual observation, as well as the use of computational methods to explore and integrate multiple traits. Phenomics is particularly well-suited to study embryonic development, as it is a dynamic process with high levels of intraindividual temporal, spatial, and functional change. Automated high-throughput longitudinal measurement of developing embryos offers huge potential to alleviate a major limitation in the application of phenomics. The EmbryoPhenomics platform is an open-source high-throughput platform for phenomics in aquatic embryos that consists of an Open-source Video Microscope (OpenVIM) and a Python package Embryo Computer Vision (EmbryoCV) for high-dimensional measurement of phenomic traits from video data sets. This platform enables the quantification and integration of interindividual and intraindividual temporal change in morphological, physiological, and behavioral traits with high resolution and to an unprecedented scale in a largely automated workflow. The application of EmbryoPhenomics is demonstrated through experiments assessing the chronic, acute, and interactive effects of environmental stressors. The efficacy and transferability of this platform are demonstrated using two ecologically important species with radically different patterns of development: Radix balthica, a freshwater gastropod mollusc, and Orchestia gammarellus, a marine amphipod crustacean.
Malaria is a major health problem worldwide, with over 200 million new cases each year and over 400,000 deaths. Although some control measures have been implemented in the last 15 years, increasing resistance to artemisinin, an important drug used in treatment, is threatening these efforts. Malaria parasites can infect and kill red blood cells (RBCs) of humans and animals, causing severe anemia, liver damage, and death. Parasites rely heavily on glycolysis to generate energy. Although they have a single, poorly crystallized mitochondrion, they can still re-oxidize electron transport chain (ETC) complexes and use pyruvate and glutamine as energy sources. However, recent research suggests that mosquito-infective stages of malaria parasites may rely more heavily on the TCA cycle and mitochondrial metabolism than asexual blood stages do. Genetic studies have shown that the TCA cycle and ETC are essential for the development of mosquito-infective stages of P. falciparum. In this study, researchers used metabolomic and reverse genetic approaches to investigate the metabolic changes that occur in mosquito-infective stages of P. berghei and the potential impact of these changes on parasite development in the mosquito. They found that these stages are highly sensitive to disruptions in multiple pathways in central carbon metabolism, including the TCA cycle, the utilization of glutamine as a carbon source, intermediary carbon metabolism, and CoA synthesis. These findings suggest that these stages are dependent on multiple pathways in carbon metabolism, opening up new avenues for targeting parasite transmission.
Oscillations are important for controlling behaviors of single cells and cell populations. In order to generate these oscillations, nonlinear reaction rates and negative feedback are required. The network constraint that allows the generation of oscillations includes 'nonlinear' kinetic rate laws for the destabilization of the steady state. While this constraint allows the generation of oscillations with a diverse set of network motifs, negative feedback (especially negative feedback with a time delay) is found in all these cases. Engineered systems based on such design constraints demonstrate the capability to generate synthetic oscillators mimicking those found in nature. For signal processing in the frequency domain, computational methods illustrate one potential mechanism, where a critical frequency defines the bandwidth for high fidelity signal propagation for each network. This capacity can be changed with an increased oscillation amplitude or with increased kinetic rates. In contrast, it is less known about how cells process oscillatory signals. One common motif shared by these networks is the Incoherent Feed-Forward Loop (IFFL), in which an input both activates and represses a single output. The IFFL motif is ideal for decoding oscillatory signals due to its ability to react to fold-changes rather than the absolute concentration of an input. In essence, this network is able to desensitize a system to a sustained stimulus while maintaining the ability to respond to periodic stimulation. In order to differentiate pulsatile and sustained signals, the network must display both states. The system must exhibit a stepwise increase of the output in response to oscillatory signals while having no response to sustained signals. Analogous to the use of radios to transform information from the frequency and amplitude domains of electromagnetic waves, the IFFL acts as a decoder, recognizing pulsatile signals.
Scrub typhus is a serious illness caused by bacteria that affects a wide geographical area. It can cause high fever, and it is hard to diagnose it quickly and accurately. It is difficult to know how many people are at risk and how many get infected. Researchers need to learn more about how the bacteria causes infections in cells to better understand the disease and develop treatments. Currently, it is hard to grow the bacteria in a lab, and it takes a long time for it to grow. In this study, the researchers aimed to find better ways to measure, grow, purify, and store the bacteria. They wanted to help researchers who study the disease and develop treatments.
Urogenital schistosomiasis, also known as bilharzia, is a common parasitic infection in tropical and subtropical countries, affecting millions of people. Children are the ones most affected by this disease, and it causes problems such as blood in the urine, stomach pain, poor growth, and decreased memory and thinking ability. Schistosomiasis can be treated with a medicine called praziquantel, which is safe, effective, and cheap. However, treatment programs only include children who are at least 6 years old, because it is believed that children under 5 are not exposed to enough of the parasite to cause problems. But some studies have shown that many young children do have schistosomiasis and that it can cause problems in them. Therefore, the authors want to study whether it is safe to give praziquantel to children who are 1 to 5 years old and whether it works as well in them as it does in children who are 6 to 10 years old. They hope that this study will help to include younger children in treatment programs for schistosomiasis.
The study aimed to identify novel genes that are involved in the growth and metastasis of human cancer. To do this, researchers used the Drosophila model to screen for genes that suppress the growth of tumors caused by a specific type of Ras mutation (RasV12). They then identified mammalian orthologs (similar genes in humans) of the genes found in the screen and analyzed their role in human cancer. Finally, they validated and analyzed the mechanism of action of one of the top 100 candidate tumor suppressor genes found in the screen. This research may lead to the identification of new biomarkers and drug targets for a diverse range of human epithelial tumors.
Meiotic drive is a type of genetic variation that can bias the transmission of specific alleles or genes from parents to offspring. This is achieved by killing off gametes (the cells that produce sperm and eggs) that do not inherit the drive allele. Meiotic drive is found in many different organisms, including humans, and can have negative effects on an individual's fitness and overall health. It is also thought to be the result of an evolutionary conflict between the drive allele and other parts of the genome. This conflict is thought to lead to the rapid evolution of new drive alleles, as well as the evolution of mechanisms to suppress their effects. The wtf genes in the fission yeast S. pombe are a good example of this conflict. Four of these genes have been identified as meiotic drivers in two different strains of S. pombe. The protein encoded by one of these genes, wtf4, works by poisoning spores (meiotic products) that do not inherit the wtf4 gene, while the other three wtf genes (wtf13, wtf18-1, and wtf18-2) are thought to suppress the effects of wtf4. It is also thought that wtf18-2 works by using molecular mimicry to suppress the effects of wtf13. This is an example of a novel type of drive suppressor, as it uses the infertility caused by the drive allele to its own advantage. Overall, the wtf genes in S. pombe provide a good example of how meiotic drive can cause negative effects on individuals and the evolutionary conflict between drive alleles and other parts of the genome.
Scientists have discovered that the expression of different genes varies widely among individuals. The reasons for this variation are complex and can be influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. To better understand this variation, scientists have studied the relationship between genetic variation and gene expression variation using a mapping approach, where each gene's expression is treated as a quantitative trait and genetic changes that are significantly correlated with expression changes are examined. This approach has been very useful in identifying many potential effectors of gene expression. However, this approach has its limitations. For example, it tends to have low statistical power and cannot detect combinatorial associations between multiple SNPs and expression changes. To address these limitations, researchers have developed multiple-SNP predictive models using ridge regression, Bayesian approaches, and multiple interval mapping. These models have been able to identify statistically significant epistatic interactions that are not found using the single SNP approach. However, these methods still examine each SNP in isolation, which limits their ability to detect associations between multiple SNPs and expression changes. To overcome this limitation, scientists have developed an algorithm that predicts changes in gene expression among human individuals using only their genetic variation. The algorithm uses multiple SNPs to predict the expression of every gene, but only SNPs that are in the genomic vicinity of the predicted gene are used. The algorithm also incorporates a comprehensive set of genomic and functional features for each SNP to weigh the importance of each SNP in the prediction. The algorithm has been shown to achieve high correspondence between its predictions on the training data and those on the held out test data. The predictions can be improved by combining the predictions of multiple algorithms, each of which explains different aspects of the expression data. However, the total number of genes whose expression can be accurately predicted using their proximal SNP data is relatively small. Nevertheless, the algorithm can determine the quality of the predictions in advance with high accuracy. The algorithm has also been shown to improve predictions when individuals from other populations are included. This suggests that some of the SNPs that are associated with expression changes are shared across populations. Taken together, the algorithm provides concrete means by which some of the expression variation among human individuals can be predicted with a low false positive rate using only their genotype data, suggesting that the time may be ripe for a broader examination of this important prediction task, perhaps while incorporating additional features such as trans-acting SNPs.
The study highlights the competitive interactions between different strains of the same parasitic species within the host. These interactions can directly affect the rate of transmission and evolution of virulence and drug and vaccine resistance in malarial infections. The study provides experimental evidence for the role of host immune response in competitive suppression of one of the clones. The results show that the avirulent clone was competitively suppressed by the virulent clone, regardless of the initial parasite numbers. However, the exact role of host immune response in the suppression of the avirulent clone could not be explored. The study also provides evidence that the virulent clone achieved a competitive advantage due to larger parasite and gametocyte densities compared to the avirulent clone during mixed infections. The study suggests that within-host competition plays an important role in the spread and selection of virulence in parasite evolution. The study also emphasizes the importance of understanding the mechanisms underlying the competitive interactions between different strains of the same parasitic species.
Eukaryotic genomes, including human genomes, are constantly changing. This change can occur through errors that happen during cell division. One type of error can cause the duplication of a specific region of DNA that is inverted, meaning that the order of the genes is flipped. This type of duplication is called an inverted triplication. Scientists have studied these types of duplications in yeast and have found that they are caused by a specific type of error that happens during cell division. This error involves the replication of a specific region of DNA that includes an inverted repeat and an origin of replication. The scientists have proposed a model to explain how this error causes the duplication of the specific region of DNA. They have now tested this model through both in vitro and in vivo experiments. They have found that the error can occur in vitro and that it can lead to the duplication of the specific region of DNA. They have also found that the duplication can be passed down to future generations and that it can change the structure and size of the duplicated region. Finally, they have found that this type of duplication is similar to a common type of change that occurs in human genomes.
This study examines how viral infection and the immune response affect the process of protein translation initiation in cells. Researchers have previously observed that viral infection and immune stress can impact this process in different ways. For example, viral infection can activate a protein kinase that globally reduces translation initiation for most transcripts, while also increasing translation of a subset of stress-response transcripts. Similarly, immune stress can change the start codon on mRNAs at which ribosomes initiate translation. The study focuses on a specific alternate start codon, CUG, which may be particularly relevant during immune stress. Researchers have previously found that CUG initiation can be induced during viral infection and immune stress, and that it may be a deliberate host strategy to generate immune epitopes. However, it is unknown if start site usage is altered globally during viral infection or if there is a preference for certain start codons. The study uses ribosome profiling, a high-throughput technique that enables genome-wide interrogation of translation, to map sites of translation initiation in viral and cellular transcripts during influenza virus infection. Surprisingly, the results show little signal for CUG initiation in viral genes, but they do identify a number of candidate AUG start sites that are downstream of the canonical start codon. The study also finds an excess of non-AUG start codons on transcripts that are upregulated during the anti-viral response. These results highlight how alternate translation initiation can alter the protein-coding capacity of both viruses and the cells they infect.
EHEC is a type of bacteria that causes diarrheal disease in humans. It does this by making a special kind of protein that can enter the cells of the human intestine. The bacteria can also make other proteins that can interfere with the body's natural defense system, which is designed to protect against infection. The bacteria can use these proteins to enter the cells and make them do what they want. In this study, scientists found that another kind of bacteria, C. rodentium, makes a similar protein that can also enter the cells of mice and interfere with their natural defense system. Scientists studied this protein in detail and found that it can bind to a special molecule in the cells called RPS3. RPS3 is important for the natural defense system in both humans and mice. By binding to RPS3, the bacteria can stop the natural defense system from working properly. This makes it easier for the bacteria to enter the cells and do what they want.
This paper presents a new approach called feature motif models (FMMs) for understanding the binding specificity of transcription factors (TFs) to DNA sequences. Unlike previous methods, which focus on finding short motifs in a sequence that are characteristic of a specific TF, FMMs take a different approach. They model the binding specificity of a TF as a set of features that are important for the TF to recognize its target site. These features can be binary or multi-valued, and global features can also be included. Each feature is assigned a statistical weight, and the overall strength of a TFBS is computed by summing the contribution of all its constituent features. The authors argue that this approach captures the essence of the TF-DNA interaction more explicitly than previous methods, and can efficiently represent complex and distant dependencies. The paper also describes a novel motif finder algorithm that uses FMMs as a basic building block, and validates its performance on yeast TF ChIP data. Finally, the authors present insights gained from learning FMMs for two human TFs, CTCF and c-MYC. They conclude that FMMs offer a promising approach for understanding the binding specificity of TFs to DNA sequences.
This paper discusses the role of the sympathetic nervous system in the fight-or-flight response. The sympathetic nervous system stimulates this response by releasing catecholamine neurotransmitters from nerve terminals and through the bloodstream. These neurotransmitters bind to receptors called α and β receptors, which are a type of G protein-coupled receptors. The α2-adrenergic receptor, specifically the ADRA2C subtype, modulates neurotransmission and behavior. Knockout mice for ADRA2C have high levels of catecholamines and behavioral alterations, such as enhanced startle response, shortened attack latency, and diminished acoustic prepulse inhibition. Chicken domestication was associated with genetic modifications near ADRA2C, and humans have noncoding DNA segments that are conserved in other species but show human-specific acceleration near genes involved in neuronal cell adhesion. Epigenomic signatures can mark the location of functional elements and provide information on the spatiotemporal specificity of their regulatory activities. In this study, the authors leveraged population genetics data and various epigenome data in neural cells or tissues to test whether noncoding regulatory regions of ADRA2C were under selection in humans. They found evidence of selection on ADRA2C regulatory regions, suggesting that the fight-or-flight response played a critical role in increasing fitness in humans.
Photosynthesis is a process that allows plants to make food using sunlight. There are two main types of photosynthesis: C3 and C4. C4 plants are more productive in tropical and subtropical climates, and they have evolved a different way of using CO2 during photosynthesis than C3 plants. The C4 pathway allows for increased productivity because it concentrates CO2 around RuBisCO, an enzyme that helps plants make food during photosynthesis.
