In C4 plants, this concentration is achieved by separating the photosynthetic apparatus into two distinct cell types. Some C4 plants have spatial partitioning in individual cells, while others have spatial partitioning in two separate cells. There are many different types of C4 plants, and they are found in many parts of the world. Some of the most productive crops in the world are C4 plants, and they play an important role in food security. To understand how C4 plants work, scientists have studied the patterns of gene expression that are associated with the compartmentalization of photosynthesis between cell types. However, these studies have only been done in a limited number of C4 lineages. In this study, scientists studied how C4 photosynthesis evolved in two different types of C4 plants, one from the dicotyledon Cleome gynandra and one from the monocotyledon maize. They looked at patterns of gene expression associated with the development of C4 photosynthesis and identified a common set of genes that are important for this process. They also found that the patterns of transcript abundance in the two different types of C4 plants were highly similar. This suggests that the evolution of C4 photosynthesis is associated with the parallel evolution of trans-factors, which are proteins that help control the expression of other genes. This finding has important implications for engineering C4 photosynthesis into other types of plants, such as rice.
The Ebola virus Makona variant is a negative-sense RNA virus that caused the largest viral hemorrhagic fever epidemic ever reported in West Africa, between December 2013 and January 2016. Two patients with this virus were treated at the National Institute for Infectious Diseases ( INMI ) "Lazzaro Spallanzani" of Rome, Italy. The patient who was the first imported case to Italy showed significant lung involvement, suggesting that EBOV can cause lung damage. The second imported case was a Health Care Worker ( HCW ) working in an Ebola Treatment Center in Sierra Leone. He was treated at INMI for Ebola Virus Disease with oral favipiravir, monoclonal antibodies against EBOV, and sustained hydration. He was discharged in good clinical condition. In this study, the authors compared the levels of EBOV negative sense genomic RNA ( neg-RNA ) and positive sense RNA ( pos-RNA ) in the clinical specimen of the second EVD patient treated at INMI to explore the potential role of different body compartments in EBOV replication.
The Machupo virus (MACV) is a type of virus that causes hemorrhagic fever in South America. It is part of a group of viruses called New World arenaviruses, which are highly contagious and can cause severe disease in humans. The symptoms of MACV are similar to those of another virus called Junin virus, which also causes hemorrhagic fever. There are currently no treatments or vaccines for MACV, and the virus has been declared a "select agent" by the US government due to its potential use as a bioweapon. In this study, researchers created new versions of the MACV virus that are less virulent by replacing the ectodomain of the virus's glycoprotein with that of a less virulent strain of the virus called Candid#1. They then tested these new viruses in vitro and in vivo to see how they behaved compared to the original MACV virus.
To ensure that chromosomes are properly divided into daughter cells during cell division, each chromosome needs a special region called a centromere. In most organisms, centromeres are determined by a type of histone protein called CENH3, which is rapidly evolving. Changes in the sequence of CENH3 can affect how centromeres function and how chromosomes are divided during cell division. In this study, researchers looked at how single amino acid substitutions in CENH3 affect chromosome segregation. They found that certain substitutions can result in haploid induction, where plants are fertile on self-pollination but whose centromeres malfunction when they are pollinated by a plant with a different type of CENH3. This finding indicates that single amino acid changes in CENH3 have dramatic consequences on the ability of the mutant plant to hybridize. It also provides a simple, non-transgenic tool for developing haploid inducers in crops.
Embryonic stem cells ( ESCs ) can differentiate into all cell types in the body and are a powerful tool for studying cell differentiation. To study the differentiation process, it is important to identify developmental cues that are required for lineage commitment. This can be done by analyzing the expression of core transcription factors and other factors that interact with these core factors. However, the mechanisms that regulate ESC maintenance and cell fate commitment are not well understood, mainly because it is difficult to obtain pure populations of fully differentiated cells and to analyze the complexity of alternative splicing ( AS ). AS is a process in which a single gene produces multiple mRNA transcripts that differ in their inclusion or exclusion of exons. These transcripts can produce different proteins with different properties, such as different signaling functions. In this study, we used whole-genome exon-level profiling to analyze AS in human ESCs that were differentiated into neural progenitors ( NPs ) and cardiac progenitors ( CPs ). We found that AS in CPs and NPs was different, and that AS events in both CPs and NPs produced changes in predicted protein domain/motif composition that could affect protein function and expression. We also found that AS events modified the predicted miRNA binding site composition of transcripts, suggesting that AS may indirectly regulate protein expression. These findings are important for understanding how ESCs differentiate into different cell types and for developing new therapies based on this process.
Trehalose is a common sugar found in many organisms, but not in mammals. It is important for the survival and virulence of some pathogenic bacteria and fungi, making it a target for developing antimicrobial drugs. Mycobacterium tuberculosis uses two main pathways to produce trehalose: OtsA-OtsB2 and TreY-TreZ. However, while the OtsA-OtsB2 pathway is essential for M. tuberculosis to survive, the TreY-TreZ pathway is not. In this study, researchers created a conditional mutant of otsB2, allowing them to regulate its expression in vitro and in vivo. They found that OtsB2 is essential for M. tuberculosis to survive, but that the mutant could still survive and grow in vivo in a mouse infection model. This study provides new insights into the unique requirements for the OtsB2 enzyme in M. tuberculosis and its importance for its survival and virulence.
This research paper is about a parasite that causes Chagas' disease, which threatens the lives of millions of people in South America. The parasite is from the genus Trypanosoma and the type of parasite studied is Trypanosoma cruzi (T. cruzi). This parasite causes a disease that is hard to treat and can be fatal, especially when it affects important organs. Researchers have found a new potential target for treatment: an enzyme called TcPR. This enzyme is essential for the parasite to infect host cells. It has been shown that when TcPR is expressed at higher levels, the parasite produces more infective forms. Researchers have also found that TcPR is a potent host B-cell mitogen, which is a process that helps the parasite evade the host's immune response. A drug that specifically targets TcPR could help combat Chagas' disease more efficiently. To understand how TcPR causes the immune response, researchers have determined the three-dimensional structure of this enzyme. They found that a large movement happens when TcPR binds to a molecule called PYC. This movement hides TcPR from the B-cell receptors, which prevents the immune response. The researchers also found that TcPR has two different forms: open and closed. The open form has not been studied before, but it is important to understand it because it may reveal how TcPR causes the immune response. To study the open form, the researchers used advanced computer simulations and compared the structures of TcPR with other similar enzymes. They found that the open form of TcPR has conformational epitopes that may be exposed to the immune system, which could trigger the immune response. This research is an important step towards understanding how TcPR causes the immune response and could lead to the development of new and more effective treatments for Chagas' disease.
In this study, the authors developed a new technology called "iKO" that allows for the inducible and reversible knockout of genes in mice. This system uses a mouse line that expresses a protein called "rtTA" in place of the gene to be knocked out, and another mouse line called "TIGRE" that contains the gene of interest under the control of a "TRE" element at a specific location in the genome. To use the iKO system, the two mouse lines are crossed to create a third line in which the gene of interest can be turned on or off at will by adding or removing a chemical called doxycycline. The iKO system has several advantages over other systems for inducible knockouts, including the ability to control gene expression at any time during an animal's life, high levels of regulation for the gene of interest, efficiency, and flexibility. The authors use the iKO system to study the effects of turning the gene encoding the protein "ApoE" on and off, as ApoE plays a key role in regulating cholesterol metabolism and atherosclerosis. They show that when the gene is turned off, the animal develops hypercholesterolemia and atherosclerosis, while when the gene is turned back on, the animal's cholesterol levels and atherosclerosis regress. The iKO system provides a new tool for studying the molecular mechanisms underlying atherosclerosis, and it could be used to study the effects of turning other genes on and off in mice.
Chagas disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, is transmitted from mother to child and can cause serious health problems for both the mother and child. Different genotypes of T. cruzi have been identified and may play a role in congenital infection. A study used a transcriptomic approach combined with biological network analysis to compare the responses of mouse placenta to two different strains of T. cruzi, one from a non-lethal myotropic strain and the other from a strain found in a human case of congenital infection. The study may help to better understand the potential role of T. cruzi genotypes in pregnancy and congenital infection.
The article discusses the transmission cycle of a mosquito-borne disease caused by Sindbis virus (SINV), which is a zoonosis with birds as amplifying hosts and mosquitoes as vectors. The authors investigate the activity of SINV in vector mosquitoes and the abundance of these mosquitoes during transmission season in the years before, during, and after an outbreak year. The study focuses on five mosquito species, including the enzootic vectors Culex torrentium and Culex pipiens/torrentium, the potential enzootic vector Culiseta morsitans, the bridge-vector Aedes cinereus, and the potential bridge-vector Aedes rossicus. The authors analyze the genetic diversity of SINV strains occurring in vector mosquitoes to understand the introduction and evolution of virus strains over the years. The main findings of the study indicate that the number of reported human SINV cases may not be adequate for defining a potential seven-year cycle of outbreaks or for scrutinizing the factors behind the outbreaks. The authors recommend using an objective marker of SINV activity for further studies on periodicity and causes of outbreaks.
The olfactory system of insects, including the locust, uses a unique way of encoding sensory information through synchronized oscillations in the activity of neurons. This is in contrast to the way sensory information is encoded in the vertebrate olfactory system, which uses sparse codes and firing rate changes. However, there is still a lot to learn about the interaction and integration of different coding strategies within neural systems. Experimental observations of the interplay between information flow and neural circuitry are generally not possible. The invertebrate olfactory system is an exception to this rule, and the relationship between oscillatory synchronization and sparse codes has been investigated both experimentally and with realistic computational models. Oscillatory activity in the brain is associated with sensory processing and cognitive states, and has been well characterized. In the antenna lobe of the locust, oscillatory synchronization is a feature of population coding during the presentation of an odorant. A small subset of neurons in the mushroom body, a structure known to be involved in the storage and retrieval of memory representations, actively responds to an odor. However, this response is sparse, and population codes differ markedly between the antenna lobe and mushroom body. Individual odorants are represented by subsets of sparsely distributed cortical neurons in vertebrates. Oscillatory synchronization is a mechanism for transferring information from the antenna lobe to the mushroom body, and is essential for reading the information contained across synchronized PN spike trains. To fine-tune this mechanism and enable the appropriate selection of coherent oscillatory signals, a form of activity-dependent plasticity between the antenna lobe and mushroom body may be required. This model makes a prediction that plasticity mechanisms governing synapses to KCs in the mushroom body will depend on the rate of spike occurrence averaged over longer intervals. This model is based on a biologically plausible computational model that includes the main processing steps of the insect olfactory system, but was designed to be general enough to allow comparisons to vertebrate olfaction and to sensory processing in other brain areas. The use of synchronized oscillations in the activity of neurons as a unique way of encoding sensory information could be a ubiquitous coding strategy exploited by several different modalities across different organisms.
The human genome has been mapped, which has led to new ways to study diseases like coronary artery disease (CAD) from a functional genomic perspective. Using new technologies and systems biology analyses, scientists hope to better understand the complexity of CAD and identify disease pathways for treatments that are tailored to specific disease mechanisms. In the Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene Expression (STAGE) study, researchers used a modified version of a clustering approach to identify functionally associated genes important for CAD. They did this by analyzing mRNA signals from multiple organs in 114 carefully characterized patients. The goal was to determine whether groups of genes worked together to contribute to CAD, and whether those groups acted in isolation in each organ or across several organs. The results of the study could help researchers understand how metabolic disturbances in organs like liver, skeletal muscle, and fat deposits could contribute to the progression and extent of coronary atherosclerosis.
This paper is about the circadian rhythm in bacteria. The rhythm is driven by a protein called KaiC, which has three functions: autokinase, autophosphatase, and ATPase. The ATPase part of KaiC is responsible for the rhythm and is controlled by a structural coupling with the kinase/phosphatase part. The circadian rhythm of cyanobacteria has been studied for many years, and researchers have found that it is driven by a protein complex of three different proteins: KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC. These proteins form stable complexes during the night, and the complexes control the phosphorylation state of KaiC. The phosphorylation state of KaiC changes over the course of a day in a stepwise fashion, and this change is responsible for the rhythm.
HIV-2 is a less harmful virus that causes a slower decline in CD4 lymphocytes, a higher proportion of undetectable plasma viral load, and a longer lifespan for infected individuals. It is more similar to SIVsm than to HIV-1, but they share only about 30% to 40% homology in the env and gag-pol sequences, respectively. HIV-2 uses a broader range of co-receptors, including CXCR6 and RDC1, while HIV-1 uses CCR5 and CXCR4. HIV-2 is not sensitive to SAMHD1, while HIV-1 is, and HIV-2 has a lower level of immune activation and peripheral plasmacytoid dendritic cell depletion. The immune responses against HIV-2 are more robust, and HIV-2 is able to establish a smaller reservoir of infected cells, which may be the reason for its lower pathogenicity. HIV-2 DNA levels in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) are equivalent to those measured in HIV-1 infected individuals with similar CD4 cell counts. HIV-2 infection takes place in both transitional-memory and resting central-memory CD4+ T cells, which may explain why it is more similar to non-pathogenic SIVsm infection or non-progressive HIV-1 infection of HLA-B*27+ or B*57+ LTNPs than to HIV-1 infection.
The human brain is able to focus attention on certain things while ignoring others. This ability has been studied extensively in the past, resulting in a wide range of theories and experiments. However, there are few models that can accurately explain multiple forms of attentional effects while taking into account the details of how the brain works. In this study, we present a new model called the Attentional Routing Circuit (ARC). The ARC is made up of many layers of neurons that work together to help us pay attention to specific things. The model is able to explain a variety of different types of attentional effects, including how attention can change the size and location of a neuron's "sensitivity" area (also known as its receptive field), how attention can make neurons more sensitive to certain things without changing their shape, and how attention can change the sensitivity of neurons to different stimuli. The ARC is made up of spiking neurons, which means that it can be tested and compared to real brain data. The ARC also makes several specific predictions that can be tested in the future.
Atrial fibrillation is a common and serious heart condition that causes significant problems. Current treatments for it have limitations and can cause side effects. It can also run in families, and it is estimated that about one in four people with atrial fibrillation has a family member with the condition as well. Researchers have identified many genes that may be associated with atrial fibrillation using various methods. However, these studies have had limitations, including small sample sizes, considering only a few genes, and lack of suitable control populations. To understand the genetic basis of atrial fibrillation and potentially develop better treatments, researchers studied whole exome sequencing data from a large group of people with atrial fibrillation and compared it to a control population. They also looked at whether certain genes that have been associated with atrial fibrillation in previous studies were more common in people with atrial fibrillation than in the control population.
Alveolar Echinococcosis (AE) is a disease that can affect humans and animals. It is caused by a type of worm called Echinococcus multilocularis. The disease has been reported in at least 42 countries of the northern hemisphere. Recent studies have shown that the worm is more common in foxes than previously thought and it has spread from rural areas to urban areas. AE is a slow-growing disease and it may take several years or even decades before symptoms appear. The disease is spreading in Poland, where a fox population has increased significantly in recent years. The Varmia-Masuria Province of Poland has the highest rate of infection with E. multilocularis in foxes. Human AE was first diagnosed in Poland in the 1980s, and since then, there has been an increase in the number of cases. These cases have been reported individually. There have been 14 human AE cases reported in total, with two of them diagnosed in the 1980s. In an attempt to coordinate scientific research into AE in Poland, four clinical centers in the country organized a reference laboratory for serologic differentiation. The first attempt to register human AE cases in Poland was made in 1998, and the Chief Sanitary Inspectorate of Poland has continued this effort since 2003. Preliminary data on 121 human AE cases registered in Poland from 1990 to 2011 have been analyzed. The treatment for human AE usually involves chemotherapy with albendazole and radical surgery. However, the cost of albendazole is high in Poland, which makes it difficult to treat the disease.
Zinc is an important metal for many processes in the body, such as immune activation, malaria parasite invasion of red blood cells, and glucose-induced insulin secretion. In addition, zinc is used by both beneficial and harmful bacteria that live in the human body. The ability of these bacteria to adapt to the host environment is dependent on their ability to withstand large changes in zinc availability. A protein called Zinc uptake regulator (Zur) helps bacteria cope with these changes by controlling the expression of genes involved in zinc import, ribosomal protein synthesis, and periplasmic zinc trafficking. Researchers have found that Zur is a highly sensitive receptor that responds to changes in zinc concentration at sub-femtomolar ranges. The Zur protein binds to a specific DNA sequence and turns off transcription when zinc is present in sufficient amounts. The researchers have also determined the crystal structure of Zur bound to the znuABC operator, which helps to understand the molecular basis of Zur-DNA cooperativity. Their findings have shed light on the mechanisms by which Zur regulates the expression of different genes and how bacteria can adapt to changes in the host environment.
Rift Valley fever is a disease that affects animals and humans. It is a virus that is transmitted by mosquitoes, and there are different types of mosquitoes that can transmit it. The disease causes high mortality rates in young animals and abortion storms in pregnant females. It can also cause severe complications in humans, such as encephalitis, retinitis or fatal haemorrhagic fever. The disease is found in most countries in Africa and has been reported outside of Africa as well. There have been outbreaks of the disease in Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania, Sudan, Mayotte, and Madagascar. In Madagascar, the disease has been found in cattle and humans, and there have been several outbreaks in the past. A study was conducted in Madagascar to understand how the disease is transmitted and to identify the factors that contribute to the recurrent transmission of the disease in that area. A model of the disease transmission was developed and used to analyze three scenarios that could explain the recurrent circulation of the disease in the study area. These scenarios include direct transmission between cattle during winter when there are no mosquitoes, low level vector-based circulation during winter with a residual vector population, and a combination of both. The study results suggest that the recurrent circulation of the disease in the study area is likely to be explained by a combination of both direct transmission and low level vector-based circulation during winter with a residual vector population.
The Asian tiger mosquito is a highly invasive species that has spread globally from Asia and the Pacific Islands to many other regions. It is known to carry and transmit several harmful viruses, such as dengue, chikungunya, and Zika. Despite its importance, the genetic structure and patterns of this mosquito population in the Indo-Pacific region are not well understood. This study used nuclear and mitochondrial markers to analyze the genetic makeup of Aedes albopictus populations in SE Asia, Papua New Guinea, and other Pacific islands. The study found that there was a high degree of genetic diversity in these populations, which suggests that they have been separated for a long time. It also found that there was a high degree of human-mediated migration between these populations, which is likely due to travel and trade. The study used ABC analysis to determine the most likely scenario for the colonization of the Torres Strait Islands in Australia. It found that the mosquito population there had gone through a genetic bottleneck due to human interventions and environmental conditions, but it was still genetically diverse. Overall, this study provides valuable information about the genetic structure and patterns of Aedes albopictus in the Indo-Pacific region and can help inform control strategies for this important disease-carrying mosquito species.
Schistosomiasis is a severe illness that affects millions of people around the world, especially in sub-Saharan Africa. In Tanzania, the condition is particularly widespread and can lead to severe health problems in children and adults. In a region around Lake Victoria in Tanzania, intestinal schistosomiasis, caused by the parasite S. mansoni, is particularly common and can cause serious health problems in school-aged children. The severity of the condition can be measured by ultrasonography and physical fitness tests. However, physical fitness tests have not been found to be useful for evaluating the severity of the condition in young children. Instead, physical fitness and quality of life questionnaires may be more effective for evaluating the severity of the condition in young children.
Leptospirosis is a worldwide zoonosis that is caused by a spirochete of the genus Leptospira. It is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions, especially in areas with heavy rainfall and slums. It can cause a severe infection called Weil’s disease in humans with a fatality rate of 5-15%, characterized by jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage. Leptospirosis also affects animals, causing reproductive failure, abortion, and infertility in cattle and acute febrile illness with renal and hepatic failure in dogs. The main reservoir of Leptospira are wild rodents, such as brown rats, which are asymptomatic and carry leptospires in their kidneys. Leptospires are shed in the rat’s urine and infect humans and other animals through direct or indirect contact with the contaminated environment. Brown rats appear to have a specific association with the Icterohaemorrhagiae serogroup that causes most human cases of leptospirosis worldwide. To understand the transmission of leptospirosis, it is important to study the infection kinetics in rats.
Sepsis is a serious condition that can cause organs to fail, such as the lungs, kidneys, and liver. It affects around 18 million people worldwide each year and the number of cases is increasing. The current treatments for sepsis are not very effective and researchers are working on developing better treatments. Some researchers are studying a protein called AnxA2 to see if it can help treat sepsis. AnxA2 is a protein that helps keep cells together and has been found to be involved in many cellular processes and diseases. It is not clear how AnxA2 is related to sepsis, but recent research suggests that it may be able to help regulate the inflammatory response during sepsis and protect organs from damage.
The paper is about how the innate immune system, specifically cells called monocytes/macrophages, can play a role in the spread of HIV-1 virus. These cells are important for early-stage viral transmission, persistence, and virus dissemination throughout the body. They can also accumulate HIV-1 for prolonged periods of time. The paper also discusses how these cells are able to migrate into tissues and how they can deliver HIV-1 to all tissues and organs in the body, including the brain. The paper also discusses how toll-like receptors (TLRs) play a role in regulating both the innate and adaptive immune system, and how stimulation of TLR-dependent pathways can lead to the activation of transcription factors such as nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-κB) and the expression of type I interferons ( IFNs) and pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. The paper also discusses how TLR triggering can contribute to HIV-1 pathogenesis, but that some TLR ligands, such as lypopolysaccharide (LPS) and polyinosine-polycytidylic acid (poly (I∶C)), can inhibit HIV-1 replication in macrophages. The paper also discusses how other innate immune cells, such as microglia, can be affected by TLR stimulation and can also inhibit HIV-1 infection in an interferon-regulatory factor 3-dependent manner. Finally, the paper discusses how microRNAs (miRNAs) are potent regulators of gene expression and how they can be regulated by inflammatory stimuli. The paper also discusses how some miRNAs can directly target the 3′ untranslated regions (3′UTR) of the viral mRNAs and how they can inhibit viral replication. The paper also discusses how some miRNAs are more abundant in monocytes than in macrophages and how they can contribute to the reduced susceptibility of monocytes to HIV-1 infection. Finally, the paper discusses how some miRNAs, such as miR-155, can play a fundamental role in establishing appropriate immune responses and how they can be up-regulated upon TLR3/4- but not TLR7-stimulation, and how specific inhibition of miR-155 can partially restore HIV-1 infection in poly (I∶C)-stimulated MDMs.
This paper looks at how plants control their growth, which involves cell division and expansion. There are six classes of phytohormones that control growth, including gibberellins, auxin, brassinosteroids, abscisic acid, cytokinin, and ethylene. These hormones regulate different types of growth, with some promoting long cell expansion and others promoting short cell expansion. The paper found that these hormones can be both redundant and specific, meaning they can have multiple functions or just one specific function. For example, a mutation in a biosynthetic enzyme of gibberellins or brassinosteroids results in a dwarf phenotype. This is because these hormones are nonredundant, meaning they have a unique function. On the other hand, treatments with gibberellins or brassinosteroids result in the up-regulation of many common target genes, meaning that there is significant integration and crosstalk between these hormone pathways. The paper also found that the circadian clock regulates many phytohormone-associated transcripts, meaning that there is an intimate connection between phytohormone activity and time-of-day specificity. The paper suggests that the circadian clock gates both IAA pathways and IAA-mediated growth. Finally, the paper shows that the circadian clock and light signaling pathways interact to coordinate the expression of biosynthetic, catabolic, receptor, and signaling genes from multiple phytohormone pathways. The coordination of phytohormone transcript abundance correlated well with the time of maximum growth, consistent with phytohormone pathways directly controlling growth. The paper also identifies and characterizes a cis-regulatory element that is overrepresented in phytohormone gene promoters, showing that it confers both diurnal and circadian cycling to the luciferase (LUC) reporter in vivo. The paper proposes a model in which the circadian clock indirectly controls growth by maintaining light signaling during the early part of the evening, which ensures that peak phytohormone transcript abundance coincides with the end of the dark period. This provides a framework for understanding how seedlings transition from dark-dependent to light-dependent growth after germination and respond appropriately to changes in the light environment.
The research group of Dr. Julio Sandoval from the Universidad Autónoma de Santa María (Chile) presented a new study to control disease vectors, such as mosquitoes and insects that transmit parasites to humans. They proposed a new strategy to control insect pests by delivering pieces of genetic material called double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) to the insects through bacteria. The bacteria are genetically modified to produce dsRNA specific to the insect's genes involved in development, fecundity, and the ability to transmit the parasite. The researchers used the insect Rhodnius prolixus, a vector of Trypanosoma cruzi, which causes Chagas disease, as an example. They showed that when the insect ingests bacteria that produce dsRNA specific to RHBP or catalase genes, it affects the normal development of the insects and their ability to reproduce. This could be a promising method for the control of disease vectors in the future.
Pregnancy and fever can be dangerous, leading to maternal death and infant illness. In 1984-1986, malaria was the main cause of illness for pregnant refugees on the Thai-Burmese border. Malaria can cause death and can lead to preterm birth, stillbirth, and miscarriage. There are no safe and effective antimalarial drugs for pregnant women, so antenatal clinics are the only option for prevention. However, diagnosing malaria can be difficult, and without a confirmed diagnosis it's difficult to give the right treatment. A study of pregnant women and their babies on the Thai-Burmese border found that fever during pregnancy increased the risk of neonatal death by 2.5 times. This study aimed to identify the organisms causing fever in pregnant women on the Thai-Burmese border.
The article discusses the importance of meiotic recombination during gametogenesis in humans, which leads to genetic diversity in the next generation. This process involves crossover events that can occur in different locations along the genome. However, there are differences in recombination rates and patterns between sexes, with females having lower rates at the telomeres, longer genetic maps, and more sex-specific hotspots. These differences may be caused by sexual dimorphism in the regulation of the meiotic process. The article also discusses high levels of variation in recombination rates among individuals, both between and within sexes. Furthermore, the number of crossovers in gametes of the same individual can also vary, but whether this variation translates into variation in offspring recombination is not well understood. The article highlights the importance of age in recombination, as maternal age has been linked to chromosomal aneuploidy. It has been observed that oocytes ovulated late in life are the result of more premeiotic mitotic divisions. To further investigate this, the article densely genotyped individuals from 68 French-Canadian families in Quebec and localized recombination events at high resolution. They found a significant genome-wide decrease in recombination rate with advancing maternal age, and that chromosome-specific effects likely drive this reduction. The article compares its results with previous studies and highlights a proposed model in which protection against non-disjunction through recombination becomes less efficient with advancing maternal age in some chromosomes.
Scientists are looking for new ways to make vaccines that work better for people who have weakened immune systems. They found that special cells in the body, called innate immune cells, can remember past infections and fight off new ones. This is called "trained immunity." They did experiments with mice and found that if they were given a special kind of vaccine, the mice could still be protected against a dangerous fungus even if they didn't have the usual kinds of immune cells that help with adaptive immunity. This new kind of vaccine could help protect people with weakened immune systems from getting sick.
Polycomb group (PcG) proteins are important epigenetic regulators of plant development. These proteins work in two complexes, PRC1 and PRC2, to regulate gene expression. Recent studies show that PcGs have specialized functions. To understand these specialized functions, researchers have analyzed plant mutants with lost PcG proteins. However, many PcG proteins are ubiquitously expressed and have redundant functions, so it is difficult to determine their specific roles. To address this question, researchers used next-generation sequencing technology to compare genome-wide H3K27me3 and gene expression profiles in loss-of-function mutants for each PcG protein. They found that the CLF component of PRC2 works with different PRC1 subunits to repress flower and embryo development. The specificity of the repression depends on the binding motifs of particular transcription factors (TFs) that interact with the different combinations of PcGs.
In this study, the authors investigated the role of the Trigger Loop (TL) in RNA synthesis during transcription by Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Sce) RNA polymerase II (Pol II). The TL plays an important role in the critical steps of Nucleotide Addition Cycles (NACs), which are essential for RNA synthesis. The TL is a mobile and flexible part of the Pol II active site that is critical for kinetic selection of correct Nucleotide Triphosphate (NTP) substrates while balancing transcription speed and fidelity. The authors used genetic and biochemical studies to analyze the functions of TL residues and identified three distinct classes of transcriptionally defective TL mutants associated with differential stress response profiles. They also examined the mechanisms by which proximal Pol II domains communicate with the TL and identified examples of inter-residue epistasis, which are likely drivers of incompatibility of RNAP evolutionary variants when placed in the Pol II context. Overall, the study provides new insights into the role of the TL in transcription and highlights the importance of its dynamic nature in RNA synthesis.
Rabies is a fatal brain disease in mammals that is caused by a rabies virus, a type of virus that can infect the brain and cause serious damage. The virus is usually spread through bites or scratches of rabid animals. After the virus enters the body, it travels through the blood to the brain and causes damage. In this study, researchers injected mice with the virus to see how the virus enters the brain. They found that the virus can travel from the blood into the brain and that it tends to go to certain areas of the brain. This can help scientists understand more about the disease and how to prevent it.
The paper explores the evolutionary history of the influenza A virus that caused the 1918 pandemic. The study finds that the virus underwent a major evolutionary shift after the pandemic, and that it continued to circulate in humans with varying degrees of severity for the next 90 years. The paper also finds that the virus underwent extensive reassortment with other influenza viruses from different species over the years.
The VTA is a key brain area that uses dopamine to signal reward and motivation, and plays a role in nicotine addiction. Nicotine stimulates nAChRs, which are activated and then desensitize quickly. The nAChRs come in different types, and different types are located in different parts of the VTA. The α4β2 nAChRs appear to be the main type that causes nicotine to become addictive, while the α7 nAChRs may help fine-tune the effect of nicotine on the VTA. It is unclear whether nicotine directly affects the dopamine-producing neurons or affects other neurons that produce GABA, which is a chemical that makes other neurons stop firing. We used a computer model to test both possibilities and found that each possibility requires different conditions to work. We also came up with a series of experiments that can be used to determine which possibility is correct. We found that the amount of endogenous acetylcholine in the VTA affects how nicotine affects the dopamine-producing neurons for both possibilities.
This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a new treatment method for cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL), a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites and transmitted by sandfly vectors. The study involved 40 patients with CL in Afghanistan who were randomly assigned to one of four treatment groups: group 1 received bipolar high-frequency electrocauterization (EC) and moist wound treatment (MWT) with sodium chlorite (DAC N-055); group 2 received EC and MWT alone; group 3 received EC and MWT with a placebo; and group 4 received a standard treatment of intralesional sodium stibogluconate (SSG). After 100 days, the results showed that group 1 had a higher cure rate of 85% compared to the other groups, which had cure rates of 35%, 30%, and 40%, respectively. Overall, the study suggests that DAC N-055 may be an effective and safe alternative treatment for CL.
The RAS/MAPK pathway is a complex signaling pathway that sends messages from the cell surface to the nucleus. This pathway is important for cell growth, differentiation, and survival. It involves a series of proteins that are activated in a specific order. These proteins include RAS, RAF, MEK, and MAPK. The goal of our study was to identify new proteins that regulate the activity of RAF and MEK, which are upstream of MAPK. We used a technique called RNAi to identify new proteins that affect the activity of these kinases. We found many new proteins that regulate RAF and MEK. Most of these proteins are involved in processing and splicing of RNA. We also found that the activity of RAF and MEK is not only regulated by proteins that act post-translationally, but also by proteins that regulate the expression of these kinases.
The Cryptococcus neoformans/C . gattii species complex is the cause of a potentially life-threatening disease called cryptococcosis in a wide range of animals and humans. There are two species of Cryptococcus: C . neoformans and C . gattii. C . neoformans is made up of two varieties and three serotypes, while C . gattii has two serotypes. Previous studies have shown that the main habitat of C . neoformans is soil enriched with pigeon excreta, decaying wood, and tropical and subtropical regions, whereas C . gattii is mainly related to eucalyptus trees in tropical and subtropical regions. However, a recent outbreak of C . gattii in a temperate area in Canada (Vancouver Island) has indicated an environmental shift of this species, and it has been found in association with native tree species rather than with eucalypt trees on Vancouver Island. The current study aimed to expand the current epidemiological knowledge by including a further 498 clinical, environmental, and veterinary isolates of the C . neoformans/C . gattii species complex.
In this paper, researchers wanted to determine how different regulatory networks contribute to the diversity of organisms. They looked at the evolution of cis-regulatory regions and transcription factors (TFs). The researchers found that evolution resulting from changes in TFs is more likely to have detrimental consequences. However, they also found specific examples of TF variation that may contribute to regulatory network evolution. They found that variations in non-duplicated TFs can change the binding specificities of DNA. They looked specifically at the C2H2-ZF TFs in Drosophila. They found that these TFs have a conserved modular structure and that changes in DNA-binding specificity are largely conferred by four DNA-contacting residues within the domain's alpha-helix. They then analyzed the DNA-binding specificity changes resulting from C2H2-ZF variation. They found that these changes often resulted in increasingly diverse predicted DNA-recognition motifs as evolutionary distance from D. melanogaster increased, implying that C2H2-ZF DNA-binding specificities may evolve gradually in evolutionarily viable steps.
Typhoid and paratyphoid fevers are major health problems in many parts of the world, particularly in Africa and South East Asia, and require quick and accurate diagnosis. This can be difficult because these diseases are caused by bacteria that can be difficult to identify with traditional methods. Molecular methods such as PCR can help with this, as they can identify the bacteria more quickly and accurately. In this paper, the authors describe a new molecular method for identifying the bacteria that cause typhoid and paratyphoid fevers. This method uses polymorphisms in a region of the bacteria's DNA called the CRISPR region. The authors tested this method on 20 different strains of bacteria, including strains that cause typhoid and paratyphoid fevers, and found that it was able to accurately identify the bacteria. This method could be used as an alternative to traditional methods for diagnosing typhoid and paratyphoid fevers.
The immune system is made up of different types of cells that work together to fight off infections. These cells are called T helper cells, or Th cells, and they can be divided into different groups depending on the type of cytokine they secrete. There is a type of Th cell called a Th1 cell that secretes a cytokine called IFNγ, which helps the immune system fight off intracellular bacteria and parasites. Notch receptors, which are proteins on the surface of cells that communicate with other cells, have been shown to play a role in the development of T cells. However, it is not clear how Notch receptors affect the differentiation of Th1 cells. In this study, researchers used mice with T cell-specific deletions of Notch1, Notch2, or both Notch1 and Notch2 to investigate the role of Notch receptors in Th1 differentiation. They found that Notch signaling through either N1 and/or N2 promotes the secretion of IFNγ by CD4+ Th1 cells. The researchers also used mice with T cell-specific ablation of RBP-Jκ, a protein that is needed for Notch signaling to occur, to investigate the role of non-canonical Notch signaling in Th1 differentiation. They found that Th1 differentiation is induced mainly by non-canonical Notch signaling. Overall, the study suggests that Notch receptors and non-canonical Notch signaling play a role in the differentiation of L. major-specific IFNγ-secreting Th1 cells, which are important for fighting off Leishmania major infections.
Sub-Saharan Africa is home to more than 62% of all HIV cases globally, despite only having 10% of the world's population. HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa may be made worse by the fact that many people there have parasitic worm infections, such as schistosomiasis. However, it is difficult to directly test this theory in humans. To better understand how worm infections might increase the risk of getting HIV, researchers used macaques infected with worms and exposed them to the HIV virus. They also studied how this infection affected the immune system and viral loads of macaques with HIV. This is the first time that worm infections have been studied in relation to HIV transmission in a relevant animal model.
The study investigates how the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) modifies the way neurons in the brain work together as a network. ACh is thought to play a role in arousal and sleep states. When we transition from deep sleep to wakefulness or rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, ACh levels increase. ACh affects neurons by working through two pathways, the nicotinic receptor and the muscarinic receptor. The nicotinic receptor directly depolarizes cells, while the muscarinic receptor suppresses voltage-gated potassium channels. When these channels are inactivated, the current associated with them (the M-current) changes the intrinsic excitability of neurons. In the past, it has been shown that ACh modulates neural excitability in two ways: by reducing spike frequency adaptation (SFA) and by altering the synchronization properties of neurons. The researchers wanted to understand how cholinergic modulation interacts with network connectivity structure to form different patterns of network activation that have been experimentally observed. To do so, they simulated a conductance-based (Hodgkin-Huxley) cortical network model that included cholinergic modulation and a Mexican hat type of connectivity scheme that was experimentally observed in various cortical areas. The researchers demonstrated that regulation of SFA in conjunction with the balance between excitation and inhibition leads to various network dynamics. They showed that ACh-driven reduction of SFA in model networks with lateral inhibition was responsible for the transition from moving to stationary dynamics, and that E/I balance was responsible for switching between highly local and global dynamics. They then studied the properties of the two states and their transition. Functionally, the high ACh state was found to be more sensitive to heterogeneities in network structure than the traveling wave state. In this neuron model, SFA and PRC effects occurred over different ranges of ACh, which led to three distinct functional regimes. Additionally, the researchers found that both SFA and E/I balance shaped network activity by setting the spatial (E/I balance) and temporal (SFA) extent of network upstates.
Esophageal adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that occurs in the food pipe and is becoming more common. The main risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma is a condition called Barrett's esophagus, which is caused by long-term exposure to acid and bile in the food pipe. This can cause inflammation and damage to the lining of the food pipe, which can lead to cancer over time. Mutations in DNA can also contribute to the development of cancer. Some genetic mutations occur more commonly in esophageal adenocarcinoma than in other types of cancer, but many mutations occur in only a small number of cases. It can be difficult to determine which genetic mutations are important for cancer development using traditional approaches. It may be helpful to look at groups of genes that work together in similar ways or pathways. One such group of genes is the SWI/SNF nucleosome remodeling complex, which is mutated in about 20% of esophageal adenocarcinoma tumors. Computational tools have been developed to help identify these groups of genes. Epidemiological studies have linked the rising incidence of esophageal adenocarcinoma to the eradication of a type of bacteria called Helicobacter pylori. It is thought that the bacteria that live in the food pipe may play a role in the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma. One way that bacteria interact with the food pipe is through a process called inflammation, which is a response to infection or injury. The TLR signaling pathway is a key part of the innate immune system, which is the body's first line of defense against infection. It is thought that the TLR signaling pathway may play a role in the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma by interacting with the bacteria that live in the food pipe. It is also thought that inflammation may be affected by genetic mutations in the TLR signaling pathway. This study aimed to look at the TLR signaling pathway in a group of people with esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's esophagus. It also aimed to look at whether genetic mutations in the TLR signaling pathway affect inflammatory signaling in an in vitro model system. Finally, it aimed to look at whether genetic mutations in the TLR signaling pathway are relevant in other types of cancer.
Taste is a major chemosensory system that helps animals to recognize different substances in the environment. Taste buds are the sensory organs for gustation, and they are found on the tongue and palate. Each taste bud contains different types of spindle-shaped epithelial cells that are involved in detecting different tastes. The study aims to understand the development of taste bud cells in mice by examining the transcription regulatory network of taste receptor calcium signaling molecules (TRCSMs). This is done by combining in silico and in vivo analyses.
In plants, roots are essential for absorbing water and nutrients and supporting the plant's body. The root system of monocotyledonous crops, such as rice, has a fibrous root system composed of a primary root, lateral roots, and adventitious roots. The primary root is initiated during embryo development and is a fundamental part of the root system that absorbs mineral nutrients and provides mechanical support for shoot growth. Auxin and ethylene are two important hormones that play central roles in root development. Auxin biosynthesis, transport, and signaling affect root development, and ethylene inhibits root elongation. In rice, ethylene promotes coleoptile growth but inhibits root elongation in the dark. In this study, we found that YUC8/REIN7, a member of the YUC gene family, is mainly involved in the conversion of IPA to IAA in auxin biosynthesis and root growth. The results provide a new insight into understanding of ethylene and auxin interaction in regulating rice root growth.
Pulmonary and other non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) infections have increased in humans globally, but these diseases are not yet considered a serious public health threat. This is because there is little evidence to support human-to-human transmission, and most NTM species have not been well defined. There are around 150 recognized species of NTM, and their species spectrum varies depending on the geographical region. Most NTM species are isolated from pulmonary samples, but many remain as colonizers. Extrapulmonary involvement of NTM is commonly seen in lymph nodes, skin, soft tissues, bones, and central nervous system. Despite this broad disease spectrum, there are not many studies on the incidence of NTM in most parts of the world, including Saudi Arabia. To understand more about NTM in Saudi Arabia, a prospective study was conducted to analyze the species spectrum, clinical relevance, underlying risk factors, possible mortality, and geographical adaptation of NTM.
Studies in mice have shown that consuming a diet that mimics calorie restriction (CR) or mutations in growth and nutrient signaling pathways can increase lifespan by 30-50% and reduce or delay the onset of many diseases. The TOR pathway is a conserved pathway that regulates lifespan in simple eukaryotes and mammals. Studies have shown that inhibiting this pathway extends lifespan in yeast, fruit flies, and mice. In yeast, this is accomplished by inhibiting the TORC1 complex, which regulates cell growth and proliferation. It remains unclear which aspects of the TOR pathway specifically contribute to aging and lifespan regulation. In this study, researchers screened a subset of yeast gene deletions using stress response and quiescence reporters to identify genes that are required for stress resistance and quiescence. They found that stress resistance and quiescence require the integration of multiple signaling pathways, including those transduced from the TOR/PKA, SNF1/AMPK, and cell wall integrity pathways. They also found that the Rim15, Yak1, and Mck1 kinases are required for metabolic reprogramming to increase energy stores and activate the anti-oxidant defense systems, which are important for extending lifespan. These findings suggest that metabolic reprogramming to increase energy stores and activate anti-oxidant defense systems are primary objectives of the anti-aging signaling network in response to nutrient scarcity.
The influenza A virus (IAV) continues to evolve to escape human immunity. Neutralizing antibodies (Abs) protect against IAV by targeting the virus's surface glycoprotein hemagglutinin (HA), which attaches to and fuses with cell membranes. These Abs typically target highly variable antigenic sites on the HA globular domain, reducing viral ability to fuse with cells. However, viruses can escape neutralization through a variety of mechanisms, including mutations that reduce antibody affinity or affect antibody binding, or that increase the virus's ability to bind cellular receptors. We have used a virus sequencing method to identify N-linked glycosylation sites within the HA globular domain that may be contributing to the fitness of Ab-escape variants, and thus increasing their likelihood of emerging.
The prolongation of the action potential (AP), the electrical activity that occurs when a heart muscle cell contracts, can be used as an antiarrhythmic strategy. However, this strategy has been difficult to use because it can cause arrhythmias. The reason why prolonging the AP can cause arrhythmias is because it can lead to something called reverse rate dependence, which means that drugs that prolong the AP can actually be more effective at slow heart rates than fast heart rates. This is because the heart naturally has a longer AP at slow heart rates, and when you add an AP-prolonging drug, it can have the opposite effect and shorten the AP, which can cause arrhythmias. To avoid this problem, researchers have been looking for ways to create drugs that prolong the AP in a forward rate dependence way, which means that they work better at fast heart rates than slow heart rates. The researchers in this study have used computer models of heart muscle cells to look at how different changes to the AP can affect its rate dependence. They found that while many changes can cause reverse rate dependence, there are also some changes that can cause forward rate dependence. This means that there are potential drug targets that could be used to create FRD AP-prolonging drugs. The researchers also looked at how the shape of the AP affects its rate dependence, and found that the shape is very important. Their results provide new insight into how to create AP-prolonging drugs that are safe and effective.
In this study, we aimed to create a new way of analyzing patient data using International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10) codes and biological test results. Our method considered a specific quantitative trait, TPMTa, to find new groups of patients with different characteristics.
Stem cells are cells that can develop into any type of tissue in the body. They have the potential to help repair tissues that have been damaged by injury or disease. Stem cells can be transplanted into a patient to help repair their body. This has already been done successfully for patients with blood and bone marrow cancer, and stem cells have been shown to help repair other organs and tissues in animals, including the liver, cornea, heart, lung, kidney, and brain. In addition to their ability to repair damaged tissues, stem cells have also been shown to have immunomodulatory and neuroprotective effects, which may help reduce rejection of transplanted organs and protect against diseases of the brain. Stem cell-based therapies have been studied extensively in animal models of traumatic spinal cord injury, and it is unclear which type of cells, where they come from, how many are needed, whether immunosuppression should be used, and whether the implanted cells need to be modified. The aim of this study was to review all controlled in vivo studies that have tested the efficacy of stem cells as a treatment in animal models of traumatic spinal cord injury. We found that stem cells appear to be effective in animal models of spinal cord injury, and that the type of cells, source, number, and modification of the stem cells used may affect their efficacy. However, the magnitude of these effects may not be large enough to be clinically meaningful, and there may be biases in favor of positive results in animal studies.
STHs are parasites that infect over one billion people worldwide. The four most common STHs are the roundworm, whipworm, and two species of hookworms. These infections are most common in warm climates with adequate moisture and occur in Central and South America, China, Southeast Asia, and sub-Saharan Africa. Factors that contribute to infection include poverty, lack of sanitation, and inadequate hygiene practices. Transmission occurs through contact with contaminated soil or consumption of egg-contaminated food. Although chemotherapy is the current global strategy for controlling STH infections, it does not prevent reinfection. This review and meta-analysis aimed to assess the global patterns of STH reinfection after drug treatment and identify the frequency and leading determinants of reinfection.
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a common cause of liver disease in Western countries, affecting 25-45% of the general US population. There are two categories of NAFLD: steatosis, an accumulation of fat in the liver, and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), which includes liver inflammation and hepatocellular injury with or without fibrosis. Gene deregulation occurs when cells lose control over certain genes, and can lead to various diseases such as NAFLD. Pathway enrichment analysis (PEA) uses metabolic maps to determine if a given list of genes is associated with a certain biochemical pathway, providing insight into gene deregulation. However, these approaches can miss information about the wide range of complex metabolic interactions and can be subject to biases associated with different pathway annotations. Modeling methods of biological networks such as metabolic, signaling, and protein-protein interaction networks can be used to study biological functions of the liver for the prevention and treatment of liver-associated disease. Here, we propose a method called Minimal Network Enrichment Analysis (MiNEA) that compares two conditions using transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics to identify deregulated minimal networks, which are reactions pertaining to various metabolic subsystems that can synthesize a target metabolite. MiNEA works by formulating metabolic tasks to mimic various NAFLD phenotypes, such as lipid droplet formation, lipoapoptosis, liver inflammation, and oxidative stress. These metabolic tasks include the known set of metabolites necessary to form the modeled phenotype. MiNEA uses these metabolic tasks to compute alternative thermodynamically feasible minimal networks applying thermodynamic constraints to a mouse GEM. We used mouse and human liver sample expression data and identified deregulated metabolic processes in mice and humans that potentially lead to the NAFLD phenotypes. MiNEA is a versatile tool for exploring and understanding different metabolic phenotypes.
The sense of smell helps us navigate, find food, and socialize. However, there are many different smells that we need to distinguish, which can be difficult because of their variety and concentration. The olfactory bulb is responsible for separating odor identity (what is there?) and odor intensity (how much is there?) to help us distinguish between smells. Researchers have found that the olfactory bulb processes the input by removing statistical redundancies and normalizing the signal, but it's not clear how this affects odor representations. One possible method is rank coding, where the order in which receptors are excited is used to encode the odor identity. This method is robust and independent of odor intensity. In this study, researchers developed a simple model of primacy coding and investigated how well it represents complex odors. They found that primacy coding is a useful way of encoding odor identity and that it outperforms other simple coding schemes. The performance of the olfactory system is dependent on tuned receptor sensitivities, which suggests that there is a strong selective pressure to adjust receptor sensitivities on evolutionary and shorter timescales.
HIV-1, the virus that causes AIDS, has a protein spike on its surface that is the only target for neutralizing antibodies. These antibodies come in many varieties and can be grouped into two main types: those that recognize glycans on the surface of the spike and those that recognize specific regions of the protein. The authors of this article describe how neutralizing antibodies work and how they can target different regions of the spike. They also discuss how the glycans on the surface of the spike can affect the way that these antibodies work. The authors found that some antibodies that recognize glycans on the surface of the spike are more effective at neutralizing the virus, while others are not as effective. They also found that some antibodies that recognize specific regions of the spike are also affected by the glycans on the surface of the spike. These findings have important implications for understanding how the virus is able to evade the immune system and how we might be able to develop new treatments for HIV.
In this study, we aim to understand how cancer cells grow rapidly, using glucose and glutamine. We reconstructed a simple mathematical model of cancer metabolism, called ENGRO1, and used it to identify the fittest way for cancer cells to use glucose and glutamine to grow. We found that cancer cells need to use glucose and glutamine simultaneously in order to grow quickly. This finding was confirmed in mouse experiments, where K-ras transformed fibroblasts grew faster when they had access to both glucose and glutamine.
In this study, the authors reinvestigate the PrPC interactome in mouse neuroblastoma cells (N2a), which are the best-characterized cell model for studying the biology and conversion of PrPC. They use quantitative mass spectrometry based on isotopic labeling to identify specific interactors of PrPC. They find that members of the mammalian prion protein family, including Doppel and Shadoo, populate highly similar molecular environments when expressed in the neuroblastoma cell model system. They also document that a subset of endoplasmic reticulum chaperones which interact strongly with PrPC escape from the ER to reside in spatial proximity to PrPC at the plasma membrane. Pharmacological inhibition of these chaperones could increase PrPSc levels in prion-infected N2a sublines, suggesting a protective role for the chaperones in this paradigm. Finally, their data consolidate multiple previously controversial interactions and suggest a scenario whereby PrPC may organize its molecular environment by its ability to recognize a specialized subset of cell adhesion molecules which recruit membrane proteins carrying high-mannose glycans into spatial proximity with PrPC.
Asthma and allergic diseases are caused by an overactive immune system that produces too many eosinophils, which are a type of white blood cell that helps fight parasites and some bacteria. However, eosinophils can also cause allergic reactions and asthma exacerbations. During an asthma exacerbation, the lungs produce a cytokine called IL-5, which causes eosinophils to move from the bone marrow into the lungs and increases the risk of asthma attacks. IL-5 is a type of cytokine that is made by immune cells called ILC2, which are found in the lungs. ILC2 are a type of innate immune cell that helps fight parasites and bacteria. They also produce IL-5 and IL-13 during infection. IL-5 helps eosinophils move from the bone marrow into the lungs. IL-13 is a cytokine that helps repair the lungs after infection, and amphiregulin, another cytokine, helps repair the lungs after infection and is made by ILC2. In this paper, the authors found that during infection with influenza A virus (IAV), there is an increase in IL-5 production in the lungs. This increase is caused by ILC2 producing IL-5 in the lungs during infection, and by the number of ILC2 and their ability to produce IL-5 increasing after the infection has cleared. The increase in IL-5 production by ILC2 is caused by IL-33, which is made by immune cells called alveolar macrophages and NKT cells that move into the lungs during infection. The significance of this finding is not discussed in this paper.
This article describes infections caused by Salmonella bacteria, which are associated with a wide range of diseases in humans. A subset of these bacteria can cause typhoidal illness, including Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi and various Salmonella Paratyphi pathovars. The vast majority of these bacteria are not commonly associated with systemic disease in humans and are referred to as non-typhoidal Salmonella (NTS). NTS includes Salmonella Typhimurium, Dublin and Enteritidis, which are known to cause diarrhea in humans. However, in some cases, NTS can also cause invasive (bloodstream) disease, which is most commonly caused by Salmonella Typhimurium and Enteritidis. This disease, called iNTS, is associated with an aggressive systemic infection that resembles typhoid fever. In sub-Saharan Africa, iNTS disease has a high mortality rate, and it is most common in children with malaria, malnourished children, and HIV-infected adults. In southern Vietnam, there is a shift in the etiology of bloodstream infections from Salmonella Typhi to NTS. A retrospective study was conducted at a major infectious disease hospital in southern Vietnam to investigate the clinical and microbiological manifestations of iNTS. The article concludes that iNTS disease is present in Asia but that there are no or few data regarding clinical symptoms, disease outcome, patient demographics, or the infecting serovars.
This article presents a method for using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to identify virus and phage structural protein sequences. The method involves training ANNs using the frequencies of amino acids in translated gene sequences, which are generalized as the percentage of the 20 naturally occurring amino acids. To determine an optimal ANN architecture, thousands of ANNs were trained with varying training parameters and assessed for their ability to correctly classify test cases using K-fold cross validation. The results showed high specificity and sensitivity for the classification of phage structural protein sequences. The method was also tested on capsid and coat protein sequences from the genomes of viruses that infect archaea and eukarya. Finally, the method was experimentally validated using transmission electron microscopy. The results of the study showed that the ANN predictions of hypothetical proteins were mostly validated, indicating that this method can be used to identify virus and phage structural protein sequences.
The oncogenic human herpesvirus 8 (KSHV), also known as Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus, is a member of the Gammaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family. KSHV is the cause of multiple malignancies, including Kaposi’s sarcoma and primary effusion lymphoma. After successful primary infection of the host, KSHV can undergo lytic replication or establish latency in infected cells. The mechanisms leading to transformation and oncogenesis are not completely understood, but both lytic replication and latency are important for KS tumor development. KSHV has a large DNA genome with at least 85 open reading frames. One of these is ORF20, which encodes three colinear isoforms: ORF20FL, ORF20A, and ORF20B. These isoforms differ in their amino acid length and start codon. KSHV ORF20 has been shown to affect the mitotic cdc2/cyclinB complex, leading to cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. However, studies with MHV68 WT and ORF20 mutant viruses did not find any effect on the cell cycle. Multiple UL24 family members have been shown to localize to the nucleoli of transfected cells. KSHV ORF20 has been shown to localize to the nucleoli of transiently transfected or transduced cells, including HeLa, 293T, primary HFF, HuARLT2, and HuARLT2-rKSHV. 219. A yeast two-hybrid screen of a human leukocyte cDNA library identified the transcriptional repressor methyl CpG binding protein 1 (MBD1) as an interacting partner of ORF20. The interaction with OASL is conserved among ORF20 isoforms and UL24 family members present in other herpesviruses. When expressed together, both OASL and ORF20 share numerous ribosomal interaction partners. ORF20 upregulates OASL mRNA expression downstream of RIG-I in an IRF3-dependent manner, but independently of IFNAR signaling. During reactivation of latently infected HuARLT2-rKSHV. 219, both OASL and ORF20 mRNA levels are upregulated early. Finally, OASL enhances KSHV infection in an ORF20-dependent manner, suggesting that KSHV has commandeered this interferon-stimulated gene to benefit its infection.
This article is about a study that looked at the causes of convulsions in children with fever ( CAWF ) in tropical countries. Viral infections, bacterial infections, and malaria are all possible causes of CAWF. However, not much is known about the contribution of Lassa virus disease ( LVD ) to CAWF in tropical countries. LVD is an infectious disease caused by Lassa virus ( LASV ) and is known to be prevalent in Nigeria. The study aimed to determine the prevalence of LVD in children with CAWF and compare its clinical manifestations with other common febrile illnesses in children. The study also looked at the current status of malaria as a contributor to CAWF in tropical countries.
Water scarcity is a major problem that affects crop growth worldwide. To address this issue, researchers have been working to understand the hormones and genetic networks that control drought tolerance in plants. Abscisic acid ( ABA ) and strigolactones ( SLs ) are two important drought-related hormones. SLs promote drought resistance in several plant species, including Arabidopsis thaliana, Lotus japonicus, and Solanum lycopersicum, through both ABA-dependent and ABA-independent pathways. Strigolactone signaling is controlled by the α/β-hydrolase protein DWARF14 (D14), which interacts with the F-box protein MORE AXILLARY GROWTH2 (MAX2) to form an Skp1–Cullin–F-box (SCF) E3 ubiquitin ligase complex. This complex targets D53 in rice and its orthologs in Arabidopsis, SMXL6/7/8, for polyubiquitination and proteasomal degradation. MAX2 is also necessary for responses to karrikins (KARs), which are a class of butenolide compounds found in smoke that promote seed germination in the post-fire environment. KAR treatment has additional effects on Arabidopsis growth that include inhibition of hypocotyl elongation and promotion of cotyledon expansion and greening in seedlings. The KAR signaling mechanism is likely to be very similar to that of SLs. In Arabidopsis, KAR perception requires KARRIKIN INSENSITIVE2 (KAI2), which is an ancient paralog of D14. MAX2 and KAI2 have not been directly associated, but residues that are required for D14 interaction with MAX2 are conserved in KAI2 proteins. Epistasis tests demonstrated that SMAX1 and SMXL2 act downstream of MAX2 as repressors of KAR responses. Because MAX2 functions in two pathways, max2 phenotypes cannot be readily attributed to defects in the SL, KAR/KL, or both signaling mechanisms. Further complicating the matter, a commonly used SL analog known as GR24 is typically synthesized as a racemic mixture; one GR24 enantiomer has the stereochemical configuration of natural SLs and selectively activates D14, whereas the other has an unnatural configuration and can activate both KAI2 and D14 in Arabidopsis. Spraying plants with rac-GR24 promotes survival after water deficit in both WT and SL-deficient max mutants. We hypothesized that KAI2 signaling may contribute to MAX2-dependent drought resistance. Here, we demonstrate a role for KAI2 in survival of Arabidopsis plants after water deficit, and identify physiological and molecular explanations for this function. Additionally, by analyzing the drought resistance of SL-specific d14 and kai2 receptor mutants, we find that both pathways promote plant adaptation to water deficit.
Schistosomiasis is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The best way to prevent it is by taking the drug praziquantel, but it has some limitations, such as not being effective against young worms and not preventing them from getting infected again. Therefore, a vaccine is needed to help reduce infection and transmission. Bovines, like water buffaloes, play a big role in spreading the disease in China. A mathematical model predicts that if a vaccine that reduces the number of eggs by 45% is developed and used with other interventions, it could almost eliminate the disease. Two types of insulin receptors have been identified in the parasite, and they may play a role in how the parasite uses glucose for growth and egg production. The receptor is located in the tegument and intestines of adult worms and in the vitelline glands of female worms. Vaccine trials have shown that a recombinant protein called SjLD2 reduces the number of eggs and size of adult worms, and a new trial is testing whether another recombinant protein called SjLD1, when used with SjLD2, can further increase the protection against the disease.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a major health problem that affects over 120 million people worldwide. It is caused by a parasitic worm (Wuchereria bancrofti) and is transmitted by a specific type of mosquito (Aedes polynesiensis) found in the South Pacific. In many areas, this mosquito species exhibits a unique transmission pattern that can hinder efforts to eliminate LF through the use of anti-parasitic drugs. One strategy for breaking this transmission cycle is through vector control, which involves targeting and removing the mosquitoes that carry the parasite. However, previous attempts at vector control have had limited success, due to challenges such as the inaccessibility of mosquito breeding sites and the difficulty of treating areas with a high density of mosquitoes. Recently, a new approach for vector control has been developed, based on the use of Wolbachia bacteria. These bacteria can be introduced into mosquito populations to cause sterility and a gradual decline in the number of mosquitoes. This approach has been successful in eliminating mosquito populations in field trials, and is now being considered as a potential strategy for controlling the primary vector of LF in the South Pacific.
In many countries, there are diseases that are not getting enough attention or treatment, including sleeping sickness (HAT). HAT is a disease that affects people and animals, and it can be spread by animals. Some of the zoonotic diseases include HIV, Avian influenza, H5N1, H1NI, and sleeping sickness. Most of these diseases happen in poor rural communities.
The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is an organelle that makes proteins and checks them for quality. If the proteins are not good, they are destroyed by a process called ER-associated degradation (ERAD). Ngly1 is a protein that helps with ERAD by removing sugar from misfolded proteins. Another protein called ENGase can also remove sugar from proteins, but leaves a small amount of sugar. ENGase is found in some animals but not all. Scientists have studied the effects of deleting Ngly1 or ENGase in different organisms and have found that the effects vary. Some animals, like fruit flies, have severe growth problems when Ngly1 is deleted. Humans with a rare genetic condition called NGLY1-deficiency also have severe symptoms, like movement disorders and vision problems. Recently, researchers found that ENGase can cause problems with ERAD when Ngly1 is deleted. They used a model protein to test this idea and found that ENGase creates proteins that are more likely to form clumps. Deleting ENGase fixed the ERAD problem in the Ngly1-deficient cells. However, it is not clear how ENGase affects animals that are missing Ngly1.
The goal of this study is to investigate how much variability there is in the spatial gene expression patterns that determine the body plan of Drosophila embryos. These patterns are controlled by a variety of molecular mechanisms that can affect the precision of the gene expression patterns, such as the concentration gradient of the Bicoid protein (Bcd).
