The study focuses on the gap gene Hunchback (Hb), which is responsible for forming segment boundaries in the body. The study shows that the Hb mRNA and protein production can introduce noise into the system, and that self-regulation of Hb expression helps to reduce this noise. The study also highlights the importance of binding site number and strength in determining the noise levels in the system. Overall, the study provides insights into the mechanisms that control the precision of spatial gene expression patterns during embryonic development.
Researchers recently found out that humans share 1.5-2.1% of their autosomal genome with Neanderthals, our evolutionary cousins. This is because humans mixed with Neanderthals around 47,000-65,000 years ago after humans left Africa and spread out. The Neanderthal DNA in humans is estimated to be from around 47,000-65,000 years ago, and there may have been a second pulse of Neanderthal DNA in the ancestors of people living in East Asia. Some Neanderthal DNA seems to be adaptive, but on average, selection has been suggested to act against Neanderthal DNA in humans. This is because Neanderthal DNA is not uniformly distributed along the human genome and some regions of high gene density and low recombination rate have low Neanderthal ancestry. Additionally, the X chromosome and the Y chromosome and mitochondria have lower levels of Neanderthal ancestry. The amount of Neanderthal DNA in Europeans has recently been shown to have decreased over the past 40,000 years, and this decrease is stronger near genes. Furthermore, a pattern of lower levels of Denisovan ancestry near genes and on the X chromosome in humans has also been reported. Researchers propose that differences in effective population size and resulting genetic load between humans and Neanderthals may have shaped levels of Neanderthal admixture along the genome. They developed a theory to predict the frequency of Neanderthal-derived alleles as a function of the strength of purifying selection at linked exonic sites, recombination rate, initial introgression proportion, and split time. They fit these predictions to previously published estimates of the frequency of Neanderthal ancestry in modern humans. Their results enhance our understanding of how selection shaped the genomic contribution of Neanderthals to our genomes, and shed light on the nature of Neanderthal-human hybridization.
HIV-1 is a virus that can cause AIDS, a disease that weakens the immune system. HIV-1 can infect cells and establish a "latent infection" that can last for decades. This means that even when someone is treated for HIV-1, the virus can still be present and cause harm. The virus has a way of controlling its own activity through a protein called Tat. But, sometimes, stochastic events can cause a change in the way the virus is regulated. This can result in clonal populations of cells that express the virus at different levels. We wanted to learn more about how these stochastic events contribute to the establishment and persistence of latent HIV-1 infections. We used a model of HIV-1 called LTR-GFP-IRES-Tat (LGIT) to study this. We found that the presence of specific proteins that bind to the HIV-1 promoter can affect how the virus is expressed. We also found that these proteins can work together, sometimes in a positive way and sometimes in a negative way, to control the expression of the virus. This can help us understand how HIV-1 establishes and persists as a latent infection.
In this study, we compared different orthology databases, which are used to identify genes with similar functions across different species. Orthology databases are important for understanding how genes and species have evolved over time. We looked at the size, quality, and methodology of eight different orthology databases, including COG, KOG, Inparanoid, OrthoMCL, EggNOG, RoundUp, OMA, and Ensembl Compara. We also compared these databases to two standard approaches used in ad-hoc analyses, bidirectional best-hits (BBH) and reciprocal smallest distance (RSD). These databases use different algorithms to group genes into pairs of orthologs or groups of orthologs and in-paralogs. We found that some databases group genes in a way that can lead to the loss of orthologous relations. To compare the different databases, we mapped the sequences of each project to OMA, which has the largest amount of sequences, and then compared the predicted orthologs. We also compared pairs of orthologs identified by different databases on an intersection set that included only the most competitive projects. Our results showed that RoundUp, Ensembl Compara, and OMA have the most predicted orthologous pairs, while OMA is able to identify the most orthologous pairs. Overall, our findings suggest that OMA is the most accurate orthology database for identifying genes with similar functions across different species.
This study presents a new approach for identifying potential new targets for schistosomiasis treatment, which is a parasitic disease that affects over one billion people globally. The researchers used a combination of methods for remote homology detection, protein structural information, and knowledge of drug-target interactions to identify potential targets within the schistosome genome. They also integrated this information with previously suggested schistosomicidal agents and their primary and secondary targets. The study identified 22 potential new targets, including CHK1, CDC2, WEE, PAKA, MEK1, ABL, and suggested approved drugs that could inhibit them, such as bosutinib, dasatinib, and imatinib.
This article explains how proteins that are unstructured or have long unstructured regions can still have a specific function. It uses the example of a protein called CREB, which is a transcription factor that helps control gene expression in response to changes in the cellular environment. CREB is a well-studied protein that has been found to be unstructured and then becomes structured upon binding to another protein called CBP. The article uses computer simulations to study the folding and binding mechanism of CREB to CBP, which involves a coupled folding and binding mechanism that typically begins with the binding of an unstructured region of CREB, followed by the folding of that region into a helix, and finally the docking of another helix. The article also explores the role of non-specific interactions in the binding process and finds that non-specific interactions increase the binding rate constant, reflecting the increased interaction cross section.
Schistosomiasis is an infection caused by worms that live in human blood vessels. It is a long-term infection that can cause anemia, stunted growth, impaired cognition, and other health problems. There are three main species of schistosomiasis, but S. mansoni is the only one found in Latin America and the Caribbean.
The transmission of HIV-1 is characterized by a genetic bottleneck, meaning that only a small number of viruses are passed on to the next person. Scientists are studying the viruses that are transmitted, called transmitted/founder (TF) viruses, to better understand the transmission process and develop new strategies for preventing HIV transmission. The TF virus has unique genetic and environmental characteristics that differ from those of other viruses in the transmitting person, suggesting that transmission is not completely random. A number of studies have identified these characteristics, including a preference for binding to specific receptors, shorter and less glycosylated proteins, and selection for more ancestral variants. To further investigate these characteristics, researchers generated infectious molecular clones with the env genes of both the transmitting and non-transmitting partners in a common viral backbone. They found that there was a strong selection bias for consensus-like HIV-1 variants in the transmission pairs. This means that the TF viruses were more similar to the consensus or average HIV-1 variant than other viruses in the transmitting person. In addition, the researchers also found that the TF viruses were more sensitive to neutralization by donor antibodies than the non-transmitting variants. However, they did not find any evidence that the TF viruses had increased particle infectivity, replicative capacity, or IFN-α resistance when compared to the non-transmitting variants. These findings suggest that the transmission potential of the TF viruses is not determined by their inherent in vitro replicative capacity or interferon resistance. Therefore, there may be other factors that are more important for determining which viruses are transmitted.
In this study, researchers have examined how the filarial worms that cause lymphedema affect lymphatic vessels in the body. They found that the worms secrete proteins that cause lymphatic vessels to become more permeable and form new blood vessels. This suggests that the worms might actually be able to help the body's lymphatic system function better, rather than causing more damage as previously thought.
The article describes a method for amplifying the genome of a single cell using a technique called Multiple Displacement Amplification (MDA). The researchers used FACS flow cytometry to isolate single cells and fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to select specific microbes. However, MDA has the disadvantages of generating DNA from non-specific templates (DNA contamination or primer dimers) and amplifying the template unevenly. To improve specificity, the researchers reduced the reaction volume from microliters to nanoliters using a microfluidic device. The device is integrated with a cell sorter to isolate single cells and reduce contamination. The researchers compared the performance of MDA with the reduced reaction volume and showed that it resulted in reduced background amplification and increased specific amplification of the desired template. The researchers used direct pyrosequencing to assemble and map the amplified genome onto the consensus genome.
Hantaviruses are a type of virus that can cause a potentially deadly disease in humans called Hantavirus Cardiopulmonary Syndrome (HCPS). These viruses are spread by rodents, which can carry several different types of hantavirus. There are three different species of hantavirus that cause disease in humans in Brazil, and some of these viruses are carried by more than one type of rodent. These viruses have been found in many different types of rodents in the Atlantic Forest and Cerrado biomes in South America. The main way that people get hantavirus is by inhaling the particles of the virus through the air or by coming into direct contact with the blood or saliva of an infected rodent. There are many different factors that can influence how these viruses are spread in the environment, including the hosts’ distributions, the arrangement of contact areas between hosts and humans, and the climate. In this study, the authors used geographically weighted regressions (GW) to explore how these factors might influence the distribution of hantavirus hosts in the environment. The authors found that the proportion of hantavirus hosts in a given community was positively correlated with the amount of agricultural matrix in the landscape, and that it was negatively correlated with native forest cover. The authors also found that the total habitat diversity of the landscape had a positive effect on the proportion of hantavirus hosts in the community. The authors conclude that landscape structure can influence the distribution of hantavirus hosts in the environment, and that this information can be used to develop strategies to prevent the spread of hantavirus disease.
The genus Flavivirus, including Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), Dengue virus (DENV), West Nile virus (WNV), and Zika virus (ZIKV), is a family of mosquito-borne human pathogens that can cause various diseases such as dengue haemorrhagic fever, dengue shock syndrome, encephalitis, and birth defects. These viruses are internalized into dendritic cells such as Langerhans cells and keratinocytes, which are then activated and migrate to the lymph nodes, leading to the spread of the virus into peripheral tissues. During infection, flaviviruses induce apoptosis (programmed cell death) in cells, which is believed to be a mechanism for the pathogenicity of flavivirus infection. However, the biological significance of apoptosis in flavivirus infection remains largely unknown. In this study, we showed that cells infected with JEV, DENV, and ZIKV specifically induced apoptosis by inhibiting BCLXL through the suppression of MCL1 expression, leading to BAX/BAK-dependent apoptosis. Moreover, we found that host protein synthesis was impaired in cells upon infection with these viruses, leading to the decay of labile proteins such as MCL1. Treatment with inhibitors for BCLXL or deficiency of BCLXL gene enhanced engulfment of virus-infected cells by macrophages without an increase of the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, leading to the suppression of viral dissemination.
Canine rabies is a serious disease that affects humans and animals. It is costly as many of the associated costs are not due to illness but rather the consequences of human deaths and efforts to prevent the disease. The case fatality rate of rabies in humans is almost 100% and the disease is preventable through timely post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). However, in many developing countries, PEP is often unavailable. Rabies exposures in humans or animals result in economic impacts associated with vaccination or death. Because rabies patients die quickly and there is no effective therapy, the cost of illness is relatively small, especially in the developing world. In contrast, the major direct costs arising from factors such as PEP and livestock deaths have been characterized in numerous studies. Resultant of the fatality of rabies and the efficacy of PEP, many individuals who are at very low risk of developing the disease still seek PEP. Canine rabies also has indirect costs, including vaccination of livestock and companion animals, and laboratory-based surveillance with diagnostic testing of animals suspected of rabies. Other impacts of rabies on the broader economy can be captured by examining changes in different sectors that result from the direct and indirect impacts of the disease. Knobel and colleagues (2005) estimated global monetary expenses resulting from rabies at $695 million annually. Hampson and colleagues (2015) estimated that approximately 59,000 people die globally from rabies each year. Rabies is endemic in Viet Nam with about 100 human cases reported annually. Most of the exposures, PEP, and rabid dogs occur in northern, more rural provinces. In addition, many of the victims are children from poor communities. In 2010, a large canine rabies outbreak occurred in Lao Cai province, resulting in 156 locals being bitten and given PEP, with three deaths. In 2011, another canine rabies outbreak was identified when nine rabid dogs from five communes in three districts of the Lao Cai province were diagnosed, biting 22 locals, resulting in one death. Common metrics to measure the impact of canine rabies were incorporated into this analysis, including the direct and indirect costs for PEP, dog vaccination efforts, livestock losses, and disability-adjusted life years. The results from this analysis detail the level of burden created by canine rabies in Viet Nam, examine whether canine rabies impacts in Viet Nam are consistent with other Asian countries, and determine if savings can be realized by reducing the impacts of PEP.
A new study from scientists at the University of California, Berkeley, has revealed that there are two different types of T2SS secretin assemblies, each with its own unique targeting pathway. The PulD secretin, which is found in Klebsiella oxytoca, is recognized and targeting by the PulS pilotin, while the EpsD/GspD secretin, which is found in Vibrio cholerae, is recognized and targeting by a different pilotin called AspS. These findings provide new insights into the structural and functional differences between these two types of secretins, and will help us better understand how these proteins are recognized and targeted for secretion in the cell.
Leptospirosis is a disease that affects humans and animals, and is spread by bacteria found in the urine of infected animals. These bacteria can enter the human body through cuts in the skin or contact with mucous membranes, leading to a potentially fatal infection. The bacteria have a lifecycle that includes several stages of infection, and it is important to understand the stage-specific interactions with the host. To better understand the disease, researchers are trying to identify and characterize proteins that mediate these interactions. In this study, researchers found that a protein called OmpL37 has strong binding to human skin elastin. This protein may play a role in the attachment of bacteria to elastin-rich tissues such as the dermis, vasculature, and lungs. The study suggests that OmpL37 is an important protein in leptospirosis and may be a potential target for vaccines or other treatments.
The immune system produces antibodies to protect against disease. Some antibodies recognize and neutralize HIV-1, a virus that causes AIDS. These antibodies can be used to treat AIDS, but they are expensive to make. Scientists have found a way to make these antibodies cheaper by using a type of yeast to produce them. They have also found that these antibodies can be stored for a longer time without losing their effectiveness. These advances could help make treatment for AIDS more affordable and accessible.
Onchocerciasis is a disease caused by parasites that can cause blindness, and it affects many people in Africa. Currently, the only way to control the disease is by giving everyone in affected communities a drug called ivermectin every year. This has worked very well for many years, but there are concerns that it may not be enough to completely get rid of the disease. A study was done to find out if it is possible to stop giving the drug to people in some parts of Africa and still keep the disease under control. This study lasted 6 years, and it found that it is possible to stop giving the drug and the disease will not come back. This means that it might be possible to eliminate onchocerciasis in some parts of Africa, and this would be great news for people who have been suffering from the disease.
The main objective of this study was to understand the process of cell entry by human rhinovirus (HRV), a non-enveloped virus. The process of cell entry by HRV involves a capsid that releases the viral RNA into the cytoplasm by interacting with membranes and forming a channel. VP4, a protein found in the capsid of HRV, plays a crucial role in this process by exposing itself on the surface of the capsid and interacting with membranes. The study also suggests that VP4 forms a homo-multimeric, size-selective membrane pore.
Tularemia is a disease caused by infection with Francisella tularensis (Ft), a bacterium that can be found in humans, animals, and the environment. Infection can occur through skin contact, insect bite, or inhalation of contaminated air. Ft is considered a bioterrorism agent due to its high infectivity and mortality, and its ability to be transmitted through the air. There are different subspecies of Ft, including Type A and Type B, which can cause disease in humans. Francisella novicida (Fn) is a subspecies that is not harmful to humans but is closely related to Type A and Type B. Fn is often used as a model for studying the biosynthesis and pathogenicity of Ft. Lipid A is a part of the lipopolysaccharide molecule found in the cell walls of many Gram-negative bacteria. Lipid A is responsible for various pathological responses in Gram-negative bacterial infections. Lipid A molecules from Ft and Fn lack the ability to activate the innate immune system and have little to no endotoxic properties. The lipid A molecule from Ft and Fn has a unique structure with amide-linked fatty acids at the 2 and 2′ positions and ester-linked fatty acids at the 3 and 3′ positions. In this study, researchers screened Fn mutants for enzymes involved in lipid A biosynthesis and modification. They identified three enzymes: FlmF1, FlmF2, and FlmK. These enzymes are involved in the synthesis and modification of the undecaprenyl-phospho-mannose or galactosamine donor lipid, respectively. The researchers created mutants of these enzymes and found that they were attenuated in mice after subcutaneous and pulmonary infection. They also found that these mutants stimulated an increased innate immune response as compared to wild-type Fn or other bacterial lipid A biosynthetic mutants. This increased immune activation appears to involve the MyD88 signaling pathway. In summary, the researchers identified enzymes involved in lipid A biosynthesis and modification, created mutants of these enzymes, and found that these mutants were attenuated in mice after infection and stimulated an increased innate immune response.
The protein Era is involved in ribosome biogenesis in bacteria. It is a member of the P-loop ribosome-associated GTPase family and is important for the maturation of the 30S subunit of the ribosome. The protein interacts with the 16S rRNA and several ribosomal proteins, and has also been reported to interact with proteins involved in 16S rRNA maturation. When bound to the 16S rRNA, Era prevents the formation of the 30S preinitiation complex until the appropriate time. Additionally, Era interacts with the stringent response, a signaling system that helps bacteria cope with stress, and is important for the processing and homeostasis of rRNA.
Anthrax is a disease caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. The bacterium produces a poison that can cause severe illness and death in humans and animals. The poison, called anthrax toxin, is made up of three parts: edema factor, lethal factor, and protective antigen. The lethal factor is toxic and can cause rapid death in animals. However, the reason for this rapid death is not well understood. Some animals are more sensitive to anthrax toxin than others, and some die very quickly after exposure. Scientists are trying to understand the molecular basis for anthrax toxin-mediated effects that lead to shock and death in animals. They are also trying to understand the role of nitric oxide (NO), a molecule that can relax blood vessels and make them more flexible, in anthrax toxin-mediated pathogenesis. In the past, scientists have studied the role of one type of NO synthase, called inducible NO synthase (iNOS), in anthrax toxin-mediated effects. They found that animals without this type of NO synthase were not more sensitive to anthrax toxin. However, the scientists wanted to study the role of other types of NO synthase in anthrax toxin-mediated pathogenesis. They found that animals without the neuronal NO synthase type were more sensitive to anthrax toxin and had more severe heart damage after exposure.
Scientists have reported the use of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technology to create mutations in the nematode Strongyloides stercoralis. This is a human parasite that causes skin-penetrating intestinal infections in around 100 million people worldwide. By targeting a specific gene called unc-22, scientists have been able to isolate mutant nematodes with uncoordinated (unc) phenotypes characterized by decreased motility and sporadic spontaneous twitching. The researchers found that these mutations are heritable and can be passed down through generations. This breakthrough paves the way for further studies of gene function in parasitic nematodes, which may eventually lead to the development of new targeted therapies to improve human-parasite control.
In this study, the authors present a model to analyze ribosome profiling data and the effects of premature termination of ribosome translation. They show that taking into account ribosome drop-off is crucial for correctly interpreting the data and modeling translation rates. The model, based on the Totally Asymmetric Simple Exclusion Process, predicts that ribosome profiles can be modified due to drop-off and that, under physiological conditions, non-intuitive density profiles can result. The authors also show that ribosome profiles can coexist with low and high ribosome density domains separated by a domain wall. They make important predictions with physiological relevance, namely, that the translation rates of mRNAs that cannot sustain ribosome queues are more resilient to ribosome drop-off than those that can. These predictions are supported by a genome-wide analysis of S. cerevisiae, which reveals that highly codon-biased and rapidly translated mRNAs coding for proteins involved in translation are highly resilient to drop-off.
Soil-transmitted helminths (STH) are parasites that are common in sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, and South America. There are four main types of STH: whipworm, roundworm, and two types of hookworm. The World Health Organization (WHO) has been working to treat children with STH to reduce their health problems. However, if only children are treated, it will not stop the spread of STH. Therefore, some people are trying to develop a plan that includes adults in the treatment program. This plan is called the "DeWorm3" project. The plan is being tested to see if it is safe and effective.
Cholera is a severe diarrheal disease caused by a bacterium called Vibrio cholerae. There are two main types of V. cholerae, El Tor and classical, and they can be further divided into two serotypes, Ogawa and Inaba. These serotypes are important because they determine whether a person is immune to cholera or not. For example, if someone has been infected with V. cholerae O139, they are immune to O139 but not to O1. Similarly, if someone has been infected with V. cholerae O1, they are immune to O1 but not to O139. We have previously created a vaccine that contains a synthetic version of the Ogawa serotype, and it has been shown to be effective in mice. We wanted to see if a vaccine that contains a natural version of the Ogawa serotype would also be effective in mice.
The study showed that the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa and the fungus Candida albicans, two microorganisms that commonly infect humans, can inhibit each other's growth in the gut. Previous research has suggested that these two microorganisms have antagonistic interactions with each other. However, whether this interaction affects the pathogenesis of the infection is still unclear. The study found that P. aeruginosa and C. albicans can inhibit each other's growth in the gut, and this interaction can have a significant impact on the pathogenesis of infection.
HIV has a high rate of mutation, but this mutation also creates "escape mutant" (EM) viruses that are not recognized by CD8+ T lymphocytes. These mutations, however, also reduce the replicative capacity of the virus. When EM viruses infect a new host that lacks the appropriate MHC alleles to recognize the epitope, they often revert back to the original wild-type (WT) virus. This reversion from EM to WT virus slows down the spread of the virus, and it is associated with lower viral loads. The rate of reversion from EM to WT virus is highly variable and can be affected by the specific epitope, target cell availability, prior vaccination, and other factors. In general, the dynamics of escape and reversion in HIV-1 are slower than in experimental infection of macaques, suggesting lower immune pressure and lower fitness costs of escape in HIV-1. However, this analysis ignores potential differences in the size and diversity of the initial inoculum in natural HIV and experimental SIV infection. Recent studies suggest that most humans with HIV-1 infection acquire just a single viral strain, while about 24% acquire 2 or more variants. The ability of minor WT variants to outgrow a dominant EM variant is difficult to evaluate in humans because samples prior to the peak of acute infection are often limited. To study this in vivo competition between EM and WT variants, macaques can be infected with known proportions of EM and WT SIV or SHIV viruses. To sensitively and specifically quantify minor variants, we developed qRT-PCRs to study escape mutations that emerged at 2 different SIV Gag CD8 T cell epitopes. These assays are sensitive to variants comprising ≤0.01% of total virus, levels that would be almost impossible to quantify with standard cloning and sequencing techniques. By using these assays, we can now study how the ratio of EM∶WT virus in the infecting inoculum affects the dynamics of reversion in vivo and how this impacts viral load in acute and chronic infection. We found that the ratio of EM∶WT virus in the infecting inoculum can affect the dynamics of reversion in vivo and the impact of this on viral load in acute and chronic infection.
The authors of this study found that certain yeast strains living in different environments could better tolerate high levels of cadmium than most known yeast strains. They discovered that this trait was primarily due to changes in the PCA1 gene, which encodes a pump that removes cadmium from cells. They also found that PCA1 had undergone multiple rounds of adaptation during yeast evolution, and a weaker version of this gene had spread to most yeast populations. This may be due to a tradeoff between cadmium resistance and fitness under low cadmium levels.
In gastric cancer, a complex disease that affects the stomach, researchers have found that many different signaling pathways are involved. These pathways include E2F, K-RAS, p53, and Wnt/β-catenin. These pathways are known to be involved in cancer in general, but researchers have not yet studied them in gastric cancer. In this study, researchers looked at patterns of these pathways in gastric cancer samples to see if they could use these patterns to classify gastric cancer into different groups. They used a method that looked at the activity of each pathway in the cancer samples and used this information to classify the samples. The researchers tested this method using breast cancer samples and then applied it to gastric cancer. They looked at eleven pathways that are known to be involved in gastric cancer, and they found that three of these pathways were active in the majority of gastric cancer samples. These three pathways were nuclear factor-κB (NF-κB), Wnt/β-catenin, and proliferation/stem cell. The researchers also found that the combination of these three pathways could be used to classify gastric cancer into different groups, and these different groups had different clinical outcomes. This means that gastric cancer can be taxonomized using oncogenic pathway activity into biologically, functionally, and clinically relevant subtypes.
Superhelical stress can destabilize DNA, affecting the ease of initiation of gene expression or DNA replication. This destabilization can have a major effect on the frequency with which regulatory events occur. The amount of superhelical stress can vary in vivo depending on the energy charge of the cell. The level of superhelicity imposed on a region of DNA can have a variety of effects on the expression of the genes it encodes. Superhelical stresses can transduce the influence of protein binding to remote positions, and this mechanism is essential to many regulatory processes. Some genes have strong SIDD properties, meaning that they are particularly susceptible to stress-induced destabilization. These genes are enriched in regions where genes are divergently oriented. In prokaryotes, the strongest SIDD sites are found in the upstream flanks of genes encoding transcriptional regulators. This pattern is not found in endosymbionts and obligate parasitic bacteria. The strong SIDD sites in the E. coli K12 genome are associated with genes that directly respond to physiological and environmental stimuli. The downstream genes in a regulatory pathway commonly have the same SIDD properties in their 5′ flanks as the controlling transcriptional regulator gene itself. The study suggests that strong SIDD sites are active and necessary participants in the regulatory mechanisms governing changes in the global pattern of gene expression in response to physiological or environmental changes in prokaryotes.
High-mobility-group box (HMGB) proteins are important for a wide range of functions, including sex determination and immune signaling. There are two families of HMGB proteins: HMGB-UBF_HMG and SOX/TCF/MATA_HMG. The SOX/TCF/MATA_HMG family contains proteins that bind specific DNA sequences and are involved in differentiation and sexual processes. The HMGB-UBF_HMG family has functions in transcription, genomic stability, and the three R's. In yeast, six HMGB-UBF_HMG genes are involved in ribosomal DNA transcription, chromatin remodeling, and mitochondrial metabolism. In addition, there are two genes from this family that are involved in sexual processes. In S. pombe, the SpLsd1 protein demethylates histones and affects the epigenetic state of the cell. In mammals, the Y-linked testis-determining factor (SRY) is a founding member of the SOX subfamily, which is responsible for male sex determination by regulating Sox9. In S. cerevisiae, there are two genes of the MATA_HMG subfamily that are not involved in sexual reproduction. In S. pombe, the SpSte11 protein triggers the nuclear accumulation of SpSte11, which is required for the sexual process. In F. graminearum, several HMG-box genes are involved in sexual development. In P. anserina, all 12 HMG-box genes were deleted and the phenotypes of mutant strains were assessed. The results showed that six mutant strains had sexual reproduction defects, and one of the remaining two mutants had vegetative defects. Transcriptional analysis showed that an ortholog of SpSte11 is the hub of the HMG-box gene network and regulates the expression of FMR1 and FPR1 and fertility.
During the West African Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone from 2013 to 2016, there were more cases, deaths and economic consequences than any previous outbreaks. Prior to the epidemic, little was known about the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors' body fluids and its potential for transmission. Because of this, the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommended that EVD survivors abstain from sex or use condoms correctly and consistently for three months after discharge. However, during the epidemic, there were concerns about the transmission of Ebola virus from survivors' semen and other body fluids, especially after a few cases of sexual transmission were reported. To address these concerns, an observational cohort study was conducted in Sierra Leone to investigate the presence of Ebola virus in semen and other body fluids of EVD survivors. However, challenges were encountered, including the need for an unknown duration of follow-up, the potential infectiousness of specimens, the complexity of interpreting laboratory results, and the urgency of translating research findings into public health practice. Despite these challenges, a study was successfully implemented and interim findings were used to prioritize the development of semen testing programs. The results of the study will be published separately.
Chemicals are found in complex environments in the gut where bacteria interact with each other and their environment. The sensory systems of bacteria, like in E. coli, detect the chemical environment around them. Chemical gradients, which are concentration differences of chemicals, are the most common type of chemical stimulus that bacteria detect. E. coli grows in the mucus layer of the gut. E. coli's chemotaxis system helps the bacteria detect and move towards chemical gradients. Scientists have found that the way bacteria like E. coli sense and react to chemical stimuli is similar to how humans sense and react to the world around them. Scientists have found that a law called Weber's law helps predict how well bacteria like E. coli can sense chemical stimuli. Weber's law states that the minimum difference in stimulus that a bacteria can sense is related to the average concentration of the stimulus. Weber's law can be extended to other stimuli with the Weber-Fechner law and fold-change detection. Fold-change detection states that if a stimulus changes, the bacteria's response to that stimulus will change by the same amount. Scientists have now used a combination of information theory and measurements to predict the chemical environment that bacteria like E. coli likely encounter in the gut. This is important for understanding how bacteria interact with each other and their environment in the gut.
Adult tissue stem cells can produce all the different types of mature cells in a specific tissue. To maintain their function, stem cells need to divide and create new stem cells. However, during cell division, stem cells can become less powerful, which leads to a decrease in their ability to renew themselves. It is still not clear how long individual stem cells can renew themselves before losing their function. This article discusses the idea that stem cells have a finite lifespan and that this may be related to the number of times they can renew themselves. The article also discusses the factors that could contribute to stem cell renewal failure, such as damage to the stem cell DNA and changes in the way the stem cell gene information is stored.
Intestinal worms are a global health problem, particularly in developing countries. Infections with parasites like Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria, and Necator americanus can cause severe pathology and make people more susceptible to vaccines. There are approximately 2 billion people infected with intestinal worms. Children are particularly at risk. Worm burdens typically rebound within 6 months of treatment. Worms are becoming resistant to drugs, which raises concerns about the long-term use of drugs. There are no effective vaccines against intestinal worms. Macrophages are a type of immune cell that can do different jobs depending on where they are in the body and the type of infection. Infections with bacteria or fungi are usually treated with classically activated macrophages that help phagocytose (engulf) and kill the bacteria or fungi. Infections with worms, such as helminths, are treated with alternatively activated macrophages (AAMs) that play a role in repairing tissue damage. Recent research has shown that AAMs play an important role in protecting against helminth infections. Our study found that antibodies bind to the surface of worms and help trap them. They also help prevent tissue damage caused by the worms. We found that when antibodies bind to worms, AAMs upregulate arginase-1 and immobilize the worms. This process does not require signaling through the IL-4 receptor, which is usually involved in activating AAMs. We call these macrophages "helminth-antibody activated macrophages" or HAAMs. Our study showed that HAAMs are a new type of macrophage that is different from those activated by IL-4. This new type of macrophage has the potential to be used in vaccines to protect against worm infections.
This study used a new method to identify cells that have suffered DNA damage and are going through a process called homologous recombination (HR) in budding yeast. This process is important for repairing damaged DNA and keeping genetic information intact. The researchers first used a tool called fluorescent repressor-operator systems (FROS) to tag a specific site on a chromosome in yeast cells. This tool allowed the researchers to identify cells that have incurred DNA damage. The researchers then used this tool to measure how quickly DNA resection (a step in the HR process) takes place and how long it takes for cells to commit to HR. The results of this study showed that DNA resection takes about 2 hours and that there is a distinct phase of confinement of chromatin (a type of DNA structure) near the DSB (a break in the DNA strand) early in the resection period. These findings could help researchers understand the process of HR better and could lead to new ways to treat DNA damage caused by cancer or other diseases.
Chagas disease, also known as American trypanosomiasis, is a vector-borne disease that is spread by various triatomine species and is a major public health concern in Latin America. Despite efforts to control transmission, the disease remains active in many countries. Reinfection, or being infected with the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi multiple times, is possible in animal models and humans, although it is not well understood. Mathematical and computational models can help infer the frequency and timing of reinfections from field data. Four different hypotheses have been proposed to explain mixed infections in humans, which occur when a person is infected with more than one genotype of the same parasite. These hypotheses include the idea that the immune response is not complete during the acute stage, and that reinfections can occur in both the acute and chronic phases. By modeling these hypotheses, we can compare the predicted rates of mixed infections to the observed pattern to infer the rate of reinfection and which hypothesis has major relevance. This provides a conceptual background based on agent-based modeling to understand the rate of re-inoculations and the rate and timing at which re-inoculated parasites evade the immune system to reach persistence in humans.
This study aimed to identify the specific immune markers that contribute to dengue pathology or protection from disease. The study was conducted using a unique cohort study in Thailand. School-age children were monitored for active surveillance, and routine blood samples were obtained before and after the peak DENV transmission season. The study design allowed detection of DENV seroconversions in the presence or absence of overt, clinically relevant illness (referred to hereafter as symptomatic and subclinical infections, respectively). In a previously published study of this school-based cohort, memory T cell responses in pre-exposure PBMC were evaluated. Higher frequencies of DENV-specific IFNγ- and IL-2-producing T cells were reported among schoolchildren who subsequently developed subclinical infection, compared with those who developed symptomatic secondary DENV infection. In the current study, we extended our analysis of cytokine production associated with the clinical outcome of subsequent DENV infection by stimulating pre-infection PBMC samples with live virus and evaluating cytokine profiles in cell supernatants using a multiplexed cytokine immunoassay.
In this study, the authors used a mathematical model to explore the mechanisms by which the Hedgehog (Hh) gradient is translated into gene expression patterns in the Drosophila wing disc. They discovered that a transient expansion (or "overshoot") of the Hh gradient is necessary to distinguish different spatial domains of gene expression in response to Hh. The authors also found that Hh-dependent Ptc upregulation is required to create this transient overshoot, which allows cells to interpret the gradient in a concentration-dependent manner.
The authors of this paper describe how they have used genetic mutations in a roundworm, a fly, a mouse, and a human to better understand how the brain processes alcohol. They suggest that the way the brain processes alcohol is highly related to how the brain processes anesthetics, and that the brain uses a similar set of genes for both. They also explain that forward mutagenesis, a technique that creates new mutations, has been used to identify genes that affect behavior in mice. One of these mutations, called Lightweight, was found to be caused by a mutation in a gene that is similar to a gene found in roundworms that is important for processing anesthetics. The authors suggest that the Lightweight mutation may be responsible for the way some people are more susceptible to the effects of alcohol.
This article is about the immune response of mosquitoes to malaria parasites. Malaria remains a major disease and killing parasite around the world, and researchers are working on many ways to stop it. One approach is to use mosquitoes that have an immune response that is better able to kill the parasite. The study looked at the immune system of mosquitoes and how it responds to malaria parasites. This study found that a certain part of the immune system of mosquitoes, called the immune deficiency (Imd) pathway, plays a major role in killing the parasite. The study also found that certain genes in the Imd pathway are important for killing the parasite and that different parts of the parasite life cycle are vulnerable to the mosquito immune response. The study also looked at how the mosquito gut bacteria play a role in the mosquito immune response to the parasite. Overall, the study provides important information about how the Imd pathway in mosquitoes can be used to help stop malaria.
Bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells ( BMMSCs ) are adult stem cells that can divide and form various cells in the lab. They can also help with tissue healing by releasing cytokines, chemokines, growth factors and genetic material (such as miRNAs). BMMSCs can also fight bacteria and are being used in some treatments to help injured tissues heal. Paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) is a disease that causes fibrosis in the lungs. Treatment with antifungal drugs can control the infection but not the fibrosis. Some treatments have been shown to reduce fibrosis in animal models of PCM. However, using some of these treatments may increase the risk of complications, so new treatments are needed. The goal of this study was to see if BMMSCs could help with fibrosis in PCM patients. Unfortunately, the results showed that BMMSCs made the fibrosis worse, and not better.
Phlebotomine sand flies transmit Leishmaniasis, which is a disease that affects humans and dogs. Researchers are studying the seasonal patterns of Phlebotomine sand flies over several years in different parts of Europe and Africa to better understand how the disease is transmitted and how it may be affected by climate change. The researchers found that the seasonal patterns of Phlebotomine sand flies vary depending on the species and the location. They also found that some species are active during the cooler months, which could increase the risk of transmission during those times. Overall, the study provides important information on the seasonal patterns of Phlebotomine sand flies and how they may be affected by climate change, which can help researchers develop better strategies to prevent and control Leishmaniasis.
Orientia tsutsugamushi is a bacterium that causes scrub typhus, a serious disease with symptoms including fever, lymphadenopathy, rash and eschar. Scrub typhus is prevalent in Asia-Pacific regions and can be difficult to diagnose because the initial symptoms are often shared with other acute febrile illnesses. O. tsutsugamushi is transmitted to humans by trombiculid mites, which infest the areas where humans live and work. No vaccine has been effective in generating protective immunity against this infection, despite efforts to develop one. The O. tsutsugamushi genome has several repetitive sequences, including genes for conjugative type IV secretion systems and genes that exploit integrin-mediated signaling and the actin cytoskeleton to invade cells. Once inside the cell, O. tsutsugamushi moves along microtubules to the microtubule-organizing center in a dynein-dependent manner. O. tsutsugamushi infects peritoneal mesothelial cells, macrophages and polymorphonuclear leukocytes in experimental animals. In humans, O. tsutsugamushi has been detected in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from patients with acute scrub typhus. The bacterium induces large changes in gene transcription in naïve human monocytes, including genes involved in type I IFN pathway and genes involved in apoptosis. These in vitro results were related to the expression of genes involved in the immune response in patients with scrub typhus. The study highlights the role of IFN-mediated monocyte activation in the pathogenesis of scrub typhus.
This research investigates how insects remember the spatial information needed to navigate back home. Researchers know that insects can use different types of information, such as landmarks and visual memories, to guide their movements. However, it is still unclear if insects store additional spatial information with their visual memories, such as a vector or sequence of vectors. The researchers used mathematical models to simulate how ants might remember the route they took to return home. They tested their model by having a simulated ant navigate through a maze and then retrace its route. The researchers found that their model was able to replicate many features of ant navigation, such as the ability to use multiple visual memories without needing to know which memory is the correct one to use. They believe that the neural architecture of the ant's memory center, called the mushroom body, could be the substrate for this type of navigation. To test this, they used a previously developed model of how olfactory memories are stored in the mushroom body of fruit flies and adapted it to simulate how visual memories might be stored. They found that their model was able to successfully simulate how ants navigate back home. They believe that their model provides a plausible explanation for how ants are able to navigate back home, but they acknowledge that further research is needed to fully understand the underlying neural mechanisms.
Plants and bacteria have been competing against each other for billions of years. Plants have developed sophisticated defense systems to protect themselves from bacterial infections. They use a two-layer defense system - pattern-triggered immunity (PTI) and effector-triggered immunity (ETI). PTI involves the recognition of microbial patterns, while ETI involves the detection of pathogen effectors. Recently, it was discovered that Arabidopsis plants shed their cauline leaves, which are attached to the stem without a petiole, as a defense mechanism against bacterial infections. This abscission response can be triggered by bacteria causing either disease or effector-triggered immunity. The abscission signal pathway originally elucidated in floral organs is necessary for this defense response. Additionally, the defense hormone salicylic acid (SA) likely regulates leaf shedding.
The visual system is responsible for detecting moving images and computing their direction and speed. This information is used to predict the trajectory of moving objects and to determine their motion relative to the environment. Motion detection is an important class of computational problems in neuroscience. DSGCs are cells in the retina that are responsible for detecting the direction of image motion. It was shown that DSGCs receive DS input and that SACs provide input to DSGCs. SACs generate DS Ca2+ signals in their dendrites. Dendritic sectors can be activated independently, and the strongest Ca2+ increases are in the distal portions of the dendrites. It was proposed that dendrite-intrinsic electrotonics and lateral inhibition are the mechanisms for dendritic DS in SACs. However, passive models are not able to account for the properties of SAC DS, and active conductances or strong interactions between inhibitory and excitatory synaptic inputs are likely involved. To investigate further, whole-cell recording, two-photon imaging, and compartmental modeling were used. It was shown that DS in SACs can be generated by a dendrite-autonomous mechanism that relies on active conductances and a somatodendritic voltage gradient.
Infections can happen when as few as 10 cells of certain bacteria or viruses enter the body, but this number varies greatly depending on the type of pathogen. Some pathogens produce molecules that help them to evade the immune system, allowing them to grow and reproduce. If these molecules work locally, near the pathogen itself, then only a few of them are needed. But if they work at a distance, then many more are needed. In this study, researchers compared 43 different species of pathogens to see if this idea was correct. They used special methods to control for the fact that some pathogens may be more closely related and therefore have similar traits not because of any biological connection, but because they share a common ancestor. The results showed that pathogens with molecules that work at a distance require more cells to infect a host, and that they are also more likely to be virulent and cause harm to the host.
This research is looking into the miRNAs in the parasite worms that cause schistosomiasis, a disease affecting more than 200 million people worldwide. MiRNAs are small molecules that regulate the expression of other genes, and they play an important role in the development of organisms. This research has identified a family of miRNAs that seem to be particularly important during the transition from juvenile to adult schistosome worms. These miRNAs target genes that are involved in transcription, signaling, and stem cell maintenance. Some of these targets are differentially expressed between mature and immature female worms, suggesting a role in sexual maturation or sexual reproduction. Overall, this research provides insight into the molecular mechanisms that regulate the development and sexual maturation of schistosome worms, which may have important implications for developing new strategies to treat and prevent schistosomiasis.
Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is a severe and potentially deadly virus. It causes fever, headache, and respiratory problems such as cough, shortness of breath, and pneumonia. The virus is highly contagious and led to a global pandemic in 2003. The virus is caused by SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV), a type of coronavirus that shares similar genome structure with other coronaviruses. It has been previously assigned to a group of coronaviruses called CoV-2b. However, it is now considered that SARS-CoV originated in horseshoe bats, with civets acting as the intermediate amplifying and transmitting host. Recently, four new strains of SARS-related coronavirus (SARSr-CoV) have been identified from Chinese horseshoe bats, and two of these strains have been successfully cultured in vitro. These new strains are similar to SARS-CoV in the S gene, the part of the virus that codes for the protein that binds to human cells, and they replicate efficiently in primary human airway cells. Despite this evidence, there is still a gap in our understanding of how and where SARS-CoV originated from bat reservoirs. Therefore, a team of researchers conducted a 5-year longitudinal surveillance of bat SARSr-CoVs in a single cave in Yunnan Province, China. They identified 15 new strains of SARSr-CoV, 11 of which were closely related to SARS-CoV. The researchers also evaluated the efficiency of human ACE2 usage and the functions of accessory genes ORF8 and 8a for some of the newly identified strains.
Soil-transmitted helminths (STHs) are parasites that live in the intestines of people and animals, causing infections that can lead to various health problems. The main way to treat these infections is by taking anthelmintic drugs. However, overuse of these drugs can lead to resistance in the parasites, making it harder to treat them. Currently, one of the best ways to detect resistance in STHs is by using a test that measures the reduction in the number of eggs in the feces after treatment. However, a recent study found that egg production in hookworms, a type of STH, actually increased after treatment in dogs, despite the removal of a significant portion of the adult worm burden. This suggests that the reduced worm density after treatment may have removed the density-dependent constraints on egg production, leading to an increase in egg output. This could make it harder to detect resistance in STH infections using the egg reduction test. Therefore, it is important to be aware of this potential issue when interpreting the results of this test.
The development of the mammalian lung is a complex process that requires many different signaling pathways to work together. Heparan sulfate (HS) is a type of sugar that helps these signaling pathways work together. Researchers have made mice that lack Ext1, a gene needed to make HS. They found that the lung development of these mice was delayed and their lungs had many defects. They also found that SHH, a signaling molecule that is important for lung development, was not working properly in the mice. This led to changes in the growth of the lung buds. The researchers found that the HS in the epithelium was needed to make sure that SHH was working properly. Without HS, SHH was not able to signal properly and this led to changes in the development of the lungs. These changes were likely due to changes in the growth of the lung buds.
The paper "Detecting genome rearrangements in tumors using paired-end sequencing" presents a strategy for discovering cancer fusion genes through the use of paired-end sequencing. The paper describes a method for identifying genomic rearrangements in tumor samples by analyzing the mapped locations of end-sequence pairs. The authors provide formulas for calculating the probability of fusion between two genes based on the distribution of clone lengths and the number of mapped clones. They demonstrate that even with current sequencing technology, it is possible to detect most fusion genes with a very low number of reads, and that next-generation sequencers have the potential to detect rearrangements with a very high probability and localize breakpoints to intervals of only a few hundred base pairs. Overall, the paper highlights the potential of paired-end sequencing for understanding cancer genome organization and discovering new fusion genes.
Chemotaxis is the ability of cells to move in a specific direction in response to a chemical gradient. This ability is found in many different types of cells, including bacteria and amoebae. The process of chemotaxis involves three interrelated steps: motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. In fast-moving amoeboid cells, such as social amoebae and human neutrophils, motility comes from the periodic extension of actin-rich pseudopods. Gradient sensing is the ability to interpret the chemical gradient and direct intracellular proteins to the area of highest concentration. Polarization is the tendency for cells to have an elongated shape with distinct front and back edges. In response to a changing gradient, polarized cells turn in the direction of the new gradient. A new model of chemotaxis has been developed that combines a previously described excitable network with cytoskeleton-mediated deformations and polarization. The model can account for a wide range of reported observations about chemotaxing cells.
The study aimed to understand the role of TDRD6 protein in the regulation of spliceosome maturation and mRNA splicing during spermatogenesis. In spermatids, TDRD6 was found to be essential for the formation of spliceosome. The study revealed a male germ cell-specific pathway of spliceosome assembly. The findings of this study provide new insights into the understanding of spliceosome regulation during spermatogenesis.
The paper proposes a new method for analyzing colonization dynamics in bacterial populations. Currently, researchers use genetic distance between isolates to determine whether they are from the same colonization event or not. However, the authors of the paper present a fully Bayesian model that allows for the determination of the probability that two strains should be considered the same. This model takes into account the genetic distance between isolates and the time between the sampling of the isolates. The authors show that their model is more accurate and robust than the previous methods. They also demonstrate the usefulness of their model by analyzing a large collection of longitudinally collected methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus ( MRSA ) genomes obtained through a clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness of an MRSA decolonization protocol. The authors believe that their method will enable studies of the characteristics that impact colonization in the presence and absence of interventions.
Auxin is an important hormone that is involved in the formation of new organs in plants. This hormone is transported from cell to cell by carriers called PIN proteins, which are located at the cell plasma membranes. When these carriers are oriented in the same direction, they create fluxes of auxin that can lead to local differences in auxin concentration, which can then be interpreted by the plant as signals to form new organs. Two different hypotheses have been proposed to explain how PIN proteins are oriented in plants: the flux-based hypothesis and the concentration-based hypothesis. Using computer simulations, we found that the flux-based hypothesis is able to explain the formation of new organs in a realistic way, while the concentration-based hypothesis is unable to do so. This suggests that the flux-based hypothesis could provide a unifying principle for the guidance of auxin fluxes in the plant.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL), also known as "black fever," is a parasite-borne disease that affects the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. It can lead to death if left untreated. The rK39 is a widely used antigen for VL serodiagnosis, but it has limitations. A new antigen called rK28 has been engineered to improve its sensitivity, but it still needs to be tested. Researchers have used DNA sequencing technology to identify proteins that are recognized by IgG1 in people with VL. They have also developed a rapid diagnostic test (RDT) that can detect IgG1 in people with VL. The test will be cheaper and more robust than current RDTs.
Granulomas are formed when there is an interaction between the host's immune system and a persistent non-degradable antigen. There are different types of granulomas, depending on the type of immune response that occurs. Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) is a skin disease caused by a parasite called Leishmania. There are different types of CL, and they are often diagnosed based on the appearance of the skin biopsy. In some cases, the skin biopsy may look like a tuberculoid granuloma, which is a type of granuloma that is characterized by a lack of necrosis. This can make it difficult to diagnose CL, especially if someone has also been infected with other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis or leprosy. In this study, the authors looked at a large group of people with molecularly proven CL to see how often they had tuberculoid granulomas. They found that a significant number of people had this type of granuloma, which could make it difficult to diagnose CL. The study also looked at other factors that might be associated with having a tuberculoid granuloma, like the type of Leishmania parasite causing the infection and where the person got infected. This information could be helpful for doctors and other healthcare providers who are trying to diagnose CL in people who might have a tuberculoid granuloma.
Insulin resistance and inadequate insulin production are the main causes of type 2 diabetes, which is often associated with obesity. The risk of developing type 2 diabetes is also partly due to genetics, and many single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) have been found to be associated with the disease. However, little is known about the functional consequences of these SNPs at the molecular, cellular, and physiological levels. Obese mouse strains, such as Lepob and Lepdb mutations, have been used to study the pathophysiology and genetics of type 2 diabetes. However, the diabetic phenotype in these strains is not solely due to the mutation, and other factors, such as genetics, play a role. Lean mice may carry alleles that are either diabetogenic or protective against diabetes. Recently, two genes have been identified that contribute to the development of diabetes in obese strains. The Lisch-like gene has been suggested to be involved in the development of insulin-producing cells, and a variant of this gene has been found to be responsible for the diabetogenic effect of the DBA background in mice carrying the adipogenic db mutation. In a previous study, we identified a QTL called Nidd/SJL that aggravated and accelerated diabetes on distal chromosome 4 when crossed with the lean SJL strain. This QTL has similar chromosomal position to a previously identified diabetogenic QTL, Nidd1, which was found in an outcross of NZO with NON. The human syntenic region of Nidd1 and Nidd/SJL (human chromosome 1) contains a QTL for reduced insulin secretion in the Pima Indian population. Recent metaanalysis of diabetogenic mouse QTL identified distal chromosome 4 as one of seven consensus regions. Thus, Nidd/SJL is a prime target for positional cloning of a novel mouse diabetes gene.
The article explains how scientists are trying to understand the different types of cells that make up our immune system. There are many different types of cells that make up the immune system, each with its own specific job. Scientists are trying to understand how these cells are created and how they change over time. They are using a type of math to help them understand this process. This math allows them to model the different cells and how they interact with each other. They are finding that the different cells in the immune system interact in specific ways to create different types of cells. They are also finding that these different cells can change over time depending on the environment they are in. This means that the same cell can change its job depending on where it goes or what it encounters. This is important because it helps us understand how our immune system works and how it protects us from things like infections and diseases.
Scientists have been studying how animal transcription factors bind to DNA in the genome. They have found that many transcription factors bind to thousands of DNA regions throughout the genome. However, most of these regions are not bound by the transcription factors in vivo, which has been attributed to several mechanisms such as competition and cooperative interactions. The scientists are now using a model to predict how these mechanisms influence the binding of transcription factors in vivo. Their results support a model that suggests that animal transcription factors bind to DNA without the aid of direct cooperative interactions with other proteins. The model also suggests that the inhibition of DNA binding by chromatin structure is the dominant force that modifies the intrinsic DNA specificity of transcription factors. This explains why animal factors show widespread and overlapping binding.
Cell proliferation is a critical event in organ formation and is regulated by multiple signals. These signals help cells determine whether to continue proliferating or to induce cell cycle arrest and differentiation. The way cells integrate these signals to control the cell cycle machinery is a crucial issue that has been studied extensively. The basic Helix-Loop-Helix (bHLH) family of transcription factors are key regulatory molecules that help control cell cycle control, cell lineage commitment, and cell differentiation. In Drosophila, the Da and Emc proteins are the only representatives of classes I and V, respectively. These proteins interact and regulate cell fate decisions. Recent studies show that Emc functions as a negative feedback regulator of da expression. Changes in the expression of Emc by different signals modulate the levels of Da, which is a transcriptional repressor of String, a main activator of mitosis. Our study shows that Da functions as a transcriptional repressor of String, thereby regulating the G2/M transition in the cell cycle. Our study indicates that Id factors regulate G1-S transition in vertebrate cells and our data suggest that E proteins can also control the G2/M transition in conjunction with Id factors.
The article introduces a comprehensive analysis pipeline to investigate the effects of filamentous growth in yeast. Filamentous growth is a stress response of yeast cells, where they form elongated and connected multicellular structures called filaments. The study generates phosphoproteomic data from a subset of kinases involved in filamentous growth, and uses a custom analysis pipeline to identify candidate proteins and signaling pathways. The pipeline includes phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation network analysis, causal relationship discovery, and validation by literature mining. The study successfully applies the pipeline to analyze the data and identify candidate proteins that can be further intervened and studied in the future.
In this study, researchers investigated the effects of exercise on the brain of people with dementia. They looked at changes in brain structure and function using a variety of imaging techniques. The study found that regular exercise improved both cognitive function and brain structure in people with dementia, suggesting that exercise may be a useful tool in treating dementia.
EPEC and EHEC are serious causes of human diarrhea and death, so researchers use the natural mouse pathogen Citrobacter rodentium to model these infections. C. rodentium causes A/E (attachment and effacement) lesions, where bacteria attach to and colonize the intestinal lining. These lesions cause inflammation and hyperplasia (uncontrolled cell growth) of the colon. Th17 and ILC3 cells produce IL-17 and IL-22 respectively, to help control the infection. The gut microbiota also helps control the infection by preventing C. rodentium from colonizing the gut. The study showed that early C. rodentium colonies are small and don't cause much damage, but they trigger an innate immune response that prevents new damage from occurring. The innate immune response helps prevent the formation of new A/E lesions, which is important for controlling the infection. The study shows that these early colonies are important for understanding how the host and bacteria interact during infection, which could lead to new treatments or prevention strategies.
Malaria parasites have a special type of gene called the var gene, which is responsible for the diversity of the malaria parasite in humans. Each parasite has a different set of var genes, and researchers have studied how these sets of var genes overlap between different malaria parasites. The Sørenson-Dice coefficient is a common way to measure the overlap between two sets of var genes, but it has a flaw in that it underestimates the true overlap between two sets of var genes. This paper introduces a new way to measure overlap between two sets of var genes using Bayesian inference, which is a way of using probability to make predictions. This method gives a more accurate estimate of the true overlap between two sets of var genes, and also gives uncertainty intervals, which show how much the estimate might vary from study to study. The paper then re-evaluates past studies using the Sørenson-Dice coefficient and shows that the new method gives different results. The paper also shows how many samples of var genes are needed to get a good estimate of the true overlap. Finally, the paper provides a web tool and open-source code so that other researchers can use the new method.
Eukaryotic protein kinases (EPKs) are important for many biological processes and are associated with many diseases. PKA is the second EPK that was discovered and it has been used as a model for understanding EPK structure and function. EPKs have a catalytic core that allows for the transfer of the γ-phosphate of ATP to a protein substrate. The catalytic core is made up of two lobes, the N-lobe and the C-lobe. The R-spine is a key component of the catalytic core and it is what allows for the transfer of the γ-phosphate. The R-spine is anchored to the αF-helix through a highly conserved aspartate (RS0) and it is supported by an ensemble of conserved hydrophobic residues referred to as the Shell. When the R-spine is assembled, the active state of the EPK toggles between open, intermediate, and closed conformations as it traverses the catalytic cycle. The binding of ATP initiates the transition from the open to the closed conformation. The αC-helix, αC-helix, and β4-strand all have a negatively charged electrostatic surface, so two magnesium ions are required to fully neutralize the negative charge of the phosphates. The Glycine-rich Loop of the N-lobe seals the active site chamber in the closed conformation. When the substrate is positioned, phosphoryl transfer is achieved. Finally, the phosphorylated substrate and adenosine diphosphate are released and the EPK transitions back to an open conformation, poised to bind another ATP molecule. The β3K-αCE salt bridge is required for connecting the αC-helix with the β-sheet region of the N-lobe during the catalytic cycle and it is what allows for the neutralization of the negative charge of αCE. In the absence of the salt bridge, the mechanism can be restored by strengthening the hydrophobicity of the R-spine and Shell residues. The positive charge of β3K is required for neutralizing the negative charge of αCE, and in the absence of β3K, the misalignment of the γ-phosphate can cause inhibition of phosphoryl transfer. Removing both β3K and αCE simultaneously partially restores catalytic activity.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a disease caused by worms and spread by mosquitoes. The World Health Organization (WHO) has a program to eliminate LF, and they recommend using a strategy of mass drug administration (MDA) and morbidity management. The program has been successful, but it can be hard to tell if LF transmission is still happening after MDA. The WHO recommends using Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) to evaluate the success of MDA. TAS involve testing children aged 6-7 years old to see if there is still transmission. However, a recent study found that TAS of children aged 6-7 years old may not be sensitive enough to detect low-level transmission. This means that TAS may not always accurately tell if there is still LF transmission. This study highlights the need for more sensitive ways to evaluate the success of MDA.
In vertebrates, sex determination occurs in two phases: primary and secondary. Primary sex determination is the process in which an animal decides if it will develop as a male or a female. This can be controlled by a master regulator (like Sry in mammals), defined environmental conditions (like temperature in reptiles), or a complex polygenic mechanism. After primary sex determination, the animal goes through a period of secondary sex determination, in which it develops sex-specific characteristics. In some animals, sex can be reversed, such as in teleost fish. However, even in animals that do not normally switch sex, there is evidence that the process of sex determination and differentiation is not irreversible once established, and instead it requires constant maintenance via sex-specific transcription factors. For example, in mice, the male-specific transcription factor Dmrt1 is expressed in both germ cells and somatic gonad cells of the testis, and conditional deletion of Dmrt1 in postnatal testes results in a downregulation of testis-specific genes and an upregulation of ovary-specific genes. In zebrafish, primary sex determination appears to be regulated by a ZZ/ZW genetic system, though the gene involved has not been identified. By contrast, several studies have concluded that the most commonly used domesticated zebrafish strains lack any major genetic sex determinant, and instead rely on a polygenic system that is strain dependent. Even in wild strains where the W chromosome is necessary for female primary sex determination, it is not absolutely correlated with female development, as a fraction of ZW individuals develop as males. These results show that while a genetic sex determining system can strongly influence the outcome of sex determination in zebrafish, it is not an absolute prerequisite. In addition, there are systems other than dominant sex-determining loci that can influence or override a genetic sex-determining strategy. Oocytes are required for primary female sex determination in zebrafish. Recent work from our lab has demonstrated that oocytes are also required throughout adult life to maintain the female differentiated state. In vertebrates, bidirectional paracrine signaling between the oocyte and the surrounding granulosa cells is critical for the proper development and function of the follicle. Oocytes receive signals and nutrients from follicle cells throughout their development while the oocyte in turn signals to surrounding follicle cells to regulate their function. The oocyte is deficient in producing key enzymes necessary for glycolysis and cholesterol biosynthesis and instead produces signals that upregulate these pathways in granulosa cells, which in turn provide these essential compounds to the oocyte via gap junctions. Two of these oocyte-produced signals that regulate granulosa cell development are Growth differentiation factor 9 ( Gdf9 ) and Bone morphogenetic protein 15 ( Bmp15 ), which are closely related members of the TGF-β superfamily of signaling molecules and are expressed primarily by the oocyte in mammals and zebrafish. In mammals, Gdf9 and Bmp15 regulate granulosa cell development and estrogen production. In zebrafish, Gdf9 and Bmp15 are also required for female sexual development and maintenance of the female differentiated state. Cyp19a1 aromatase is the enzyme responsible for estrogen production by the ovary in mammals and zebrafish. In zebrafish, there are two genes that encode a Cyp19a1 aromatase, called cyp19a1a and cyp19a1b, which are products of the teleost-specific whole genome duplication event. In mammals, Cyp19a1 is expressed most highly in the granulosa cells of the oocyte follicle in the ovary and at significantly lower levels in Leydig cells of the testis. By contrast, in zebrafish, cyp19a1a appears to be restricted to the ovary while cyp19a1b is most highly expressed in the brain. In the present study, we test whether the oocyte-expressed signaling molecules Gdf9 and Bmp15 have any role in female sex determination or maintenance of female sex differentiation in zebrafish. We find that bmp15 mutant females initially have normal development but during the juvenile stage, oocytes are degraded after they arrest at early stages, and the premeiotic germ cells switch to a spermatogenic program as the gonad transforms to a fully functional testis. Consequently, all bmp15 mutant adults are fertile males. Additionally, we find that in wild-type ovaries, cyp19a1a is initially expressed in theca cells, but not granulosa cells that surround early stage oocytes, but then is upregulated in granulosa cells that surround stage II oocytes. In bmp15 mutants, by contrast, cyp19a1a expression in theca cells is apparently normal, but we do not detect its expression in granulosa cells.
