Overall, our analysis demonstrates that the Rho-GTPase cycling can access qualitatively diverse pathways in different cellular systems or through different experimental manipulations.
Schistosomiasis is a disease caused by parasitic worms that infects the intestines or urinary tract. It affects approximately 240 million people worldwide and is considered a neglected tropical disease. To reduce the burden of the disease, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends treating people with praziquantel, a drug that kills the worms. However, the WHO recommends treating school-aged children (SAC, 5-14 years) differently from adults. SAC are more likely to be infected by the parasite and may therefore be more important to target with treatment. However, the WHO does not currently recommend treating adults with praziquantel. Recent studies have shown that praziquantel may be safe and effective in treating pre-school aged children (pre-SAC, under 5 years). WHO recommends monitoring and evaluating treatment programmes regularly to determine progress. However, most data is collected from SAC only, which may not be an accurate indicator of the burden of infection in adults. To determine the impact of treatment strategies, it is important to collect broader age-specific data, including data on adults. This study explores how different age profiles of infection and burdens of infection in adults can impact the treatment coverage levels recommended by WHO. It highlights the importance of monitoring and evaluating treatment programmes regularly, and collecting data on all age groups.
Epilepsy is a brain disorder characterized by recurrent seizures that are caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a common form of epilepsy that occurs when seizures start in the temporal lobe of the brain. Anti-seizure drugs are the first line of treatment for epilepsy, but surgery can be an effective treatment option for people with TLE who do not respond to medications. In TLE surgery, the brain tissue that is believed to be causing the seizures is removed. However, not all patients who undergo surgery become seizure-free. Researchers have used magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to identify areas of the brain that are affected by TLE. Recently, it has been suggested that TLE may involve areas of the brain beyond the temporal lobe. Diffusion weighted MRI (DW-MRI) is a type of MRI that allows researchers to infer the pathways of white matter fibers that connect different parts of the brain. Researchers have used DW-MRI to create a detailed map of the structural brain connectivity in people with TLE. They have also used this information to create a computer model of the brain that can simulate the electrical activity that occurs during seizures. Researchers have used this model to predict the effectiveness of different types of surgery for TLE. They found that the model predicted that surgery would be effective in reducing seizures, but that subject-specific surgery would be even more effective in reducing seizures than standard surgery.
This article is about a virus called human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and its ability to cause tumors. HHV-8 is associated with a number of diseases, including Kaposi's sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma (PEL), and multicentric Castleman's disease. HHV-8 has several genes that have been shown to have oncogenic properties, meaning that they can promote tumor growth. However, most of these genes are active during the replication process of the virus, suggesting that they do not directly contribute to the development of tumors, but rather help the virus to replicate. It has been previously shown that the vIRF-1 protein of HHV-8 can inhibit the p53 protein, which is involved in tumor suppression. In this study, the authors found that vIRF-1 can also inhibit the GRIM19 protein, which is involved in apoptosis (cell death). They also found that vIRF-1 can bind to and inhibit the ATM protein, which is involved in the repair of DNA damage. These findings suggest that vIRF-1 may have an important role in the development of HHV-8-related diseases, and could be a target for new treatments. The authors conclude that further research is needed to understand the mechanisms by which vIRF-1 interacts with these proteins, and how these interactions contribute to the development of HHV-8-related diseases.
The human lung is constantly exposed to many microorganisms and foreign substances. The lung immune system helps protect us from these harmful substances by removing them quickly. However, sometimes the immune system overreacts and causes damage to the delicate structures of the lung. This damage can lead to acute lung injury, which can result in impaired gas exchange and even death. The air-interface structure of the lung contains a complex immune cell population that helps to control lung homeostasis and prevent damage from occurring. One of the most important players in this process is the αVβ6 integrin, which is only found in the lung. Deletion of the β6 subunit of this integrin has been shown to protect mice from acute lung injury caused by bleomycin, ventilator-associated lung injury, airway hyper-responsiveness, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia. In addition, β6 KO mice have large and foamy alveolar macrophages that produce more of a type of enzyme called MMP12. Respiratory infections such as influenza can lead to acute lung injury. Deletion of the β6 subunit in mice has been shown to protect them from influenza-induced acute lung injury. This protection is due to the fact that αVβ6 helps regulate the lung's immune response to infections. These findings have important implications for the treatment of acute lung injury, as transient inhibition of αVβ6 may be an effective therapy.
The leishmaniases are a group of vector-borne tropical diseases that affect millions of people in the world, mostly in tropical and subtropical regions. The most common form of the disease is called ATL, which is caused by the parasite Leishmania (Viannia) braziliensis and affects the skin and/or mucous membranes. One of the challenges of diagnosing ATL is that the parasites are difficult to detect in the skin and mucous membranes, especially in mucosal lesions. To help diagnose this disease, doctors use a test called the LST, which involves injecting a sample of the parasite into the skin and measuring the swelling that occurs. This study aims to compare the results of the LST in people suspected of having ATL in an area where this disease is common. It includes a comparison of the results of the LST with other clinical and demographic factors, such as age, gender, the type of lesion, and the duration of the disease.
Atherosclerosis is a form of chronic inflammation that causes plaque buildup in artery walls and is a leading cause of heart disease and death worldwide. Genetic variants can increase the risk of atherosclerosis, and researchers have used genome-wide association studies to identify over 40 genetic regions that contribute to this risk. However, the precise mechanism of how these genetic variants increase the risk of atherosclerosis is often unknown. In this study, researchers used a technique called FAIRE-seq to measure changes in chromatin accessibility in human macrophages in response to atherosclerosis-associated lipids. They found that these changes in chromatin accessibility were correlated with local gene expression and the binding of key transcription factors. Additionally, they found that many of these regions contained variants that increase the risk of coronary artery disease. They also identified a specific variant that affects the expression of a gene involved in foam cell formation and atherosclerosis. The protein product of this gene is upregulated in foam cells and has increased enzymatic activity for degrading pro-inflammatory mediators. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of atherosclerosis and suggest potential therapeutic targets.
Trachoma is a problem in many parts of the world. It is caused by a type of bacteria that infects the eyes. The bacteria can cause swelling and redness in the eyelids, which can eventually lead to blindness if not treated. There are ways to prevent trachoma from spreading, but it can be hard to know where to focus those efforts. In this study, researchers looked at how well a single treatment with antibiotics could reduce the spread of trachoma in Malawi. They found that the treatment was effective and helped to reduce the spread of trachoma. This study is important because it helps researchers and health workers know how to best treat trachoma in different places around the world.
Scientists have discovered six plant proteins, called calcium-dependent protein kinases (CPKs), that help plants fight off invading pathogens. These proteins play a crucial role in recognizing when a plant is under attack and then triggering the plant's immune response. The scientists found that different CPKs are involved in different parts of the immune response, including the production of nitric oxide and the activation of programmed cell death. They also discovered that different CPKs interact with different proteins inside the plant to trigger these immune responses. This new information will help scientists understand how plants recognize and respond to pathogens more effectively.
The article focuses on the prevalence of schistosomiasis in Mali. The study found that the overall prevalence of schistosomiasis in Mali was 55%, with a case distribution orbiting the 7–14 age-category. The study highlights the lack of Schistosoma sp. time-series forecasting methods, particularly in Sahelian locations such as Mali. To address this issue, the study used general-purpose exponential smoothing (ES) methods within a state-space framework to produce contemporaneous on-line forecasts of Schistosoma sp. consultation rates for the district of Niono in Mali. The state-space framework allowed for the capture of seasonal and inter-annual TS fluctuations and could assist with managing Schistosoma sp. infection in this district and possibly elsewhere in the Sahel.
Herpesviruses, like human cytomegalovirus (HCMV), have the ability to interfere with the cell cycle of infected cells to help the virus replicate. To do this, HCMV encodes two proteins, pUL21a and pp150, which have specific interactions with the cell cycle. pUL21a blocks the progression of the cell cycle at the mitotic stage by targeting cyclin A for proteasomal degradation. On the other hand, pp150 arrests the cell cycle at the G0/G1 stage, preventing viral replication. However, pp150 is also subject to cyclin A-CDK-dependent regulation, which allows viral gene expression to resume in the G2 stage. In this study, the authors found that the pp150-RXL motif alone is not essential for viral growth, but when combined with a mutation in the pUL21a-RXL motif, it enhances the mitotic phenotype and growth defect of a pUL21a-RXL single mutant virus. This suggests that pUL21a and pp150 work together as a fail-safe system to ensure undisturbed HCMV replication under non-mitotic conditions.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a rare, progressive and fatal neuromuscular disorder that affects motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis. The majority of ALS cases are sporadic, meaning they occur without a family history of the disease, but 5-10% of cases are familial, meaning they are inherited in a Mendelian fashion within a family. While there is only one approved treatment for ALS, there has been a recent explosion in the number of genes linked to ALS, thanks to advances in next-generation sequencing techniques. However, many of the known ALS genes have been identified in familial cases, and the genetic landscape of sporadic ALS remains largely unknown. In this study, the authors used a hypothesis-driven targeted sequencing approach to identify new variants in known ALS disease genes, as well as genes associated with ALS, in a cohort of sporadic ALS patients and controls. They also tested previously identified variants in their cohort, and identified new variants in genes previously identified in a trio study and in genes that contain RNA recognition motifs, like TDP-43 and FUS. The study showed an increase in novel and rare variants in cases versus controls, and demonstrated the utility of rare variant binning to show that sporadic ALS individuals have a higher burden of deleterious mutations in previously implicated ALS genes. The study highlights the challenges and limitations of such studies and the need for further studies with more patient and control samples, but also provides important information on the genetic landscape of sporadic ALS.
Influenza is a dangerous virus that can be fatal, especially in children and the elderly. Scientists are trying to understand more about how the body's immune system fights against this virus. A protein called interleukin-6 (IL-6) is thought to play a role in how well the immune system fights against the virus, but it is unclear how important it really is. To figure this out, scientists studied mice with and without IL-6 to see how they responded to the virus. They found that without IL-6, mice did not develop as much long-term memory of the virus as they did with IL-6. This means that IL-6 is important for helping the immune system remember how to fight against the virus in the future.
Researchers have found that Dnmt2, a protein that helps DNA methylation in bacteria and some eukaryotes, can also methylate tRNAAsp, a type of transfer RNA. They also discovered that enolase, a protein involved in sugar metabolism, can inhibit Dnmt2. This finding adds to our understanding of how DNA methylation works and how it is regulated.
The study was aimed at discovering miRNAs, which are small non-coding RNA molecules, in the saliva of Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes and understanding the effect of CHIKV infection on miRNA expression profiles. The researchers used deep sequencing to identify and characterize miRNAs in mosquito saliva. They discovered a total of 103 mature miRNAs in Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus saliva, of which 31 were potential novel miRNAs. They found that 59 miRNAs were upregulated in Ae. aegypti CHIKV-infected saliva, and 30 miRNAs were upregulated in Ae. albopictus CHIKV-infected saliva. These findings suggest that miRNAs play a vital role in CHIKV transmission and dissemination in the host.
Mitochondria are important organelles in cells that produce energy for the body. They have their own DNA that is different from the DNA in the cell's nucleus. Mitochondrial DNA is smaller than nuclear DNA and it contains genes that are essential for the body. These genes make proteins that help the electron transport chain, which is a group of proteins that helps the mitochondria make energy. The remaining proteins needed for energy production are made in the nucleus and then sent to the mitochondria. The mitochondrial DNA has its own replicase, a protein that copies the DNA, and its own polymerase, a protein that adds nucleotides to the copied DNA. There are also other proteins in the nucleus that help replicate the mitochondrial DNA and make sure that it is copied correctly. Rad51, Rad52, and Rad59 are nuclear proteins that are essential for recombination, a process that helps fix DNA damage. It is not known how these proteins help fix DNA damage in the mitochondria. They have been found in the mitochondria, which suggests that they may help fix DNA damage in the mitochondria. There is also a system in yeast that can be used to study the process of repairing DNA damage in the mitochondria. This system can show when a specific type of DNA damage occurs in the mitochondria and how long it takes to fix the damage. The results of this study showed that Rad51, Rad52, and Rad59 are important for fixing DNA damage in the mitochondria. This study also showed that these proteins have different roles in the nucleus and the mitochondria.
Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a big health problem in many parts of the world, particularly in developing countries or disadvantaged communities within developed countries. It is caused by an abnormal immune response to a type of bacteria called Group A Streptococcus (GAS) that infects the throat (streptococcal pharyngitis) or skin in people who are susceptible to it. GAS is spread through direct person-to-person contact via saliva or nasal secretions. RHD is a long-term, debilitating condition that can cause heart problems like arrhythmias and heart failure. It most often affects children and young adults. To prevent RHD, it is important to prevent GAS infection and stop it from causing ARF and RHD. Current prevention strategies include early detection and treatment of GAS infections, regular injections of penicillin, and medical and surgical treatment of heart failure. However, these strategies may not be effective in areas with poverty or disadvantage, and medical treatment may not completely eliminate the risk of RHD. To help prevent RHD in these areas, it is important to understand the specific aspects of poverty that create the conditions that cause RHD, and to evaluate any public health interventions that target these factors. We did a study to find out more about this.
The PhoQ/PhoP system in E. coli is a well-known example of a two-component signaling pathway that is responsible for responding to a variety of environmental stimuli, such as low Mg2+, low pH, and the presence of cationic antimicrobial peptides. It controls transcription of a large set of genes and has an architecture found in many bacterial two-component signaling systems. The system is bifunctional, meaning it has both a kinase and a phosphatase activity, which allows it to regulate its input-output relationship, suppress cross-talk, and have autoregulation. The PhoQ/PhoP system responds to stimuli in a graded manner, meaning that as the stimulus increases, the response also increases. However, when a single point mutation is made in the histidine kinase PhoQ, it abolishes its phosphatase activity, resulting in bistability. Bistability means that the mutant can exist in two different states for many generations - an OFF and an ON state. This mutation is shared among many two-component systems. However, the bistable phenotype comes at a cost to the fitness of the population, which can become trapped in a low-fitness state. This is an example of how a single mutation can drastically change the properties of a protein and its network, and how epigenetic traps can affect the fitness of a population.
The amoeba Naegleria fowleri can cause a serious infection of the brain known as primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM). PAM is a rare but serious condition that affects healthy children and young adults and is fatal in most cases. The amoeba infects people when contaminated water enters the body through the nose and then travels along the olfactory neuroepithelial route to invade the brain. Currently, there is no effective treatment for PAM and the only option is to treat the infection with a combination of drugs, including anti-mycotic drugs, antibiotics, and an anti-inflammatory drug. However, some anti-fungal drugs, known as conazoles, have been found to be effective against the amoeba in vitro and may be useful in treating PAM.
Gut worms affect around 2 billion people worldwide and are the most common parasite infection in humans. These parasites can cause many problems such as anemia, growth stunting, undernutrition, and cognitive deficits. When a person is infected with gut worms, their body produces a lot of a kind of protein called cytokines. These cytokines are important for fighting off the worms. One cytokine in particular, called IL-4, helps expel the worms from the body. To fight off gut worms, the body needs a specific kind of protein called IL-4Rα. Without this protein, the body cannot effectively fight off gut worms.
Bartonella is a type of bacteria found in many animals, including humans. It is responsible for several diseases in humans and animals, and it is often difficult to trace the source of infection. In this study, researchers constructed large phylogenies from genes found in the blood of humans and animals, using two different genes: 16s rRNA and citrate synthase. The 16s rRNA gene is often used in studies of microorganisms found in water or soil, while the citrate synthase gene is commonly sequenced in Bartonella studies. By analyzing these genes, the researchers were able to determine the evolutionary history of Bartonella, patterns of host switching, and its spillover into humans or from human commensals into wild species.
The human genome contains a large number of noncoding RNAs, which include lncRNAs and small ncRNAs. These RNAs play important roles in several cellular processes, such as regulation of gene expression and maintenance of chromatin architecture. LncRNAs can act as scaffolds to keep several proteins tethered to a specific cellular compartment or recruit proteins to a specific chromatin site. Nuclear-restricted lncRNAs act as structural components of specific sub-nuclear domains. Some lncRNAs regulate transcription and RNA processing events, and serve as precursors for small RNAs. Several lncRNAs exhibit temporal and spatial expression patterns, indicating vital and diverse biological roles of lncRNAs. A recent study demonstrated cell cycle-regulated expression of lncRNAs in mammalian cells. The authors identified lncRNAs encoded in close proximity to more than 50 protein-coding genes involved in cell cycle, including cyclins and cyclin-dependent kinases. During cell cycle progression, the levels of both lncRNAs and the nearby cell cycle gene mRNAs displayed dynamic fluctuations. However, the expression of these lncRNAs did not correlate either positively or negatively with the expression of the nearby cell cycle genes, indicating that although some lncRNAs and mRNAs could be regulated in concert, they may not necessarily regulate each other. On the other hand, several other studies have demonstrated the involvement of lncRNAs in regulating the expression of cell cycle genes in cis. For example, ANRIL lncRNA, which is located upstream of the tumor suppressor locus encoding p16INK4A and p15INK4B, recruits TLS, an RNA-binding protein, to the CCND1 gene in response to DNA damage, and results in the transcription repression of CCND1. Additionally, lncRNAs can influence alternative splicing of pre-mRNAs, which can alter the local concentration of a particular splicing factor upon a specific external signal or during specific stages of the cell cycle. This mechanism could be important for fine-tuning the cellular response to external signals and coordinating RNA polymerase II transcription and pre-mRNA splicing during the cell cycle. Finally, MALAT1, a highly abundant nucleus-restricted lncRNA, modulates the cellular distribution and activity of SR splicing factors, thereby influencing alternative splicing of pre-mRNAs. MALAT1 has a pro-proliferative function, and its depletion in normal human diploid fibroblasts induces DNA-damage response and results in the activation of p53 and its target genes. The cell cycle defects observed in MALAT1-depleted cells are sensitive to the cellular levels of p53, indicating that p53 is an important effector of MALAT1 function. Furthermore, MALAT1 is involved in regulating the expression and/or pre-mRNA processing of oncogenic transcription factors, especially those that control mitotic progression.
JH is a key hormone that helps insects grow and reproduce. It helps insects stay in their larval stage and prevents them from turning into adults when exposed to a hormone called 20E. When JH is not present, the insect turns into an adult. Met is a gene that has been found to be the JH receptor. It helps JH bind to other genes to control development and reproduction in insects. The Met gene is important for egg production and development in many insects. JH helps prepare the insect's fat body for egg production, and it also affects how eggs are laid. Met plays an important role in JH-dependent egg production, and it helps the insect's fat body produce more eggs. JH also helps the insects' oocytes mature, which is also controlled by Met.
Leprosy is a contagious disease caused by bacteria. Since antibiotic treatment was introduced in the 1980s, the number of leprosy cases has decreased dramatically. However, there are still many cases of leprosy worldwide. Leprosy can cause nerve damage, which can lead to deformities. To prevent disabilities, it is important to treat nerve damage early. The treatment usually involves a medicine called prednisolone, which reduces inflammation and relieves pressure on the nerves. However, it is not always possible to adjust the treatment to the individual's needs in field clinics. For this reason, the World Health Organization recommends a standardized treatment that lasts for 12 weeks. While observational studies suggest that prednisolone can improve nerve function in many cases, this has never been confirmed in a clinical trial. It is not clear how long prednisolone treatment should last to be most effective. Therefore, we conducted a clinical trial to determine whether a 32-week prednisolone course is more effective than a 20-week course in restoring and improving recent clinical nerve damage.
The two closely related cervid species, European red deer and Rocky Mountain elk, have different types of mating calls. European red deer make low frequency roars, while Rocky Mountain elk make high frequency bugles. The red deer's mating call has low vocal tract resonance characteristics that provide reliable information about body size, which is related to physiological, ecological, reproductive, and aggressive factors. In contrast, the elk's high fundamental frequency whistle-like bugle (around 1000 Hz) does not consistently provide information about body size. To better understand the physiology of this system, we simulated red deer and elk calls using a finite-element model of oscillating vocal folds positioned within a laryngeal cartilaginous framework, applying intrinsic laryngeal muscle activations and a wave propagation model of the vocal tract.
The article explains how next generation sequencing has enabled a powerful technique for large scale profiling of transcription factor binding and chromatin modifications. This technique is called Chromatin Immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput next generation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and is commonly used to map DNA fragments to a reference genome and retain reads that map to unique locations. However, discarding multi-reads, which map to multiple locations, can lead to inaccurate estimation of expression of genes that reside in repetitive regions. Furthermore, ChIP-seq data analysis software do not take multi-reads into account. Therefore, the article investigates the effects of discarding multi-reads on two different ChIP-seq datasets: STAT1 binding in interferon-stimulated HeLa S3 cells and GATA1 binding in mouse G1E-ER4 cells. The article develops a method for utilizing multi-reads and illustrates that incorporation of multi-reads can lead to an increase of up to 25% in the sequencing depth and identify high quality novel peaks. Location analysis of these peaks reveals that a large fraction of them reside in close proximity to promoters and in genic regions within segmental duplications of the genomes. Furthermore, true peaks are highly enriched for retrotransposon elements such as LINE and LTR. The article supports its computational experiments by experimental validation of a subset of GATA1 peaks that were only identifiable when multi-reads were incorporated. This leads to identification of novel GATA1 target genes.
The study focused on the health and economic consequences of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) on disadvantaged populations from low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). The authors argued that innovative and intensified disease management (IDM) is needed to control or eliminate these diseases. They highlighted the fact that these populations often live in rural or remote areas, which limits their access to diagnosis and treatment of both the diseases and the disabilities they cause. The authors emphasized that relatively few studies have examined the impact of NTDs on the productivity and out-of-pocket payments (OPPs) of individuals, households, communities, and countries. They pointed out that controlling and eliminating NTDs would have a direct and sustainable effect on the economic growth and financial welfare of the affected populations and consequently lead to greater national and global prosperity. The authors also mentioned that advances in understanding the economic consequences of NTDs could help to further encourage prevention and control actions. They argued that these efforts are a good investment, as they would result in increased health policy dialogue, and could assure funders and policymakers that resources committed to these efforts are worthwhile.
Scientists have studied how the brain processes sensory information by looking at neurons that only respond to certain types of stimuli. These neurons are thought to provide more information about the sensory input if they are more selective, or if they respond to a narrower range of sensory input parameters. In the auditory cortex, where we studied this, neurons tend to respond to a wide range of sounds at the beginning of a stimulus, but as time goes by they become more selective, responding to fewer sounds. Based on this, it's been thought that the more selective (sparse) responses at the later time points would encode the identity of the sounds, while the less selective (dense) responses at the beginning encode the presence of the sound. However, our study found that this theory is incorrect. We looked at 171 neurons in marmoset primary auditory cortex and found that our results contradicted the current theory. Instead, our results suggest a new sensory encoding principle that could apply to other sensory systems.
This study examines the role of OX40, a co-stimulatory molecule that helps T cells survive and function, during LCMV infection. While OX40 is needed for T cell responses to LCMV during acute infection, it is not as important during chronic infection. In fact, OX40-deficient mice are unable to control the virus during chronic infection. This shows that OX40 is important for controlling LCMV during persistent infection, but not during acute infection.
Scientists discovered that fish and other swimming creatures share a common pattern of movement that has evolved independently at least eight times across three different types of animals. This pattern is characterized by undulating elongated fins while keeping the body rigid. The specific wavelength (SW) of this pattern is approximately 20 times the mean amplitude of movement. This pattern is not restricted to any specific type of animal and is observed in fish, invertebrates, and jawed vertebrates. Scientists call this pattern the optimal specific wavelength (OSW) and suggest that it is the most efficient way for these animals to swim. This finding sheds new light on the evolution of swimming in marine animals and provides a quantitative framework for understanding this complex phenomenon.
The formation of the cerebral cortex is a complex process that involves many steps, including cell proliferation and differentiation. At the early stages of cortical development, neurons divide to produce two daughter neurons. These neurons then migrate away from the ventricular zone and into the cortical plate. Scientists have found that two condensin protein complexes, called condensin I and condensin II, are important for chromosome inheritance during mitosis. However, it is not known which condensin complex is more important in cortical development. In this study, scientists used conditional knockout (cKO) mice to investigate the roles of condensin I and II in NSC divisions during cortical development. Surprisingly, the scientists found that both condensin I and II are essential for NSC division and survival. Loss of either one of the condensin complexes induces DNA damage and p53 nuclear accumulation, eventually leading to apoptosis. The scientists also found that depletion of individual condensin causes distinct phenotypes, indicating that they have non-overlapping functions. Most importantly, the scientists found that pericentromeric heterochromatin regions form abnormally large clusters in condensin II-depleted neurons. Overall, this study provides important insights into the distinct functions of condensin I and II in cortical development.
This paper describes the life cycle of Schistosoma mansoni, a parasite that causes intestinal schistosomiasis. The authors provide an overview of the parasite's genome and life cycle, highlighting the sexual dimorphism that occurs in the adult stage. The authors also discuss how the parasite interacts with its host and the role of host immune and endocrine signals in the development of the parasite. The authors provide a comprehensive analysis of the transcriptome of S. mansoni at various developmental stages, including cercariae, schistosomula, and adult worms. Additionally, the authors provide an analysis of the chromatin structure of S. mansoni before and after sexual differentiation. Overall, the paper provides valuable insights into the development and reproduction of S. mansoni and its interactions with its host.
The study proposes a new approach for measuring the quality of manual curation. It introduces two probabilistic models to quantify the certainty of individual annotations made by several curators. These models are tested using computer simulations and applied to a newly annotated corpus of 10,000 sentences, each of which was annotated by three experts. To test the utility of the computational predictions, the authors randomly sampled a subset of 1,000 sentences for reannotation by five new experts. The results of three- and eight-expert curation are compared to evaluate the models' predictions. This approach can help to improve and enhance existing curation methods and ensure consistent quality control in biomedical research.
Andes virus, also known as ANDV, is a type of virus that causes hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS), a potentially fatal illness that affects the lungs. There are no approved vaccines or treatments for HPS, but research is underway to develop them. One approach being explored is using antibodies from animals that have been vaccinated against the virus. In particular, antibodies from geese that have been vaccinated against ANDV have shown promise as a potential treatment for HPS. Researchers have tested the effectiveness of these antibodies in a model of HPS in Syrian hamsters and found that they can protect the hamsters from the disease.
This paper is about how changes in the way that DNA is methylated can contribute to cancer. Researchers have known for a long time that changes in DNA methylation patterns are common in cancer cells. Over the last 30 years, many studies have helped to understand what these changes look like in general. Recent studies have used a new technology called whole-genome bisulfite sequencing to confirm this model and show that some parts of the genome are hypermethylated (meaning that the DNA is more likely to be methylated) while others are hypomethylated (meaning that the DNA is less likely to be methylated). The enzymes that are responsible for adding methyl groups to DNA are called DNA methyltransferases. There are three of these enzymes: Dnmt1, Dnmt3a, and Dnmt3b. These enzymes have been linked to cancer in many studies, but it is not clear exactly how they contribute to cancer. This paper describes how mutations in the Dnmt3a gene have been found in some types of blood cancer, and how these mutations are associated with a poor prognosis. This suggests that Dnmt3a might play a role in the development of these cancers. However, the methylation differences between patients with wildtype and mutant Dnmt3a do not seem very big. A recent study in mice that had conditional deletion of Dnmt3a in hematopoietic stem cells showed that this deletion caused both hypermethylation (where the DNA was more likely to be methylated) and hypomethylation (where the DNA was less likely to be methylated) of promoter regions. This suggests that Dnmt3a plays a role in regulating the methylation of genes. The paper also describes how deleting Dnmt3a in mice with lung cancer caused the loss of methylation in large active chromatin domains. This is a new function for Dnmt3a that has not been described before.
The study aimed to understand how different parts of the brain are connected and how they work together to create complex behaviors. Specifically, the study focused on the songbird premotor nucleus HVC, which is responsible for producing highly precise, learned temporal sequences. The authors developed new methods for multi-channel electrophysiology and calcium imaging in singing birds to investigate how activity in HVC is organized in space and time. Through their research, the authors found that activity patterns of excitatory and inhibitory neurons are spatially clustered, and that two cell types, HVCX projection neurons and HVC interneurons, fire in alternating phases of a local 30 Hz rhythm. These results show that there is a fundamental mesoscopic length scale and timescale in the premotor cortical area HVC, which may be a core property of motor cortical microcircuits across species.
Scientists have been studying how the lifespan of organisms is controlled by both genetic and environmental factors. They have found that loss-of-function mutations in a specific part of a cellular process can increase the lifespan of an animal. This process is called insulin/insulin-like growth factor-1/daf-2 signaling pathway and it is present in many organisms including worms and mice. The regulation of this pathway takes place in adulthood. In worms, the insulin-signaling pathway negatively regulates a transcription factor called DAF-16, which ultimately positively and negatively regulates transcription of different genes. The regulation of lifespan by an insulin-like signaling cascade is an evolutionarily conserved mechanism. It has also been demonstrated in flies and mice. Scientists have also found that the regulation of DAF-16 activity is modulated by different factors in worms, including the JNK signaling pathway, the SIR-2.1 deacetylase, and HSF-1, LIN-14, and SMK-1 in the nucleus. In many organisms, the rate of aging is tied to reproduction. In worms, germline proliferation produces a signal that negatively regulates lifespan, while the somatic gonad promotes lifespan extension. Caloric restriction (CR) also extends lifespan across species including yeast, worms, flies, and mice. Scientists have found that in flies, imposing CR at any time can increase lifespan. Perturbations in mitochondrial function have been shown to increase lifespan in worms. However, mutations in the ubiquinone biosynthesis gene clk-1 do not further increase the longevity phenotype from CR. The mechanism of longevity induced by defective mitochondria is thought to occur during development, as previous attempts to use RNA interference (RNAi) to inhibit mitochondrial function in adults have not been shown to increase lifespan. Recent genome-wide RNAi screens for increased lifespan have identified ∼100 potential regulators of lifespan in worms from diverse cellular pathways, many of which are evolutionarily conserved. However, genes essential for viability are underrepresented in genome-wide RNAi screens for postdevelopmental phenotypes such as aging, unless these genes are inactivated after their required developmental roles. Here, scientists report 64 genes that, when inactivated postdevelopmentally by RNAi, increase adult lifespan. They also report the enhanced survival phenotype of the animals arrested during development by these essential gene inactivations.
Vertebrates have limited ability to regenerate complex structures. Teleost fish and urodele amphibians, however, can regenerate major appendages, such as limbs, spinal cord, and heart. Previous studies of appendage regeneration identified three phases: wound healing, blastema formation, and regenerative outgrowth and patterning. After an amputation injury, exposed stump tissue is rapidly covered by a sheet of epithelial cells, a process known as wound epithelialization. This epithelium matures into a structure known as the wound or regeneration epidermis and expresses markers of developmental signaling pathways. Factors such as Fgf20a and igf2b are induced in mesenchymal cells within hours of fin amputation and are required for formation of the regeneration epidermis and subsequent bone regeneration. However, the mechanisms by which these pathways define the morphology and signaling activities of the regeneration epidermis are not fully understood. In this study, we used forward genetics to identify a critical role for Laminin beta 1a (lamb1a) in zebrafish fin regeneration. Lamb1a is induced upon fin amputation in the basal layer of the wound epithelium and is required to establish polarity in basal epithelial cells, induce and maintain basal epithelial markers, localize receptors for signaling, and align regenerating osteoblasts. Lamb1a induction is dependent on Fgf signaling, both immediately after amputation and throughout regeneration. Therefore, Lamb1a is a critical node between growth factor signals and formation of the regeneration epidermis in an amputated vertebrate appendage.
Linear mixed models (LMMs) have recently emerged as a useful alternative to principal component analysis (PCA) for adjusting for population substructure in genome-wide association studies (GWAS). These models build upon previous work in animal breeding and human genetics to include a genetic effect of interest as a fixed effect in a regression model, with an additional random effect to model genetic correlation between individuals. While these methods were originally proposed for pedigrees with known relationships, they can also be used with samples of unknown or uncertain relationship, such as apparently unrelated individuals who may nevertheless display distant levels of common ancestry. The genetic relationship between all pairs of individuals is estimated based on genome-wide genotype data, rather than being fixed at their known theoretical values. Several approximations have been developed to construct tests of fixed SNP effects of interest in the LMM, including MERLIN, GenABEL, EMMAX, TASSEL, FaST-LMM, and Mendel. These software packages can generate p-values for each SNP in the genome-wide association study. A limited comparison of several LMM implementations was performed on real and simulated data from the Genetic Analysis Workshop 18 (GAW18), where the LMM implementations performed rather similarly in terms of association test statistics and p-values achieved. However, a more comprehensive comparison of LMM approaches, and a formal investigation of power and type 1 error, has not been performed until now. Here, we compare the LMM approaches to family-based approaches and alternative previously-proposed approaches based on extending standard case/control tests. We applied these approaches to real and simulated data from a genome-wide association study of visceral leishmaniasis in 348 Brazilian families comprising 3636 individuals. We compare the approaches via application to real and simulated data derived from a genome-wide association study of visceral leishmaniasis in 348 Brazilian families comprising 3636 individuals. We investigate the sensitivity to various methodological details (such as whether an LMM approach is used, and, if so, whether an exact method or an approximation is used) and the success (or otherwise) of the approaches in controlling the overall genome-wide error-rate in both real and simulated data (into which artificial simulated disease loci have been inserted).
Chagas disease is a potentially deadly disease caused by a parasite called Trypanosoma cruzi. The parasite is found in the blood of infected animals, and can be transmitted to humans through a mosquito bite or contaminated blood. Once inside the human body, the parasite goes through two stages of development: the amastigote stage, where it develops inside cells, and the trypomastigote stage, where it is released from cells and can infect other cells. To find new treatments for Chagas disease, researchers have been using a genetically modified version of the T. cruzi parasite that can be easily detected and tracked. By testing different compounds against this parasite, researchers have discovered three new drugs that can stop the parasite from multiplying inside cells. These drugs are effective in very low doses and have low toxicity for mammalian cells. These findings are very exciting and could lead to new treatments for Chagas disease.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a disfiguring and disabling tropical disease caused by parasitic worms. LF affects more than 120 million people worldwide, and the World Health Organization has set a goal of eliminating the disease by 2020. To achieve this goal, mass drug administration (MDA) programs have been implemented in many countries to reduce the infection rate. However, MDA has some limitations. It requires repeated treatments over several years and has high costs. Additionally, MDA can be inconvenient for patients and health workers. To address these limitations, a new diagnostic tool called "Backpack PCR" has been developed. It uses molecular xenomonitoring (MX) to detect parasites in mosquitoes that transmit the disease. This tool uses a test strip-based methodology that is easy to use and can be done at the point of collection. This makes it possible to monitor changing infection rates in real-time during MDA programs. It also makes it possible to determine when MDA can be stopped. The "Backpack PCR" tool has the potential to be used in many other tropical disease control and elimination programs. It could be used to detect other parasites that are transmitted by mosquitoes, such as malaria and dengue. It could also be used to detect other diseases that are transmitted by other vectors, such as ticks and lice.
Elastomeric proteins have many important biological functions, such as providing extensibility and elastic recoil. They are self-assembling and their properties can be modified to be useful in tissue engineering. Elastomeric proteins such as elastin, resilin, abductin, spider dragline silks, and wheat gluten have evolved independently and have different architectures. Scientists have studied how the arrangement of elastomeric and cross-linking elements affects the self-assembly and mechanical properties of these proteins. They have done this by using a modified Diffusion-Limited Aggregation (DLA) algorithm to simulate the self-assembly of elastomeric proteins. DLA is a model that has been used to study other biological processes such as collagen fibrillogenesis and diatom morphogenesis. The results from these simulations have given insights into the relationships between elastomeric domains and cross-linking domains, which helps guide the rational design of new elastomeric-peptides.
A recent paper looked at Ebola viruses, which cause dangerous and deadly diseases. The paper is about how these viruses make their proteins. Ebola viruses have a special piece of genetic material (RNA) that helps them make their proteins. This RNA has a specific code that tells the cells what proteins to make. However, this code can be changed to make different proteins. The paper explains how these changes affect the proteins that the viruses make.
The study by [Authors] aimed to investigate the distribution and nature of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in the human genome. DSBs can lead to chromosomal damage and cancer, and are known to be more prevalent in certain regions of the genome. The study used deep sequencing to map DSBs in human chromosomes from cultured HEK 293T cells. The results indicate that DSBs are not randomly distributed and are mainly located within 50-250 kb “forum domains” that are protected from damage. The study also suggests that some forum domains contain coordinately expressed gene clusters, suggesting novel regulation of transcription within large genomic regions defined by DSB hotspots. The authors suggest that the mapped breaks could correspond to fragile sites in human chromosomes and that their technique can be used to study fragile sites in many types of human cells.
Trypanosomatids are uniflagellated protists that can infect plants, invertebrates and vertebrates, including humans. These parasites can have monoxenous or heteroxenous life cycles. Monoxenous trypanosomatids are thought to only infect insects, but have recently been found to have heteroxenous life cycles. Trypanosomes are a group of heteroxenous parasites that infect vertebrates, including humans, and are transmitted by blood-sucking vectors. The study looked at the diversity of trypanosomatids in bats in two areas in the Atlantic Forest of Rio de Janeiro. One area is Guapiaçu Ecological Reserve, which is more preserved and larger, and the other is Fiocruz Atlantic Forest Biological Station, which is smaller and more degraded. The study found that the diversity of trypanosomatids varies according to the local chiropterofauna, which is modulated by the level of preservation of the habitat.
This study aims to determine the prevalence of 37 different known and neglected tick-borne bacterial and parasitic pathogens, and co-infection levels in adult female ticks. Female ticks have had an additional blood meal compared to nymphs, and are more likely to be infected and co-infected. Additionally, this study aims to determine the presence of four suspected or known bacterial tick symbionts in parallel, as they may affect the replication and survival of pathogens and ticks. The study used a novel high-throughput method to identify these pathogens in a single sample. The results showed that the most common tick-borne pathogen in adult female ticks was Babesia microti, and the most common co-infection was with Anaplasma phagocytophilum and Babesia microti. The study also identified Spiroplasma spp., Wolbachia sp., and Midichloria mitochondrii in adult female ticks.
This article is about a type of gene regulation that happens in stem cells called hematopoietic stem cells, which can make different types of blood cells. There are two main genes that determine which type of blood cell is made: PU.1 and GATA-1. These genes are both turned on at the same time, but they turn each other off. They can also turn each other on in a process called priming. This means that the stem cell can make either type of blood cell, but it can only do it once. This process is important for making different types of blood cells.
Enterococcus faecalis is a common bacterium found in the digestive system of humans. It has been proposed to be involved in the development of inflammatory bowel disease and colorectal cancer. Infections caused by Enterococcus faecalis can be difficult to treat because of their resistance to antibiotics. The organism's ability to evade the immune system is one factor that contributes to its infections. Enterococcus faecalis has an intrinsic resistance to lysozyme, a key component of the innate immune system. This resistance is caused by several mechanisms, including the modification of peptidoglycan by OatA and PgdA, the alanylation of teichoic acids by DltA, and the control of pgdA expression by SigV. In this study, the authors used a quadruple mutant of Enterococcus faecalis that lacked the oatA, pgdA, dltA, and sigV genes to identify additional genes that contribute to resistance to lysozyme and virulence. They found that several genes involved in the decoration of the enterococcal polysaccharide antigen are essential for resistance to effectors of the innate immune system and for virulence. These findings suggest that these genes may be targets for new treatments against infections caused by Enterococcus faecalis.
The goal of the study is to develop a new computational model to integrate various types of high-throughput genomic data to identify important regulatory relationships between transcription factors (TF), miRNAs, and mRNAs in cancer. The study proposes a two-stage regression framework, called RACER, that first infers sample-specific TF activities from ENCODE ChIP-seq data, and then uses these estimated TF activities to infer miRNA/TF-gene regulatory relationships across samples. The study validates the proposed RACER model by comparing it with other alternative models and shows that RACER performs better in predicting gene expression and identifying known or confidence TF/miRNA-gene interactions. The study also identifies a novel role of a recently identified miRNA, hsa-miR-548p, in AML pathogenesis by identifying its significant target gene enrichments for leukemia-related pathway and its inferred interaction with another prominent feature regulator, YY1. The study also identifies a potential prognostic marker, C-Fos, using the inferred TF activities.
RNA-mediated silencing mechanisms control how genes are expressed in different organisms at different levels. These mechanisms are highly conserved in eukaryotes, including plants, animals, fungi, and other organisms. In fungi, there are two major RNA silencing pathways: the quelling and the meiotic silencing by unpaired DNA (MSUD) pathways. These pathways are effective in protecting the fungal genome during asexual and sexual development. Fungal RNA silencing pathways have been proposed to be involved in pathogenicity, development, and antiviral defense. Mycoviruses, or fungal viruses, are widespread in fungi and can be classified into different groups, such as Totiviridae, Partititiviridae, Chrysoviridae, Hypoviridae, Endornaviridae, ( + ) ssRNA, and ( - ) ssRNA. Mycoviruses can be transmitted vertically by spores or horizontally by hyphal anastomosis. Most mycoviral infections are associated with cryptic (non-symptomatic) and latent (expressed under specific conditions) infections, but some mycoviruses can cause debilitating phenotypes in their host, making them potential tools for the control of fungal plant pathogens. In Colletotrichum higginsianum, a hemibiotrophic fungus that infects plants of the Brassicaceae family, including Arabidopsis thaliana, RNA silencing plays a critical role in maintaining low levels of accumulation of a novel dsRNA virus, designated as ChNRV1. Production of viral small RNAs is dependent on ChDCL1, and loading into ChAGO1 demonstrates a strong preference for 21-nt, 5’U sequences.
Meiosis is a special type of cell division that results in haploid cells, which are half the number of chromosomes as the parent cell. Meiosis involves chromosome pairing, recombination, and segregation, which all rely on the fidelity of chromosome interactions. These interactions are established through the formation and repair of programmed double-strand breaks (DSBs) in the DNA, which are repaired through two pathways. In meiotic prophase I, three waves of H2AX phosphorylation occur, which are all initiated and expanded in different ways than in somatic cells. The third wave is important for meiotic sex chromosome inactivation (MSCI), which is a process where the unsynapsed regions of the sex chromosomes are silenced to prevent them from being passed on to offspring. MSCI is regulated by a protein called MDC1, which recruits ATR for H2AX phosphorylation and γH2AX signal expansion. However, the spreading of H2AX phosphorylation in leptotene and zygotene spermatocytes is unaltered in Mdc1-/- spermatocytes, and is therefore regulated by unknown mechanisms. In this study, researchers used gene knockout technology to remove the gene for MOF, a major histone acetyltransferase, from male germ cells. They found that MOF is involved in the expansion of chromatin-wide H2AX phosphorylation in leptonema and zygonema, and also in MDC1 recruitment and MSCI in pachytene spermatocytes. Without MOF, XY-H2AX phosphorylation expansion was absent, and RAD51 foci persisted in Mof cKO spermatocytes until diplonema, resulting in a significant reduction in crossover markers and chiasma formation. These results highlight novel roles for MOF in meiosis, including the expansion of different waves of H2AX phosphorylation, efficient DSB repair, and the formation of crossovers during male meiosis.
In this study, the authors are trying to understand how HTLV-1 infection affects human T-cell development. They do this by infecting "Human Immune System" (HIS) mice with HTLV-1 and then observing how human T-cell development is affected. They also looked at how the protein Tax, which is made by HTLV-1, affects T-cell development. They found that HTLV-1 infection caused a lot of problems with T-cell development, and Tax protein also seemed to be involved in these problems. They also saw that some of the problems that occur in people with ATL (a type of leukemia that is caused by HTLV-1) also happened in the infected mice. This animal model might be useful for understanding more about the early stages of the leukemogenic process caused by HTLV-1.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease caused by tiny worms that live in the veins around the intestine or urinary bladder. These worms release eggs in the stool or urine, and when humans come into contact with contaminated fresh water, they can become infected. The World Health Organization estimates that over 249 million people need treatment for schistosomiasis every year. In Sudan, both the urogenital and intestinal forms of schistosomiasis are prevalent, with the dominant form being urogenital. The Blue Nile Health Project was implemented in the 1970s to control schistosomiasis, malaria, and diarrheal diseases, but there have been no further integrated programs to control schistosomiasis in Sudan since then. In 2000, the Sudanese government established a national schistosomiasis control program, and as part of this program, a schistosomiasis control project was supported by the Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA) in Al Jabalain locality in the White Nile State of Sudan. This project included mass chemotherapy, health education, construction of a drinking water supply facility, provision of laboratory equipment, dispatch of Korean experts to Sudan, and follow-up evaluation. The present study evaluates the outcomes of praziquantel administration and health education for students and residents, as well as the impact of a filtered drinking water supply facility at Al Hidaib village.
The article describes a study on the matrix (M) protein of Nipah virus (NiV), which is responsible for outbreaks of severe encephalitis in humans and animals. Previous research has shown that NiV-M can form viral-like particles (VLPs) that contain all of the necessary proteins for the virus to replicate. The study found that NiV-M translocates from the cytoplasm to the nucleus at early stages of infection, before moving back to the plasma membrane. This movement is necessary for the virus to assemble and release virions, which are the infectious particles that spread the virus from one cell to another. The study suggests that NiV-M may have evolved to use cellular pathways to move between the nucleus and cytoplasm, and that this movement is essential for the virus to replicate.
This paper describes the cell entry process of the poliovirus, a nonenveloped virus that causes poliomyelitis. The virion binds to a protein on the surface of cells called PVR, which causes the virion to change shape and expose peptides that insert into cellular membranes. The virus then anchors to the cell membrane and forms channels and pores in planar membranes. The genome is then released from the virus into the cell cytoplasm. The exact pathway by which the genome is released is unknown, but it appears to be an energy-dependent process that does not require clathrin, caveolin, flotillin, or microtubules. This paper also discusses the challenges of studying viral entry pathways, including the high particle-to-plaque forming unit (pfu) ratio of animal viruses and the difficulty of distinguishing between productive and nonproductive pathways.
Dengue fever is a significant health problem in tropical and sub-tropical regions, including Cambodia where it is particularly prevalent among children. Over the past decade, dengue has increased in prevalence and in 2007, there was an especially deadly epidemic with 34542 cases and 365 deaths. The main control activity of the National Dengue Control Program (NDCP) is the distribution of temephos and insecticide spraying, and health education. However, many people with good knowledge of dengue do not translate this knowledge to practice because they do not understand disease transmission or the methods promoted are flawed. School-based education is an important compliment to community education because it can increase children's knowledge of dengue prevention and control. While health belief and behavioural change models have been used as a basis to develop educational materials, little work has been done on the mode of delivery or effectiveness of routine programs. To address these gaps, this study explored the input, process, and effectiveness of community outreach, HC, and school-based education for dengue control.
Filarial nematodes are a group of parasites that cause many public health problems around the world. To diagnose these infections, doctors use different methods, but none of them are perfect. These methods can be invasive, expensive or have low sensitivity. In this study, the authors looked at whether circulating microRNAs (miRNA) could be used as a new approach for diagnosing these infections. They found several miRNAs in the plasma of dogs infected with Dirofilaria immitis and in the serum of people infected with Onchocerca volvulus. These miRNAs could be used as potential biomarkers to diagnose filarial infections.
This paper is about a family of proteins called Src kinases. These proteins are involved in signaling pathways that regulate cell growth and proliferation. They have the ability to switch between different "states" depending on whether they are in the presence of an intracellular or extracellular signal. The switch between these states is important because it plays a key role in the onset of many human diseases, particularly cancer, making them important targets for therapeutic intervention. The structure of these proteins has been studied using high-resolution crystal structures, which have revealed important details about how they work. However, it has been difficult to fully understand how these proteins dynamically switch from one state to another because the process is transient and it is hard to observe. To address this issue, the authors used a coarse-grained model of a protein called Hck kinase, which is a member of the Src kinase family. This model incorporates two individual experimental structures and allows switching between them. The authors used a "two-state Gō model" to explicitly encode both experimental end-point structures in the energy function. They then simulated the transition process and mapped the trajectories onto a two-dimensional free energy landscape, a detailed structural network, and a discrete Markov model. The results of these simulations suggest that there are two parallel pathways for the conformational switching process, and that one of these pathways is coupled with local unfolding of the N-lobe of the catalytic domain. Overall, the authors' findings provide new insights into the thermodynamics and kinetics of conformational activation of the catalytic domain of Src kinases.
The paper discusses the phenomenon of postzygotic lethality in plants, which is the death of the resulting offspring when two individuals of different ploidy (number of sets of chromosomes) are crossed. This can occur when a haploid individual (one set of chromosomes) is crossed with a diploid individual (two sets of chromosomes), resulting in an unreduced gamete and the production of a triploid offspring. The triploid offspring are often unable to survive and cause lethality in the F1 generation. This phenomenon can prevent the formation of polyploids and can play a role in speciation.
This paper is about how bats and rodents carry certain bacterial pathogens. There are many different kinds of bats and rodents, and they have a wide range of characteristics, such as their lifespan, size, and eating habits. There is also a large diversity of bacterial pathogens that bats and rodents can carry, and many of these pathogens can be harmful to humans. However, much of the research into these pathogens has focused on viruses, such as Ebola and Marburg viruses, rather than bacteria. This paper aims to look at how these pathogens have evolved over time in relation to their hosts. Specifically, the paper focuses on two types of bacteria, Bartonella and Leptospira, that are known to cause neglected tropical diseases in humans. These bacteria are carried by a wide range of mammals, including bats and rodents. To understand how these pathogens have evolved, researchers looked at the genetic similarities between the bacteria and their hosts. They found that there was a lot of congruence between the two, meaning that the pathogens and their hosts had a lot of similarities in their evolutionary histories. This suggests that these pathogens have been adapted to their hosts over a long period of time. However, there were also some differences in the evolutionary histories between the two, indicating that there were likely instances of the pathogens jumping from one host to another. This is important because it shows how easily these pathogens can spread from their natural hosts to humans, and how quickly they can evolve to better survive in new hosts. Overall, this paper provides valuable insights into how these pathogens have evolved over time and how they have adapted to their hosts. It also highlights the importance of studying these pathogens in order to better understand their potential for causing disease in humans.
The study focuses on the movement of swimming animals like undulatory swimmers, which starts from muscle activation. There are two main issues that need to be understood: (1) how muscle activation leads to the observed deformation kinematics and (2) how deformation kinematics produce movement of the body as a whole. The study discusses how muscle activation, body mass, elastic properties, and interactions with the environment cause the observed deformation of undulatory swimmers. The study proposes an active-passive decomposition framework, in which passive swimming has only passive component of deformation, while active swimming has both active and passive deformation components because muscle activation as well as external fluid forces are present. The study presents a detailed mathematical description of passive motion induced by external vorticies and discusses the different swimming gaits and their optimal conditions for movement. The study also discusses the pathway of power transfer during the swimming cycle and the optimal deformation kinematics for fast swimming.
Scientists have discovered that a parasite called Trypanosoma brucei can change its genetic makeup by combining DNA from different strains. This can create new strains that may have new abilities, such as the ability to infect humans or resist drugs. This happens when the parasite's genes mix during a process called sexual reproduction in tsetse flies, which are the parasite's insect hosts. The parasite's DNA mixes during meiosis, a type of cell division that occurs during sexual reproduction. This creates new strains of parasite that may have different abilities, such as the ability to infect humans or resist drugs. The parasite's genes are stored in something called an expression site, which is like a gene factory. This factory has different parts that work together to make proteins. One of these parts is a gene called SRA, which is important for the parasite to be able to infect humans. The parasite has different versions of SRA in different parts of its gene factory. Scientists found that when the parasite's DNA mixes during sexual reproduction, it creates a new version of SRA that is different from the versions in either of the parent strains. This new version may have different abilities, such as the ability to infect humans or resist drugs.
This article is about a study that used a network theory to describe the complex behavior of a group of cells called islets of Langerhans, which are located in the pancreas and make insulin. These islets are made up of beta cells, which make insulin. When beta cells don't work properly or die, it can cause diabetes. The study found that the cells in the islets are electrically connected to each other and that this electrical connection helps to coordinate the behavior of the islet. The study also found that changes in the behavior of one cell can affect the behavior of the whole islet.
We introduce a standard model for gene transcription networks that includes protein production, decay, and reversible binding reactions between transcription factors (TFs) and promoter sites. We call a transcriptional component that takes a number of TFs as inputs and produces a single TF as an output, a node in a transcription network. We assume that mRNA dynamics occur on a time scale much faster than protein production/decay and neglect them. We simplify our notation by treating gene expression as a one-step process. We write the dynamics of the module as (1) where is the stoichiometry matrix and is the reaction flux vector. We partition into and , representing the reaction flux vectors corresponding to production/decay and binding/unbinding reactions, respectively. We assume that the DNA copy number is conserved. With we obtain (2) which we call the isolated dynamics of a module. Next, we consider a module inserted into a network, which we call the context of the module. We represent all the quantities related to the context with an overbar. We write the dynamics of the species in the module (and ) and in the context (and ) as (3). The upper left block matrix in is zero as DNA is assumed to be a conserved species. We obtain (4), which we call the connected dynamics of a module. We call the retroactivity to the output of the module , encompassing retroactivity applied to the module due to the context of the module. Similarly, we call the retroactivity to the input of a module , representing retroactivity originating inside the module. The general interconnection of a group of modules can be treated similarly. As an example, we consider a module connected to its context and find that retroactivity applied by the context changes the dynamics of the module significantly. We seek a model that captures the effects of retroactivity , unlike standard regulatory network models of the same dimension based on Hill functions. We want to explicitly describe the change in the dynamics of a module once it is arbitrarily connected to other modules in the network. This model is only a function of measurable biochemical parameters, TF concentrations, and interconnection topology.
Pseudoautosomal regions (PARs) are sections of DNA that are similar between the X and Y (or Z and W) chromosomes. In humans, there are two PARs, PAR1 and PAR2. PAR1 is located at the end of the short arm (Xp) and long arm (Xq) of the X chromosome. It is important for fertility and disease. However, we do not fully understand the biology of PAR1. In this study, the authors built a genetic map of PAR1 using data from over 14,000 sperm from 383 men. They also looked at the role of PRDM9, a protein that helps determine where recombination happens on autosomes, in PAR1. The authors found that recombination happens at specific locations in PAR1, and that PRDM9 does not seem to play a role in specifying where recombination happens in this region. The genetic map will be useful for medical genetics research, and the authors also used it to learn more about the evolution of recombination in PAR1.
Scientists discovered that a certain type of proteins called histone methyltransferases can add methyl groups to the tails of histone proteins in the DNA of eukaryotic cells. This helps to regulate the expression of genes. Scientists also found that another type of proteins, called histone demethylases, can remove these methyl groups. They also discovered that one specific type of histone demethylase, called JMJD2A, can help to regulate the expression of genes involved in the process of muscle cells differentiating into myotubes. This is important for the development of skeletal muscles in our bodies.
Guinea Worm Disease (GWD) is a parasitic disease caused by the parasitic worm Dracunculus medinensis . This disease is spread by tiny copepods in contaminated water sources. It is estimated that over 3 million people were infected with GWD in 1986 and it was spread across 21 countries in sub-Saharan Africa. During the early years of the disease, death due to tetanus was not uncommon. The absence of a known cure or vaccine makes it difficult for affected people to seek medical care. However, the disease can be prevented. The Global Programme to Eradicate Guinea Worm Disease (GWEP) was established in 1986 with the goal of eliminating the disease globally. The programme has successfully reduced the number of cases by 99.9% and there are now only 25 cases reported in four countries. The eradication strategy relies on identifying all villages with endemic transmission and interrupting transmission in each village. The ICCDE and WHO work together to assess the quality of surveillance during a three-year pre-certification period. The programme has certified 198 countries, territories and areas and the latest country to attain certification was Ghana in January 2015. To achieve global certification of GWD eradication, WHO must formally certify every individual country, even if no transmission has ever been recorded in that particular country. TCC has responsibility for assisting national GWEPs to interrupt transmission and supporting the four remaining endemic countries to prepare for certification. Other partners, such as UNICEF and Water Aid, have focussed on providing safe, clean water.
Lyme disease is caused by bacteria called Borrelia burgdorferi. These bacteria can spread through the blood and infect many different parts of the body. To survive and grow in the body, these bacteria need to avoid the body's immune system. The immune system has a special system called complement that helps defend the body against infection. The complement system is made up of many different proteins that work together to fight infection. Borrelia burgdorferi have proteins that help them avoid the complement system. Researchers have now found out that these proteins work by binding to a protein called C1r. The researchers made a map of how the proteins work and found that they are very similar. They also made mutations to see how the proteins work and found that the proteins need the SP domain to bind to C1r. These findings help us understand how Borrelia burgdorferi avoid the immune system and make it harder to treat Lyme disease.
Candida albicans is a common fungus that can cause serious infections. It can exist as a harmless commensal in healthy people, but it can also become an opportunistic pathogen that causes diseases ranging from mild infections like thrush to life-threatening infections in immunocompromised patients. The ability of C. albicans to grow as budding yeast or hyphal forms is key to its pathogenicity. When growing at low densities on mucosal surfaces, C. albicans mostly exists as a commensal and is tolerated by the host immune system. However, when growing as hyphae, it invades and damages tissues. The hyphal form of C. albicans is also a key part of the structure of biofilms, which are communities of fungal cells that adhere to each other and to surfaces. The ability of C. albicans to switch from budding yeast to hyphal form is regulated by a complex set of proteins and pathways. In this study, the authors searched for proteins that show a hyphal-specific pattern of phosphorylation and found that the fork-head family transcription factor Fkh2 changes its phosphorylation profile dramatically within five minutes of hyphal induction. They then investigated the mechanism of this change and found that it is mediated by two kinases: Cdc28-Ccn1/Cln3 and Cbk1-Mob2. The shift in phosphorylation specifically activates Fkh2 to promote the expression of genes required for pathogenic processes in addition to its normal general housekeeping function. This study provides new insights into the regulation of hyphal growth in C. albicans and the role of phosphorylation in its pathogenicity.
Scientists are trying to find new drugs to treat sleeping sickness, a disease caused by a parasite that affects 20 million people worldwide. They have found that the parasite needs certain chemicals to make DNA, RNA and sugar molecules. One of these chemicals is called uracil. The parasite gets uracil from the food that people eat. However, the parasite can also make uracil on its own. Scientists have found that the parasite needs to make uracil in order to grow. They have also found that uracil is very important for the parasite to be able to survive inside animals. They have tested different chemicals to see if they can stop the parasite from making uracil. They have found that one chemical, called UMP synthase, is very important for the parasite to be able to survive inside animals. They have also found that another chemical, called UPP, helps the parasite to make uracil. Scientists are now trying to find new drugs that will stop the parasite from making these chemicals.
Shine-Dalgarno (SD) sequences are found in the 5′ untranslated regions of prokaryotic messenger RNAs and are important for translation initiation. They act as ribosome-binding sites by recognizing a complementary sequence motif at the 3′ end of the 16S ribosomal RNA via base pairing. These sequences are highly conserved across the prokaryotic kingdom and are even present in some cell organelles that evolved from prokaryotes more than a billion years ago. However, an alternative mechanism of translation initiation exists that is independent of the presence of an SD sequence. Even some highly translated mRNAs in bacteria lack a recognizable SD motif. Recent analyses have indicated that SD-independent translation is more widespread than previously appreciated. We have discovered that mRNAs lacking an SD sequence exhibit a pronounced minimum in mRNA secondary structure at the translational start codon, suggesting that start codon accessibility is the major factor in SD-independent translation initiation. We have confirmed experimentally that local RNA unfoldedness is necessary and sufficient for initiation of protein biosynthesis in the absence of an SD sequence.
This article describes the findings of a study that followed 8,311 people who were treated for their first episode of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) with 20 mg/kg intravenous liposomal amphotericin B.
