Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by parasites that live in a special organelle inside cells called a parasitophorous vacuole (LPV). These parasites can cause a range of diseases from skin ulcers to organ damage. It is important to understand more about the composition of the LPV in order to develop new treatments for leishmaniasis. Recent studies have shown that molecules that are normally found in secretory pathways can also be found on the LPV surface, and that these molecules are important for LPV formation. One such molecule is syntaxin 5 (Stx5), which is found in early secretory pathway vesicles and is important for their fusion. When Stx5 is blocked, LPVs are smaller and contain fewer parasites. This suggests that blocking protein transport could be a way to treat leishmaniasis. A small molecule called Retro-2cycl was found to block the movement of molecules along the secretory pathway, including toxins and viruses. Analogues of Retro-2cycl were then found that could block the movement of toxins and viruses even more effectively. These analogues were then tested on Leishmania parasites and were found to be lethal. This suggests that Retro-2cycl and its analogues could be useful in treating leishmaniasis. In addition, blocking protein transport could also help to stimulate the immune response of the host.
The nucleosome is a fundamental unit of genomic organization made of an octameric protein core surrounded by ~147 bp of DNA. It plays a crucial role in organizing the DNA and regulating gene expression. Recent studies have shown that nucleosomes can be positioned in specific sequences within the genome. These specific nucleosome positions are regulated by chromatin remodeling enzymes or by the basal affinity of a given sequence of DNA for a nucleosome. The specific positioning of nucleosomes can affect gene expression. This study focused on the transcriptional regulation of the Ly49 family of immune genes by nucleosome positioning. Ly49 receptors are expressed on natural killer (NK) and other immune cells. These receptors interact with the class-I major histocompatibility complex (MHC-I). The sensitivity of Ly49 receptors to MHC-I expression levels allows NK cells to distinguish healthy cells from cancer or virus-infected cells. In this study, the authors used a mouse cell line called RMA to investigate the effects of nucleosome positioning on the expression of the Ly49 family of immune genes. RMA expresses only Ly49A and none of the other Ly49 receptors. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq), the authors compared the nucleosome coverage of expressed Ly49 genes to that of the silent ones in the same population. They found that AML-1a binding sites are preferentially depleted of nucleosomes in expressed Ly49 genes when compared to the unexpressed genes within the same population. This suggests that nucleosome positioning is a possible mechanism to regulate Ly49 expression in vivo.
This paper discusses the process of cell cycle commitment in G1 phase and the role of the CDK4/6 kinases in this process. CDK4 and CDK6 are activated by D-type cyclins, which are produced in response to mitogenic signals. This leads to the phosphorylation of the cell cycle/tumor suppressor pRb, which results in cell cycle commitment. The CDK4/6 kinases are controlled by several mechanisms, including feedback loops involving E2F and p27/Cip1. These feedback loops can result in a bistable switch, which either commits the cell cycle or keeps it in a quiescent state. In addition, the phosphorylation of CDK4 at T172 is a critical step in its activation, and this phosphorylation is regulated by proline-directed kinases, which are separate from the CAK/CDK7 kinase that is commonly thought to activate CDKs. The paper concludes that the CDK4/6 kinases are essential for cell cycle commitment and that their regulation is complex, involving multiple kinases and feedback loops.
In plants, the process of meiosis is essential for reproduction, resulting in the production of haploid gametes. However, few transcriptional regulators of meiotic gene expression have been identified. DUET is a PHD finger protein required for male meiosis in Arabidopsis. Loss of DUET results in defective meiotic gene expression, chromosome condensation, and segregation. The protein interacts with chromatin and H3K4me2 is required for function. The phenotypes observed in duet are partially rescued in duet partially complemented lines, but the parallel spindle phenotype during meiosis II persists. DUET is expressed only during diplotene in prophase I. TDM1, a gene required for meiotic cell cycle transitions, is a direct target of DUET and its onset coincides with the timing of DUET expression. TDM1 is not expressed during female meiosis, suggesting a possible role for DUET in regulating male meiotic gene expression. DUET functions as a transcriptional regulator during male meiosis and its PHD finger binding to H3K4me2 is critical for function.
Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is a genetic disorder caused by a specific mutation in the FMR1 gene. The most common feature of FXS is mental retardation. The symptoms of a related disorder, Fragile X-associated Tremor/Ataxia Syndrome (FXTAS), include tremors, ataxia, and psychiatric symptoms. FXTAS is caused by a different mutation in the FMR1 gene, known as a premutation. The premutation causes the levels of a specific type of molecule to be high in cells from people with FXTAS, while the amount of another type of molecule remains normal. It is thought that this difference in molecule levels is what causes the symptoms of FXTAS. Researchers are studying specific proteins that bind to the abnormal molecules and may be contributing to the symptoms of FXTAS. They have identified several proteins that may be involved in the disorder and are now studying their roles in causing the symptoms of FXTAS.
Biofilms are communities of bacteria that are embedded in a slimy substance called extracellular polymeric substance (EPS), which helps them to stick to surfaces and resist treatment with antibiotics or host immune systems. These biofilms are prevalent in environments and can cause diseases, such as cystic fibrosis, infections in catheters, and contact lens infections. Scientists have known that bacteria called Pseudomonas aeruginosa can form biofilms, and that their biofilms have a matrix of EPS made of polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins. However, the specific chemical composition of P. aeruginosa EPS and how it is anchored to the bacteria and how it helps the bacteria to stick together are unknown. In this study, scientists used a technique called confocal scanning laser microscopy (CLSM) to visualize the EPS of P. aeruginosa biofilms. They found that the EPS is composed of a network of long fibers that form a matrix around the bacteria. They also found that the bacteria are anchored to the surface of the biofilm by the EPS. Furthermore, the scientists used a lectin specific to a type of polysaccharide, called Psl, to stain the EPS of P. aeruginosa biofilms. They found that the Psl fibers are laid in a helical pattern around the bacteria and that Psl is essential for the formation of the EPS matrix and the initiation of a biofilm. They also found that the EPS matrix is constantly changing structure to maintain the biofilm architecture during development. Lastly, the scientists used a technique called double staining to visualize the EPS of P. aeruginosa biofilms and the extracellular DNA (eDNA) of the bacteria in the biofilm. They found that the EPS and eDNA matrices do not overlap but appear to coordinate activities to maintain the biofilm structure. The scientists propose that P. aeruginosa may use programmed cell death and autolysis to degrade the EPS matrix in the center of microcolony to free 'the seeds of biofilm' for future dispersal.
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a deadly and difficult-to-treat cancer. The study looked at three different types of disease models to see how well they recapitulate the genetic complexity of PDAC. The three disease models are patient-derived organoids (PDO), patient-derived xenografts (PDX), and cell lines. The study found that PDO and PDX models have limited fidelity when it comes to recapitulating simple mutations found in PDAC patients. However, when it comes to large structural variations and copy number changes, the study found that PDX models can retain some of the heterogeneity of the donor's tumor. Overall, the study provides new insights into the interplay and fidelity of different disease models toward recapitulating PDAC heterogeneity and genomics.
Breast cancer is a common cancer found in women around the world, including those living in East Asian countries. While there are some genes that have been linked to breast cancer, most of the genetic risk factors for this cancer have not been confirmed. Recently, genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified several new genetic factors that increase the risk of breast cancer. However, these newly-identified genetic factors do not explain a large portion of the heritability for breast cancer. Many of the genetic factors discovered in studies of European-ancestry populations did not show a significant association with breast cancer in East Asian populations. Therefore, it is important to conduct GWAS in East Asian women to fully understand the genetic basis for breast cancer susceptibility.
Cryptococcal meningitis (CM) is a major cause of death for people with AIDS, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, where it is estimated to cause over 500,000 deaths per year. Despite access to antiretroviral therapy (ART), acute mortality from CM in sub-Saharan Africa can be as high as 70% in real-world practice. Researchers have identified several clinical prognostic markers for CM, including high fungal burden, poor cryptococcal clearance rate, and altered mental status at presentation. However, the underlying mechanisms that lead to these clinical outcomes are not fully understood. Researchers recently found that the in vitro phagocytosis of clinical cryptococcal isolates by J774 murine macrophage-like cells was associated with poor patient survival in a cohort of 65 patients with HIV-associated CM. Previous studies have shown evidence of genetic lineage associated with phenotype and clinical outcome in other pathogenic microorganisms and fungi. In a recent study of 140 Cryptococcus neoformans (Cn) isolates from Uganda, researchers provided the first evidence of genetic lineage associated with phenotype and clinical outcome in Cn. Cn is one of the most common causes of fungal meningitis worldwide, and it is believed to have a primarily human host. The majority of the global disease burden is caused by the Cn var grubii (Cng) subspecies, which is known to infect severely immunocompromised HIV-infected individuals. Cng can be divided into three major molecular types: VNI, VNII, and VNB. VNI and VNII are globally distributed, while VNB appears to be endemic to Southern Africa. However, there is growing evidence of globally distributed VNB. In this study, researchers genotyped 230 Cng isolates from well-characterised patients enrolled in four clinical trials conducted in South Africa using multi locus sequence typing (MLST). They studied the genetic diversity of Cn present in the patients from the region and explored associations between genotype and in vitro phenotype in a subset of 89 patients. Finally, they analysed the whole patient cohort and looked for relationships between genotype, clinical presentation, and outcome of CM. The researchers hypothesised that genotype was associated with cryptococcal virulence and that if true, they would find a correlation between phenotypic and clinical parameters, and the underlying lineage and genotype of Cn.
The white cell pheromone response pathway in Candida albicans, a fungus that can cause opportunistic infections, evolved from the opaque cell mating pathway. The opaque cell mating pathway controls the formation of a biofilm, which can facilitate mating between minority opaque cells of opposite mating type. The white cell pheromone response pathway, however, does not control mating but does promote adhesion, biofilm formation, and expression of specific genes in white cells. A screen of a library of overexpressed transcription factors revealed that Tec1 was the missing component of the white cell pheromone response pathway. Tec1 is also involved in filamentation and is a target of the S. cerevisiae transcription factor Ste12.
The variation in genomic GC-content among different bacterial species is quite remarkable, ranging from 16.5% in Carsonella ruddii to 75% in Anaeromyxobacter dehalogens. This variation is thought to affect both coding and non-coding sites and is not limited to specific groups of bacteria. The reasons for this variation are still unknown, but many factors are thought to influence genomic GC-content, such as genome size, whether the bacterium is free-living or not, environment, aerobiosis, nitrogen utilization, and temperature. However, it is not clear whether these correlations are due to mutation bias or natural selection. Some bacteria, such as Escherichia coli, have an AT-biased mutation pattern, but their genomic GC-content is higher than would be expected based on this bias. This is because functional constraints prevent the mutation pattern from reducing the genomic GC-content. Synonymous sites in lowly expressed genes also have a GC-content of about 57%, which is considerably higher than the equilibrium inferred from mutation studies. This excess of GC→AT mutations is less acute in common polymorphisms and can be explained by natural selection against GC→AT mutations. Similar patterns are seen in the pseudogenes of Mycobacterium leprae and are thought to be due to the loss of DNA repair enzymes. To test whether genomic GC-content is simply a consequence of mutation bias, we investigated the pattern of synonymous genetic variation in 149 different bacterial species.
In Africa, many countries have programs to reduce soil-transmitted helminths (STH) infections. These programs often use schools to give deworming medicine. This paper shows a way to map where STH infections are most common in Kenya using a special type of math called Bayesian geostatistics. The paper also shows how this map can be used to decide where it is most important to give medicine to school-aged children.
Innate immune cells recognize pathogens and act as the first line of defense against infection. Some types of these cells, such as γδ T cells and NKT cells, are functionally defined as innate lymphocytes. These cells serve important roles in host resistance to different infections. However, it is not clear whether these cells contribute to immunity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. NK cells and γδ T cells become activated and produce interferon-γ (IFN-γ) after Mtb infection, which helps activate macrophages (Mφ) to fight the infection. However, mouse models of Mtb infection in which NK or γδ T cells are defective or depleted have not shown that these cells are essential for immunity to tuberculosis. Despite this, these cells may play a role in controlling bacterial replication or forming granulomas. An in vitro model has been established to study the role of innate lymphocytes in immunity against Mtb. In this model, splenocytes obtained from uninfected mice are cultured with primary Mφ infected with virulent Mtb. Under these conditions, splenocytes produce IFN-γ, stimulate NOS2 upregulation and NO production, and suppress intracellular Mtb replication. This report identifies the cellular mechanism that mediates this innate effector function against the intracellular human pathogen Mtb.
This study looks at the protein Tgl, which plays an important role in the formation of spores in bacteria. Spores are hardy structures that bacteria can use to survive in harsh conditions. Tgl helps to protect the spores by cross-linking proteins in their outer coat. The study finds that Tgl only cross-links proteins in the outer coat, not in the inner layers. This is because Tgl only binds to the outer coat when its substrates are already present. The study also finds that certain residues in Tgl are important for cross-linking substrates, and that these residues are involved in both the enzyme's catalytic cycle and its assembly. Overall, this study sheds light on how Tgl cross-links proteins in the outer coat of spores.
Opisthorchis viverrini is a type of parasite that causes severe liver and bile duct diseases in Southeast Asia, particularly in Lao PDR and Thailand. The parasite has two freshwater intermediate hosts: Bithynia snails and Cyprinidae fish. People become infected by eating raw or undercooked fish. Open defecation into water bodies can contaminate them, which then spreads the parasite to the second intermediate host. Environmental factors such as temperature and rainfall influence the transmission of the parasite between the two intermediate hosts. The purpose of this study is to create a map showing the distribution of the parasite in a southern province of Lao PDR where opisthorchiasis is highly endemic. We want to understand which environmental factors are more important in determining the distribution of the parasite compared to demographic, socioeconomic, water, sanitation, and behavioral determinants.
The study focused on Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, where 29% of the urban population lives in slum conditions. The study aimed to analyze the typology of mosquito breeding habitats in Dar es Salaam, particularly drains, and assess their importance as a source of larval habitats for vectors of LF and malaria. The study found that drains are a common breeding habitat for mosquitoes, particularly Culex and Anopheles, which are vectors of LF and malaria respectively. The study also found that certain characteristics of drains, such as the presence of organic material and vegetation, were associated with the presence of mosquito larvae. The study highlights the importance of drains as breeding habitats for mosquitoes and suggests opportunities for a coordinated effort of vector control to control both LF and malaria in Dar es Salaam.
Dengue fever (DF) is a serious illness that affects many people worldwide. It is caused by the dengue virus (DENV), which consists of a single strand of RNA. The virus enters the cell and produces 10 different proteins, three of which are structural (capsid, membrane, and envelope) and seven of which are nonstructural. These proteins play an important role in the replication of the virus inside the cell, which is aided by the presence of lipids in the cell membrane. During the replication process, the virus uses lipids to build its new shell, making it important to understand how DENV interacts with lipids in the cell. Research has shown that DENV infection can lead to an increase in the total cholesterol levels in cells, which is caused by the uptake of low density lipoprotein (LDL) particles. Additionally, the enzyme that is responsible for producing cholesterol (HMGCR) becomes less active during DENV infection, causing cholesterol levels to increase. It is also known that AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) play important roles in regulating the activity of HMGCR. In this study, researchers found that DENV infection can lead to a decrease in the activity of AMPK, which can cause an increase in HMGCR activity. This increase in activity can result in the accumulation of cholesterol at the site of viral replication. The researchers also discovered that activating AMPK can have a significant antiviral effect, which highlights AMPK as a potential new target for developing antiviral drugs against DENV.
The current research aims to better understand the energy landscapes of biological machines, which are composed of molecules such as proteins, RNA, and other cofactors. To do so, the research uses all-atom molecular dynamics simulations to identify groups of residues that undergo collective rotations and displacements. From this, reaction coordinates were identified that capture key motions during ribosome-mediated substrate translocation, such as 30S-body rotation, 30S-head swivel, and tRNA displacements. By analyzing an explicit-solvent simulation of the pre-translocation complex, effective diffusion coefficients were calculated in each coordinate space. These quantitative measures of short time-scale fluctuations and effective diffusion were used to relate the kinetics and free-energy barriers of translocation. Overall, the research provides experimentally-grounded upper bounds for the long length-scale barriers associated with translocation and estimates for the magnitude of the short-scale energetic roughness.
This article is about a study that looked at the genetic makeup of a type of cancer called medullary thyroid cancer (MTC). The study used a new technology called next-generation sequencing (NGS) to look at the genes that are changed in MTC. The researchers found that the RET gene is commonly mutated in both familial and sporadic MTC, and that the RAS gene is also frequently mutated in sporadic MTC. The researchers also looked for a genetic change called ALK rearrangement in MTC, but they did not find it. The study suggests that the RET gene mutation may be a predictive factor for the effectiveness of a new drug called cabozantinib, which is used to treat advanced MTC.
Visceral leishmaniasis is a disease that is spread by a specific type of sand fly and caused by a type of parasite called Leishmania donovani. It is estimated that 200,000 to 400,000 new cases of visceral leishmaniasis occur worldwide each year. In India, Nepal, and Bangladesh, Leishmania donovani is the only cause of visceral leishmaniasis, Phlebotomus argentipes is the only known vector, and humans are the only reservoir. These three countries have started an initiative to eliminate the disease by 2015. However, one of the challenges they face is that some people who are infected with Leishmania donovani do not show any symptoms and can spread the disease to others. The present study was conducted in an area where visceral leishmaniasis is common to determine the number of people who are infected but do not show any symptoms and the rate at which they develop signs and symptoms of visceral leishmaniasis or post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL).
A new method is presented to analyze genome instability, which is important for normal cellular growth and development. Genome instability, such as genome rearrangements and aneuploidy, is associated with abnormal cellular growth, such as cancer. Genome rearrangements are also associated with inborn genetic diseases, such as Down Syndrome. The genetic factors that suppress or enhance genome instability are less well understood. A quantitative genetic assay was developed to measure the rates of genome rearrangements in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Genetic studies using this assay have revealed that numerous genes and pathways contribute to genome stability. To analyze the structure of genome rearrangements, a technique called Multiplex Ligation-dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) was adapted to provide more detailed information about the GCRs at a lower cost and in less time. MLPA is a multiplex amplification technique that has been used to identify duplications, deletions, and aneuploidy in human cells. In the present study, MLPA was used to investigate target site bias of Ty1-mediated GCRs, RAD52-independent formation of Ty1-mediated translocations, and aneuploidy induced by deletion of RTT109, a gene encoding a histone acetyltransferase. This study provides valuable insights into the mechanisms by which genome rearrangements and aneuploidy are formed.
The paper describes a new algorithm, called SDU (Semi-Definite programming-based Underestimation), for minimizing funnel-like functions. The SDU algorithm uses general quadratic functions to construct a smooth underestimator that is optimized to minimize the original free energy function. The paper explains how the SDU algorithm works and how it has been successfully applied to test problems that resemble the free energy functions. The paper then describes a docking method that uses the SDU algorithm to find the global minimum of a funnel-like function approximating the free energy over regions of the conformational space. The paper explains the challenges associated with the application of the SDU algorithm to docking and describes two implementations of the algorithm: SDU1, a cyclic coordinate descent strategy where rotational and translational moves alternate; and SDU2, a 5D strategy in which the distance of the two proteins is separately optimized and the SDU-driven search is performed in a lower dimensional space defined by 5 angular coordinates. The paper shows that the SDU1 and SDU2 strategies are effective in discovering broad energy funnels, generating high quality docking predictions, and providing a substantial efficiency gain compared to Monte Carlo methods.
